description:
Wonderful miniature Kyoto here in the middle of San Francisco!! I saw the pictures and wanted to come, I am a huge Japan fan as it is. Besides the small japan town with the daiso, Japanese restaurants and several hair salon, I enjoyed this place as well. Just that it's a hop on the bus away. It's in a huge park, reminds me of Central Park in New York. 

The arrangement of the tea house in conjunction with the mAze like walk through the garden is very zen. The menu offers small plate desserts. It's not the place for a full meal, but don't let me stop you.

The best things here to get is a cup of tea and a dessert while you take in the surroundings. For a moment I felt as if I was in Japan again :)
author: Ren N.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden was the main reason for my visit to the Golden Gate Park.  I suppose I should've done a bit more research prior to going, and I wasn't necessarily surprised that there is a charge to enter (I think it's $8 or $9) but certainly worth it.  

The grounds are stunning, with a walking path throughout, which leads you to a new little surprising area at every twist and turn.  The landscaping is stunning.  There are bridges, large koi ponds with a ton of massive koi, large pagodas, stone lanterns, Japanese plants including bonsai and cherry blossom trees.

Bring your camera!

It would actually be quite a tranquil and peaceful place had there not been a several groups of small screaming and crying children.
author: Danielle W.

description:
The Japanese tea garden was probably my favorite place in Golden Gate park.  I didn't even realize it existed until my wife and I were nearby and I saw it on maps.  Like every place in GG park, it costs $9 per person to come in here.  I'd never really been in a traditional Japanese garden before.  Suffice to say, it was tranquil.  I really like the weird vertical bridge they have; some of the pagodas looked like they needed a new paint job, but I digress.

In addition to the scenery, inside is a little Japanese store and a tea place overlooking one of the ponds.  We sat down there, and got jasmine and hojicha teas.  They were good and it was nice they were served in traditional cups.  They had a small menu of food too which is cool.

Would definitely recommend if you're visiting and you/your wife likes tea!
author: Justin L.

description: I haven't been to the Japanese Tea Garden in many years. I was surprised that the buildings were not as well maintained as I expected. The pagodas looked a little worn but still majestic.  The koi fish are well fed!  The admission price was appropriate for the visit.
author: Mitzi W.

description:
Beautiful place. 9 bucks entry per person. No regrets. Gets you access to the awesome tea house and great place to take pictures. U can get a ton of beautiful pics here. The high arching bridge. The great Buddha statue. The great Japanese architecture. 

5/5 and a must come if you're a tourist . Parking wasn't bad either. Lots of parking around the golden gate Park. Just gotta walk a bit but it's great exercise and scenery!
author: Dennis L.

description:
Beautiful place to take a break after hours of walking situated in the Japanese Botanical Garden.

The tea was unspectacular and subpar compared to what you'd find in a typical Japanese teahouse, and the confectionaries weren't any special either, but you should judge it as a tourist attraction you come for the experience rather than a place to get good food or tea, and I'd gladly pay a few dollars to take a rest here any time I come and visit.
author: Stanley W.

description:
Visit MWF before 10 AM for free admission!

My boyfriend loves going here and I think its a very pleasant and relaxing garden to visit, if you are in the Golden Gate Bridge Area. 

There are small ponds with stone walkways, a pagoda, various statues, gates, and the iconic high arched bridge. I believe there are also free tours if you arrive by 9:30AM. 

I would not recommend purchasing any of the over priced trinkets in the shop, since they are things you can easily purchase at a lower price in SF Japantown or Chinatown. Additionally, if you are to eat at the cafe, know that seating is extremely limited, and I would only recommend getting the traditional matcha set or some other kind of tea there. All the other food items are easily purchased at a fraction of the cost at Nijiya market or Daiso, honestly. 

Come early to avoid the crowds because it gets packed quick!
author: Ann T.

description:
Personally, I don't think that the garden is worth paying the admission fee. So! Go on MWF before 10 am for the free admission. 

Once you walked in, it feels like you went into another world. It's so green in there. 

The money that you didn't spend can be use at the restaurant! I love the space. It's not huge and seems very busy however if you're lucky, you'll find some open seats. 

Ordered - the matcha set, which comes with a matcha tea and a sweet red bean paste daifuku. The price came out to be about $9ish (including tax). The daifuku and the matcha made a great pair since the matcha is brewed in the traditional way and is super concentrated. It is a little bit on the bitter side so when paired with the daifuku, it was wonderful.
author: Yuan Z.

description:
LITTLE, PEACEFUL PLACE EVEN WITH CROWDS
[Warning: Young adults from Central Florida in for vacation] This place is much larger than it looks. We weren't able to enter during a 'free admission day' (which there are many of) but there were plenty of people during our Thursday visit; yet there were many areas throughout where we could still admire the view without any bodies shuffling around. Side note: children may enjoy this place, but overall, I wouldn't recommend this for young children unless they have a lot of patience and are well behaved.

GREAT WITHOUT BEING CHEESY
I've never been to Japan, but I've been to exhibits which try to cram as much miniature attractions of the country in focus into a small area and it ends up feeling very... Disney, LOL. At this tea garden, there were a few cheesy moments, but overall, it felt like I had entered someone's beautifully, decorated backyard; and I mean that in the best way possible. Naturally, there's several areas that attracted the photogs and their models such as the bridge and the statues.

A FEW AMENITIES AS WELL
No need to escape the Gardens into the park in order to visit some bathrooms. A little cafe sits at the center as well as a small gift shop. I recommend just getting tea if you go to the cafe since I noticed they didn't have a formal kitchen, so all non-tea items were pre-packaged.
author: Pyra-Danny S.

description: The gardens were lovely well groomed.  However, the garden was pretty crowded.  We enjoyed walking around the paths.  We didn't sample and of the food from the restaurant.  Some of the structures could use a little touch up of paint and a little TLC.  We enjoyed walking around and taking photos.
author: Stacy S.

description: It was so authentic and beautiful , particularly under the second-to-None Californian sunshine. Absolutely gorgeous in terms of all the details in the little gadgets , miniature pagodas , bamboos and so on. Love California for its Japanese influence . One of my fav culture
author: Lulu Y.

description:
Such an outstanding example of what a well designed garden should emulate, and simultaneously a painful reminder of how much work I still need to put into my own garden. Mine looks like a pile of rocks and a few stick figure trees compared to this place. 

I can't imagine how difficult this place was to construct, let alone maintain! The drinking fountain is killer alone!

If you have time to visit this place after spending time at the Golden Gate park, Calif Academy of Sciences or museums, then this place is well worth it. There is an admittance fee, but if you arrive early enough you also can enjoy fantastic macha tea or some light Japanese food snacks. This is a MUST VISIT!!!
author: Ron M.

description:
What a gem! The SF Japanese Tea Garden is so beautiful and serene. We came here first thing on a Monday and it was a "free admission" day. Right when it opened around 9:00 am, the crowd was lighter. We were able to get around and take good photos. My favorite is the big statue of the Buddha and the Bridge. It got annoying though when a couple of people took forever to take photos on the bridge. Get off already, there is a line, lol!

There is a tea shop but we didn't go during our visit, but hope to be able do do next time. It would be perfect for an afternoon tea. There is a small gift shop where they sell various good quality Japanese stuff. I bought a couple of maneki neko lucky cats.

It got busier around noon when we left. The place is small and easy to get around, but it can get crowded. My recommendation is to get there early! This is inside the magnificent Golden Gate Park. We parked at the garage next to Academy of Science.
author: Joan T.

description:
Went during the week in the afternoon. It was a little crowded. Cost $9 to get in $6 if you live in SF. Mon, Wed, Fri in the am until 10 am it's free. I would opt for then, probably would be less crowded.

It was nice to see and visit. Very beautiful. I wasn't particularly blown away. Probably spend about 20 mins. It didn't take long to go through the whole thing. Might be better if it wasn't as crowded. Even to get tea there was no seating because it was all taken. Wasn't much room to seat down, relax, and enjoy the scenery.
author: Ashlyn K.

description:
Considering how crowded it gets I don't like the size, at all. I was also hoping this would be less touristy and more full of locals. Nonetheless, I did enjoy the garden although, it's less Japanese and more of a smaller scale botanical garden which is directly across from here. 

Too bad I wasn't a resident. I think the $6 admission is worth it but $9 is overrated for its quality and scale. 

Oh and the bathrooms aren't that great either.
author: Chels C.

description:
Surly woman at the Kiosk who would not accept other forms of official ID, but in the end asked for an amazon address on the phone.
If you have any difficulty walking, there is no handicapped access whatsoever and the same charming woman told me to wait down the stairs and across the street on a park bench while my daughter waited in line. At that point what would be the point?
The tea garden was lovely and the service charm
author: Suzanne D.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is a great stop inside Golden Gate Park. I hadn't been inside the garden since I was a little kid. It's really worth the $9 (non-resident) price of admission. $6 for SF residents. 

The walking paths around the garden are fairly easy to navigate. There is one set of stairs near the tea house that is very steep but it does have a rail in the middle. I would avoid that as it might be an issue for some. I liked seeing the Zen garden, the different plants, the pagoda and the koi ponds. Speaking of the koi ponds, those are some well-fed koi fish. They are HUGE. Probable the plumpest koi fish I've ever seen. 

As I said there is a tea house. It's where you can purchase hot tea and small meals. We didnt partake in any of that although we saw that a lot of people did. We just enjoyed the grounds. It was really nice inside the Japanese Tea Garden. I recommend it for tourists and locals alike. It's nice and serene. Just what I expect of a tea garden. We went on a Sunday and there were a good amount of people there. But it wasnt too crowded where you didnt enjoy yourself. It's a nice walk for sure.
author: Chuck D.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is a beautiful oasis in the city. Yes, it was crowded and a bit smaller than I was expecting, but beautiful.
author: Rachelle B.

description:
It's so clean and beautiful: a wonderful place to take a break from the city views of San Francisco. The "restaurant" area has outstanding customer service. The tea, though seemingly expensive, can be refilled with hot water if you ask for it! 
The server accidentally spilled a few drops of water on my kuzumochi and immediately gave us new ones. Thank you for that!! If I ever come back to San Fran, I would definitely come here again :)
author: Emily T.

description:
Before visiting SF for the first time, I didn't really understand the magnitude and size of Golden Gate Park. It's 20% larger than Central Park in New York and there is so much to do in the park! It's free to enter and there are museums, special gardens like the Japanese Tea Garden, lakes, a bison paddock, sports fields, etc. Some of the places within the park charge an entrance fee, including the Japanese Tea Garden.

My boyfriend and I rented bikes and took a ride through part of the park while vacationing in SF. We decided to check out one of the places inside the park that had an entrance fee and picked this garden as it was one of the more reasonably priced attractions and we didn't want to spend an entire day there. It was $9 for non-resident adults, but if you get there by 10 am on Monday, Wednesday, or Friday, it's free! The price we paid was definitely worth it. The garden is very peaceful and tranquil, and a really nice place to view some interesting plants and be quiet in nature. There is a zen garden that is really pretty as well as a few koi ponds. The garden is very neat and well-maintained. There is a tea house inside the garden where you can enjoy several kinds of tea including matcha, and have some light snacks like miso soup, udon, tea sandwiches, and some sweets. We didn't stop there but it looked like a nice place to have a light lunch or enjoy a hot cup of tea. When we went, it wasn't too crowded as it had been a little rainy. I can imagine it can get pretty crowded and less peaceful so I was really happy that we lucked out. I could see myself coming here to meditate or read quietly if I lived nearby!
author: Katy C.

description:
I stopped by here with some friends from out of town on 1/2. It was very very crowded and not what I expected when I thought of a japanese tea garden. I'm not sure what it's like other times of the year since a lot of the plants were hibernating for the winter, but for $9, i thought the garden was a bit small and not worth visiting multiple times. 

I'd definitely recommend visiting off season and make sure you bring a proof to residency for SF residents. I may come back in the future to try the cafe, but on the day we were here, there were so many people we didn't even try going to the cafe. 

Having been to japan multiple times, I felt like this wasn't all that "japanese themed." It's definitely more of an american garden and I would say the gardens in Vancouver are much better and those are free :P sad times san francisco.
author: Annie Z.

description: Some neat sites here but pretty small and not worth the $9 non California resident fee. It was nice and quit and the koi were cute. Thought there would be a real zen garden that I could sit in and relax but it's roped off.
author: Priscilla D.

description: It has been years since I've been to the Japanese Tea Garden and for $9 per person unless you are in SF resident, I need something special these days in order to spend that for just an hour or two here since it is on the small side.  Like most previous visits, I came when the Cherry Blossoms were in full bloom.  Coupled with the pagoda, bamboo, and tea house, it is a peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle of the city - http://aroundthebayandaway.blogspot.com/2018/04/cherry-blossom-season-at-japanese-tea.html
author: Joyce Z.

description:
We enjoyed our visit to the Japanese Tea Garden. It was $9 per person since we were non residents but the website says it's free admission Mon, Wed, and Friday if you enter before 10am, so we may try that next time.

We were lucky to visit when the weather was nice (even in January) and felt like we could spend most of the day there as it was very relaxing and peaceful. There's a small cafe that we stopped by to get some sandwiches, udon, and tea. The gift shop next door had lots of Japanese items we wanted to get as well
author: Minh N.

description: This is one of the most impressive Japanese gardens outside of Japan. I love visiting these gardens because they not only tell a lot about Japanese culture, but they also teach about balance, in nature, and flow. This particular garden has an amazing vibe and everything has been placed perfectly to create the highest dramatic effect, or should I say, energetic chi flow.
author: Julio H.

description:
Yelp 100 Challenge 2018
53/100

Definitely worth the $8

I had the best time here. Everything is really relaxing and soothing. I just sat down on a bench and took everything in -- the fresh air, smell of trees and the whole ambiance of the garden for like 30 minutes.
author: Stacy A.

description:
EXTREMELY OVERPRICED!
I love mochi so I got the 10pc mochi and was extremely disappointed. I've never had such mushy mochi...it was not even the slightest bit chewy. 
Also ordered the petite fours, which also continued to disappoint me because they weren't very special, and I've had better. 
The matcha was okay and probably the only thing on the menu worth the money. It came with a red bean filled matcha mochi, which was actually very good!

All in all, spent over $25 for 10 pieces of mushy mochi, 3 pieces of cake covered in chocolate, and hot matcha tea. :)
author: Melanie T.

description:
Came here with my cousin and it's a lot smaller than expected. When entering it seemed never ending but the trails circle around in a short loop, which brings you back to where you started. Nonetheless, it's a cute area around the golden gate park. Coming here made me want to go back to Japan. 

Just a heads up, you have to pay in order to get in. Adults are $9 a ticket. I also ordered food at their small snack bar. Very peaceful and relaxing to sit outdoors, enjoy the scenery, and have food with your tea. It was a bit chilly but not too cold the day we went, so it was perfect weather to order a bowl of udon. We also got the green tea cheesecake, hojicha tea, and an iced green tea. We were very content with what we ordered. 

This is something I would come and do at least once but not sure if I would go again due to the entrance fee. Although, I really want to try their premium tea next.  I suggest going with a group a friends and order a few dishes and teas to try and share. Get a taste of everything so you don't have to make a second trip. Certain drinks are a bit pricey and adding food/desserts definitely racks up the bill.
author: Ester S.

description: Cute place with a few interesting bridges. Not large but well groomed and a good use of space. Not too much crammed into the space which is more authentic. Tea house serves good teas. I got the non traditional ice green tea but it was a hot day and it was delicious.
author: E H.

description: It took us about an hour to get through everything the Japanese Tea Garden had to offer, but we also took lots of pictures. Admission was slightly more than we expected ($9/adult) but it was worth it.
author: Kristina H.

description:
One of my All-Time-Favorite places, and my husband's All-Time-Favorite place in SF. 

I have very fond memories of visiting here with my mother as a little girl and into my teens. It really hasn't changed much at all over the past 40 years (and where else can boast that?). I think that's what I appreciate about the Japanese Tea Garden. Everything is intentional and in it's place and it calms the spirit. Children and adults both delight in watching the koi swim. The Japanese maples are serene. And the almond cookies and tea are still scrumptious.

Our family chose this location for our photo shoot last year, and it was perfect.
author: Camille L.

description:
Little japanese dream in the middle of SF city! 

Relaxing atmosphere at the tea house/cafe and delicious tea and snacks while hearing the fountain and beautiful nature all around. 

It can get crowded so start your day early!
author: Henali P.

description: It is a cute garden, mostly in the Japanese style but was kind of disappointed in how it's not maintained well. A lot of dead plant refuse around, and the shrine and other buildings need refurbishment. And so many spiders. There was a dead fish in the pond. The restaurant was expensive for already paying to get in. Nice for a little walk around but I wouldn't do it a second time.
author: Sunita T.

description: This place is exquisite! My first time checking this place out and I had a wonderful time. I came here with my fiancé and we enjoyed our walk through the garden. Now I'm already thinking of visiting Japan soon for a getaway trip.
author: Neloffer E.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is one of my favorite spots to connect with nature. I take off my shoes and feel the cold crisp grass underneath my feet while listening to the brook babble as giant koi swim underneath giant lily pads. I love testing my balance as I skip past all of the stepping stones. 

And my favorite part is...

Eating It-Its underneath the canopy of the beautiful tea house. It surely is not a traditional Japanese treat but it is pure San Francisco and nothing screams California than eating this national treasure of an ice cream sandwich here. I like to pair it with a cup of green tea to really soak in everything.

Whether you are here to connect with nature, take some killer Instagram pics or eat an It-It, this is a spot that can't be missed! Truly one of my favorite spots in San Francisco.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
Beautiful Japanese garden! I've never seen anything like this outside of Japan.

Great place for a walk, a date or just to take pictures. There's quite a few sights including pogoda towers, fancy bridges, houses, statutes and koi ponds. But it's not that big and is usually overcrowded on weekends.

Admission is $9, but $6 for SF residents with ID. It's free on Fridays in the morning?
author: Vincent H.

description:
"The Japanese Tea Garden is a popular feature of Golden Gate Park, originally built as part of a sprawling World's Fair, the California Midwinter International Exposition of 1894. The garden's 3 acres contain sculptures & structures influenced by Buddhist & Shinto religious beliefs as well as rock, water, & plant features. It is the oldest public Japanese garden in the U.S.

After the conclusion of the 1894 World's Fair, Makoto Hagiwara, a Japanese immigrant & gardener, personally oversaw the modification of the temporary Japanese Village fair exhibit to the permanent Japanese Tea Garden and was official caretaker of the garden from 1895 to 1925. 

He imported from Japan many plants, birds, and the now famous koi fish, and he more than tripled the size of the garden. After San Francisco's 1915 Panama-Pacific International Expositionclosed, he obtained the large ornamental wooden gate from that fair's Japanese Pavilion. Following Makoto Hagiwara's death, his daughter, Takano Hagiwara & her children became the proprietors & maintainers of the garden. 

With the onset of World War II in America & rising anti Japanese sentiment, Takano Hagiwara was evicted from the family's home & sentenced to a U.S. concentration camp along w/ over 100,000 other Japanese Ameticans even though they were not convicted of any crime. The Hagiwara family was not allowed back into their home nor reimbursed after the war ended. 

In the period of their absence, the garden was renamed "The Oriental Tea Garden," and any structure expressing Japanese sentiment was demolished, including the Hagiwara home & the original Shinto Shrine. 

A plaque contrived by artist, Ruth Asawa, famed artist known for her elegant, organic, woven metal sculptures, was gifted to the garden in honor of Makoto Hagiwara & his family for their dedication to the garden's beginnings & expansion."

Crowded as the Hagiwara Japanese Garden gets, there are still nooks & crannies where the crowd thins out to provide a serene setting. Spring is a great time since flowers abound, but any time of the year is fine. 

Great place to chill out when the city gets too overwhelming. Some people complain about the price of admission, but then will spend hundreds of dollars on material things without a thought that just clutter up their homes & their lives. To me, seeing the squirrels being playful in the refined, peaceful garden is priceless.
author: Gary I.

description:
Beautiful place - tastefully designed and well-maintained.  There's a lot of culture to be enjoyed here.  It's a little hard to call this place entirely peaceful, though, particularly on the weekends, as this is a popular destination for visitors and locals alike.  However, despite the crowds it is actually possible to enjoy some moments of reflection here.  Children will love this place as well, with stepping stones and a high-arched bridge to provide some adventure, plus some large koi swimming languidly in the ponds.  On occasion (not sure how frequently this occurs), you may find yourself lucky enough to enjoy a Japanese music or dance performance, both inside and outside the grounds.

Perhaps the biggest obstacle to visiting here is finding parking.  However, if you don't mind a short walk, you can usually find a place a little farther down along MLK Drive towards 19th/Park Presidio.
author: Lee L.

description: It's not as nice as the one we've got in SJ. No bias. I went in with no expectations whatsoever but was ultimately underwhelmed. The only thing this Tea Garden has really is their sweets cafe which I feel is the only reason people come to visit anyways. It's not too expensive to get in and it's just another thing to do if you're in the area, so why not though???
author: David N.

description:
Right smack in the smack middle (sorta) of Golden Gate Park is the beautiful.
The only reason this is a 4 star and not a 5 star review is because you have to pay $9 to get into the garden, If i didnt care about parks and how amazing they are i wouldn't have paid or gone to check this out.
Once youre in you get taken to a magical place with ponds, a massive wooden bridge, pagodas and a zen garden. Take your pictures quick if you see that no one is around the moon bridge (massive wooden bridge). You can also see some craw-fishes and I think I saw a koi fish..... maybe just a HUGE craw-fish lol..
The garden is pretty small and can be enjoyed thoroughly in about an hour and a half.
Overall, this place is so relaxing and peaceful inside - life is beautiful in here.
author: Steve S.

description:
I came here as a kid and never forgot it. It's absolutely beautiful. So peaceful, tranquil and mesmerizing. This past trip, I found myself sitting on a bench in front of the Zen Garden not wanting to uproot myself forever. 

Once inside, you would never know you are in the middle of Golden Gate Park in San Francisco. From the trees, to buildings, coy fish, flowers, etc. it looks like you were placed right in to the middle of a picture you've seen online. There's a huge statue of Buddha as well as different buildings that model areas of worship and such. 

They do sell food and drinks in here and have what seems to be a little gift shop? Not quite sure about the shop though. It's 9 dollars to get in but well worth it. If you're visiting Golden Gate Park, stop in! You won't regret it.
author: Zoe F.

description: Its a little green gem! Very cute and extremely pleasant to the eyes. It did take me back to my trip to Japan! It has positives vibes and gives a very brief good Japanese cultural experience. The food and teas served good and apt for a small tea break in the evening after a long walk in the park! Because there are so many tress, even on a hot day it feels cool. We ordered a pot of Macha tea and the red bean buns. Perfect for sharing, light and felt refreshed!
author: Premila M.

description: I went here with Debra R and Jose R. We went to the tea house and walked around the garden. The tea was really good and the garden was beautiful. We saw the really steep bridge and this place has a nice gift shop.
author: Julia R.

description:
Came here for a nice date with the bf. We had to stop and get some dessert/tea because can you really say you were here if you didn't? Personally, I don't think so. The ramen/other real food items were a little too much for us because we were going to have some sushi in the next hour. However, I do not regret ordering the matcha cheesecake/mochi. 

The matcha cheesecake was creamy and had the right amount of matcha. It was definitely not too sweet and the matcha was not overpowering at all. I really could not stop myself from eating it. Even my bf, who really doesn't eat sweets that often enjoyed it. But he let me take the last bite. I really wish there was a larger size I can buy to go. 

The mochi each had their unique flavors. Personally, I think I have to go with lychee as my favorite. They were super soft and not extra chewy. It was different from the typical mochi you get at froyo places or wrapped around ice cream. 

The tea was nice and hot. I personally could take a stronger concentration of tea but its just a personal preference. It was a decent glass but I think the most "expensive" item considering it was just water and tea. 

Overall, I would come back for the dessert. Maybe I'll just buy the tea leaves and make it at home. It is way cheaper and I can make it to my liking.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
My first time being here with my hubby. Both of us came early so we're able to get street parking. We paid our tickets (credit card acceptable) in front of entrance and then we walked around the garden. 

The garden isn't really big. Overall we maybe spent 45 minutes for walking and took some photos. The garden is definitely pretty, tidy and feel comfortable to visit. But I think $8 per person will be my only one time to be here unless come with other friends for next time. 

It's still worth to come and visit this little garden in San Francisco. It's a relaxing garden to look around. And they have Koi fish in the pond also. The garden has a very steep bridge that you can try to walk through which I think it's really fun to try out.
author: Jaane F.

description:
A tranquil spot in the city. There's free admission MWF before 10am, but the price of admission is worth it, especially for first timers! 

I love feeling "transported" to another place and experienced that upon seeing the drum bridge, pagodas, stepping stones, Japanese plants, and koi ponds. From the tea house, I recommend the dorayaki and genmaicha tea. I'd also like to try their tea sandwiches next time. The garden can be explored in about an hour, but it's a great place to slow down and take your time, especially if you have a full day of sightseeing ahead of you. Definitely visit while checking out Golden Gate Park!
author: Edwina D.

description: The Japanese tea garden is quite small for the fee. Nevertheless, its a cute place with a nice bridge and some koi fishes, a tori gate and a shrine. It can get pretty crowded on weekends. The tea place is nice but can be busy and little noisy. They are pretty quick with the service. I would highly recommend trying the mochi which is served in different flavors. The tea sandwiches were some nice bites too. Please note that this is not a lunch place. Its a tea place with good small bites.
author: Tejashree M.

description:
This beautiful tea garden, located inside Golden Gate Park, is a great way to soak up some greenery in the midst of busy San Francisco. I came on a Saturday afternoon during a holiday weekend and although it was fairly busy, I had enough space to walk through and enjoy the park without bumping into people.

Lots of photo opportunities here, everything is well kept. There's a tea room for tea and snacks, but I can't comment on that because I didn't try any. There's also a small gift shop for your souvenir needs, some items I felt were overpriced.

Admission is $8, which I think is very reasonable. Free for SF residents, but your ID needs to have a SF address. Overall, I spent about 90 minutes here and felt I saw everything, I'd love to come back again!
author: Jean L.

description:
It's nice and pretty but really small! It was not worth then $9 to get in. You would be better taking your nine bucks over to the botanical garden which is walking distance in golden gate park plus it about 5 times the size.

Highly dissapointing that we were unable to feed the fish. Coy fish love eating fishy food and they sure aren't coy about begging for it. 

The gardens is nice lots of cool bonzi trees and Japanese maples with statue's. I really like the drum bridge never saw or used one in the past. It's fun to stand back and watch people's confusion as they try to cross over it.
author: Mike D.

description:
I fell in love with the Japanese tea garden the second I set my feet inside. Probably due to the early time I got in, there weren't that many of people at all and I could enjoy all the beautiful scenes all by myself. There was multiple lanes, leading to different areas (small temples, bridges, gardens, pools), yet it was not difficult to always find your way back.

At the entrance, there was a small food snack bar, where you could feed yourself with some light sweets, paired with Japanese tea selections. I could not think of a better way to enjoy the view with a small cup of matcha in hand, warm and cosy. Udon noodles, or sandwiches would also be provided for those who preferred a larger meal.
author: Elaine H.

description:
The gardens itself are beautiful and so relaxing.  I enjoyed myself thoroughly at the garden.  It costs about $9 to get in but they do have free times when you can go to get the fee waived or if you live in SF then it's cheaper.  I do think it was worth the visit while I had my weekend in in the Bay Area.  They also have a small gift shop by the restaurant for small little gifts. 

The restaurant: The world's longest line for the smallest portions of food.  I know that Japanese culture is all about the littlest details and the immense flavors in small bowls but....this is definitely not the place to go if you're actually hungry.

My recommendation: Go see the gardens and enjoy the beauty of it THEN leave the garden to go get food elsewhere (if you're hungry).  If you're looking for a light refreshment then by all means grab a seat by the waterfall and enjoy!
author: Kaitlin D.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me so long to come here! (If truth be told, it's not "the" best Japanese Tea Garden I've been - it's smaller and more crowded, for instance - however...). It was definitely worth the trip out to Golden Gate Park to check it out. When I managed to find quiet spaces, it was very peaceful and a good place to reflect. The plants and trees and other flora and fauna are beautiful, as well as the structures and statues. The water too. The garden was perfect for taking some very lovely photos. 

If you're a resident, the discounted rate is $6, even on weekends. Otherwise, I think it's $8 which still isn't too bad. Oh, and there's also a cafe in the centre if you would like some tea and/or snacks, but I didn't stick around for those this time 'around. 

Overall, loved it, and I'd like to try to come back again during a less busy time to feel less crowded in and rushed.
author: Bianca C.

description: Thankfully the sun came out long enough for us to enjoy this beautiful outdoor experience in the park.  We stopped for some tea and took a few pics.   Very peaceful place.   Highly recommend you stop by the tea garden when you're in the park
author: Sabrina M.

description:
"The secret to living well and longer is: eat half, walk double, laugh triple and love without measure..." 

One of my highlights at Golden Gate Park is the Japanese Tea Garden on Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive, just East of Stow Lake. The oldest public Japanese garden in the United States, it was opened in 1894 as part of the California Expo. Japanese landscape architect Makoto Hagiwara and the city of San Francisco reached a gentleman's agreement, allowing Mr. Hagiwara to create and maintain a permanent Japanese style garden as a gift for posterity. He became caretaker of the lands, pouring all of his personal wealth, passion, and creativity into a garden of utmost perfection.

The Japanese Tea Garden is a complex of many paths, with classic elements such as an arched drum bridge, pagodas, stone lanterns, stepping stone paths, native Japanese plants, serene koi ponds and a zen garden.  Cherry blossom trees (Sakura) bloom throughout the garden in March and April. The elements of water and rocks combine to create a calming landscape designed to slow people down. To appreciate. To breathe. 

The traditional Tea House is where you can experience Matcha, a high quality powdered green tea that is the only form of tea served in tea ceremonies. It is customarily served with popular confections or wagashi. Tea's of other sorts, such as Jasmine, Hojicha, Genmaicha, Sencha or Iced Green Tea can be purchased here as well, prices range in the $4-$5 range, with the exception of the Matcha which cost $8.50. Tea House sandwiches, Udon, Mochi, Tea House cookies are available too. If you are a traditionalist or just like things legit I'd suggest you experience the Matcha. 

The Hagiwara family lived in the garden for many decades, until sadly, in 1942 Mr. Hagiwara and his family were uprooted and sent to an internment camp due to ignorance common at the time. They never returned. 

Today, the Japanese Tea Garden has endured for well over a century. The Hagiwara legacy continue to live in the manicured bonsai trees & delicate koi ponds here. Tranquility now. Open 365 days of the year.

"A hundred hearts would be too few to carry all my love for you..." maybe even a thousand.
author: Eric R.

description:
It is definitely zen. A perfect place to sightsee with a group or for an afternoon alone. You'll definitely be in a spiritual mood when you're here.

The garden is well maintained. You'll enjoy seeing the koi or walking along the winding path while crossing small bridges or stone paths that lead you through one end of the pond to other. It's fairly small but take your time and enjoy the peacefulness of it.
author: Shiela T.

description:
A fantastic escape from the city.

We love Golden Gate Park in general, and the Japanese Tea Garden in particular -- we have been visiting for twenty years. Beautiful sculpted gardens, with many places to stroll and sit and enjoy the many vantage points. 100 year old bonsai garden, water features, various structures  and glorious plantings. Don't miss the cherry blossoms in late March -- early April. Trivia: Where the fortune cookie was invented.
author: John C.

description:
Beautiful garden and scenery! A lot of great areas to snap some photos. They also had a small gift shop but we didn't care to look for anything, except to enjoy the nature!

Admission was 8$ which I thought was just a little too much. They also had a cafe that sells teas and small snacks. My family and I all got the matcha tea with mochi that was about 9$. The tea itself was great and had a bold flavor. The mochi was gooey in texture but tasted delicious. To finish it off we ordered a yummy green tea cheesecake. 

Parking was tough, we parked in the garage stall but there were still a lot of people.
author: Samantha O.

description:
This is such a cool little place tucked away in San Francisco! The Japanese Tea Garden is one of several gardens found in the Golden Gate Park. This garden has a small restaurant located within it that serves various teas, soups and other Japanese treats. You can have a bite as enjoy the scenery within the open sitting area. If you're not quite that hungry, there's plenty to do and see as you walk through the rest of the garden. There are Koi fish happily swimming in the ponds that are beautifully surrounded by trees, foliage and sculptures. There are also Pagodas, a zen garden and a very interesting bridge. Take a moment to climb the bridge if you're feeling brave. 
The gift shop is also a fun place to grab a few trinkets as you stop through. 
For about $8 this was a fun and inexpensive find in our travels to the west coast. We really enjoyed it!
author: Lael M.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is located in Golden Gate Park.  It is an easy drive to get to from anywhere in the city and there is convenient parking nearby.  The admission I believe was 8 dollars for adults who are not residents of San Francisco.  

The garden itself is masterfully landscaped and creates a serene experience. It is great for taking a relaxing stroll and enjoying your surroundings. It is quiet inside and is great for just decompressing.  There are different pathways to walk so not everyone is going to same way through the garden.  

There are great areas for taking pictures whether you want structures behind you, plants or Koi.  Parts of the paths are shaded and some are in the sun.  The size of the garden is great, especially with kids.  You could spend as little as 30 minutes and see pretty much everything or you can linger, take your time, have a snack and hang out for a couple hours.

There is also a gift shop and little restaurant inside in case you want to find some neat souvenirs or have a bite to eat. When you are done, there is a back exit so you don't have to go back to the front if you don't want to.
author: Angela D.

description:
$8 to get in for a little bit of tea and tranquility.

Tea isn't free, but I recommend getting yourself a small pot and just sit out and enjoy the scenery. And when you're done with your tea, go for a walk around the garden.

There's a bit of history here, so when you're looking around at some statues, stick around and read their description. There's history here ever since just right after WW2.
author: Mike C.

description: We came on a free Wednesday. The garden is absolutely beautiful, but quite small. I was expecting more. We were able to get a bit of history from a free tour guide. The garden definitely has an interesting history. I was just hoping for more.
author: Jenn D.

description:
A beautiful display that will calm every nerve in your body is what you will find when stepping foot into the magical Japanese Tea Garden.  This man-made, but yet so ethereal creation is something that very may well make you mistake the fact that you are in San Francisco.  For the hour or two that I spent soaking up the peaceful energy of the garden, I certainly forgot where I was.  Then again, it's nice to get lost in nature's beauty and wonderment.  

Sure, the entire Japanese Tea Garden was thought up and put in place by someone (which of course, is not "natural"), but it is nature, and it's art.  The garden is truly a masterpiece, where every blade of grass and ripple in the pond is exactly where it should be.  The pagodas, the bridges, pathways and flowers the lined them were nothing short of magnificent.  I honestly cannot say that I have encountered a more serene environment; walking through the garden instantaneously eased my anxiety, and I genuinely felt refreshed when leaving tbe garden.

Perhals I am not alone whe  I say that the Japanese Tea Garden, besides awing you, also has a wonderful calming effect - I would bet that is supported by empirical evidence too.  As much as this is a tourist attraction, it is one that won't really feel like one, that is once you get past the part where you have to pay a $15 admission fee.  You won't feel like a tourist again until you hit the gift shop, which even then has the feel of a small Japanese shop you'd find on the streets of Kyoto.

The gift shop does have some neat items, but having gone to Japantown a few days later, I found very similar (if not the same) items for slightly cheaper.  I, personally, liked that I bought a gift from here for rememberance sake even if it was more expensive.  Oh, and before you leave - don't go without stopping at the cafe...at least for some tea!
author: Lauren K.

description: Perfect place to visit on a weekday in the morning before the tourist foot traffic picks up. It's small but beautifully laid out with koi and a tea room. There are small benches and areas where you can sit and just enjoy the beauty of the garden. SF residents get a discount on entrance ($6 instead of $9).
author: Sarah N.

description:
What a beautiful way to spend an hour or two.  The Japanese Tea Garden is located in Golden Gate park and is easy to get to.  There is also a parking garage not far away that costs $5/hour.  

Admission was $8 however my 4 year old was free.  My sister and I brought my nephew here on our trip to San Francisco.  We thought it would be a nice place to walk around and enjoy the scenery.  We ended up spending about an hour there and honestly could have spent quite a bit longer if my son would have relaxed and enjoyed it.  

The area is gorgeously landscaped with plenty of different areas to explore.  There are some neat architecture items as well as a koi pond which my son absolutely loved.  There was also an area to order food and drinks and a gift shop.  This is a wonderful place to take pictures because it is so beautiful and calm feeling.
author: Ashley E.

description: My favorite spot at the Golden Gate Park! It was absolutely stunning and a great place for photo ops. There's also a place to get food with comfortable outdoor seating. There are multiple lunch options but we opted for some light green tea mochi, which came with a couple pokie sticks. This is the first place we visited at the park, which I'm glad about, because it got a bit crowded by the time we left.
author: Maysa M.

description: It cost 9 bucks for adults but it's overly priced for the size. The grounds ARE beautiful to walk but it's small. You're in and out within 15 minutes depending on how fast you walk it. I kept feeling g like there should be more to see. It should be free admission due to its size and the upkeep money should be gathered from the tea house concessions. Definitely a tourist trap unless you're into Zen gardens and need to see it. Not very serene because of us tourists chatting away. Great pictures tho!
author: Tijuanna D.

description:
Saw some really cute photos on yelp and had to visit while I was in town. There is an admission fee, which is different from other japanese gardens I've been to. I was expecting some extravagance because you have to pay, but it's a typical japanese garden. I do like some of the scenic shots I've taken and it makes you feel tranquil.

I love the green environment and I was expecting it to be bigger, but with the amount of space that was given, there was plenty of photo spots.

I would come back here again if there are more flowers in bloom. Overall, it was a relaxing walk, but nothing that really stood out from other japanese gardens; so if I need a filler of photos I would visit here.
author: Anh L.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed our visit at the tea garden! Easy to navigate through. The garden is very well cared for. I even brought my 3 year old in her jogger. There was a couple of narrow parts over the water but totally manageable! The gift shop is super cute.
author: Ondrea H.

description:
I was excited to see a different Japanese Tea Garden.

I appreciated the variety of tea and food choices they were serving as well as the gift shop.

Great place to take pictures and the walk around the garden was peaceful and honestly relaxing place to go.
author: John Kevin G.

description:
This is a great place to take a date or just to unwind, the grounds are beautiful and the food isn't too shabby!  

What we ordered:

Iced green tea- light and refreshing, and not too sweet

Udon- standard but pretty flavorful and much needed on a cold day

Green tea cheesecake- my favorite, you can taste the green tea, super delicious

Next time I come back I want to order the matcha green tea, price is kinda steep at 8.50 but worth a try!
author: Sarah K.

description: I recently went to the Japanese Tea gardens for the first time. I have been wanting to go for several years and I am happy that I was able to do a shoot here. They are really easy going when it comes to photography so that is a huge plus. I was not able to actually enjoy some tea here but I cant wait to come back and give that a try! So much fun.
author: MJ L.

description: This is such a cool spot in the middle of Golden Gate park! I am so happy we stumbled upon it. Expect to spend maybe an hour there, as it is very small, but worth the $8 admission in my opinion. There is a little restaurant you can order hot tea and noodles from. Walk around, take some pictures, and have some green tea for a unique experience.
author: Shama P.

description:
I love this place and have been visiting with my family for the past year for at least once a month.  They need a membership because we are always here and i hate having to pay each time we enter.  Although if you do visit early on Monday, Wednesdays and Fridays and arrive before 10 am, you'll get in for free.  

This place is just magical and I have to get their iced matcha tea with the tea sandwiches every single time I go.  My little boy and baby girl love this place as well.  It's a wonderful little place in the city. We love the bridge and watching the koi fish.  

Beautiful place to take pics as well and to bring family and friends visiting the city.  
It's definitely one of my favorite places in SF.
author: Christine P.

description:
Walking a garden is always refreshing for me. I forget and often go too long before visiting one again. So many great views! Beautiful all around. I noticed the staff grooming the grass by hand to avoid the typical noise associated with landscaping.

The actual tea shop had a small selection of tea and food. I eventually ordered Iced Green Tea and Soba noodles. It was early, but I was on vacation so why not noodles for breakfast. Yum. 

I left feeling actually refreshed.
author: Marcy H.

description:
This is a must see tourist site if you are in the San Francisco area . There isn't much of a line . Entry fee is $8.00 to get in for an adult .

The outside decor is really enticing to make you want to go inside .

Once you walk in there will be several paths you can go down . There's fish , flowers , plants and great scenery to see . I do highly suggest if you have allergies to not go so deep inside . However , excellent spot to take pictures and just relax.

There is also a tea garden located on the right side of the entrance . YOU MUST GO!!!! Excellent tea and prompt service . You can order and take a seat on the benches by the little restaurant and your order will be brought out to you . Ordered sencha tea and edamame and it was a perfect pick me up snack . Not to mention - excellent tea .
author: Binita S.

description: Definitely one of the most Japanese garden in USA. A sensation of peace and serenity comes to the mind as soon as you get into the garden. I enjoyed to see many colorful carps, the pagoda, Buddha statue and the zen garden. The garden is very well taking care of and clean. They have a japanese souvenir and a tea house that I didn't have the opportunity to try. For adults no residents it's a little pricey but it worth to go and my advice is: if you are resident you must show a document to prove it. Don't forget your best camera. It's a good place to take nice pictures!!
author: Elis H.

description: I always get this place confused with the botanical garden. My first time coming with my family this past weekend. We had free passes my little one won from a SFPL sumer reading program and took advantage of it. Great place to relax and get out of the city within the city. It seems as if I've escaped to Japan for a moment. A perfect location to help you improve on your picture taking skills.
author: Tina L.

description:
Came here on a sunny Saturday afternoon. Ticket pirce is $9/adult for non SF resident.

It is a Japanese-style garden located in the central of Golden Gate Park. The garden features many classic elements, such as Zen garden, stepping stone paths, serene ponds, and a moon bridge.

The garden is not a large one, but we had a great time here.
author: Yu S.

description: Beautiful garden! We went on Friday in the summer so I cant wait to go when it is not tourist season! Go before 10 mon, wed and Friday and it's free entry. People get pretty aggressive about spots to take pics ie: the tall bridge so def hold your ground and just get up there or you'll never get a pic- if thats what your into :-) tea was pretty tasty and the bathrooms and grounds themselves were impeccably clean! We will be back!
author: Morgan D.

description: My number one tip is DON'T COME HERE IN THE SUMMER. I visited today on a June weekday at 1pm and the garden was so busy with families, summer camps and tour groups that you barely had space for yourself. There was no seating at the tea room because it was so crowded (along with a line all the way to the shop) and no serenity you're supposed to enjoy from the running water and garden atmosphere. Aside from this, the garden has always been beautiful was a rich history and health koi ponds, Japanese maples and all the flora you would expect. The traditional structures need renovation, you can see chipped wood and cobwebs, but the zen garden is always well maintained. If you do go to the tea room, the Matcha is a must. It is served traditionally with mochi with red bean paste and it is exquisite.
author: Ashley L.

description:
A beautiful place to visit in Golden Gate Park. We visited this place during Spring so there were flowers blooming everywhere. 

There are cherry blossom trees, koi fish, buddha statues, Japanese architecture, and more to look at and take pictures with. There's also a gift shop and a cafe inside to drink tea.

At the cafe we ordered green tea ice cream and an iced green tea. I really enjoyed the iced tea as it wasn't too biter somehow. Pass on the green tea ice cream -- it's definitely store bought and sitting in the freezer for a while.

Overall, a great place to visit if you're in the area.
author: Ashley D.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden inside San Francisco's Golden Gate Park is absolutely beautiful. If you're visiting the city/park and have never been to the tea garden before, it's definitely worth a visit.

Be aware of the garden's hours which change seasonally. March 1 to October 31: 9am to 6pm. November 1 to February 28: 9am to 4:45pm. Open 365 days a year.

There's free admission Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 9-10am. Otherwise, admission rates are $8 per adult, $6 per senior (age 65+) or youth (age 12-17), and $2 per child (age 5-11). Children under 5 get in free. City of San Francisco residents get discounts (ID with San Francisco address required). Students do not. Credit cards accepted. I think it's a good value any way you cut it.

The garden originally opened in 1894. Today, it encompasses about 5 acres; tiny compared to the rest of Golden Gate Park, but I can't think of a place in the park that's more peaceful and serene. It's like an oasis within an oasis.

There are several things to see and visit including a tea house (for tea and food like inari and futomaki -- pocket tofu and fat sushi rolls), gift shop (selling traditional Japanese items like tea and sake sets), pagodas/temples, bridges (including a steeply arched drum/moon bridge), pond (with koi), fountain, lanterns, sculptures, Buddha, and rock (or zen) garden. It's all packed neatly into a relatively small, clean, nicely groomed, and well manicured space.

A visit to the tea garden could take anywhere from 15 minutes for a quick tour to an hour if you visit the tea house and gift shop.

I love the entire look, feel, layout, design, and overall age-old aesthetic of the garden. A lot of paths and bridges wind and weave their way through the site. Seemingly at every turn, there is something neat or creative to discover. The views are magnificent, particularly around the water, and the attention to detail, especially as it applies to the garden's landscaping (trees, bushes, flowers, stones), is palpable.

Inside Golden Gate Park, the Japanese Tea Garden is located next door to the popular de Young fine arts museum and across the Music Concourse from the California Academy of Sciences. The road the garden and museum are located on, Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive, is named after Makoto Hagiwara, the creator and original caretaker of the garden.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I love this place! So beautiful and peaceful. The admission fee is under $10 and I guess locals get a discount. Too bad I'm from SoCal. There was a cool bridge inside that went straight up and made a very high loop back down. There were koi fish in the pond and other Japanese buildings and structures to see. The gift shop was filled with pretty cool trinkets like chop sticks and tea sets. My husband and sister in law both bought their fortune there for $2 or $4 which proved to be fairly accurate. On the fortune, it says if you don't like it or don't want it to come true, you can leave it hanging up in a tree (I think) nearby. 

The café area was pretty cool too. I got the popcorn tea which was fragrant and tasty. The whole café was positioned right next to the water so it was a good view all around. Overall, it's a whole different world inside. It's like you're not even in Golden Gate Park.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
The gardens around this within Golden Gate Park are beautiful and FREE. If you're not local you'll pay more than locals to enter the Japanese garden. 
I wish I could say it was serene and lovely. The tea cafe is loud and I hope you enjoy spending your time with loud tourists. One American mother literally Just FaceTimed and made calls for 30 minutes at volume. But all the tourists are loud as they comment on their mochi and I get that. The part that bugs me is the actual staff kicking the chairs around and complaining. They're not that into atmosphere. 
I won't pay to come back.
author: A R.

description:
Super cute garden to walk around and have a relaxing zen afternoon.  It was such a relaxing stroll and cute place to take pictures at.  They have a cute tea house near the entrance where you can have lights meals, snacks or just drink tea.

It was a nice place to relax but other than that, not much to do except walk around and take cute pictures.
author: Jackie N.

description: Well that was a short visit. I was so excited to see this place that it was my very first stop during my stay here. Sadly I didn't make it in. I walked up to the paying booth where a boy pointed me to the next window. The woman there literally closes the window in my face without even saying a word and picked up a phone call. I again approach the boy to say about food inside when he emotionlessly stated there was some light food. So I step back to wait for the woman at the other window who was done with the call but still did not even acknowledge me. I understand they get a very large amount of visitors and it's so sad that they are the first people to great you. No sense of hospitality or welcoming.
author: Gordis L.

description:
This beautiful garden has had a tough go of things, surviving some difficult periods in American history. Created initially as part of the worlds fair it's wonderful that it's still going strong. There is a garden you can wonder with stone walkways, koi ponds, a pagoda, and a fun half moon bridge. 

The garden is a beautifully desiarea with walking paths perfectly designed for contemplation and meditation. But don't plan on getting any peace and quiet because this place gets backed with visitors. Go early and during the week for the quietest Times.
author: Marie B.

description:
What a wonderful garden with rich history of SF and the family that were the caretakers until WWII.  SF CITY GUIDE gives a wonderful walking tour.
This is a true Gem in GGP
author: Kay C.

description: There is an admission fee to go into the garden. It's a very nice and scenic garden to visit overall. A great place to take pictures and just enjoy a nice afternoon in peace. I also like the gift shop, and it's nice that they have some affordable gifts to purchase. The tea room cafe had ok food, although the food itself looks delicious. The guy at the cashier/possibly owner there was not very welcoming though.
author: Wendy T.

description: Try the mochi! The matcha flavor is super great. Lychee and strawberry are okay. They offer great tea but everything is a bit spicy
author: Linh D.

description: This a really serene setting, nice and beautiful, but I kind of wish it was a little bigger or a little more to see. There's a few main things to take pics with and there are lots of ponds through out the place for you to see some koi fishes and also pretty lotus flowers. It's definitely a place for an escape into a beautiful garden. There's also a little cafe there that has really good desserts. Overall this place is pretty cool for a first timer but after that I think I'll probably just come back for the cafe and maybe a little bit of it beauty.
author: Maybeline C.

description: Little hut in between a perfectly manicured Japanese garden. Everything feels super authentic. The tea selection is really good and we tried 3-4 of them. We also tried pretty much all the snacks they had to offer. The pancakes were surprisingly good and mochis too. Sencha tea was one we liked best. They have plenty seating and it's all so very beautiful!
author: Namrata J.

description:
This garden is absolutely breathtaking and tranquil inside;  everything is so green and vibrant. There is a great blend of nature and Japanese architecture here. I took a picture of the scenery and it so beautiful to the point it looked fake. If you want to escape the city life and take a breather, come here! 

There is an entrance fee of $8 for non-residents and $6 for SF residents which I think is worth it to upkeep the garden. We did stop by the small tea store and ordered a ice green tea, hot Jasmine tea, and kuzumochi. I do agree that the prices are expensive for the food, but if you are hungry, you don't really have a choice. The food taste good but I didn't think it was too special worthy. 

Overall, I would've rate the tea store 3 stars but the garden is beautiful so it deserves a nod of 5 stars.
author: Hong L.

description:
This was my first experience in a Japanese Tea Garden. 8$ entry fee but totally worth it. For SF locals it is 6$. Don't forget to * Take A Deep Breath* occasionally while you are here. This garden gives you a different kind of Amazing, Refreshing, Fresh feeling. This place is like a dream. Very Quiet and Peaceful. There are many dwarf trees/plants, nicely trimmed and add a beautiful charm to the garden. The walk trail is very well maintained and beautifully carved. They have beautiful pagoda's in the garden. A drum like bridge, beautiful calm fishes in the pond, a cute little gift/souvenir shop, a small Tea house, a big bronze buddha everything complimented the way the garden was architected. 

Definitely recommend everyone to visit this place at least once :)
author: Jaya W.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is a lovely historic garden located in Golden Gate Park. It has been around for over one hundred years and it is nice to see a mature garden so well kept. There is a teahouse too that will serve you delicious Japanese teas and a selection of snacks. We really enjoyed their fresh mochi. JTG really is reminiscent of the many shrines and gardens of Tokyo and makes me want to go back to Japan ASAP.  This garden is not to be missed and should be on high on your itinerary of places to visit in San Francisco. Street parking. Highly recommend.
author: Jerry M.

description:
This garden is truly breathtaking. The entry fee is only $8 if you're not a local, and it's totally worth it.  

The shop at the center of the garden offers a variety of green teas, including traditionally prepared matcha. They also have some sweet treats like mochi, green tea cheesecake, and a variety of prepackaged ice cream. 

Once you have your tea fix, take some time to stroll through the gardens and admire the beautiful surroundings. This is a lovely place to decompress after a long day.
author: Hayley B.

description:
We went here for our engagement photoshoot. The admission is reasonable, but the snacks at the shop are expensive! We were hoping to get some actual lunch here, but it was just to costly so we got some tea and mochi, which tied us over.

As for the scenery and location, it was very pretty! We came at the perfect time because it was warm and we stayed there until sunset. There were nice structures, pretty ponds with rocks, koi fish, nice greenery. There was also a circle bridge that you could walk over. It was lovely afternoon to walk. But it was alot smaller than I thought. We thought it might take us a couple hours to go through the full space, but it only took about 30-45 min and we read everything posted, ate there, and went to their giftshop.

It was a nice experience, but not somewhere I need to go again. If admission was free or cheaper, then I might've come more often just for walking around!
author: Okapi C.

description:
The garden changes with every season- sakura trees and azaleas blossom in spring and the ginkgo leaves become golden yellow in autumn. It is rather small for a Japanese garden, but I spend at least an hour every time I go. My favorite thing to do is to sip hot green tea at the teashop and enjoy the serene view of the koi pond and lush greenery. Absolutely relaxing! This is a fun place to practice your photography skills, explore every nook and cranny, climb the challenging bridge, and admire all the kawaii items of the gift shop.

The kuzumochi was not very soft, maybe because they took it directly out of the fridge. The strawberry mochi was a little too tart. I would recommend trying the green cheesecake instead. The teapots have enough tea for 2-3 cups. Tea sandwiches are tasty and very neatly made.

How to enter for free: The garden is free on Monday, Wednesday, and Fridays before 10AM. If you are a bay area resident with a local library card, go to your library's Discover and Go website and print out tickets to enter for free anytime!
author: Tes Y.

description: One of my favorite spots to visit when I'm in SF. I love the atmosphere and the tea. Always a good spot to take the family or just to relax.
author: Mike K.

description: its beautiful! its very nice if you sit down with a cup of tea and observe the little details that makes this place different
author: Soojeong H.

description: The Japanese tea garden was small for the $9 You pay to get in. It was pretty and the little cafe they have there had some tasty treats .
author: Danyelle H.

description:
I've always wanted to visit the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park. This winter holiday, I finally got my wish. 

We were late leaving home and didn't get to the tea garden till well after 10 am, so we missed the free admission - had to pay $8 per adult and $2 for our older kid. On the other hand, we got lucky and found free street parking just a couple hundred feet from the entrance, so it was a wash. 

The garden is small but quaint, with bridges, pagodas, lots of flowing water and beautifully landscaped trees. Some of the structures looked a little run down and in need of a paint job. There were so many people milling around it was anything but tranquil, but we didn't mind, as our kids were happy to run around adding to the chaos after being cooped up in their car seats for over an hour. 

The tea house was nice. We found a table easily and ordering was quick. We opted for food and beverages that were as authentic as possible -Japanese sencha and hojicha hot teas for my wife and I, hot chocolate for the girls, assorted sweet rice cakes (kuzumochi), red bean paste pancake (dorayaki), and tea house cookies for everyone. The kuzumochi was hands down my favorite - especially the mango and lychee flavored ones. 

Couple of other tips: 
--- You can leave the garden and return if you speak to the ticket booth person and keep your receipt. Came in handy as I had to run back to the van a couple of times. 
--- There are relatively clean bathrooms on site so be sure to use them before you leave. 

The Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate park was lovely and I'm glad we went. Looking forward to visiting other such gardens in the Bay Area and beyond.
author: Navin K.

description: The garden was really beautiful I just wished it was less chaotic. There were so many people there who were so loud and it really took away from the peace and calm of the environment. Maybe I need to go back at an earlier time in the day. I also felt it was quite small for the $9 admission fee. Sitting in the tea house and drinking hot tea was lovely, and I recommend it to anyone who goes.
author: Jenna B.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is a beautiful garden nestled within Golden Gate Park. There is an entrance fee *with a discount for SF residents*, but it's well worth the experience. There is a ton of greenery to admire and koi fish filled ponds to hold you attention as well. There are a few sculptures and a cool staircase type structure that you can climb up and down on. The tea garden does have a gift shop and small restaurant/tea shop of sorts that serves different types of tea and some small food items. I did stop by and try the sencha and the traditional matcha with mochi. The price for the food/tea is a bit steep, but I felt that it was well worth the experience. Overall, the Japanese Tea Garden is a really great place to visit, though you may want to go on a warmer day for more sunshine.
author: Lakshmi M.

description: I love the Japanese Tea Garden, located in SF's Golden Gate Park, and visited it when I was 18 and again recently when visiting SF in May 2017.  It's a lovely and expansive garden with so many peaceful, tranquil areas, and is apparently the oldest public Japanese Garden in the United States!   One of the most iconic parts of the garden is the "Drum Bridge," which you can climb up.  You get a great view of the garden standing up there.  Some of the other highlights include the "Treasure Tower" pagoda, the rock garden, and the tea house.  I haven't been to the tea house, but it looks lovely.  This place is great for a walk, great for sitting and reflecting, and great for just escaping the busy city life and feeling at peace in nature.  I will certainly return in the future when I visit SF again.
author: Pegah Y.

description:
I always try to visit this garden when I am in Golden Gate Park. It's free admission on some weekdays before 10am, check their website. It's a great experience even if you have to pay and definitely worth it if it's your first time. The garden has more colors obviously in the fall or summer. This last time I went was in February but nevertheless it is beautiful. The trees are well taken care of, and beautifully shaped. It is tranquil and a nice place to just relax. The reason for an average rating is for some reason there are nowhere near as many koi fish as before...where have they all gone?? There used to be so many that there were hardly room to swim and they were all chubby and so pretty. Maybe because it is in the middle of winter...but I was disappointed. 

There is a little gift shop that sells knick knacks and Japanese culture related things such as tea sets and household ceramics. My bf got me an adorable sheep keychain! But really most things are overpriced and aimed to entice tourists into spending. 

Next to the gift shop is an adorable tea shop overlooking the pond.  Take a menu and order at the register. They give you a number and you sit anywhere you want. Try to sit next to the pond, it's so peaceful and a lovely place to sip tea. My boyfriend ordered the matcha tea, a red bean pancake and I ordered my favorite tea sandwiches. The matcha was actually pretty fragrant, though I thought was very expensive for the quality. It came with a really good green tea mochi. The mochi was not to sweet which was nice. The red bean pancake was ok, I think it needed more red bean flavor. It was a little too artificial to me. My sandwiches were adorably yummy. It seems simple...but the bread is so soft, and the fillings are just so decadent. Watch out because you can easily spend a lot of money at this tea shop for just snacks! 

Take your loved ones here or enjoy a stroll on your own. Either way it's a wonderful way to spend some quiet time.
author: Yen P.

description:
Really not a lot to do, 
The Buddha was cool to look at, the two little
Japanese buildings were cool 

I went up that bridge and dropped my iPhone.
author: Ash S.

description: Not sure why, but me and my brother ordered the same thing. He tipped the lady and got loose leaf tea. Mine was just a bag of regular tea in a pot?
author: Mitchell M.

description: The zen of the sweet little tea garden is only ruined by all the noise of people talking and photo opting. I found when I ditched my company and walked the paths quietly and slowly I got from it what it is intend for. Strolling the paths in quiet and solitude is soul pleasing. Just, shhhh. I'd recommend just looking and listening as you stroll.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
This is a beautiful tea garden - very relaxing - very well-maintained and easy to find with plenty of street parking.  

This was one of the places I knew I was going to visit before I left San Francisco - so the morning of my departure I checked out of the hotel and drove to Golden Gate Park to hunt this down as well as a few other things inside the park I wanted to see. 

Entrance is $9 or so if I remember correctly and it's a large enough park with some very pretty water elements and other things that I wasn't horribly upset about the price - though I do feel like that is still a bit steep.  

There is a really cool arched bridge you can do a neat photo on if you are brave enough to climb it and stand in the center (it has handrails and foot planks). 

There is a tea shop inside that sells some cute tea-related items and touristy stuff as well as a small cafe where you can get snacks and teas. 

I was in a hurry so I only spent an hour --- honestly it's not HUGE so it probably wouldn't take that much longer even if you had the day --- it's pretty though and is one of the nicer Japanese Tea Gardens I have seen.
author: Alison M.

description:
It's been a pleasant experience every time I've visited this garden. 

I've only gone when it's free entry (MWF before 10am), so the garden gets understandably crowded during those times. The garden itself isn't very big, but everywhere you turn there is something to see. It could be a pond with koi fish, a small but high bridge (think of a giant horseshoe), a small restaurant, purposefully placed rocks, or some staff that are performing maintenance. It's easy to tell that it's meticulously taken care of by the staff there. The visit itself might take around 50 minutes for a relaxed walk. There's also a few benches strategically placed around the garden to sit and enjoy the view.
author: Cameron G.

description:
The worst experience ever at this place. The one star wasn't dedicated for the place. The view itself worth 5 star. But BE WARNED before you decided to visit this garden!!! 

My family and I visited this place during our holiday from Los Angeles. We parked our car by MLK, about half a mile from the Japanese Tea Garden. We toured the garden for about one hour. As soon as we returned, we found out that we had our front passenger window car smashed and had most of our valuables and belongings stolen. There was no security to summon and when we called the park workers for help, they told us to called 311 instead. No help was even offered. I was so disappointed to see their reaction. Like they know this crimes occurred on daily basis and decided not to care. Even after our line was picked up by 311, they only took our report by the phone. We were told by a sympathetic passerby that our car wasn't the only one who got break-in that day. Luckily she said there was a police nearby so we ran towards the other location and called the police for help. 

After everything that had happened and what I heard from the passerby, we would think with daily robberies in an area frequented by families and tourist, the city would provide and increase surveillance. To think we had to pay $9 per person to had our valuables stolen and our holiday ruined wasn't worth all those beautiful views. We won't be coming back. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED PEOPLE.
author: Susan B.

description: Pretty nice lay of the land. This is settled inside golden gate park, which is beautiful in of itself. This little gem is small but worth going inside to walk the grounds and take some nice pictures. They have a little shop and a spot where you can buy some food and tea.
author: Marcos O.

description:
Perfect place to spend some time relaxing in a beautiful place and for a little snack. We went on a Friday and it was not busy at all - nice grounds to explore and peaceful to walk around. We had the matcha tea, udon, miso soup, kuzumochi and dakayaki
 (sp?) - everything was delicious and eating at the open air tea house was charming
author: Kate S.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is fine but I don't remember it being quite so crowded and costing quite as much as it did.  Then again, it had been 14 years since I had last been here so who knows.  It was a beautiful Saturday afternoon in Golden Gate Park, so the whole place was packed.  When we arrived at the Tea Garden, the line to get in was pretty long.  We almost didn't wait but ultimately, did.  

I guess the serenity you would like from such a beautiful garden is lost when there are so many people.  It's very cool inside and has some great opportunities for beautiful photographs, if you can get the people to stay out of your shot.  Probably my own fault for going on a Saturday.   

So, choose your days wisely because this place is free on certain days.  Look it up because I don't recall the days.  I am sure it is a better experience on an "off" day than it was this particular Saturday.  A more quiet and serene experience likely awaits you on that day.  If so, enjoy.
author: Lance F.

description:
It was a beautiful Sunday morning when I took my sister and aunt here for their birthday.  We lucked out on street parking around the corner from the garden.  After the $8 admission fee we went straight to the tea house!  

So it's pretty much outdoor seating but under roofs and some trees for shade.  I was lucky there wasn't a line but while I was next, my sis and aunt snagged a table.  The set up is you order at the counter and then you sit down and wait for your goodies to come.  It doesn't take long at all; a lot of the goodies are already prepped.

Here's what we shared between the 3 of us:

SENCHA TEA - $4.99
Japanese green tea prepared by steaming its leaves and rolling them into their signature needle-life shape.  It is characterized by a distinctly bright, sweet, aroma and flavor.  This tea is steeped and served in a small teapot. 
This is enough for one cup for each of us. It's nice and I really can't say much more about to be honest. But it fits with the goodies we had.

TEA SANDWICHES - $8.99
Assortment of Tuna Salad, Apple and Cheese, Turkey and Cucumber, Turkey and Cheese sandwiches on white bread.
I thought all of them were delicious.  It wasn't amazing--I'm also that very picky.  

MISO SOUP - $3.95
