Traditional soup mad with miso (fermented soybean), green onions, tofu, and Wakame seaweed.
It was warm and it was tasty. It's your pretty standard miso soup.  

GREEN TEA CHEESECAKE - $6.50
Smooth and delicious Japanese style cheesecake.
This fluffy and fish cheesecake was pretty good.  You definitely taste the green tea flavor and was a good portion to share.

KUZUMOCHI (6pcs) - $4.95
House-made sweet rice cakes.
The 3 flavors that came in our set was:
MANGO, STRAWBERRY, and GREEN TEA.  I thought they all tasted wonderful, tender, soft and full of flavor!  This was fun to eat!

PETIT FOUR - $6.50
These little cakes tasted mostly like almond probably because of the fondant.  This was the least favorite and we only got it cuz it looked pretty.  One of them had a bean filling.  

UDON SOUP - $8.99
This seems to be one of the specials of the day.  It's was a decent bowl of thick noodles and soup.  With a piece of naruto.

Overall the food was fine. It wasn't mind blowing or anything but you know what, it was convenient.  It was a lovely place in a beautiful garden.  I had a wonderful time and would do it again!
author: Tu-Anh N.

description: When going to San Fran, going to the Golden Gate park is normally on the itinerary. There is so much to do there so prepare to plan almost a day in the park visiting the different attractions. One of the peaceful and tranquil places is the Japanese tea garden. Take your time walking through appreciating the environment, plants, koi and also how the garden is structured. Within the garden is a tea house where you can enjoy different types of tea, udon, miso soup or mochi ice cream. There's a lot more to order from the menu. So appreciative of this garden in the midst of such a massive park.
author: Lisa M.

description:
If you're in Golden Gate Park on a Monday, Wednesday or Friday, definitely take a moment to check out the Japanese Tea Garden! It's free those days, but otherwise $8 for non-residents to visit, which is a rather steep price for a small garden.

It's a peaceful spot though with pagodas, koi ponds, zen gardens and lots of green bamboo and bonsai trees. There's also a small teahouse inside that offers a few teas and some food/snack options. Also pricey though, so if you actually want tea or Japanese food or snacks, I'd recommend finding something in the Sunset or Richmond areas around Golden Gate Park.

Honestly, as a SF local, I never bothered visiting the tea garden until recently and I don't feel like I missed out on much.
author: Jessie L.

description:
My family came for vacation and ordered some of their desserts.
For drinks, we all ordered the green matcha iced tea. 
The green tea cheesecake is highly recommended! 
The mochi weren't really good in my opinion.
author: Grace H.

description: We had a great wonderful time getting our Zen in in the Japanese Tea Garden! My wife and I are expecting our a beautiful baby boy in November so it was awesome for us to walk around the garden and think about our blessings while also getting some great pics!
author: Sam T.

description:
I love Japanese gardens. I've been to several in various cities in California...and I have to say that after only two visits, this one has grown to be my favorite so far. Both visits were during the autumn..but unlike my first visit which was in the afternoon, this time we stopped by shortly after it opened in the morning.

This tea garden is gorgeous. The landscapes are beautiful, simple and complex woven with water, wood, rock and plant features, including stepping paths, bridges, hills, streams and waterfalls. There are shady glens that rarely see full sun, and thin pockets of trees through which the morning light was next to magical.  Each turn of the winding garden path takes you to a new tiny world.

The autumn colors (ginkgoes' leaves were golden yellow and maples were starting to turn gold and red) were lovely, and glistened in the morning sun. I can only imagine how beautiful this place is in the other seasons as well. 

All ponds were stocked full with large graceful koi fish, and there were plenty of tucked away benches to sit on to enjoy the peaceful space for a few more moments.

Some of the architectural features include a half-circle wooden bridge, several statutes, an outdoor tea house, and a gift shop--both inspired by Japanese architecture and design, 

The tea house sells tea and some snack foods. My favorite tea was the gen mai cha (toasted rice and green tea). The mochi variety snack plate was okay, with the peanut flavored mochi falling flat. Strawberry and lychee flavored mochi was pretty cool.

It does cost to get in, but I didn't mind paying. If the money is what keeps this place well manicured and clean--it is worth it.  If you are looking for a respite from a busy life, a lovely place to take family, or just something to break up your usual routine, stop by and rest awhile.
author: Tashara H.

description:
My culture crush on Japan continues, in part thanks to this tranquil garden in Golden Gate Park. A five acre homage to all things Japanese (complete with tea room and shop), it's a great place to stroll after a trip to the de Young or a day in the city. A visit during springtime, when the cherry trees are in full bloom is an absolute must. It's just beautiful.
Despite the quietude, the garden's a surprisingly good place to bring children. My little boy comes to watch the koi swim, climb the drum bridge, and to eat green tea ice cream. Everyone's happy :)
author: N. M.

description: I highly recommend visiting here if you can. It's beautiful, peaceful, and well tended. You can order tea and snacks and sit by a bubbling waterfall, which we enjoyed after walking the grounds. Parking nearby can be tricky, so taking the bus is a good idea.
author: Bren C.

description: I've wanted to come here for a long time because I really like Japanese gardens, and I finally got the chance to come. And it was free! I arrived to the garden on a Friday morning before 10AM, so I didn't have to pay the (high) entrance fee. The garden is really small so I don't think the fee is really fair, but hey just come in the morning. Anyway, when my friend and I came, it was kind of crowded which was unexpected. I think there was some international school program going on so there were a lot of people walking around. Anyway, the garden itself was really pretty; there's of course a pond with koi fish in it, some temple structures, and Japanese-looking shrubs and trees. It was a really pretty walk around, and we had a good time!
author: Andrea W.

description: A wonderful, serene, peaceful park. Great place to slow down, enjoy the beautiful landscape and take awesome pictures!
author: Joy R.

description: We went on a weekday so the parking was okay on Martin Luther king drive. Not too crowded. $9 for non SF residents and $6 for residents. But you need to show ID with your SF address on it. So it doesn't work if you moved recently. Very beautiful. Has a very steep and curvy bridge that people climb up take pictures on. Very peaceful like a meditation land. Many peaceful ponds with koi fish in them. Some shrines and things. A gift shop with cute things. Many chopsticks and chopstick holders and cute stuffed animals. A tea house with tea, udon, and little Japanese eats. Has a big Buddha.
author: Amanda L.

description: I could literally spend all day at this place. Amazing botanical views, beautiful architecture, and the sounds of nature. Nothing more you could ask for. If you happen to be there during the colder seasons grab a miso soup, tea, or even hot cocoa to stay warm!
author: Kyil W.

description: Nice but its so small, would be back one day. Love drinking hot tea with some mochi ice-cream
author: Vy N.

description: Beautiful.!  I wish this was my backyard!  If I could change anything it would be the loud people that bustle thru here. The entire areas so beautiful and zen. You just can't get away from the loud city sound of people. This is obviously not the fault of the gardens . We had tea and udon at the Little place on one of the ponds. Walked thru their beautiful gift shop which I felt was reasonably price. All in All it was amazing and gorgeous. I will definitely go back !
author: Patrice M.

description:
Unfortunately, I felt like this was kind of a rip-off...Some folks have taken some wonderful pictures of this park on Yelp but I didn't really get that great of an experience since I found myself taking photos of folks taking photos of folks...taking photos with the sculptures and scenery.  

I've always felt like Japanese Gardens should evoke feelings of serenity but for $8 a pop ($6 if you're a local), you got a handful of koi fish in ponds that could be kept up a little better, a pretty flower here and there, children crawling passed you on little walkways, and someone's selfie-stick hovering near your head like a mic boom. 

They had a little gift shop, and a café that we didn't patron. They also have a bathroom on site, which is appreciated. There is also this crazy bridge that looks like a lawsuit waiting to happen. 

Maybe going earlier in the day would have been more peaceful, or maybe they should consider a capacity that would make for a more enjoyable experience.
author: Morgan F.

description: Had a great experience here. Too bad its too small. I expect more. Special thing about this place is where there is sort of gazebos where u can enjoy japanese snacks and tea with the view of the garden. My intake on their dorayaki, its tasty not oversweet, the sweetness mostly came from the red bean. And i love their hojicha.
author: Ron N.

description: Such a quaint spot! The paid entry seems to be enough of a deterrent that it doesn't feel super crowded. They've got limited tea and snacks, but great ponds and gardens.
author: Parnian D.

description:
Wanna drink tea while enjoying a japanese garden vibe? Then come here! Its tea time!

This is the first stop I did when I went to SF. For $8 admission fee you got to experienced a japanese garden vibe without even going to Japan. 

The place is not that big but big enough to roam around & take great photos. They have souvenir shop with lots of interesting items & also the tea shop that you can chill after getting tired of roaming around the place. 

I tried the green tea cheesecake- it was really good with the exact softness & sweetness. Good pair for their teas. I got the hot hojicha for their teas- kinda basic tea with a nice aroma. Bf got the iced green tea- he liked it. It was unsweetened & very refreshing.

Great place to visit, take pictures & relax!
author: Jean Claire G.

description:
Come prepared with a camera in fading daylight, and you'll have yourself an incredible photographer's playground. Diffused lighting, soft sunlight filtering through foliage, mirrorlike ponds and dignified rocks mean you'll find some amazing views.

Very tranquil and beautiful.

I'd love to come again in the early morning when there aren't so many people and the light is perhaps softer. FYI MWF before 10am is free admission. It's $9 for adults who aren't SF residents.
author: Connie L.

description: This is a pleasant place to stop by if you're in SF! It cost around $8 for entry fee (no student discount btw). Their cherry blossoms are beautiful in here if you are planning to visit during Spring. Definitely check it out if you have an extra hour or two to spare!
author: Shaina H.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is one of the hidden treasures of Golden Gate Park. As tacky as it sounds, I've never felt more at peace than when I'm at the tea garden. The perfectly groomed greenery along with intricate stepping stone paths, the calming sounds of water streams, the beautiful pagodas and the arched drum bridge. 

Located inside of the tea garden is the Tea House where you can enjoy a nice cup of tea and sample some popular japanese pastries and sandwiches. I highly recommend the green tea cheesecake which was my favorite. The richness along with the matcha green tea flavor was absolute perfection. 

Also located inside is the tea garden is the Gift Shop where you can find authentic japanese tea and sake sets, cute little figurines, and of course a wide variety of teas to choose from. 

The Japanese Tea Garden is definitely a must if you're visiting SF. It's a nice change in pace from the hustle and bustle of Downtown SF or Fishermans Wharf. Admission is FREE Mon, Wed, Fri if entered by 10AM. After that it's $6 for residents and $8 for non-residents.
author: Chris I.

description: Always a very nice walk through the Japanese Tea Garden.  Really interesting plaques telling the stories and history of this venue.  If you want a relaxing walk and love Japanese culture and tea, check them out.  The pricing structure is reasonable....compared to the DeYoung or Steinhart.  Parking is easy but I do recommend getting their early.  They open at 9am daily.
author: Joel C.

description: Absolutely gorgeous! The koi ponds and zen garden were picturesque and the gift shop was perfect for SF souvenirs.
author: Katie K.

description:
Really nice introduction to japanese gardens.
The place is not really big but really offers lots of beautiful gardens.
This is definitely a place you want to avoid in crowded summer week ends. I would recommend to visit it on spring days or winter days.
Take the time tonrelax and get the athmosphere. Do not gesitate just to spend some time at the restaurant/tea house.
A good relaxing and beautiful place.
The shop has standards japanese souvenirs.
author: Gaetan S.

description:
The garden is located within Golden Gate Park and is the oldest public Japanese garden in the United States. It was reasonably priced admission for $8. It's not that big as I was here for less than an hour. 

I was most intrigued with the drum bridge- a high arched pedestrian bridge found in Chinese and Japanese gardens. I walked across it slowly. Other features include a large bronze Buddha statue, a five-tiered pagoda (Buddhist shrine), and plenty of koi fish in the main pond.  Bronze plaques here and there were helpful and informative in telling visitors about some of the features. I was hoping there was a brochure, because I wanted to make sure I saw everything. I later found them at the gift shop- for $2.25. I found that to be ridiculous. 

Being as it is a tea garden, there is a tea house. Six kinds of tea and a variety of light snacks and sweet treats are offered. I didn't get a chance to try anything though.

Come here to find some inner peace.
author: Helen H.

description:
Beautiful, tranquil, and I almost missed it.  I took part in walking tour and after a delightful brunch we walked a mile to get to Golden Gate Park.  When we were done exploring it I split from the group and walked all the way back to the California Academy of Sciences because it looked really interesting.  After wandering through that I was pretty much ready to call it a day.  When I looked on a map to see where the heck I was I noticed that a Japanese Tea Garden was extremely close.  Thinking I would regret it if I didn't go see it I braced myself for more walking.  At this point it was getting later in the day but with only eight bucks charged for admission I didn't mind that my experience would be short.

Considering how late in the afternoon it was I was surprised that there was a sizeable line to get inside.  This is obviously a popular attraction.  Once I started walking through the gardens I instantly was glad that I had decided to visit.  It was just one beautiful sight after another and brought back happy memories of my trip to Japan.  I thought the arched drum bridge was a fun climb but be careful because it's quite steep!  I'd love to come back here during cherry blossom season.  After I had my fill of pagodas, koi ponds, etc I made sure to stop in their gift shop to get something to remind me of this special place.  I'm so glad that I didn't miss this!
author: Chris W.

description: It's a really nice afternoon if you're at the Golden State Park, and good to take advantage of if you have a City Pass. It seems really authentic and it's something different. Have the jasmine tea in the little café inside!
author: Aymara L.

description: We love this garden, we were so relax walking around. The way the garden was put together was outstanding. This place is beautiful and peaceful, we totally recommend to check it out.
author: Henry G.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon at around 3 pm. The garden wasn't too crowded, so it was pretty relaxing to walk around aside from the families taking photos everywhere. $7 for non-residents of SF and on MWF admission is free before 10 am. In a busy city like San Francisco, it's refreshing to see a place like this.

The Garden:

Pretty nice to walk around, and a great opportunity to take pictures with the landscape There are ponds and rock gardens among nicely kept lawns. I've always admired the Japanese culture for their attention to detail with gardens and how it's aesthetically pleasing to the eye, even when the colors are just natural hues of green, brown, and gray. The hedges are nicely trimmed, with some having perfect roundness or looking like cubes. It was pretty warm that day, so I think all the koi fish were trying to avoid the middle of the pond - they kept bundling up in the shaded areas.

The structures they have are nice, especially that arch bridge. For a garden that's supposed to be relaxing, that bridge seems kinda dangerous to cross... but it's easy to do. Be careful since there are people who crowd at the top for photos or take photos while climbing, then there are the unsupervised children who are climbing all over the bridge. Fear not, you do not have the take the arch bridge as there are stone paths to get around. I do like how some of the paths were just flat rocks to cross a pond.

Be sure to check out the red pagoda above the garden, as it's a great photo opportunity and there is a gate as well. They do a good job of putting benches everywhere in the garden, so if you're here on a weekday when it's less busy, it'd be the perfect place to read a book or sketch.

The Tea House:

The cafe/tea house overlooks the garden - I'd recommend sitting on the edges to enjoy the view. It can get pretty crowded with seating, but once you get your number after ordering, it shouldn't be hard to find a table aWe decided to have an afternoon snack of iced green tea, tea sandwiches, and mochi. Iced green teas ($3.75 each for a mug) was perfectly chilled - not sure why others complained it was too sweet... since mine tasted like actual matcha, and not the crap you get at Starbucks.

The sandwiches were tiny for $8.95 (you could finish in 2 bites) but tasty and a little refreshing on a warm day. No crusts on these sandwiches and the white bread they use is super fluff. 

There's 2 of each flavor:
- Cheese and Apple: This was my favorite, I'll have to start putting apples with my cheese sandwiches.
- Cucumber + Turkey: Good combination.
- Ham and Mayonnaise: Tastes like what you'd expect.
- Tuna: Eh, tuna is tuna but it wasn't too fishy.

I'd highly recommend getting the mochi here, as it's sweet, chilled, and chewy! We got the 6 pieces for $5 - they came in green tea, mango, and strawberry. Mango was my favorite flavor, as you could taste the mango.

Food is pretty expensive here, but sometimes it's worth the experience. Also I really enjoyed having some iced matcha green tea after walking around all day.

Overall, it's a nice stop while exploring Golden Gate Park, more like a 3.5. We ended up spending 1.5 hours here between walking through the garden and chilling at the tea house - the garden is pretty small compared to other Japanese gardens I've visited around the country, but still well kept. If only admission could be $5 for everyone...
author: Alyanna C.

description:
This was my first time at a Japanese tea garden, I was expecting a bigger garden. Nevertheless a beautiful place to visit while in SF. It's a perfect backdrop for pictures, because it consists of small waterfalls, ponds and bridges surrounded by greenery all around. I fell in love with the dwarf trees, they  were so geometrically cut. I was inspired to have my own Japanese garden in my backyard. One day!!! 
They also have a tea house you can visit after your stroll through the garden. You can pick from a variety of flavors. I tried their macha tea which was the most expensive one and was sorely disappointed . Surprisingly the inexpensive $3 tea was way better!! 

Overall great a experience. Do take advantage of their free morning hours Monday, Wednesday and Friday before 10 am
author: Pheebz M.

description:
One of San Francisco's hidden treasures! 

The Japanese Tea Garden is a beautiful, impeccably manicured garden in Golden Gate Park with winding pathways and bridges. It's incredibly peaceful as you meander through the gardens and ponds filled with koi fish. There are also lovely statues of Buddha as well as small temples throughout. In the middle of the garden, there's a small restaurant where you can get snacks, mochi, and hot tea on a cold San Francisco afternoon.

Overall, highly recommend for both locals and tourists, it's well worth the price! 
Be sure to take your camera because you'll get some excellent photos of sculpted trees!
author: Nisha P.

description:
Free on Mon, Wed, Fri, before 10.  Otherwise, $5 admission for residents and $7 for non-residents.  As an LA guy, this was a nice, peaceful break from the non-stop hiking, eating, etc itinerary that we built up for ourselves during our visit.  There are a lot of people, but there are also tons of street parking to accommodate, even though you may have to walk a little bit.  

There are plenty of beautiful greens, towers, and arcs to transport you away from the SF city life, and also for picture ops.  My favorite part of this place was the little cafe they have in the middle, overlooking the pond.  We were lucky to snag a counter spot to look directly over the pond while snacking on our flavored mochi and tea drinks!
author: Jeff T.

description:
I'm not a big fan of the $8 entrance fee. It should at least be free for SF residents, like the Botanical Garden. 

The garden could be very peaceful, but is so overcrowded. I recommend going on a weekday for a better experience. 

Lastly, if you were wondering whether drinking tea at the tea garden is a thing--wonder no more--it is a thing! There's a cute little tea house in the Garden. Enjoy!
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
I was in San Fransisco for work and while the weather didn't want to agree most of the time, the day we went here was perfect!

If you get here early enough when they first open, then you don't pay an entry fee.  I will say though, that after coming here...I would pay double the entry fee.  If you want a place where you can be totally relaxed while seeing the most beautiful Japanese designs, then this is the place.

They have plenty of beautiful stone work, buildings, and plant life that all make you feel like you have escaped the city and are walking around feudal Japan.  They have a perfect little restaurant inside where you can get all sorts of treats!  They also have a great gift shop for souvenirs to take back home.  If I lived around this area, I would probably be here at least once a week!

I highly recommend you make this your top priority if you visit San Fransisco!
author: Joshua D.

description:
Price - $8 per adult is reasonable once you see how pretty it is and how much you now want a Japanese garden in your home.

Time - Easily an hour to notice everything, take pictures like a tourist, and read the signs even at the pace of a quick stroll and covering every single pathway. 

Bridge - People climb on it and take pictures.

Gift Shop - Super cute. Hide your wallet. 

Restaurant - Interior matches the mood of the garden. It's simple, clean, and the view from wherever you sit, faces some part of the garden. There are small snacks, noodle dishes, and tea.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
I did not study Japanese gardening ever so I can't comment on the flora or how true is it to real Japanese gardens. I can only compare it to the gardens I've been to in the past. 

Compared to the Japanese garden in Balboa Park (San Diego) this one has more structures to see and more expansive flora. The one in SD is a few bucks cheaper,  maybe a little larger,had a deeper basin area, more running water and bamboo forest but this one had a more scenic casual vibe. The SD one had mini Japanese house/museum workshop area with kimonos on display and a variety of other characteristically Japanese structures but all in all, it seemed a little bit contrived. The SF one was less like that and more a place to relax and stroll around. Both gardens have very circular paths, i.e, there aren't paths that lead to exciting or new things. You can finish checking the garden out in ~10 min if you don't stop for pictures. It's also nice that the footbridge is climbable and there are rocks you can walk on. 

HOWEVER, I wouldn't spend my money just to take a 'stroll' at these parks again. Don't get me wrong--both were beautiful places to visit and I'd recommend people to check it out if they've never seen a Japanese garden before, but there wasn't anything particularly special about them. 

The only garden place that is worth spending money to visit in my opinion is the Huntington Gardens in Pasadena. They have by far the best Japanese garden I've been too. Very intricate landscapes and setup (the footbridge is off-limits unfortunately) but with less structures than the SF one. It is also much larger and explorable so it takes a good ~30 min to just walk around.
author: Lydia Z.

description: Beautiful area of trees, grass, and stocked ponds with coy fish. Cost for out of state adults is $9 which is pricey for what is received in return in my opinion. There are a couple of pagodas but overall not much. Pretty to see once if you've never been to Asia but otherwise I'd pass. It's missing more of the cultural influence, flowers, etc.
author: Gary G.

description: I love having the matcha and mochi here, it's so peaceful.  This is best sitting at the benches facing the pond.
author: Trinh T.

description:
Went to Hakone Estate & Gardens, in Saratoga and was slightly disappointed. The oldest Japanese garden in the US needed money to keep up its grounds. This garden is well funded and well kept and has throngs of visitors, too many in fact to be able the enjoy the garden in any sense of peace and quiet. The advise was to visit on weekdays when there are fewer people but I am never in San Francisco during the week. 

Quite spectacular in its structures and landscape design. You need about an hour to go through this and you can go to the De Young Museum or come here after you are done with the science center.
Best Japanese garden I have seen and I have not been to Japan, so this is it.
author: Keo N.

description:
There's just something so peaceful about Japanese Gardens that you just have to visit one sometime in your lifetime. I've been to only one garden before (in Portland), and I had a grand experience that I knew I had to one day check the one in San Francisco out.

This Japanese Tea Garden is located within Golden Gate Park. You can just follow Nancy Pelosi Drive and you'll see it. Admission on weekends is $8 for each adult and only $6 if you are a resident. I find that price a bit too steep because you can definitely get through the garden in less than 30 minutes.

Overall, the garden is very beautiful. I wouldn't consider it very tranquil or calm since it can get extremely hot with all the tourists walking around. It's pretty much impossible to get a picture at hot spots such as the drum bridge without waiting.

That said, there are a number of beautiful "exhibits" worth mentioning. One is the famous drum bridge. Apparently it's been around since the early 1900's. That's wacky! Also, there's the tea cafe if you really want the full experience. It's pricy, but maybe the tea is worth it? And the koi pond is huge! Except for the fact that there's not many fish around... 

tl;dr I'd come here when I have a discount. I don't mind paying $8, but I find that excessive for the experience you get. But hey, it's a donation to the park!
author: Bryan W.

description:
The first time I visited this I was blown away. It is much larger than I imagined. The landscaping and architecture is second to none. Built and maintained by people who care. 

The bridges are worth crossing and a stop for tea is a must. 

Worth the trip.
author: Jay N.

description: This was not a good use of my nine dollars. The garden was too crowded, even on a weekday. There wasn't much to look at, and there were only a couple koi fish in the ponds. It was quite boring.
author: A W.

description:
Tucked inside golden gate park is a beautiful Japanese garden. For about $8 admission will get you in. It was very small and didn't take long to walk around the entire place. 

Maybe for those who like to meditate it is nice. Sit back and enjoy the beautiful surroundings. Get a cup of tea for around $4. I didn't try it. 

I'll give them that it is beautiful but not worth the admission price in my book. It would need to double in size.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Had A great time with my kids visiting the gardens. The Teagarden is very nice although of course it is geared for tourists so it is quite expensive but if doing it couple times a year it's worth it it's nice and quaint. We came on a weekday and it was nice and light for foot traffic but I am sure that on the weekends it gets a lot more tourism. The quoit pond you're very lovely filled with fish and surrounding lovely plants and flowers. Definitely a great place to bring visitors from out of state, out of town and out of the country.
author: Linda L.

description:
$8 for admission beautiful place to visit although very crowded you can still view everything patients is key on a busy day if you want to get some pictures in. 

Took us an hour to get around everything cause we constantly stoped to take pictures and relax. 

Favorite part watching these 2 very overweight squirrels messing around and eating all from the distance of my arm. Also the vertical bridge was very cool. 

Definitely recommend going I believe it's free mon, wed, and Friday if entered by 10 am and kids under 4 are always fee
author: Blanca S.

description: Cute and tranquil  garden, just small and there are a lot of visitors. Also one of the shrines needs to be restored and overall the gardens could be kept better. Pleasant experience with a super cool half moon bridge
author: Livia R.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden does a great job of making you forget that you're in the city. It's definitely worth the inexpensive entry fee. Although I did not go to the tea room you can see it from the entry and it is beautiful. The whole garden is fairly authentic and is big enough that you are not crammed with other visitors.
author: Alice G.

description: We went here in a group of 3 people in March end, which was a bloom time. There was quite a big line outside to get in, but it was fast moving. As I went to park the car after dropping the other 2 in my party, I asked them to get 3 tickets for us but that wasn't allowed. Everyone needs to get their own tickets by getting in the line. So my friends had to wait for me at the tea house where they ordered tea and some small sweet snacks. Tea was okay but it was a nice experience pouring it out and sitting with the view of the gardens. The gardens themselves are little small, but have some highlights and good photo points. The bridge was pretty popular and so were the small japanese style pagodas which were giving a nice feel to the gardens. Cherry blossoms were blooming too. Its a very small walk and $9 is about the max that I would like to pay to get in here. Outside the gardens is nice area to just hang out or bike around on a nice sunny day in the city.
author: Roma M.

description:
when you consider just where this oasis is located and the number of people who live nearby you cannot help but be amazed. The garden is beautiful and peaceful and a welcome respite from the crowds elsewhere in the park. After entering we enjoyed some green tea, Japanese soda (I almost had to ask the little boy next to us for help in opening the rather unique glass bottle (yes, glass!) and Tea House Cookies. Reasonably priced at $12.95.

There are walking paths everywhere, some with benches situated in quiet nooks for contemplation. No matter how noisy it may be outside everyone seems to dial it down when they are in the Gardens. Opportunities for pictures everywhere and bring a jacket in case it gets cold. While there I watched a man on a ladder, in a pond, trimming a large bush/tree with a pair of special scissors. No weed whackers her!

Worth the price of admission ($6 for senior non-residents).
author: Dave W.

description: We went on a Saturday afternoon which was pretty busy. There's a $8 fee for adults but it's cheaper if you're an SF resident. Theres a restaurant where you can buy tea and other Japanese desserts. Great shots of photography. There's this steep bridge that you can climb but it was so crowded and lots of people going up and down it was hard to get a good picture. Parking was alright theres a good amount of street parking.
author: Jessica D.

description: Somewhat small, although it is beautiful! I'd like see some other (hopefully larger!) Tea gardens before I'd recommend this, as it was a quick 30 minute tour. We stayed and got some food while we were here but aside from a few good sites I wouldn't take anyone here if I was showing someone around...
author: Chase H.

description: This place has great scenery, vibes, calm atmosphere, great place for the family. Nice little tea shops too that has little food and tea . Come check it out
author: Brandon P.

description:
My husband & I enjoyed tea & snacks in the cafe before strolling in the garden. Although it was noon on a Saturday, it was not that crowded. Perhaps the cooler weather kept the crowds away -- or they were diverted to Bay to Breakers event that took place that day. 
In the outdoor cafe, there was no line & the service was very prompt. I enjoyed the udon noodles and hot tea. My husband enjoyed a plate of small sandwiches. We shared mochi for dessert. It made for a light lunch in a pleasant setting. 
We are not SF residents, so we paid the full price. It's true that the garden is not large. But we hadn't been there in many years, and it was worth the price of admission to re-acquaint ourselves with the garden, which includes several plaques that explain the historical significance of special features. 
A lovely way to spend a hour or two.
author: Vickie M.

description: Clean air, pretty place, maintained well. Makes for a wonderful stroll or two, though I do wish there'd be less people - you have to stop quite a few times out of courtesy for others who are taking pictures. Not a fan of the $9 admission fee and the abundance of coins in the waterworks - poor fish (koi)! However, the gift shop is actually quite nice if you're looking for reasonably priced entry-level Japanese teaware.
author: Josh L.

description: I really like the vibe of this place. It's a beautiful place and I appreciate that they do free admissions for early visitors. The price for regular admission is pretty high sadly. I was fine with it but I expected more for the price. It's beautiful the parts they have but it is small. The little tea place was cool. The service was good but it just didn't have good food. We got the mochi and it was pretty gross. Me and my sister were kinda grossed out after. I also got the dorayaki and that wasn't very special or super tasty either. To drink I got the iced green tea. Sorry to say it but, I feel like even Starbucks has better iced green tea. This place's food isn't special and it's not good. The worst part about it is that it's pretty overpriced. Overall I would not recommend the actual restaurant thing and just bring your own snacks like others. I still love the place but #kevinrathersitonthebridgethaneatthatfood
author: Kevin L.

description: Meh, I wasn't impressed but I do feel bad giving it 2 stars because I love Japanese gardens... I just wasn't amazed by this one. I feel like when I usually go into Japanese gardens, the moment I step in I always feel some type of way. I was let down here. Before going, my cousin who resides in SF told us that we'd be in and out real quick and she actually didn't even come in with us because she didn't want to waste the money as it wasn't worth it since she's been. To be honest, we really could've been in and out quickly because there wasn't anything special to see. However we did take longer than expected just because of the one tall bridge that everyone wanted to take pictures with had a line, except no one else waited in a line except for my group and two other people. Others kept going up and down the bridge without any courtesy to those on the bridge trying to take individual pictures. The people who were in line in front of me and the ones on the bridge were so annoyed as people kept coming up into the pictures. I know it's a tourist place and everyone's roaming around, but there are designated spots where a staff member needs to be around to control and direct traffic. It literally took forever to get one perfect picture and even then it was rushed and not so perfect because we felt bad taking too long knowing there was an actual line as we waited in. Not to even mention the wailing little girl that was on there and her parents who supposedly couldn't get her down. I wouldn't even know how to describe the situation but let's just say it took up a long 10 mins of our time waiting until the dad finally took action and carried the girl down as he should've done from the start. Then him and his wife started arguing about how the little girl kept bawling and it was totally a scene. I know this isn't the Japanese garden's fault but if there was a staff member there, that person could've helped move the situation along! As mentioned, nothing impressing at this specific Japanese garden. I've been to a handful that has blown me away so this was disappointing. I would've rather gone to other destinations instead.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I couldn't forget about my trip to Japan a few months before, and this Tea Garden really brought the memory back to me. As if the ornate gateway wasn't a telltale sign enough, the beauty that lies within - especially the entrance scene of the tea hut in the midst of a peaceful pond - was simply remarkable. Even with so much green shrubbery around, the garden emits a peaceful sense of Zen and a stroll through this garden was so pleasant! The arrangement of plants was definitely well-planned and everything was well-maintained. All in full-scale, the Shinto gate, the pagoda, and the bronze Buddha definitely reminded me of the beauty I have witnessed in Japan.

The garden is relatively small that can be strolled through within an hour. The tea room is extremely expensive so expect to eat only a light snack if you do decide to go. Free admission during early opening between 9-10 AM on Monday Wednesday Friday!
author: Jay Y.

description: For $9.... the garden is pretty small and you can probably go through the whole thing in a short amount of time. It was very beautiful and breathtaking buuuuuut not worth the money.
author: Tracy D.

description: On our first day in San Francisco, we visited the Japanese Tea Garden before 10am in order to get in for free. It was a beautiful place to spend the morning. Upon entering, we went to the tea house and ordered two iced green teas and a matcha cheesecake. The atmosphere was very relaxing and calm and if I lived nearby I would love to come here in the mornings for tea by myself. This was one of my favorite places in San Francisco and I hope to come back next time I'm in town.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Hidden gem in San Francisco. The botanical gardens, surrounding museums, and FREE street parking make this place even better. 

The center of the park reminded me of Paris. We didn't have enough time to explore all the museums and the gardens, but it will be a full day of activities during our next trip.
author: Malisa R.

description: The garden is absolutely gorgeous; One of the best I've seen. Great spot for photography and to kill a couple hours easily just taking in the beauty of it all. However I had to take my review from 5 down to 4 stars and that is solely due to the rude employees working here. Employees in the gift shops weren't too great, but the ones working in the tea house were very rude. No one passed a smile, a simple question resulted in an eye roll from the young lady working the register and taking orders. We had a great time walking in the garden for a couple of hours, so the tea house despite being a great experience in regards to the tea and finger foods and the environment....was off putting due to the couple of rude young women working there. If you don't enjoy that line of work, perhaps you should work elsewhere. Some employees don't realize that they are also a part of a person's experience and memories. Don't give paying customers something negative to remember about you. Just an FYI, they are not pet friendly, not even for small dogs in carriers/strollers. Visit was on 6/25/18.
author: Sheena K.

description: Loved this place! Oldest Japanese tea garden ever. I went with my two daughters. The tea, cookies and sandwiches were amazing. The view was beautiful. A must see!
author: Luisa S.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is a MUST in San Francisco. Not only is it tranquil but there are a lot of hidden areas to explore (brides, Koi ponds, statues and templates). The owners try to keep it as close to an actual tea garden that you would find in Japan. It takes at least forty-five minutes to walk around the whole garden and I would also suggest trying some Japanese snacks and tea before you leave. Also, right outside the garden is the California Academy of Science and the music concourse. Note that you do have to pay to enter and the snacks are pricier than normal but for a complete experience it is well worth it.
author: Priya S.

description: Wonderful free tea tours daily. We did the 11am tour, lasted an hour. So fascinating and informational! Beautiful grounds. Tasty tea.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Beautiful place. We visited on a Monday during the Spring - a perfect time, since the cherry blossom trees were in full bloom. 

Prior to arriving, I was afraid there would be nowhere to park or we'd have to pay an outrageous amount for parking, but I was surprised to find out that you can just park on the street for free. The Japanese Tea Garden is located in Golden state Park, and is a nice, long walk from where we parked. 

Admission is $8.00 per adult, children is $4 and on Mondays and Wednesdays it's free before 10:00 am. Unfortunately, we got there late and ended up paying for admission. But it was worth it. 

The grounds are beautiful, with the traditional manicured landscaping, koi ponds, bridges, Japanese structures and cherry blossom trees. There's a cute tea shop in the middle, which served traditional Japanese food like udon soup, mochi, edamame, Japanese snacks, etc. We ordered the tea sandwiches, which were so good! About  $9 for a plate of about 8 pieces. We also had the sencha tea, and other misc goodies.

I took off one star simply for the amount of people that were in the garden at that time. It was hard to enjoy the place without some tourist running around with their cameras out getting in the way of the views. But honestly, I don't blame them...it is pretty in there. I would love to come back when it is less crowded.
author: Anna D.

description:
I'm not sure how crowded this garden is on a regular basis, but when my boyfriend and I came it was packed.  We had to wait in a line that was nearly 20 people long to get in, and once we got in were just surrounded by more people.  This was in the afternoon on a beautiful summer weekend though, so I suppose that's expected.

Don't get me wrong, the garden is beautiful.  Once you do find a spot that's not full of tourists, it's very peaceful.  Lots of great spots for pictures!

We paid around $14 for being non-residents, and once you've walked through it once I don't think I would pay to return.  A fun place to come at least once as a tourist or resident, but not worth paying to visit on multiple occasions. 

I think my favorite thing to see was the bridge, but there were a lot of beautiful things in the garden.  In comparison to the Japanese Garden in San Diego that I'm used to, this one was much bigger!  So much more to see, and so much farther to walk.  This one is better for those reasons, but the one in San Diego is much more peaceful because it's less populated.
author: Kenna H.

description:
Japan will always be my favorite country to visit, so I appreciate any opportunity that I get to visit a Japanese Tea Garden, especially if it is local. The garden has free admission Monday, Wednesday and Friday if you arrive by 10 AM. If not, I believe it costs $6 per person.

I was very surprised at how authentic the garden felt. It truly felt like we were in Japan! The garden is relatively small, but there are so many wonderful photo spots to choose from that you would spend about an hour there. They serve green tea, but the cafe was incredibly packed and had a long line outside. Sadly, I never got to try the sampling of their tea. The garden was very clean and well kept. It was also the first time I had the chance to see cherry blossoms in San Francisco, so that was pretty cool.

I'd highly recommend visiting the Japanese Tea Garden if you are a purveyor of Japanese culture like I am. Its authentic, affordable, and easy to find!
author: Steve N.

description: I usually come here every time I come to San Francisco.  It's one of the bigger Japanese gardens in the US.  It's free before 10:00 AM on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays.  Otherwise, you have to pay $9 admission for adults.  It's less if you're a resident, child, or a senior citizen.  The garden is very pretty and well maintained.  There's a teahouse inside that serves pretty good Japanese tea and sweets.  I wouldn't get the food since it's overpriced.  The highlights inside are the moon bridge, pagodas, large koi pond, zen garden, and waterfalls.  The moon bridge is the most popular attraction so go there first to take pictures.  You have to climb to get to the top so I would skip this if you're elderly.
author: Julie Ying X.

description:
In the midst of the Golden Gate Park lies a beautiful quaint Japanese garden. The ticket price was okay ($9 per person ). The reason I needed to visit this place is because there is this really awesome  arched bridge that's amazing to do photo shoots on! Then you got a couple of areas you can go into. But the garden is quite small and for the price , I don't think it is worth the ticket price because it is such a small area to walk around. It is probably because it is in SF, hence the reason why the admission is so high and it definitely has a high volume of tourists here.

If you really want to see the arch bridge and get some pictures on it then it is worth it but if you don't really care, I'd suggest save your money and go somewhere like the botanical gardens of conservatory of flowers which has more photo opportunities. If you do come here, stop by for some tea and snacks and enjoy the garden even if it is a tad bit crowded!
author: Jason H.

description: We came during a weekday afternoon and we're surprised to see so many people there. Entrance is $8 for adults and free for sf residents. The garden is much smaller than the Japanese garden in San Jose and was so crowded there were lines forming near the bridge just to take pictures. The garden is supposed to evoke a sense of serenity but there were so many people there that it was somewhat chaotic.  We quickly walked around to look at the koi ponds, Japanese sculptures and architecture, and then went to stand in line to order food at the tea house. Out of everything we ordered: sencha, green tea cheesecake, tea sandwiches, and dorayaki, I think only the green tea cheesecake was worth ordering. All the food and snacks are pretty much pre-prepared and brought out to you immediately after you order. I think we spent a total of 30min there including ordering food and eating at the tea house.  Overall, I wasn't very impressed and prob wouldn't come back again. If you must come then prob come early in the morning to avoid the large crowds and lines.
author: Helen J.

description:
This is easily one of my favorite things to do with my daughter. We both get to enjoy beautiful scenery, and the stroll through the gardens is not strenuous enough to solicit any complaints from her. The only problem is trying to get her to leave when it's time to go.

The gardens here are stunning and serene enough to make my day. I've never even tried the food or tea. Never even really thought of trying it until I read Jeremy the CEO's review in my sidebar just now. 

The gift shop has all kinds of cute knick-knacks and gifts for under $10. I get sucked in every time.  

Admission is $10 total for my daughter and me. Parking is generally tricky, so, good luck with that. 

Once, my daughter and I accidentally cut off a group of people while going over the arched drum bridge in the garden. I didn't fully realize it until I heard this guy snap and say, "First of all, you can see your underwear." 

I leaned down to my daughter and whispered, "Baby, are these pants see-through?"
She sighed and said, "Looks like you're wearing your cheetah underwear." 

And that's how you make friends in San Francisco. 

Anywho, this place is incredible. It's complete with a giant zen garden, several mini pagodas, stepping-stone pathways interlaced with koi ponds, and fascinating bush carvings. There are also all kinds of Japanese plants, of course.

The gardens can be pretty thoroughly explored within one to two hours.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Recommendation: Worth going once to spend an hour on the free tour, get tea at the tea house, and then explore a little bit more. 

The Japanese Tea Garden is a beautiful little green space, even in the winter! The multicolored koi living in the various ponds were perhaps my favorite part. However, I must insist on utilizing the free 1 hour long City Tours guided walking tour around the garden, as there is so much underlying history behind the tea garden that really adds value to the various sights, sounds, and structures. Jay (and Norton the dog) were our guides and were extremely knowledgeble and enthusiastic about sharing information about the garden's history. I don't want to spoil it, but almost every part of the garden has completely unexpected significance or history. 

With regard to the entry fee, I would say it is worth going once, but not multiple times. Being able to go into the tea house and grab a 4-dollar cup of tea on top of the entry price is definitely on the expensive side and not really worth it, but considering it goes to the maintenance of the garden I'm happy sending my money along once.
author: John B.

description:
A beautiful oasis.  Free some days/hours, and discounts for SF residents.  A perfect place for a stony saunter, take cool photos, and zen out. 
Precicley & tenderly manicured and offers a new perspective for every season.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Very cute garden and tea spot for a relaxing afternoon, however it's definitely overpriced so keep that in mind. Glad we checked it out but I wouldn't pay to go again. So many other free spots nearby. 
Food was okay. Tea was really good but again overpriced. A good spot to take visitors if you've never been.
author: Mallory S.

description: The garden is beautiful. Peaceful and zen. However, the size is very small. I walked around the entire garden within 15 minutes. $9 adult entry for outside residents of SF. I parked in a small lot for $10. Such a short experience. There's a small cafe and gift shop, but other than that you're not really missing out.
author: Eureka P.

description: It's been 10 years since we last visited this wonderful tea garden. This is not a botanical garden or a city park garden, its a tea garden that is not that big but well maintained. Many of the art, sculptures and plants have a meaning. It's a place to relax and reflect not about trying to get your money's worth for another "attraction".  I do recommend they prohibit use of selfie sticks. It's only a matter of time before someone falls in the water trying to take a selfie. We did stop at the cafe and ordered $9 Udon. Tasted like it came out of a bag. The green tea cheesecake was good. It's a tourist eatery so buyer beware. If you want good Japanese food visit Japan town. If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of the Museum and CA Academy of Sciences visit here. The price is reasonable when you consider the grounds.
author: Gerald H.

description:
This place was extremely serene. I felt like I could just lay in the grass and spend days in this oasis. The garden is well kept and full of interesting landmarks to photograph and enjoy.  

The price for regular admissions is $8 per person. It is discounted for locals if you have proof of residency. It is free Monday, Wednesday, Friday at 10am.  We spent an hour here and honestly, I would've stayed longer if we didn't have anywhere else to go. Parking is available on the street. 

In comparison to the Japanese tea garden, this place is a little larger and has its own tea shop.  The tea is a little on the pricey side. We ordered sencha tea and kuzumochi (very pricey). I'd rank the kuzumochi flavors as strawberry being my favorite, then green tea, and mango being the least. It comes in 2 pieces per flavor (total of 6 pieces).  

There is a bathroom and gift store located inside the tea garden. 

The only thing I wished this garden had was the ability to feed the koi fishes like the one in San Jose. Other than that, I definitely look forward to coming here again.
author: Jessica Q.

description: Save your money. Water is mucky and it was impossible to see any fish. The entire garden takes 10 minutes. Not worth $9
author: Charlotte G.

description:
Before I was a Bay Area resident, I had vacationed in San Francisco and have fond memories of visiting the Japanese Tea Gardens in Golden Gate Park. It was one of my favorite and most photographed spots. Fast forward several years and it's still a joy to visit and I always make it a point to bring visitors here. While the beautiful staples of the scenery (such as the koi pond, pagodas, and arched bridge) are a constant, the landscape and lighting will vary based on the season. Come in spring for an array of flowers in bloom, while in the fall you'll be treated to the colorful foliage.

It's a calming happy place for me. Sure you can stroll through the place in 30 minutes or less, but take some time to meander the foot paths over the pond, gaze at the small waterfall and find a quiet bench to sit and just be for a little while. All this and it's only $8, less if you're an SF resident. One of my favorite spots in the city.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I was there more than 15 years ago when I first visited San Francisco (I would have never imagined at that point that I would be moving here someday :-) Life's funny). I remember it was a cold cold day of August, and we wandered around in the garden but not long enough as our schedule was tight. 

My husband and I came back here this Thanksgiving day. First good surprise: it was free to come in and visit :-) The sunny weather made the garden look even prettier than in my memories. It's really a lovely and quiet place (well, there's quite a lot people visiting and taking pictures but the atmosphere is so peaceful that no one makes too much noise :-)). 

We took a walk in the garden, around the pond, the pagoda, we had a look at the gift shop (very cute things but a bit expensive in my opinion) and we ended up at the tea house. We ordered sencha tea, matcha cheesecake and some cakes and fortune cookies (apparently, those were created just there :-)). The sencha tea (that is available in the shop) was very good, so were the cookies. I was a bit less convinced by the matcha cheesecake that was very rich. The place was very nice, especially with the good weather as we seated outside and enjoyed the tea peacefully. 

This place is definitely worth a visit!
author: Caroline P.

description: Japanese Tea Garden - Golden Gate Park - 5 Stars: loved Golden Gate Park and this is one of the little jewels nestled in the vast park...located very near the de Young Museum. It is a classic Japanese tea garden and just a peaceful delight to walk through on any given day. Very old trees with huge big-butt trunks, this garden has been here for decades. They also have a special bridge that is very steep on each end...great place for pictures while you linger. Worth the trip and the slight extra expense, see it when you are here.
author: Rick B.

description: Great natural scenery and just felt like such a pleasant Sunday! The snacks and food were also filling (I was really hungry though). I enjoyed the tuna sandwich, the udon was acceptable, the mochi was good!
author: Hoang T.

description:
I haven't been here for many years. Finally came back since my family wanted to take my cousin from Switzerland here. I was surprise there was a line even though there was only 1 hour left until closing time. I guess since its a holiday (new year day) and a lot of people have a day off. 

Anyways, I totally forgot how small this garden is, but it is a great place to spend time with family and take nice pictures of the place and with family or yourself. You should try climbing over the bridge step...thats always one of the attractions at this garden. They have a small little shop if you want to buy souvenir. Since this place includes a tea area, it is a must go too...they have few teas, snacks, soup to try while enjoying the scenery and accompany and with friends. 

If you're a SF residents, you pay $6. For non-SF resident, you pay $8. Only $2 difference.

They have hours differences for winter and summer. For Winter time, from November to February, its 9 am to 4:45 pm. For summer time, from March to October, its 9 am to 6 pm.
author: Julie N.

description: Very touristy spot. Tickets are $8 for non-residents and $6 for SF residents. It's a pretty big place to walk around and explore. Take about 20-30 minutes to see everything. The little café they have next to the gift shop was super cute. A bit over-priced but the goodies were tasty. I definitely would go back for their iced matcha green tea! Would highly recommend for those who want to check it out!
author: Tuyen H.

description: Definitely this is very nice and beautiful garden but looks like the $8 ticket was a little bit expensive for me.  Just 10 min was enough for walking around whole garden but small tea restaurant in the middle was a good place to stop by to enjoy a meal or tea and have a break. The best fun thing was to hear the bell ringing when you enter the gate on the right hand side. It will mean you 'Pay Here' for ticket.  :)
author: Chris H.

description:
THE PERSON WORKING AT THE TICKET BOOTH IS TERRIBLE.

We were on a family outing for mother's day and having a good time. We were paying for our tickets here and the ticket booth lady yelled at us to stay back. She could've just asked us to stay back in a polite way. 

We noticed that she yells at children too. She pissed off another family as we were leaving. There was a shouting match.

The garden itself is nice.
author: Sophia I.

description: First time coming here. I love it. The tea is wonderful with the scenery made it a perfect day with my date I met in the EGL community. Will be going again again.
author: Ikaros A.

description: Beautiful serene place with Koi ponds and bridges and a zen garden.  This would be a great place to spend a few hours and relax.
author: Tom T.

description:
I was really disappointed in this place. Yes, it was pretty but we paid $9 a person and it took maybe 10 min to see the whole place. We didn't eat or drink anything there besides a 7up so I can't speak to that. If we were going to sit and have some tea though it would not have been relaxing due to the amount of people that were there. I had 3 people try to cut me in line while trying to order the soda. 

I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Taylor R.

description:
Amazing! The Japanese Tea Garden is a must do while visiting. I used to think that it wasn't considered a vacation unless I was relaxing on the beach. This place proved me wrong. It is so peaceful and I felt as I was able to breathe better when we were here. 

My husband and I brought our recently turned 4 year old here and were a little worried that she would get bored. Impossible. The garden is so interactive. My  husband who isn't easily impressed was all over the place, climbing bridges and trying to find other little gems. 

*Parenting tip* Leave the stroller behind. There are several narrow pathways.
author: Melissa M.

description:
The garden was beautiful with its traditional red buildings, koi fish ponds, abundance of lush plants, and fit the expectations of what a royal Japanese family's backyard look like. It was quite tranquil walking through the pathways and admiring the layout and cohesiveness of the garden.

However, it was a bit small. I was able to finish visiting every corner within 20 minutes. As a result, I didn't think it was worth the entry fee. The Huntington Garden in Los Angeles was much more comprehensive and boasted larger grounds with more attractions.

Overall, the garden was okay but I wouldn't make a visit more than once.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I came here late June, 2015.

This garden is a very beautiful place to visit on a nice, sunny day. The visual appeal of this garden is definitely one of a kind. There are koi fish, excellently trimmed trees and well structured paths and architecture. This place is a definitely worth a visit for anyone who wants to go for a quick walk. The only thing I have to say that I did not enjoy about this place is that it can be easy to get lost while looking at all the plants and scenery.
author: Kevin R.

description:
Pros:
-Very relaxing
-Several good photo shot ops
-Inside is also a gift shop and tea cafe

Cons:
-Beware of lots of spiderwebs
-Unsure if worth $8 entry fee
author: Laura D.

description: Gardens were to stunning and well kept up. A little crowded on Mother's Day weekend but not too bad. Also remember to take time and read the signs with descriptions about what your looking at it makes it more interesting when you know the history.
author: Hayley q.

description: All around lovely and relaxing. I would recommend arriving early to beat the rush. The plants are so beautifully and delicately manicured. The different structures offer interesting historical facts. After a stroll through the garden, I treated myself to a green tea cheesecake and hot hojicha tea.
author: K S.

description:
It was a beautiful experience. I'm not giving this 5 stars because it had too little to offer for the high entrance FEE. 
I've seen better and bigger Japanese gardens that are completely free not only in the U.S but elsewhere in the world.

It has a very cozy and nice cafe inside, which I truly love. I like the seating, how it faces the garden or the park. 

Green tea ice tea was truly well made. 
Miso soup was quite alright. 
Bite size sandwiches were amazing, tuna, cucumber and ham were the varieties. 
Rice cakes weren't the best. 
All in all, good selection and good tasting items. Quite romantic to eat there too, especially when it's warm to sit outside.

In short, I highly recommend their cafe inside. Garden itself is unfortunately not so special.
author: Bella J.

description: It was great tea time with great view in the patio, we got iced green tea and mochi. The iced green tea was sweetens and mochi was not the same taste or texture..? as we normally had. I would get the mochi ice if we come back here lol
author: Ji P.

description:
Another tourist spot on SF's must do list would be the Japanese Tea Garden. The only other Japanese Tea Garden I've been was in Oregon last year so I was excited about seeing how SF's one would be like. 

There's an entrance fee of $8 or $6 for residents with valid ID. I saw that if you enter before 10am on Monday, Wednesday, and Fridays it's free admission. So I would suggest you take advantage of that. It's located inside the Golden Gate Park. There's a lot of free street parking around but we decided to just park in the structure so we didn't have to park far.

It's known as the oldest public Japanese garden in the US. Once you step in you feel a sense of zen and calmness while walking through the whole garden. Although there's a lot of tourists there, I had an amazing experience taking it all in enjoying the views and sculptures. 

My favorite part was the mini bridge that you could go up carefully and view the garden from above and I also enjoyed the peaceful waterfall setting that surrounded the gift shop. We were on a time limit so we couldn't stop in for a cup of tea. Perfect place to take picture of the landscape views. Of course, we took every picture opportunity throughout the whole place. It was awesome. They really maintain this place quite beautifully. 

If you get a chance, you should also visit the Japanese Tea Garden in Portland, Oregon. You'll be amazed.
author: Roxanne Lynn T.

description: I love this place!! It is so relaxing and beautiful. I gave 4 stars only because you really spend max 2 hours there and it's expensive admission to get in for something that last 2 hours. Have tea after your tour!
author: Elle P.

description:
Really nice and unique experience to have in SF. It was not that close to Fishermen's Wharf where we stayed so got Uber, about half an hour ride. 

We didn't know it is a part of Golden Gate Park where there are many other attractions to visit so beware and plan ahead :) Botanical garden, museum, etc.

Back to Japanese Garden, $8 admission fee. Not much line and it is like 30-40 minutes long visit area with photo shooting and staff. Lake with huuuuge and colorful fishes is relaxing. Not much to see but what you can shoot quality photos, rich environment. 

My favorite session was tea time :) mini tarts were so fresh and yummy. Jasmine green tea! Loved it. They also serve some light food like sushi and sandwich. You pay at the register and they bring your order to table.

Bathrooms are next to ticket booth. Gift shop next to cafe.
author: Ceren A.

description:
A little bit of heaven.

Living here, I can pick just the perfect time to come here, when it's not heaving with folks.

Nature is so restorative.

Come here, breathe in the tranquility that lives here. Very woo-woo, I know, native born Californian. But it works.

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: Cute, quaint, nicely kept. This was my final stop before heading to airport. Depends on how long you anticipate being here, you can easily stroll through within 15 minutes.
author: Michelle V.

description: Went here for a day trip with a good friend. It had been YEARS since the last time I was here and so much of it was exactly how I remembered. It brought back memories of a grade school field trip long ago. The gardens are fantastic. Truly a lovely way to spend a beautiful day in SF!
author: Shannon W.

description:
At $6.00 for locals and $8.00 for visitors is well worth the visit. The Tea Garden has decent restrooms, a gift shop and a teahouse also serving soups and sandwiches.
.
Near the entrance one might see and hear the laughter of children on the a climbing bridge. The entire space is beautifully groomed and has wonderful little maze like paths that wind through and around many shallow ponds with colorful Koi.  These paths extend through a little redwood grove beside a Zen Garden then up and over small maple and bamboo populated hill with miniature cascading waterfalls. 
.
A few attractive Japanese structures adorn the top of the hill and a larger than life bronze Buddha bestows blessing upon passers bye.  A few scattered benches under the shade of trees provide resting stops.
.
Enjoy...
author: Caesar A.

description:
At first, I was surprised it cost 8$ for a little garden.

I quickly realized why; the garden is simply STUNNING. It's also larger than I originally thought too. There are no shortage of beautiful features to take pictures of.

The gift shop is great, a plethora of cool, not-so-touristy, Japanese trinkets. I bought a stoneware mug, and I'm really happy with it.

The cafe is also a cute respite for the weary.

Check this place out if you're in San Fran, or near/in Golden Gate Park!
author: Milo G.

description: That tea garden is smaller then I expected but worth every penny. I went on a Friday around 2pm so there wasn't a lot of people.  The garden is beautiful and the details are even more impeccable. I ordered the sencha tea which I recommend. The staff is friendly but sometimes hard to understand. But overall, I was pleased.
author: Lense E.

description: This is a very small garden! If you come before 10AM it is free admission on Wednesday. Unfortunately due to traffic we didn't make the cut and had to pay $8 per person! A little pricey for such a small garden area, but it should go towards good use. The garden is a great place to take LOTS of selfies and pictures, it is well maintained. There is a small snack area inside the garden that served tea and such. There are a couple ponds that have koi fishes. Like I said it is a small garden took us about 15 minutes to walk through it and take pictures. Nothing that is mind blowing there !
author: Cindy W.

description:
Finally got to go here! I've been wanting to check this place out for years! The Japanese tea house is a really cute nice spot to walk around. Perfect spot for photography and a place to enjoy some tea :) almost made me feel like I was in Japan, haha!

we tried the jasmine tea and the sencha, both were really good. My favorite one though has to be the green tea cheesecake. I'm not a cheesecake fan, but this has to be my favorite of all cheesecakes I've tried. We also got the variety mochi, I wasn't really impressed but it wasn't bad either. 

*$8 admission 
*free admission if you go early 
*beautiful Landscape
*cute date spot
author: Keycee D.

description:
What a lovely gateway spot! My love surprised me by taking me here and it was quiet and not a lot of people. Maybe cause it was still early in the morning. 

I went to the one in San Jose and I've always wanted to go to this one even though this was is smaller I enjoyed it. We ate breakfast here and it was perfect. Again, not a lot of people which I was happy about, haha. 

We had miso soup, edamame & iced matcha green tea (I loved it!). I didn't expect it for the ice tea to taste like it tasted, it was refreshing! I loved it. Then we got the green tea ice cream which of course was yummy!! :) 

What a very cute place!!
author: Trina R.

description:
This place is so peaceful. The design of the garden is beautiful, the only thing is that I almost wish it was bigger! There is this high arched bridge along the way that you're allowed to essentially climb up to, it's kind of scary, but really cool! (So don't wear heels or something of that sorts hahah). This place is a good escape from the noise of the outside world. 

PARKING: street (around GG Park) 

PRICE: 
-Adult: $6 (SF residents), $8 (non-residents) 
-Seniors (65+)/Youth (12-17): $3 (residents), $6 (non) 
-Children (5-11): $2 (both) 
-Children (under 4): Free 

*FREE on MWF before 10am.
author: Vivian S.

description:
I was a little disappointed with my visit here. I've been to a couple of Japanese Gardens in the Bay Area, and I was excited to visit this one! But it seemed a bit small to me. It is beautiful, don't get me wrong, but I had higher expectations...I guess because there was an entrance fee. And the other Japanese Gardens I've visited are just as beautiful, if not bigger - for free.

From what I remember, you can avoid paying a fee if you come between 9am and 10am. So just a tip! Maybe I'll come back because I apparently missed the advertisements for getting my fortune and the yummy food they have near the entrance.
author: Melanie B.

description: Stop and have the tea and sweets. This place reminds you to slow down and savor nature and the simple but complex ritual of tea.
author: Kristy M.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden itself is immaculately kept and very nice. I don't know if this is why they charge $8 to enter (as of 7/2016). It seems pricey for what it is, yet I confess I do not know what it costs to maintain that kind of garden in a place like the Golden Gate. 

Were you to attend the garden during a less heavily trafficked time, it would probably be very calm and peaceful and pretty. I suspect especially in the summer, when I was there, you will also see its burgeoning wildlife: the tourist. You will not miss them taking 5000 selfies with little bridges and gates like they were the lost city of Atlantis. (Hell i'm a tourist, and could not resist taking one either, so color me double-standard.)

This by itself is not a diss on the JTG. It's just what you're going to see, along with the small tea restaurant and the assorted traditional Japanese tea garden stuff. 

Really I give the JTG 3.5 stars, but that is still not an option on the Yelps. 

Gokigenyou, Japanese Tea Garden. Perhaps we shall meet again. In winter.
author: Edison C.

description:
I came here over the summer and really enjoyed the visit. It really is quite beautiful and seems to elude tranquility. It features all kinds of classic Japanese style designs and architecture - plenty to see and take pictures of!

If you come on MWF and enter before 10am, you get in for free. Unfortunately, that also typically means more people, so pick which is more important to you. When I visited, we arrived just before 10am and didn't have to wait to get in, but it was pretty crowded inside. 

Also, the tea house is a bit pricey, but the matcha and desserts are amazing and worth a try if you've never had them before. Definitely a great place for a casual stroll and very picturesque.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I really enjoyed my visit to the Japanese Tea Garden in June 2017.  The admissions fee is reasonable; however, there is not too much to see.  You can see the entire grounds in about 15 minutes.  The atmosphere is beautiful.  I would definitely go back.
author: Sonia R.

description: So beautiful! Free admission before 10am on MWF.  If you're like me and like to pack multiple touristy things in one day, this is the thing to do.  You can spend a lot of time here as well as make it a quick trip if you like.  We enjoyed our visit here, especially with the bridge, the ponds, and the temples.  The entire place made us feel like we were in a different country.
author: Loretta C.

description:
This place is $9 admission for NON-SF residents. 

Really enjoyed the space. It was great to explore this small tea garden. They had an amazing buddha statue, the funky bridge and a beautiful pond with HUGE koi fish.

I was lucky to have visited on a sunny day. It can be quite crowded if you go during peak hours.
author: Jenn H.

description: Beautiful garden! I've been visiting this place since I was a kid and I've always loved it! I visited with my sister and grandmother during one of their free mornings. We enjoyed tea, miso, Michu and cookies before our tour. We had an awesome time! Great service.
author: Jennifer C.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is always a favorite spot of mine to visit when I'm in Golden Gate Park. The garden is well-maintained and beautiful. Admission is free if you make it here before 10am on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. Otherwise, it's $7 for non-residents and $5 for residents.
author: Steph F.

description:
This is a pid garden even for residents of San Francisco. You can get a discount if you live in SF so bring ID or any proof of residence. I loved the novelty of this garden - everything was so cute and thought through. The little bridge, the mini tree decorations, the coi fish and more. It's really amazing the type of things you find in Golden Gate park. The only downside is that this place gets super crowded so we had to wait to take photos on the bridge and under some of the houses. 

They have a tea place so it was nice to have a hot cup of tea on a chilly afternoon in SF in such a cozy little garden. I would recommend coming here if you're touring SF, it's definitely a very unique experience.
author: Dasha K.

description: Beautiful but rather small so $9 seems rather steep. Even more so because they were cleaning the big pond so it was empty. Worth seeing if you're in the area but recommd the botanical garden more.
author: Paul H.

description: Love the garden and the jasmine tea is delicious. If its hot out enjoy the Mochi at the café, strawberry was excellent!
author: Peter H.

description: Beautiful garden! This is something different from what we're use to living in the city that never sleeps! This garden makes it feel like you're in japan! Admission is free if you go early in the morning so that'll be the best time to go but even if it was $8, it'll still be worth it. It's a great experience and you have to try that little cafe in the beginning for authentic japanese snacks.
author: Dennis K.

description:
After dning at one of my favorite spots, we decided to stroll through Golden Gate Park and somehow ended up inside the Japanese Tea Garden.  Apparently there's an entrance fee but I guess that's' the beauty of wandering; you get lost and eventually find something unexpected.  

Just like Japanese culture, the Garden is very clean, serene, calming, and peaceful.  It was very pleasant walking through the park and enjoying the scenery.  The bridge, although a short one but don't let the size fool you, was fun to walk over.  We found a nice little area with a bench where the branches hovered over us like a dome of leaves.  It was nice and quiet perfect for good conversation.  It was the perfect set up for a scene in a Korean drama.

Whether you're here solo, with a friend, on a date, or with family, this place is enjoyable for all.   

Love, peace, and chicken grease.
author: Linda N.

description: Beautiful place to visit if you're in the SF area, but it's pretty small and you can get through the entire garden in a hour. They have a small tea shop, but I didn't get to try it due to how crowded it was. Admissions is only $8, and if you're lucky u can find good street parking if not, there is a parking garage which charges an hourly rate (can't remember how much or if it varies depending on the day). I only give it 3 stars because I heard a lot of excitement about "The Famous Japanese Tea Garden" but for how small it is, I don't really see what the hype is about.
author: Laila A.

description:
The entrance fee is $8 - they take cash & card.
I recommend going early (like we did) because by the time it was about 3-4pm, the line was cray long!

As soon as you walk in - there is a place to drink tea & snack ($8 Green Tea Cheesecake?!?!?)
