There is the bridge that not everyone goes over but I SURE DID! :)

There is always a ton of people taking pictures everywhere so you're bound to photobomb someone by accident or on purpose. Who knows?

The Buddha is right by the restaurant - just FYI.
They also have coy fishes swimming in the ponds - probably about 10.
The landscaping is freakin' GORGEOUS! There is a massive Pagoda that I think is so pretty!
There is a Zen Garden & so much nature - such an amazing place to just sit & think. 

They have random benches here & there - some with views, some without.

All in all, I think this is definitely a place to stop if you happen to be in San Francisco - Golden Gate Park.
author: Camille C.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park is so beautiful! When you enter, you will pay an entry fee. Please note that your ID must say "San Francisco" in the city section to get their discounted rate. If it says another city aside from "San Francisco" then you will pay full admission. It's only a $2.00 difference for adults but it's $2.00! Make sure to bring ID if you live in San Francisco. 

We casually walked around the garden and it took us about an hour or so. It gave us an opportunity to see everything and take many pictures. Some of my favorite pictures were with the flowers, the two bridges, Buddha and the benches underneath the trees. Inside the garden is a gift shop and a restaurant. The restaurant serves tea, mochi and green tea cheesecake. This is a relaxing garden to escape to with many photo opportunities. Bring a light jacket because it was a little chilly.
author: Minky C.

description: While the garden was nice, it certainly didn't warrant a $9 entrance fee.  Worth $3 at best.  Biggest swindle in the city and in my opinion, save your money and do something else.
author: David N.

description: Don't waste your money here. It is full of green bushes and hardly anything unique. They charge 9 dollar per person.
author: Sunny H.

description:
Adorable!
Cost about 8$ a person for non-residents and can get a little crowded but a very fun stop to check out while you are wandering the park. I would highly suggest sitting down and having some tea and desserts. We got the dessert sampler and it was fun to eat.
I would not bring kids here, I could see them getting bored pretty quickly, take them to the fun museum next door instead
author: Alli D.

description: Absolutely beautiful, although much too small for the high entrance fee. But we like to support culture so we didn't mind. We didn't eat there at the garden, but there's a really cute hot dog stand outside that sells vegan hot dogs that I really recommend. I probably wouldn't come back on a full-price day, but it would be a great place to write or paint or something like that.
author: M G.

description: I had an amazing experience here today. I had desserts wit green tea and I loved it. The weather was nice, the trees were blooming. Plus, coming here on a weekday in an off-touristy season is primarily the key to enjoying Japanese Tea Garden.
author: Maryna C.

description: Such a cute, serene location unlike anywhere else in San Francisco. The entrance fee is $8 per person, but if you get there before 10 on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays the entrance fee is waived (according to the website). The giftshop sells the same things as a couple of the shops in Chinatown, however is way overpriced. A $35 cast iron tea kettle in Chinatown sells for $90 here. Aside from the giftshop, the overall landscape is beautiful. It's not just boardwalks to walk on, it's stepping stones, bridges, all these nick nacks to make it fun for everyone. You may not spend more than an hour here, but it is well worth a visit.
author: Sabryna L.

description:
Do not go here if you're just looking for a fun inexpensive activity! 

Beautiful garden. But it was $8, overpriced in my opinion for such a small park area. I had seen the entire garden within a span of 20 minutes. There is one area where you can order food and tea but it's overpriced.
author: Shauna-Li W.

description: Beautiful garden! I didn't really walk around much so my review is mainly the cafe there. We were really hungry and decided to eat there. Everything is prepackaged. I tried to order a vegetarian tea sandwich, but they couldn't accommodate it since it was already prepackaged. The tea sandwich plate has 4 different kind of tea sandwiches- one of the 4 is vegetarian. Unfortunately they do not have anything to order that's vegetarian except the assorted Japanese crackers. I ordered that & then my friends let me have one of their vegetarian tea sandwich. The vegetarian one is SO yummy though! It's apples and cheddar cheese- so delicious. They definitely should offer vegetarian options for people to eat. I was very disappointed I only could order Japanese crackers.
author: Kim P.

description:
Beautiful beyond measure. I loved everything about this tea garden. The lush landscape really allowed me to gaze into some of the most beautiful exotic flowers, trees and plants. Cherry blossoms are my absolute favorite and being able to walk around the green wooded forest areas also added such a value to my experience. I was able to take pictures that made it seem that I had traveled abroad because the quality of this garden is well above average. 

I actually had a chance to also have tea and pastries in the garden and the experience felt so authentic. Although it was packed with tourists, we all seemed to gather together and bask in the beauty of our day.
author: Nova H.

description:
A really lovely place if you're willing to pay $8 a person ($6 if you're a San Franciscan) for 30 minutes of walking around. Also, tea is a bit pricey at $3.50 for a regular tea (Jasmine is pretty good) and $8.50 for matcha green tea and mochi. 

Nice place, but expensive for what you get.
author: Chelsea N.

description: We got in around 10.30am on a weekend and it was a bit crowded already but the visit was worth it since it was so refreshing to see the beautiful landscape.
author: Joan T.

description: We can't change history when it's inconvenient to the narrative. Japanese Americans didn't just relocate to other places during World War II. Their possessions weren't simply entrusted to others. This insinuation is an embarrassment and is absolutely terrible for those who were forced into internment camps.  What FDR did was terrible. We can't write it history out of history because it's inconvenient to the narrative.
author: c p.

description:
This is, hands down, one of my favorite places in the world. Beyond being a part of the always wonderful Golden Gate Park, it's relaxing, educational, delicious, intriguing, and fun! The pathways, the histories, the tea and rice crackers, the architecture, and the gift shop... there isn't a single aspect of this place that I don't love. It's a slice of heaven.

Be sure to check out the variety of green teas they offer - each one is a unique delight for any tea-lover!
author: Christian S.

description:
What a great place to visit. The Tea Garden is beautifully landscaped and overall such a delight. $8 and you can enjoy some time at this beautiful Garden.
If you're looking for thrills this isn't the place for you.

I thoroughly enjoyed coming here because it was nice and quiet, and a great place to reflect if you give yourself that opportunity. After strolling past the Zen Garden take in a breath of fresh air. The air smelled delightful in this part of the Garden.

The Tea Garden also houses the Tea House where you can grab some Tea and delicious Kuzumochi  (see review for Tea House). There is also a small gift shop. 

We left this place and I was not ready to go. It was a very relaxing time, and a great little getaway from the boisterous city.
author: Nasha W.

description: Although well maintained and well manor we staff we were disappointed  in the size of the garden and its overall lay out.
author: Quentin R.

description: Woohoo, 1001th review! This garden is very authentic. Although there is a price to get in, it is nice if you want somewhere to relax, completely surrounded by nature. It is quite packed due to the small size of the park and it does not take long to walk through it. There are fish in the pond, and various structures. Beautiful little spot to relax!
author: Amelia J.

description:
Some people say that this place is small and not worth $8 but I think that if you take your time to enjoy the view and REALLY take your time... Then I think it's worth $8. I spent two hours just being in there observing everything. This place is definitely a great way to unwind and just relax for a bit. 

They have a small gift shop and it is the cutest thing! They have pretty cute and unique stuff. I spent a good 30 minutes in there just to explore the gift shop. I'm not sure whether they accept cards but just to be on the safe side, bring extra cash with you. 

They also have this resting area where you get to sit. If you're feeling hungry, they have food there! I would recommend jasmine tea(very floral and semi sweet). 
A good place for tourists to come and take pictures. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend anyone to come here and enjoy the view.
author: Tilia L.

description: Outdoor near the Tea Garden water. I personally loved it and didn't mind it. It was super nice. Good quick food. Sure it's not michelin star or anything, but for a place like this - it works!
author: Michael L.

description: This is a great place to visit if your in SF. Considering the busy city that is a couple blocks away I was surprised the garden was nestled in this part of town. Fee is around $8 and they have a tea and snack area. Be prepared to take a lot of pictures and wait for some folks to finish taking theres. It can take an average of 30-60 mins to get through the whole garden during busy weekend time. We enjoyed the ponds, temples, garden, stone work and bridge. If your in the park this is definitely a must see exhibit.
author: Khoi N.

description:
The one star review is for the gift shop in the garden (read below), the garden itself is five stars. 

BEWARE of the gift shop next to the cafe in the garden. I started to enter the shop after a lovely snack at the cafe- I was barely half way through the door when I heard something fall from the glass shelf which was literally within an inch to the right side of the entry door- and it turned out that a little clay painted Japanese doll (about 2 inches tall) had fallen from the glass shelf , and had fallen backwards between the shelf and the glass walls of the shop. It was stuck between the shelf and the glass wall and hadn't fallen all the way down to the floor. 

The store lady immediately came to check and and put her hand behind the shelf and pulled it out and took it away. I felt guilty because it fell while I was entering the store, so it was possible that something I did might have caused it to fall (although as I said, I was barely one foot in the door- but whatever it was, at the time of the fall, I was the one closest to the fallen doll) and I went after the store lady to ask her if the piece was OK. She said she will have to ask the store manager, and went into a room behind the check-out counter. 

I didn't want to leave the store while she was gone as I didn't want it to appear that I was running away after damaging their stuff, so I waited for a few minutes and then the store manager came out and said that he wouldn't be able to see the piece and that I had to buy it. I didn't argue, because I had no proof that I was not responsible for the doll falling off the shelf, plus I didn't want to create any drama, as I fully understand that if you break something in the store then you have to pay for it- so I paid the $15 for the doll (thank goodness it wasn't too expensive!). 

While the lady was packing it up in a bag, I told her to please not put these show pieces right next to the entry way in the future as it could potentially cause such issues again. She just ignored me and said 'Next'. I quietly walked out of the store thinking to myself that I would go home and write a yelp review about the store. But I didn't as I got lazy to write the review and I said to myself "Forget it".  

However, a few weeks later (i.e. today), I opened the brown paper bag in which the doll was wrapped in, and I was shocked to see the state the doll was in- there are paint smudges on the doll, dirt marks, and several areas on the doll that has some white spots (like the paint has chipped off). I was surprised that the fall from the shelf and getting stuck between the shelf and the wall could cause all these damages to the doll. So, I kept the doll on my kitchen island and made it fall all the way to the ground several times, and believe me, nothing happened to the doll, it didn't break, no chipped paint, no nothing!! 

I am now furious and am writing this yelp review. I feel cheated. I didn't check the state of the doll before buying it when I was there because a lot of customers were just standing and looking at the manager telling me that I had to buy the doll since I dropped it, and I felt at the time that if I asked to see the damage then it would imply that I didn't want to pay up for a mistake I made, and I was feeling embarrassed anyway. But now, I realize that this was a bad piece to begin with and the store manager jipped me by saying that he couldn't sell the piece because of me. 

I am really angry. It's not about the $15. It's about feeling cheated. And I blame myself for not being more assertive at that time. Lesson learned. I just wanted to warn you all as well.
author: Tripthi K.

description: Terrific place. Not too big, not too small. Perfect place for a delightful stroll. Lots of beauty and history. Great cozy snack shack with lots of items to eat. The udon was quite tasty. Terrific staff. Delightful gift shop with all sorts of Japanese goodies. Surprised that all the staff is Japanese. They're very organized in there. Fun to see some artists on a date sitting outside gift shop sketching. Very reasonably priced for adults and kids.
author: Amy M.

description: It costs $6 to get in, which I didn't know and was a little annoyed about because I was really only going to see the gardens and there is no student discount. That being said, I came this far for the green tea cheesecake and a few extra bucks wasn't going to stop me. The grounds were really pretty, although quite small. Walking through means going over some rocks and such so while that didn't bother me I overheard some older people complaining about the walking. The best part definitely was the cafe. I had some miso soup $4 and the green tea cheesecake $6. It was really relaxing and I enjoyed this serene landscape in the middle of the park, very cool addition.
author: Marisa L.

description: So calming here. Take plenty of pics and enjoy a stroll around everyone even outside this exhibit. I didn't get a chance to eat the goodies but I'll be back again.
author: Linda N.

description: If you're in Golden Gate Park make sure to stop in the Japanese Tea Garden to explore.  It is worth the entry fee to see this beautiful scenery and walk around on a nice day.  The gardens are small, but very peaceful and relaxing to experience.  There is a discount for SF residents (and students too I believe), a nice tourist attraction that is totally a great experience.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
I was really disappointed by this Japanese tea Garden. Maybe that's because I recently visited the Japanese garden in Portland and it was much larger and there was much more to see. 

This Japanese tea Garden in Golden gate Park is really tiny. Though the admission price is fairly cheap, i'm not sure the size of this garden even warrants that price. 

When you enter the gate you pay at the little kiosk. There are different prices for San Francisco residents versus non-residents. Note there is no reduced student fee. 

Once you're in you find there are really only two directions to go. If you walk quickly and don't stop to take any pictures you can probably be done in 15 minutes. 

There isn't much to see, the highlights are two small Japanese towers. A pond with fish in it. And a very tall vertical bridge. 

We probably spent the most time at the teahouse that's inside the garden. They serve a few varieties of tea as well as mini sandwiches, cake, and ice cream. 

This is a place I will not be returning to. If you really like Japanese gardens then maybe it's worth a visit, but definitely not more than one.
author: Kathy L.

description:
I really love the Japanese tea gardens, it's a great place on a nice sunny day for relaxation and time to reflect. The grounds are so well kept and so beautiful. I love the Zen rock garden, the bamboo, the Japanese maple trees and all of the beautiful pagodas and statues of Buddha.

It can get really busy here so it's nice to get in early before the crowd really gets large.

The tea house is great. It's open air seating overlooking the water. It's absolutely necessary to stop by here get some tea and some mochi. It would be sacrilegious to come here and not do that. unless of course you're allergic to mochi but really I've never heard of anyone who's allergic to mochi, so just do it!

The many different restful scenes are always calming. Pick a nice day and go chill at the garden.
author: Ben M.

description:
Their tea house is a great place to experience sipping Japanese tea with Japanese delights while looking at breathtaking zen gardens. I was full of spirits and at peace while sitting down and listening to the nature around me. All the great Japanese inspired trees and plants gave out this cool breeze and harmonious feel to my mind. 

I definitely think everyone should experience this. People should get away and just relax in the tea garden while drinking hot made tea. I want to try their tea sandwiches and their authentic matcha drink. 

I recommend people to arrive early so people can get the feel of nature and a better dining experience at the front bar-tables that face the front of the Tea Garden entrance. These are the exclusive VIP seats lol!
author: Allister D.

description:
I was so excited to visit this place when I visited SF. May have hyped it up too much for myself. I was hoping to see cherry-blossoms, but of course there were no flowers at all. I should've looked up the blooming season which is only March through April. 

- located inside Golden Gate Park
- street parking 
- $8 admission fee for non-residents 
- small garden which only took 20 minutes to walk around
- nice koi ponds & zen atmosphere 
- Japanese tea house in the center & a cute little gift shop behind it 

I love Matcha Green Tea, but $8.50 for a cup? I'll pass.
author: Annie W.

description: I'm such a fan of Japanese tea gardens! This garden is so beautiful. I wish it didn't get so busy at times. After hiking around sf I tend to stop here and enjoy the views. On big note parking is crazy here so good luck. They do have a parking garage below but it can be pricy. Once you figure that situation out nothing is more relaxing then the garden. Take a nice stroll around and enjoy the beautiful tea garden. I swear I have been here so many times and still find something new each trip. If you come early you will be able to take amazing pics with nobody on the way. So if you plan on visiting golden gate park. I recommend hitting this place first then going to the amazing Museum next door.
author: Tony B.

description: My favorite parts of our visit was the lunch area and the gift shop. Everything was gorgeous walking around but I just wasnt into it. The gift shop, I wanted to buy everything though.
author: Brianna J.

description: Very dirty water in the coy ponds. Almost all of the pathways are paved and packed with people. The atmosphere is loud and not relaxing at all. The zen towers are decrepit and decaying due to lack of maintenance. The majority of the plants are from the local area not Japan and only one of the waterfalls was working. The area for tea is very small and cramped leaving very little room to relax. This is more of a playground for children than a garden for zen. Save your money and go to the local parks for free.
author: MidTnight T.

description: This is a beautiful garden, but very very tiny! It took me only 15 minutes to tour every corner. Because it is so small, it tends to be very crowded. So think about the $$ for parking and park admission before you visit. I liked what I saw, but felt I had an appetizer but paid for a 3-course dinner.
author: Ether L.

description: Absolutely beautiful. Hate San Francisco; it is a tourist trap for sure but this place is a real gem. I cannot see how tripadvisor rates this great place behind Fishermans Wharf. The garden is fair priced and a beautiful place for everyone.
author: Rick T.

description: Great time to spend with friends. Very pretty, well maintain, manicured gardens (even though i do not distinguish a bonsai from another similar green thing). It was a pretty walk ending at that cute tea house (too full with visitors when I went, so ordering was pretty slow). SF residents that can prove it pay less (nice perk). Very relaxing, although I would not pay again to go, as is located in the huge Golden Gate park and I have seen several Japanese gardens before. Nice for first timers.
author: Carmen V.

description: The garden itself isn't really that big but it is definitely a very relaxing walk if you never been to a Japanese garden before. I highly recommend going on the weekdays or early morning because it does get crowded in the afternoon which could ruin the atmosphere and mood.
author: Lawrence C.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden lies in the eastern portion of Golden Gate Park near the de Young Museum. It is a small, well manicured Japanese garden with a nice open air tearoom in the middle. There is a nice path through several parts with a lots of ponds, waterfalls, traditional structures, and a Zen garden. It is a rather unique experience for visitors with little exposure to Asian-style gardens and is pretty exotic.

Unfortunately, the place seems a bit overpriced for both the admission and tea. It is showing its age, and the tea - while great - is much cheaper in other places. You are paying for the experience, so this is a nice rare treat rather than a regular destination. They do offer lower admission for residents and even free admission before 10 on certain weekdays, so this makes it much better. It does get rather crowded which can dampen the overall meditative experience desired in most Japanese gardens, but overall it is a nice place.
author: Kristian D.

description: I really enjoyed the Japanese tea garden. The atmosphere is very great. I felt a lot more calm and relaxed walking there. The reason I'm giving this place 3 stars is because finding parking is not easy, and once you find parking you find yourself having to pay $8 to get in. So even though the tea garden itself is really awesome, the price is not so awesome. Once inside the garden I suggest getting a good spot at the tea shop, ordering some tea and sitting down, relaxing and enjoying the beautiful scenery. Its a really nice spot for a date or even a family outing.
author: Amir H.

description:
Absolutely beautiful. 

Bit of a distance from any entrance since it is within the center area, but it is definitely worth the walk. $8 per adult if you're a non resident, which I don't mind if it's used to preserve the park's beauty. It is a fairly small park, but if you take your time and actually enjoy the essence of this park and read every stand, you'll easily be here for over an hour. 

Great place to take pictures, start a drawing, or a place to take your loved ones. 

The cafe within is also a bit small. I ordered iced green tea and some sweet rice cakes. Rice cakes are obviously on the sweet side, but very flavorful. Iced green tea was decent. 

The gift shop is expensive, but they do have some very cute stuff that would make it hard for anyone not to buy something. They have a wide assortment of chop sticks, Japanese decor, tea arrangements, and a handful of San Francisco based souvenirs. Just as a tip, don't buy your San Francisco souvenirs here, they are definitely overpriced. Buy them around the Fisherman's Wharf area!

Overall, an absolutely stunning place.
author: Stephanie V.

description: Highly recommend stopping by if you're in Golden State Park! $8 entry fee for adult tickets, and it's definitely worth it. The Japanese Tea Garden is an incredibly serene escape from the surrounding city. The space is well maintained and is filled with beautiful plants, walk ways, stone work, and pagodas. The garden also has a tea cafe for you stop and eat if you need some sustenance, and is right next to a cute gift shop where you can buy Japanese trinkets and tea accessories.
author: Kathy M.

description: One of the many attractions in Golden Gate park. I would say this is worth the $8 entrance fee. It's a great change of scenery from what's going on all around Golden gate park. The tea garden offers a lot of things to do from sites to see, various types of gardens, great spots of photos, a koi fish pond, gift shop, and even place to have a light snack that focuses on the flavors of tea. A cool place to check out.
author: Vincent T.

description:
Maybe I'm not the type of person that likes to pay to see nature. Don't get me wrong - this was a lovely and serene place to walk around and see some beautiful flowers and koi. I guess having been able to visit Japan and Hawaii where seeing beautiful natural scenes were free, I was expecting a bit more than this.  

It is quite a small area so my friends and I were there for about an hour which included us getting a drink at the tea shop located inside the garden. It was a sunny and warm day so it was nice to walk around and we were able to get some really nice pictures.
author: Betty L.

description:
I loved the Japanese Tea Gardens the most out of all the other fantastic gardens to visit inside Golden Gate Park. Other reviewers mention crowds of tourists (of which I am one), but the Tuesday afternoon when my husband and I came it was relatively empty, quiet, and tranquil. Since we aren't from San Francisco, there's an $8 entrance fee which I gladly paid, and after spending about an hour in the park I would gladly pay it again. I love Japanese gardening, and this place has it all- water features, Koi ponds, carefully pruned trees and plants that just imbue peace everywhere.

There's also some beautiful pagodas and statues around the park, and a stroll around the perfectly manicured lawns will make you wish your landscapers could replicate something similar at home. There's a large drum bridge that is fun to climb and take a photo on top, but otherwise impratical as a means of crossing water. 

There's a small tea cafe and souviner shop in the park, so if you really can't wait and have to have some sustanance, grab a pot of tea and some cakes to munch while you people watch and enjoy the beauty around you. 

The history of the garden is so long and rich, so take the time to read the different plaques located throughout to educate yourself on the long and (at times) sad history of the family who has cared for and made the gardens the fantastic park they are today.
author: Melinda R.

description: This is the place to come to nature, to slow down, to see beauty, and to stop and be still.  There is a place to eat, a place to sit, and to use the restroom, all vital things a visitor needs while going through the Golden Gate Park.  I highly recommend checking this out and well worth admission fee of $9 (as of Oct 2017).
author: Mee-Jin Y.

description: Really cute place in Golden Gate Park.  Decided to come here instead of going to Cal Academy and it was a nice place to peruse.  We walked around, took pictures of the beautiful sanctuary, and felt at peace with nature...haha well...to rephrase, there were a lot of other people there so it wasn't a true peaceful sanctuary, but I like the concept of the garden and it's pretty cheap to get in.  Not sure if I would go back but it was a nice thing to see with great company. :)
author: Monica J.

description: I don't know what the hype is all about. It was very crowded and maybe I'm blind but I don't see any colorful flowers. Space is not that big, too many people I could smell body odor which I find revolting and I am supposed to be in a garden. Rest assured we are not coming back.
author: James B.

description:
Tourist spot.

Easy to finish in about 15-20 minutes through the garden and gives you a sense of Japan a bit. Tickets are $6 so not too bad, also cheaper because we are San Francisco residents. The little cafe in the middle is cute but everything was super overpriced and doesn't even taste amazing :/ definitely a trap for tourists. It is pretty and wonderful for photo ops but not somewhere a resident would go haah. They also have a little gift shop with overpriced items haha.
author: Amanda C.

description: Being of Japanese descent, I love visiting anything Nippon in America.  Of course, Frisco offers more Japanese themes than most North American cities.  In the middle of Golden Gate Park is this hidden gem.  Like most of the specialty areas in the park, you will have to pay to get in here.  It is beautiful and nicely laid out.  Many photo opportunities can be found.  Parking is difficult as with any other area in the park.
author: Darrell K.

description: Beautiful Japanese Garden located inside Golden Gate Park.  Only $8 admission for non residents but so worth the money.  Plenty of beautiful green shrubbery, Japanese structures, picturesque views, waterfalls, a gift shop and cafe where you can grab a cup of your favorite tea blend while taking in the amazing garden view.
author: Christy A.

description: We love this place.  Looks tiny, is huge.  Must go!  Try the tea and the udon! See if you can climb the curved bridge. Wow
author: Josh K.

description: Definitely a must see, its small but its beautiful. 8 bucks to get in so make sure to take lots of pictures to make it worth your while. I was able to climb the bridge, which was nice.
author: Monica S.

description: This place is so beautiful! Although it is a small garden, everything is so nice and well-maintained. There's a little shop inside and they sell desserts, tea, and food like noodles. Tables are very limited but the scenary is lovely. I went on a cloudly day and it was slightly sprinkling but it still looked nice!
author: Michelle K.

description:
As you visit the Japanese Tea Garden, you'll enjoy gorgeous landscapes and scenery complete with kaleidoscopic floral arrangements, waterfalls and koi ponds.  You will also see a rich display of Japanese culture by prominent structures such as the pagoda, a drum bridge and a tea house.

What you probably won't be able to see, however, is its rich history of the past - a past that many would rather forget.

Built in 1894 by Japanese immigrant Makoto Hagiwara using his own personal fortunes, it is the oldest public and formal Japanese Garden in the United States.

Hagiwara was responsible for the funding, building and upkeep of the garden until his death in 1925.  His children and grandchildren continued to maintain his legacy until 1942, when the Hagiwara family, along with about 120,000 Japanese Americans, were forced to leave their homes and were imprisoned in internment camps.

During WWII the word "Japanese" was removed and the garden was renamed Oriental Tea Garden.  The garden went into disrepair.  Many plants and floral arrangements withered due to a lack of care.  Many sculptures, structures, and valuable artifacts were destroyed or stolen.

After the war has ended, the Hagiwara family was not allowed to return to their home in the tea garden.  Although the name Japanese Tea Garden was reinstated in 1952, it no longer resembled the original garden created by Mr. Hagiwara, which has been, for the most part, erased.

The Lantern of Peace that you'll see when you visit the garden was placed there in 1953 in an attempt by the city's officials to ease the tension with Japanese Americans.  In 1965, a large collection of dwarf trees, stones and lanterns originally belonging to the Hagiwara family were returned to the garden, which now represent the last remnants of the past.

Most of the structures that you'll see, such as the Mount Fuji landscapes, the pagoda, the Zen Garden, among others were actually additions made from 1960's through 1980's.  The original gates, which are rich in history and culture, were restored in the 1980's.

It was not until 1974 before the Hagiwara family was finally honored, with the city of San Francisco placing a bronze plaque at the Main Gate.

To access the Japanese Tea Garden by car, from eastbound John F. Kennedy Drive turn right into Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive.
author: Rob L.

description: Nice place to roam around and have a relaxing cup of tea. Downside is that you see a lot and lot of people around. It would have been so much nicer if it was a quieter place. I liked the tea and rice cakes there.
author: Aayush S.

description: Super beautiful and relaxing. We went on a weekday which was probably best since we were able to take our time and have some quiet. Tea spot was adorable, little pricey for what we got but it was the experience for us.
author: Jenny D.

description:
Very small place and doesn't deserve  $8 entry fee. Nothing special about it. 
The problem at that location is the parking, so after the hassle of finding a spot you would figure out that it is not worth it. Unless you have something else to do in the area like visiting California academy of science or the botanica garden.
author: Louie B.

description:
This was my first time to Golden Gate park and such it was my first time to visit the Japanese Tea Garden.  

Parking is crazy but it is available if you can find it along many of the major routes through the park like MLK or JFK for free.  Since Golden Gate park is so large there will most likely be walking involved.  There is a parking garage if I recall nearby but you have to pay for it.

If you get to the Tea Garden between 9am and 10am the admission I believe is free for Mon, Wed or Friday.  If you arrive after that it's 8 dollars for adults, 6 for seniors or teens and 2 dollars for kids.  Under 4 are free.

This garden is very well maintained and very aesthetically pleasing.  There are all sorts of manicured trees, rock gardens, ponds and structures to make some great picture taking.  There is also a gift shop and cafe inside the grounds where they do serve tea and other fare.

Some of the paths are not traversable if you are disabled so be aware which way you are going.  Some stairs, a steep half circle bridge and rock bridges are there as optional paths.  

It is a wonderful place to see green and beauty.
author: Lambert P.

description: $9 is WAY over-priced for this tiny place. It can be a little more interactive and perhaps taken care of, as bushes were overgrown and buildings were not particularly gorgeous. Save your money and go across to the street to the Botanical Gardens instead
author: Kylie K.

description: This place stinks, you can't compare it to the real thing. It's small, poorly kept and is full of weird design choices. Don't bother coming here, it is a trap. Go to Japan instead!!
author: Nathan B.

description:
"The delicate and subtle pagoda style house was at the heart of the park, with an almost temple look and feel. Enjoying traditional meals and listening to the flowing water seemed like a serine idea for our morning. "
"We learned that Hojicha Tea was roasted in a porcelain pot over charcoal, not steamed. Also that it was made from Bancha which is a late summer tea harvest with the leaves turning from green to brown. The brew had earthy, nutty and slightly smokey flavor to it."

Just a few bites from our full review..
author: IS Palette S.

description: Beautiful garden and a fruitful gift shop. There were so many cute items to browse through.
author: Lisa D.

description:
A must-see if you're visiting SF. Adult admission I believe was $8/ticket, but very worth it in my opinion. The garden is absolutely stunning, housing a wide array of Japanese flora and Asian architecture, which was also aesthetically pleasing and meticulously placed throughout the garden. Though I've never been, it truly felt like I was chilling in a Japanese suburbia removed from all the noise/hustle bustle of the city.

There's an outdoor cafe inside the garden which serves Japanese teas and snacks. The iced green tea was refreshing!!

Great place to go with the family, or friends, or a significant other. Loved it so much!
author: Jane N.

description:
Now THIS is a beautiful sight to see in one of the most beautiful cities. It has such a calm to it, and such a beauty/history to it, that it made me want to stay longer than I should have because of my tight schedule. I have always wanted to visit Japan, and this was probably the closest I am going to get in the near future to that. Their tea was very authentic and the gift shop had some great things to buy if you are an avid tea drinker. 

Will definitely recommend visiting this site again.
author: Melvin M.

description: One of the oldest Japanese tea gardens in the United States.  Instagram worthy, tranquil & beautiful for the eyes & Soul.  This garden promotes & encourages meditation so get your Zen on!  It's must see when in the area ;)
author: Mary S.

description:
I enjoyed my time at the Japanese Tea Garden.  They have clearly worked hard to maintain a zen like atmosphere and have done a great job of upkeeping the grounds.  Maybe it's because I like wildlife, but my favorite part was the HUGE fish they have swimming around in their ponds.  I also enjoyed their quirky circular bridge that takes minimal yet some athleticism to walk over.  See pictures to know what I am talking about.  It is something like a museum as well with plenty of places to stop and learn a bit about Japanese culture and history.  

The only complaint I would have about this place is that it is overpriced.  Yes, it is San Francisco I get that but 8 dollars to walk around in a garden (that isn't all that big) seems a bit much. I got to see all of Yosemite for 8 dollars a person (30 dollars for a car that fit 4 then round for you math people).  Their tea was also very overpriced.  Take a little walk from the tea garden to chinatown and get even better tea for more than half the price.  

Overall, I would recommend paying a visit here on your trip to San Francisco (especially I'd you live in state it is cheaper for you)
author: Michael P.

description: Well, I understand the tellers situation however I dropped my kids off on a Friday morning during the free time slot - went to park and arrived just as they started charging. I do think that it would have been kind of them to let me in with my kids- however, there were no smiles, no ideas to help... just pay up and why would you let your kids in without you! I chose to not even go in I was so frustrated. Not happy! As a local I would love to promote the places my city has to offer but this has just left a very bad taste in my mouth. I have older kids with my younger ones 16, 13, 11, 8 so they were fine. Just so inhospitable especially considering  how many people they let in and are in the park for free each day!
author: elana w.

description:
Tranquil Japanese themed garden located in the Golden Gate Park.
Admission is a non-refundable $7 for non-SF residence.
No military or student discount.

Meticulously kept bonsai trees and quiet koi ponds are the center of natural attractions.
There are several man made bridges, stone paths and benches to enjoy throughout the garden.
Nice place to spent a romantic hour and take photos of the not-so ordinary scenery.

Tea Service Review:
Small traditional tea shop offers a few types of hot tea for $3.50 a cup
(Including Green, Jasmine, Hoji and Matcha) 
Menu also offers miso soup, edamame, mocha and other Japanese dishes for a moderate price.

The Matcha was a disappointment as I was expecting the very dark and bitter Japanese version.
It tasted like Jamba Juice matcha powder mixed with hot water.
Came with a small an-mochi (sweet red azuki bean filling)
author: Celina Q.

description:
Music for the Japanese Tea Garden: (Optional)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OUZN0z0d1Ps

****************************************************
With every walk and breath we take
We remember
With every mistake and accomplishment that we absorb
We remember
With every heart we touch and hurt
We remember
But what we remember the most is that uncanny connection
A connection that we will always remember from friends or love-ones
A connection of  rhythm, drop, and beat
Take a walk with me into the Japanese Tea Garden
And lets remember...
-EB (June 2015) 
****************************************************

To be honest, i'm not sure if free verse poetry is allowed in reviews, but this will be my first.  

Japanese Tea Garden is something to remember when visiting SF. If you want to leisurely browse around or photograph, this is the place.  When i was in the city a couple years ago, i remember how the Japanese Tea Garden was the prime spot for wedding photography and school field trips.  

There are no words to describe how beautiful this place is. 

Overall, from A-Z i give this place a 5/5
Oh on a personal note, every-time i pass by that Buddha statue time just slows down and my BPM just drops...And then i always recall this memorable quote:

"Do not dwell in the past, do not dream of the future, concentrate the mind on the present moment." -Buddha"(lol my poem says remember, but i meant in a healthy way)
author: Erwin B.

description:
So much beauty in such a small space.

I was never expecting to visit the Japanese Tea Garden. We just stumbled upon it one day while exploring Golden Gate Park. 

It was $7 to get in, which can be steep if you're a large family. In fact, if you have small children they may not appreciate the garden. And with all the other things to do nearby, this may be something to wait for until the little ones are a bit older.

The gardens are of course meticulously cared for. Everything neat and tidy, just as one would expect. They don't meter out people that enter the garden so it can get super packed and a little uncomfortable by mid-afternoon on weekends.

Come early. Bring the camera. Leave the little kids.
author: McKenzie S.

description:
This tea garden can be summed up using three worlds - scenic, small, and touristy.  I enjoyed wandering through the garden and admiring the exquisite architecture of its tea houses, bridges, and pagodas.  There was also an adorable koi pond in the middle of the garden.  However, the garden was overcrowded and noisy with the chitter chatter of fellow tourists, so there was no ideal tranquil environment of a typical tea garden to enjoy.  Also, the $8 entrance fee was a bit pricey considering the small acreage of the tea garden.  

It was a good experience to walk through the tea garden, but its a destination that only needs to be visited once.  I definitely recommend coming here on MonWedFri before 10am for free admission if your schedule allows!
author: Vy N.

description:
A beautiful, well-cultivated Japanese Garden, this is a perfect place to get away from the city and relax. It is still full of other tourists, but set up with so many paths that it doesn't feel crowded. 

Before or after exploring the garden, you can visit the Tea House to enjoy small Japanese delectables, including but not limited to Mochi, Japanese Green Tea Cheesecake, Dorayaki, and Taiyaki.

You have to pay $7 to get in if you are from out of town, but it is well worth it for the photo ops. I personally liked taking pictures hugging those huge spherical and square bushes.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
I love this spot, and love even more the free admission before 10am.  It's a great place to start your day in the park, and were particularly fond of grabbing a snack and tea before taking the little to the Academy of Sciences. 

If you're here early, though, it gets BUSY.  We could barely walk the gardens because it was so packed, I assume because of the aforementioned free early admission.  It really detracts from the experience.  The condition of the garden is impressive given the level of foot traffic it gets.
author: Kali M.

description:
On a beautiful crisp Tuesday mid-morning, I was fortunate to come to the Japanese Tea Garden to experience being in Japan but actually be in San Francisco.

This park is open to the public year around in the Golden Gate Park with free parking around the vicinity. For $5 (SF residences) and $7 for adults you can explore at your own pace and appreciate this landmark beauty. The garden is filled with foliage and architecture from Japan which will give you a sense of peace and tranquility. 

The grounds are manicured with a sense of being in Japan without taking an 8 hour flight. One of the highlights is the beautiful koi fish and the gorgeous red maple leaves. During my walk along the paths, I found many beautiful photo opportunities and a few "sigh" moments.

This garden will only take maximum 45 minutes. Be sure to be amazed by the steep bridge which deserves a photo opt. There is also a tea station which I didn't spend any time in.

By all means, if you're going to stop by the Golden Gate Park, be sure to visit and take in a fresh breath of air while absorbing the beautiful landscape.
author: Santi T.

description: Such a beautiful, unique area, but we visited on a Saturday afternoon so it was fairly crowded. Took away from the serenity of it. I didn't expect to pay admission to just walk around, but we did (not too bad-$22 for all of us) and then matcha tea was $8.50. We skipped it. If you don't drink the tea, it's just kind of a loop around. Gorgeous and unlike anything else we typically see, but it took about 30-40 minutes and then it was over.
author: Emily G.

description:
Update: Bob from Yelp corrected me. Mon, Wed, Fri: FREE admission if entered by 10:00 am
I went on a Thursday, that's why it wasn't free. Thanks for clarifying Bob.
Original review:
It is no longer free before 10AM. The garden could be a nice walk and the cafe offering $3.50 cups of coffee or tea could be a nice time in Golden Gate Park.
author: Jeff H.

description: A nice place to visit but it really does feel like they're milking tourists and locals for their money. There is a gift shop and cafe inside the garden, which would be great if the prices were super jacked up. $8/$6 for a visit is already quite pricy; save your money and buy your gifts elsewhere.
author: Alfonso C.

description:
This place is a complete rip off !!! Stay away from here.Instead, visit the nearby Botanical Garden. They charge some crazy $$ for entry fees to this so called place "Japanese" Tea Garden.However, they don't tell you that this place is actually as small as Japan and perhaps there is nothing Japanese about it. I finished the entire garden in 10 minutes and then took another 2 rounds just to make use of what I paid to enter this garbage area.
!! DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY !! There is nothing Japanese here !! There is not a single tea plant here !! The tea that they were selling here for $$ on top of entry $$ can be easily found in any Ranch 99 !!
author: Ashraya T.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is perhaps my favorite Golden Gate Park destination. It's so peaceful and beautiful and just a nice place to relax with some tea and cookies.

The entrance fee is $7 for non residents, which kinda sucks they charge just to get into the place, but I think it's a pretty cheap price compared to a lot of other attractions in the city. It's definitely worth it if you've never been.

The garden isn't too big, but it's got some koi ponds, a pagoda, some bridges, a zen garden, a gift shop, and of course the tea place. The tea places serves a few different types of tea (all green I believe), cookies, sandwiches, soup, and ice cream. The perfect treats to enjoy the views of the ponds and the trees.

I believe they do special tea ceremonies there as well, look it up!
author: Emily G.

description:
Has anyone else ordered a miso soup, taken a few sips, and then allowed the miso soup's structure to equilibrate back to its loofa structure? Let your miso soup sit and the soup's insides will shrink back to a coral reef-like state. 

The soup looks like the universe is in your bowl. 

Comes with tofu and scallions. Pair it with a jasmine tea, and you're on your way to diplomatic relations with Japan. In the garden is a peace bell paid for by Japanese schoolchildren. That's very sweet of them, considering the U.S.'s involvement in World War II, the Japanese internment camps, etc. The Japanese are a very warm and generous people, so let us enjoy their culture while in Golden Gate Park. 

I came to this garden five years ago with my mom, and it was very nice. This time I was with my friend and we sort of stumbled upon this place.

I noticed one dude with a shape up and clean basketball sneakers. He was modeling with his posse friends. He thought he was the coolest thing since sliced bread. After this yo-cool guy was finished posing in front of the Japanese temple, he said in a condescending manner "to the bridge." In fact, we saw many people modeling with a paid-by-the-hour photographer. This other dude getting his pictures taken was very unattractive but he was convinced that if he contorted his head at a particular upward angle while grabbing his jaw, he would have the perfect pic to put up on his Tinder account. 

Anywho, we walk into the tea garden and are very confused. Do we sit, do we wait to be seated? Walk up to the counter! Order your food and choose a seat. Everything looks good so I go with the aforementioned items (soup and tea). We're debating between multiple seats, and we settle on a view of the lake, but then we notice someone's two amputee legs so let's not sit there. We settle for the tree-supported table, and a French couple sits down to our right. Behind us are a couple on their first date. They sit with an upright posture, and I'm not sure how comfortable they are. There are two 15 year olds catching up on gossip. A few other families visiting from across the country. Rusty came with his Midwestern family. 

The food really warmed up my belly. $20 including tip. Very good food and tea. Quaint environment.
author: Jerry B.

description:
Third time to SF and finally made it to the tea gardens. It's a beautiful place and I think the architects and designers were spot on when they designed a zen-like experience. Beautiful landscaping, lovely ponds and waterfalls with koi fish swimming, and fun temples. I really felt like I was walking through Japan. Anyone can have a true appreciation when they visit this place. You can finish the entire garden and walk through the shop in half an hour in case you are pressed for time. 

I didn't try the tea there but I took a look at the menu and immediately thought it was overpriced. Typical for a touristy place, I know, but still had to comment on it. 

The shop was fun to look through but you can find the same items for less in Chinatown.  

A place well worth visiting, but I wasn't upset that I didn't get to it until my third visit.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
This was a cute place to walk around and take pictures and I'm not going to act like I didn't have a good time there, however the little tea parlor needs to be read for filth....
I can't believe you guys have the audacity and nerve to be charging people more than $2 for prepackaged fortune cookies that are basically worth its value in Trident Layers. 
You guys are dead wrong for that!
Also the fact that there wasn't an innovative or unusual variety of teas there made me feel slighted. If I'm going to a Japanese tea garden it would be nice to at least see a blooming tea on the menu, or even perhaps cutesy things like square sugar cubes...sugar in the raw, simple syrup! Something!! 
If I'm going to buy food I don't need Id at least like a little more incentive. 
At least the scenery and the serene atmosphere was worth the entrance fee. However I do not foresee myself going back anytime soon unless it was free.
author: Ariel T.

description:
I wanted to book the Japanese tea ceremony but they didn't pick up the phone when I called... several times. I did sit near them when they did it for 4 people so I could snoop around and see what it was like. 

I liked: 
- photo ops: bridges, ponds, flowers, Japanese looking things
- the gift shop: GO THERE 
- tea: sit down and enjoy a cup of tea and some mochi (although the mochi were just okay) 
- free admission 9am-10am Mon, Wed, Fri!
author: Elsie W.

description: Beautiful gardens..Excellant to walk around on a lovely autumn day..Tea house is great to enjoy green tea to warm you up.Great for a family outing!
author: Priya K.

description: There is no way that we are coming back in this place. First of all if they are not happy with kids they can politely ask parents or family no kids policy here is this is place. Me and my kids was discriminated when we went inside the gift shop. I was hoping to buy a nice tea pot for me to use. It was my first time here and I got so excited. My son is always hyperactive. That is normal of him. And I will never hurt my son just to keep him quite. So I was trying to calm him down and wanted to cut my shopping short for us to exit the place. But the Lady at the store was very rude to us. Sending us out in the shop. I was in tears already as there a lot of people inside. I respect if they have it in their policy, but I was hoping too that she will respect me and my kid as a human being.
author: Danna P.

description: Definitely a must if you're heading over to Golden Gate Park. This cute little garden has a tiny cafe that serves a variety of authentic teas and finger food. We loved the udon bowl and the green tea cheese cake. Grab a few items off the menu and plan on sharing before you stroll through the beautiful garden.
author: Brooks A.

description:
I'm going to keep reviewing San Francisco until it kills me.  Stupid 150 challenge.  It's all for you, Damien.

As with all Japanese gardens I have ever visited (which is two), there is an entrance fee here.  I don't mind the entrance fee that much, because barring specifically coming here to do a photoshoot of some sort, I can't imagine going here more than once a year...even if I lived in the area.

That, of course, is not a knock against the garden itself.  It's a very nice, peaceful walk with a lot of little pathways by koi ponds and bits of Japanese architecture.  It feels very secluded as well, so it was a welcome respite from the streets outside the park.

A few highlights of our trip here include the precarious climb up and down the warped bridge (there is probably an actual name for that type of bridge...I don't know it obviously), admiring the many ceramic items in the gift shop (they also had a variety of Boo dogs...not sure why), and commenting on how we felt like we were in a miniature gold course, which goes to show how respectful and culturally aware we truly are.

The major downside here is that the entire garden is a little small.  Unless you really sit down and take a few breathers, you'll be in and out of there in about half an hour (and this includes walking along every path provided.

I do recommend it, honestly.  Just don't make this your day.
author: Tim O.

description:
Their garden was beautifully maintained and lots to see.
Very relaxing atmosphere but you also get to feel some history of Japan.
You get to enjoy watching koi fishes and explore the unique bridge. 
I tried their macha at a tea house and it was superb.
Deep taste matches well with Japanese sweets.
Their gift shop has variety of things and you get to enjoy some shopping too. 
It was really nice visiting here and want to come back for sure.
author: Andrey I.

description: Awesome Japanese garden in Golden Gate Park is a must when visiting.  It's absolutely beautiful and amazing.  It's my favorite part of the park.  It's $8 to get in however, on Monday, Wednesday and Friday, if you get there before 10am, it's free.
author: Anthony G.

description: What can I say, this place is beautiful and extremely peaceful. With the location being extremely close to the bay, the temperature is cool and adds to the zen-like environment!
author: Terence W.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is a gorgeous garden in the Golden Gate Park of San Francisco, California.  This garden is the oldest Japanese Garden in the United States.  The garden consists of 5 acres and is filled with lush native Japanese and Chinese plants, koi ponds, a moon bridge, carefully landscaped paths, and beautiful art sculptures.

There is a traditional Japanese tea service in the spring, but if you do not visit during the spring they still serve tea and finger food in the tea house.  Be weary that the food and tea is really expensive here.  We spent $38 on two plates of tea sandwiches and tea for four.  The cucumber and tuna sandwiches were kind of bland and very skimpy.  I would recommend taking Kelleigh M.'s advice and eat at King of Noodles instead.  

This stunning garden is definitely worth stopping by.  Admission is cheap; $7 for tourists and $5 for locals.  There are also student and senior discounts.
author: Michelle M.

description: Stunning garden! So well kept and ever turn you make is another gorgeous view. Our Japanese Garden in Oregon might be bigger but they charge way more and the gardens are not nearly as impressive.
author: Mikhail H.

description:
Since this was my first time exploring the park and the city of San Fran, my boyfriend and I decided to do and see as much as we can while we were there. On our way back from the science museum, we decided to stop in and check this place out. It has pretty paths of lush trees and plant life. It was serene and peaceful. With a couple koi ponds and a pagoda, there wasn't much else to see. The pictures other people have posted on yelp is the extent of what there is to see here. The admission price was $7 for non residents and felt it was inflated for what they had to offer. 

Inside the garden, there's a tea shop that offered different types of tea and snacks. We ordered the matcha green tea. It was well made but over priced for what I could get elsewhere. I feel that this is a great place to have a glimpse of Japanese culture, but didn't offer anything unique. If you're a visitor of San Fran and have limited time there, I would recommend skipping this place and spend your time elsewhere, unless you go between 9am-10am on Monday, Wednesday and Fridays where the admission is free.
author: Jennifer M.

description: It was really cool, but it was pretty pricey in my opinion.
author: Wyatt S.

description: Stopped by just to get some udon and tea sandwiches. Lovely setting overlooking koi ponds.
author: Debbie F.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden within Golden Gate Park is a nice place.

I remember it growing up as being small and rather uneventful, bordering on boring.

As an adult, I can appreciate the aesthetics more now.

It's a nice place to visit and takes anywhere from 15-30 minutes to walk around.

It costs a paid admission to get in, but I'm not sure what that price is.  I heard it's $7, but also know the money goes towards the overall upkeep of Golden Gate Park, so that's not a bad worthy cause to support.

On certain days, between 9am-10am it's FREE however, and I'd recommend waking up early to check it out in conjunction with other activities. It's definitively, worth it to check out for FREE, whether a local or a tourist, or especially if you have a large group where # x $7 = $$$ and you're trying to find fun things to do that won't break the bank or empty your wallet/purse.

It's sort of a "side dish" or "appetizer" to the "main course" or "entree" of other things to do in the world of activities in my opinion.
author: Rick S.

description: I love this place. As a little girl I used to come here with a friend and feed the squirrels unsalted peanuts while the tourists took pictures of us with these wonderful critters walking up and down our arms.
author: Rachele K.

description:
Do I really need another reminder of why I love San Francisco so much? It's been my city home away from home for most of my life, yet up until a couple weeks ago I'd never been to one of Golden Gate Parks greatest attractions. 

The garden is beautifully crafted, from the intricate and authentic Japanese structures to the stone bridges to the clean walkways and carefully trimmed hedges and flowers. Walk around for a little while on a weekday morning and you'll easily feel like you've been transported across the Pacific. There are little plaques explaining the gardens history and importance, as well as the story of the architect behind it. 

One minor criticism is the cost. It's a beautiful garden in a park for everyone, so why does it cost a pretty penny to get in and why is everything in the gift shop so damn expensive? They need to make money to keep the park going, I assume. And for that reason I forgive them.
author: Alex L.

description:
$5 for parking and $7 to get in so I can see a bridge.  Not just any bridge... It's a moon bridge!   I really won't attempt to climb it since I will fall off. I could've tried to slide down. going up looks easy. High places are horrible! The kids are braver than I am! Well they have their parents to hold their hands. Hopefully next time I visit then ill have someone with me to help me down.

If you're a resident of SF then your admission would be $5.  It was my first time to the Japanese Tea Garden.  I loved seeing Japanese gardens in Japan.  It's nice since this one is close to home. There are lots of tourists including me since I'm still being a tourist resident until I see everything I want to see. The garden is gorgeous and its a huge area. You can relax, look in their little shop, or eat in their restaurant. I loved the models of the temple. It's a beautiful garden to see.
author: Chrissie O.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city and it's relatively cheap ($8 for adult).
It's hella cute and a nice place to take pictures, and right inside the Golden Gate Park.

Went on a Friday afternoon so it was pretty crowded inside but nonetheless still had a great time watching other people enjoy the garden and play Pokemon Go.
author: Edward K.

description: I'm pretty sure I came here when I was a young child... I remember the super steep looking bridge.  But I feel like it was painted a different color and there were more plants around it.  Admission was $8 for a non-SF resident adult ticket.  If you showed your ID with your SF address, I think admission would have been $2 off?  This place is so tranquil and serene.  You'll find benches placed in areas with great views.  Fun for all ages - large koi fish swimming in the pond, Japanese stone garden sculptures, traditional plants flourish the entire landscape, there's a small gift shop and tiny restaurant where you can enjoy green tea or food such as edamame or udon all while admiring the lush landscape.  I'm an amateur photographer and managed to get some great shots (with my iPhone, lol).  I didn't get a chance to climb the bridge because I had a lot of stuff with me and I was by myself so until next time!!  I will climb and check out the view from up top instead of from the ground up.
author: Allie P.

description: No visit to San Francisco is complete without visiting this place. It's beautiful and very Zen. Just love it.
author: Rita S.

description: Beautiful! Highly recommend!! This is a fun activity to do before or after the Academy of Sciences as you can walk across from one to the other. You can also rent a quad bike before/after and take it around this beautiful area. I brought my four year old and two year old. Not stroller/wheelchair friendly. I parked our wagon at the front and we explored on foot. This is really fun for calm well-adjusted children. A lot of the paths don't have side rails, there are steep steps, and to cross the streams you need to step from rock to rock. This would be a disaster for clumsy or impulsive children.
author: Melissa O.

description: Enjoyed a wonderful walking tour with City Walking Tours highlighting the Japanese Tea Garden. I learned so much more about the garden and the history around it. This is a great spot to relax. The tea house is fun with yummy deserts and the gift shop some nice craftsman styles. One of my favorite spots in SF.
author: C L.

description:
This is one of my favorite Japanese Tea Gardens in California. I feel so zen whenever I visit, even if I'm surrounded by a bunch of tourists. When you take your first steps into the garden, there is so much to take in... then you realize that you have to pay admission. Of course. I forgot my SF City ID at home so I had to pay $8 instead of $6 boo. I tried to stay longer just to make that money worth my while. If you are local, try to go in the morning on weekdays because it's free.

You can buy snacks or trinkets here (though I'm sure they are overpriced) but I just like walking around for an hour or so. Great for catching up with a friend or trying out your newfound photography skills. There are koi fish, bridges, and lots of pretty flowers. I definitely want to come back in the spring when the cherry blossoms are in bloom. Beautiful place that I would recommend to any tourist or local -- I like this place better than the de Young Museum or the Academy of Sciences.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Awesome way to burn an hour. This is a great place to wander around, grab some tea, and relax. Located right next to the De Young and California Academy there is ample parking, and plenty of other stuff to do.
 
You are able to sit in the center eating area and order food/dessert along with tea. After tea there are a few pretty awesome little bridges and buildings to look at, as well as plentiful amounts of koi swimming around. 

Totally worth a visit if you've got an hour to kill.
author: Chris S.

description:
I wanted to see at least one thing in Golden Gate Park on a recent trip to SF and decided upon the Japanese Tea Garden. Admission was $8 and it was a beautiful stroll on the stone paths and little bridges winding through peaceful gardens and koi ponds. Several interesting sculptures and pagodas to look at along the way. 

I went on a weekday afternoon and it really wasn't crowded at all. Just a few people strolling through. On days like that it would be pleasant to sit on a bench and enjoy the peaceful surroundings but it's a small garden so it wouldn't be nearly as nice on a crowded day. It doesn't take that long to walk through but there is a tea room and gift shop to browse through.  A lovely way to spend an hour!
author: Catherine B.

description:
Great place to take photos and relax.  I don't think $8 entry is too much for non-residents if you consider you are in San Francisco.  The guy working at the booth had terrible customer service skills and it looked like the lady working with him had to take up the slack.  

The food was overpriced, but I had to buy it.  My thought was it would be ridiculous to visit a Tea Garden and not try tea and tea sandwiches.

On a side note - there was a sign which read, "lock your doors" on the road where we parked.  I guess it should have read "hide your valuables" because a car four or five ahead of where we parked, had it's window busted and was burglarized.  Also, I had an aggressive driver almost crash into my because I was observing the speed limit and all of the pedestrians.  I realize neither of these things have anything to do with the Tea Garden, but if you were a tourist like me you should be aware.
author: Isaac B.

description:
I'm from out of town and I was so excited to go to the Japanese Tea Garden! It was so pretty and it was nice to walk around and take lots of pictures.

However, two sections were closed. With this said, the areas that were open made the place seem super small and an hour into it, I felt like I could leave cause I've seen it all. It was really busy and so it was kinda hard walking over the bridges with so many people and being scared someone was gonna fall in the water. 

I would consider going back if the sections are open next time and if they're a lot bigger. If not, I'll pass because I've seen a huge portion of it already. I would recommend going when the sections are open! But it really is a beautiful place.
author: Ruby F.

description: Yes, take your time here.  Don't rush through and take in all of the details that you will miss if you don't take the time to appreciate all the beauty in this attraction.  Having misso soup and tea mid-day here really let us enjoy this special place.  A beautiful step away from the rush of the city.
author: Lisa E.

description: Absolutely beautiful and very well-maintained little garden, but not really worth the $8 admission fee in my opinion. Great place for photo ops, and perfect place to take your date! The garden itself is pretty small, and you'll be able to walk the entire place within 30 minutes. They have a little cafe near the entrance, which is worth a visit since you're already paying to be in the park.
author: Tashnuva E.

description: Came here around 3:30 on a Saturday. It was pretty busy, quite a few people roaming around. The gift shop and Tea house were packed but I managed to get some kuzumochi. The garden was kind of small as well but very pretty and there are coy fish and a life size rock garden (not for guest usage). We were able to leisurely walk the entire grounds in 30 mins. Overall I think it's worth going at least once(but not much more than that), especially if you use the resident discount.
author: Bev S.

description:
When the cherry trees bloom in this garden, I doubt that there is a prettier place in San Francisco. 

The Japanese style tea house overlooks a koi pond. It's a popular and a very busy spot to sit and enjoy tea and snacks. The pagodas, the massive Buddha, and the drum bridge are also major attractions. Because of the layout it is possible to meander about and enjoy the gardens from different vantage points. Despite the hordes of tourist and locals somehow it is still a soothing garden to spend some time wandering in. 

The garden was originally created as a "Japanese Village" exhibit for the 1894 California Midwinter International Exposition. From that one acre site it expanded to its current size of about 5 acres. It is the oldest public Japanese garden in the United States. 

The garden is open seven days a week; it is very busy on the weekends. My only complaint is that local residents pay less to come into the garden. I really think the entry fee should be the same for everyone. 

I thought that the admission, reasonable as it is, might make this a 4 star review. But no, it is at least 5 stars. My mother loved this garden and told me she use to sit in it at play Mahjong when she was a girl. The first time I went here with my family I scampered over the drum bridge. These memories and  the sheer beauty of the garden make it more than a 5 star location.
author: Terry T.

description: It's a lovely place to visit, and if you can time your visit with the SF Walking Tour group tours (donation based with admission to the Garden, admission is free with some tours), it's even better as you'll get more of the history and background of the Garden. It's a bit of a challenge to take pictures of some of the more popular spots without other tourists in it, but you just have to be patient, wait and try again. We completely enjoyed our visit here, and capped off our time here with a bowl of miso soup and edamame to share at the little tea house in the Garden.
author: Maile N.

description: My friend brought us here for a quick stroll and it was quite lovely. A lot of little paths to peruse, great photo ops, and a delicious cafe to order tea. I loved the ladder bridge, the koi, and my iced green tea drink. Worth the ticket price!
author: Hannah R.

description:
Very pretty place. It's better to come here on weekdays when it's not crowded if you're planning to take good pictures.

The thing that I love the most here is their tea house and their shop. They good quality japanese items in the shop though some are quite pricey. But if you're looking for tea pot/cup/sets, chopsticks and other ornaments, this is a great place to visit. 

They have delicious tea & food at the tea house although very little room for sitting so expect a long line & limited seats during weekends & holidays.
author: Julie O.

description: This place is absolutely beautiful! The running water, the koi fishes, the flowers, & buildings are gorgeous. It was so tranquil and relaxing to walk around and explore. Granted the day my husband & I went it was freezing cold. However, it didn't take away from the experience. This is definitely a place I think everyone should at least go to once to experience.
author: Amber P.

description:
Located in Golden Gate Park. There is an ultra reasonable price to get awesome nature picture or Japanese tea temples on the grounds.

Lots of people but plenty of opportunity to make something picture perfect. Family. Love ones. Selfies. Not a shortage to be found here. 

There is still a tea restaurant onsite if you believe you must get tea. A gift shop is also found onsite.

Good for family visits, outdoors. 
Bad not sure what is bad here. 

Plan to spend a good hour or two to explore. Take pictures as you go.
author: Denny T.

description: It's really not that great. This garden is small , and compared to others it is mediocre. Plus the cost to enter isn't worth it. I wouldn't recommend visiting this garden unless you want to be bored. If you're a tourist it's better to skip it.
author: Cali G.

description:
This is the oldest Japanese Garden in the country. It's very scenic, lots of bridges, ponds, and water features to see. Especially the super arched bridge. Expect to wait to take a picture on it. There's an entrance fee, but it's not too expensive. There's a tea shop and a gift shop. I got some matcha from the tea shop, it was pretty good.

The garden itself isn't very large. You could walk every path in less than an hour if you wanted to, so don't plan on making this a whole day affair.
author: Nick C.

description:
Every time I tell someone I have never been here they give me a crazy look. I guess everyone has taken a scroll through the garden but me. The day had come that I would end my tea garden virginity. 

Came in on a Saturday afternoon. Being a holiday weekend it was busy. The entry fee was $7. for non-SF residents. For SF residents entry fee is $5.

The garden is absolutely beautiful. The paths are narrow that whine through the garden. The ponds have koi fish, there is a couple of bridges and all of the trees and plants are well kept. 

It is a nice place to have a mini escape and enjoy the scenery. My favorite area was the water fall. There are some beautiful areas to take photos. 

While in the garden we had to have the whole experience so we sipped some jasmine tea and ate some edamame. You order at the tiny stand, take a number and find a table. It took close to 30 mins for the employee to arrive with our snack. Menu is small, just a few teas and light snacks. 

There are restrooms available. They weren't in a clean condition and were out of supplies so beware. But when you gotta go just about anything will do. 

The garden is a nice place to bring the family, friends or your special someone.
author: Amber S.

description:
Finally made it here!  It's exactly what the name says: a Japanese tea garden.  Cute trees, nicely raked gravel, manicured lawns, and KOI.  I love koi.  Lots of nice colorful koi.  

They give you $2 off a regular $8 adult admission if you're a SF resident, but you must prove it - your driver's license with your old address will not cut it, but they'll allow you to pull up your PG&E bill on your smartphone if you don't mind making everyone else wait.  

Oh, right!  They also serve tea.  Not a huge selection, but it does include genmaicha.  And some snacky food items including miso soup and cookies.  There's also a gift shop which had a rather awesome selection of chop sticks, tea pots, Japanese stationery, etc.  You know the drill.

Careful, they close early, like 4:45 or 6pm
author: Aaron M.

description:
Absolutely BEAUTIFUL. Even on a cloudy, overcast day with terrible lighting for pictures. We must have taken at least half of our SF photos here. (Google Images: "how asians take pictures") According to their website, this is the oldest public Japanese garden in the U.S.

$6 for residents and $8 for non-residents (a tad pricey perhaps but, in my opinion, completely worth it). Free admission between 9-10 AM Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. There's an outdoor teahouse where you can sit and enjoy some tea and snacks, as well as a gift shop with cute knick knacks to drop some dough on. A must see!
author: San W.

description:
Well, I guess if you live in the chaotic downtown of San Francisco, this is a major nice change of pace... 

But... like everyone else mentioned, this is a TINY garden and it's not really worth the admission price at all... 

I mean, you can see the whole place in a few minutes. I think I just slowly kept circling around, had tea and just stayed there for an hour before it closed. It should be free... but if it was, I guess it would be more crowded and not very peaceful. Luckily, when I went, there weren't that many people at all and it was a nice overcast day.

I got some tea and green tea cheese cake... it was pretty good and peaceful.. 

When I got my entrance ticket and also when ordering food, I noticed the staff weren't even Japanese, though... it sounded like they were Filipino. But the gift shop, the workers were Japanese.

I had no idea you could go up that curvy bridge... It seemed too steep and dangerous that I did not try. lol

I parked inside the music concourse underground parking lot for $9.50, which was a couple distance away; probably the worst thing is how it can end up being a major pain to get out of there...Luckily, I parked near the exit so I was able to cut in front than go all the way around, which seems like it would have resulted in having to wait over an hour to get out of that gridlock. 

Just one thing to check off the San Francisco to-do list and say you went there... but definitely not necessary. It's okay if you want some slight change of pace around there.
author: Kiyo M.

description: I feel very relaxed, when I go to this place. If I compare this visit with my 2011 visit, it lacks maintenance . My son loved the colorful fishes.
author: Vishali N.

description:
I feel guilty telling you that I didn't pay for admission to the Japanese Tea Garden. I just cheated the fine city of San Francisco out of 8 bucks. 

But, I didn't do it on purpose, I swear. I just kinda strolled in with my friends, assuming they paid for my ticket. I saw them paying for theirs, why wouldn't they pay mine? Boy, you just can't trust anyone these days.

A well known feature of Golden Gate Park, it's the oldest Japanese garden in the US - circa 1894 to be exact. Tours of the garden are given daily, as they're open everyday, with no holiday closures.
