Imagine 5 acres of Japanese and Chinese plants, sculptures, bridges, pagodas, koi ponds, lanterns, paths, ponds, a gift shop, and teahouse. I really wanted to try a cup of the delicious green matcha, but the prices were kinda stupid, so I just opted to pass. What a TEAse.

The garden is almost so trivial, you feel obligated to check it out. Similar, to your High School Prom, it's one of those events that are really good to experience, but afterwards, you'd probably come to the realization that life goes on without it. Was that analogy too exaggerated? I'm surprised you even read this far.

Anyways, every March & April, cherry blossom trees bloom throughout the garden. Now, that's a site I'd gladly pay eight dollars for. But next time, I promise to fork over the dough. Scout's honor.

FORTUNE COOKIE
Makoto Hagiwara was the Japanese immigrant that was responsible for the creation and maintenance of this timeless garden. His descendants claimed to have introduced the very first fortune cookie in the US from Japan. Garden visitors were served fortune cookies made by a local bakery called Benkyodo.
author: Chris C.

description:
This garden is a gem of the Golden Gate Park. It is a small garden with greenery everywhere which is so soothing to your eyes. It has $8 entry fees which is very decent. You don't need more than 1 hour unless you plan to eat at the cafe. You get a lot of selfie opportunities. 

Spending sometime in this garden surely refreshes and re-energizes you. It is definitely a must visit place in SFO.
author: Fatima D.

description:
One of my favorite spots when I need to clear my head. Five acres of perfect landscape that transports you to the gardens in Japan. This place is incredible and I'm glad there's an entrance fee because that's probably how everything stays so nice.

The cafe by the gift shop is the perfect place to take a break after your long stroll. Sip on some authentic Japanese tea or miso soup and enjoy the sushi (if it's not sold out) with the most beautiful backdrop in San Francisco! Actually, I have not had futomaki this good since Japan. It's pricey but worth every penny.
author: Mike T.

description: Such a great experience at the Japanese tea garden! It's so beautiful inside and the view is great while sipping tea there. The edamame and udon was good, but could be better. The pricing is moderate, such a great location, and fasts service. I hope they will have more food selection and better quality food!
author: Mandy Z.

description: Definitely a nice place to go on a date.  I checked this place out with my girlfriend and it was absolutely stunning.  The Pagoda, the Koi fish, the zen garden, the whole place just makes you feel at peace.  You definitely get your money's worth for the $8 dollars.  My girlfriend and I came early and left to take a look at the other gardens.  On our way back to the car, we saw a huge line waiting to get into the park.  The Japanese Tea garden is a bit small, so I can definitely see it not being as fun with a lot of people everywhere.  So, I would highly recommend going a bit early in the day to avoid the long lines and get the free parking on the side of the street.  Also, you can get some nice pictures before it gets crowded later in the day.  There is a nice bridge in the garden that is perfect for pictures and guaranteed to get you a lot of "likes" on facebook.  The food is a bit pricey but the green tea cheesecake is definitely worth it.
author: Dang L.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is a great place to stop by for a couple of hours. It's smaller than most Japanese Tea Gardens, but for the price, it was worth it. 

There is a Garden Cafe & Gift shop with cute little gifts to take home! I had the Green Tea Cheesecake - it wasn't that great for something costing $6.50. There was more of a cheesecake taste and no matcha. Sad life, but well! The Hojicha was good, though!

Overall, my experience here was amazing. A small little maze of a place, but fun. The restrooms were a little hidden (on the left of the entrance), but was still able to find it. If you have an hour or two to spare, definitely come here for your touristy photos.

Adult Tickets: $8.00 non residence
$6.00 residence
author: Julie T.

description:
I haven't been here since my 7th grade field trip but it was as I remembered. 

The garden is well-manicured, and very pretty (lots of photo opps) regardless of the weather. You almost forget you're in SF until you notice Sutro Tower when facing SE. 

$6 for SF residents which isn't TOO bad. We'd finished walking around in less than an hour.
author: Esther A.

description: This place is blissful! A very mindful place to sit and sip a cup of tea. It probably helped that the weather was perfect the day I went and I went on a free admission day. The mochi you can get at the cafe is divine.
author: Alli B.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco for a while but never really thought of going to the Japanese Tea Garden. A friend was visiting from out of town and needed to meet up with some friends there so I went with her. 

I wasn't particularly aware of the prices and if I had known, I would have brought some sort of mail with me. You get $2 off if you're a resident! The staff is pretty impatient everyone purchasing tickets, it was pissing me off. I understand that there are people who try to cheat their way into buying a cheaper ticket but damn.

My mood lifted after walking around the garden some more. It's a really beautiful garden and very relaxing to walk in. It had just rained the night before so the air smelled really fresh.

There's a little area for sipping tea and everything looked pretty good so my friend and I sat down and had some. I ordered an iced green tea (sencha and matcha mix) with assorted mochi. Cost about $7 total or something. My friend ordered sencha tea for herself. 

My friend's sencha tea was really tasty. I think it tasted better with the mochi I ordered compared to the tea that I had. My tea was good for sure too but hot teas are better compliments to the little treats there. 

Assorted mochi was yummy. The pink ones were strawberry, the white ones were lychee, and the green ones were green tea. All were pretty good but I liked the lychee ones the best.

Good experience. I would love to go back....but at a discount or for free. And probably when the weather is much nicer.
author: Sofia R.

description:
So I felt like I just walked through a scene from Memoirs of a Geisha. The Japanese Tea Garden is gorgeous!

Two weeks ago when we were walking in Golden Gate Park, I saw this building that looked like a temple and I was like, "I wanna go there!" We had a little bit of time and the place closes at 6pm.

Admission to the Japanese Tea Garden was like around $7 per person, which wasn't too bad.

As soon as we walked past the ticket booth, there was a photo opportunity. Every corner, every step in this tea garden is a photo op! There's ponds, koi fishes, a Buddha, exotic flora, and some unique little buildings that embody the Japanese style. This is one of those places where I have to let the pictures do the talking because I'm not really an expert on flora. 

Also, there's a moon bridge! Most people I saw tend to walk to the top and go back the same way. I totally just walked that thing across.

Yes, they do sell tea. Although I wasn't really there for the tea. I was just there to take pictures.

The Japanese Tea Garden isn't really that big. However, it's really beautiful and it's also the oldest public Japanese Garden in the United States (yay trivia!) If you like beautiful gardens, then I'd highly recommend this place! Oh, and don't forget to bring your camera here! You'll regret it if you don't!
author: Jane L.

description: We came here on a Friday before 10 and we were admitted free. The gardens is very nice and clean. With A lot of beautiful picturesque areas. We finished walking around the garden in an hour including a stop for some hot tea. Would definitely recommend if in the area.
author: Donna Y.

description: My friend and I decided to go on a little day trip to the city. Mistakenly, we forgot to check the weather, so it was rather moist, especially for the parts of the city west of Twin Peaks. After touring the de Young, we decided to see if the Tea Garden was open, after all the mist was extreme from the fog. It was, so walked in, strolled the paths and relaxed in the mist-filled atmosphere surrounded by the beauty around us. After our stroll, we went to the tea house and ordered the sencha tea with the petit fours. The service was kind, the tea was amazing and the petit fours were a perfect treat. Normally, moist, muggy days wouldn't be the best for a day in Golden Gate Park, but this day was definitely the exception.
author: Zachary D.

description: Must see tourist spot when in SF! It's so relaxing & zen. There is a cafe with diff types of teas, coffees & hot chocolate w assorted types of dessert. Once I had my hot chocolate in hand- you're good to start exploring the beautiful garden. I wish it were bigger but it is still a sight to see. Don't forget to take a quick snap across the bridge!
author: Hena A.

description:
Reason for visit: Playing tourist. 
Visit date: October 12, 2012
First time? Yes.

The garden is relatively small and there were a lot of people during our visit, but surprisingly the garden was still calming. My cousin and I started with snacks and tea, ahem, the cutest little chicken snacks and most delicious tea. Then we explored the garden. So many pictures were taken on this visit. Our favorite spot was the steep bridge. The entry fee of $7 is definitely a tourist price, but can be well spent by finding a cozy spot to people and/or koi watch.
author: Erin G.

description:
This is a great place, but boy did I pick the wrong day to come here. I came during the Labor Day weekend, and lets just say it was packed! 

It seems that this location is meant to be a serene place, but it loses some of its magic if there are a butt load of people blocking every square inch of the place. Don't let that deter you from coming here, as I'm sure it's not so bad on other days. 

This place is a thing of beauty and it actually resembles the real thing. (I've been to Japan) There is a lot of work put into this place and it shows. 

I hope to come again and this time I'll make sure it's not a holiday weekend as I really did enjoy everything. (Including the funky bridge) It's a sight to behold.
author: Benny H.

description: Our short trip to San Francisco was a wonderful experience. As always sightseeing was spectacular and I loved the Japanese Garden. Would always love to go back with friends and family for quality time.
author: Anna N.

description: Expensive for such a small garden to visit. Was expecting much more for a $9/pers entry fee. Not worth the money.
author: Samantha O.

description:
I've made many trips to the city, just never got around to the Golden Gate Park, so I was determined to go on my last visit to SF. Admission is $5 for residents, $7 for non-residents, and FREE on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 9am-10am. Open daily at 9am, but closes earlier during the winter months. They also do not close on holidays (according to their website).

The best way to describe this place is serene. It's lush and beautiful. We really enjoyed walking around, admiring the architecture, landscaping, and koi ponds. It's not extremely large, so even with a leisurely walk and photographs, it's less than an hour. There's a gift shop with very cute Japanese and San Francisco-themed trinkets in the garden (I got an adorable panda matryoshka doll) as well as the Jack Hirose Teahouse. 

The teahouse is located in/near the center of the garden, offering hot teas and light snacks. We chose the Matcha (high quality powered green tea) served with Green Tea Mochi for $8.50, Genmaicha (Japanese green tea blended with brown rice) for $3.75, and Kuzumochi in mango and lychee (6 pieces for $4.95). The Matcha and Genmaicha were delicious and a nice treat for the unusually cold summer weather. The mochi was very soft and chewy. It's a great place to relax because it's open-air and you can enjoy the carefully manicured trees around you while sipping tea.

It was a truly wonderful way to spend a couple hours of our morning with a good friend. If you have time to kill and want something relaxing, I recommended taking advantage of the free admission times during the week and grab some delicious Japanese tea and treats!
author: Amelinda L.

description: We went there on a lazy afternoon and actually ended up staying there for a while. The garden itself is well decorated and maintained. There are some interactive pieces like the big bridge and some really nice structures like the Japanese house. The place has arrays of bonsai trees which is one of my favorite trees. The koi is pond is medium sized and is quite nice. There is a gift shop with extremely overpriced Japanese stuff, which we definitely passed on. There's a small eatery which light meal options. Our favorite pieces was the big Buddha status and small sitting areas around the garden. We are definitely going back and next time, we'll bring our parents to this place.
author: Sudha S.

description:
Clip-clop. Clip-clop. Clip-clop. No, that's not the sound of Mr. Ed walking to the glue factory. It's my little wooden geisha sandals (geta) as I walk very slowly to the Japanese Tea Garden, an oasis of serenity (kinda) that has not seen my face since my first grade field trip with Mrs. Kullman, who had bye-bye arms when she wrote on the blackboard. Far be it for me to spread trivialized Japanese stereotypes, so for review #2100, Jamie W. and I have returned to the tranquil garden of my people where I do not have to deal with da' man. No, not Jamie. I'm talkin' 'bout da' Man! 'Cause da' man can get me down. Know what I'm sayin'?

Like many others, I tend to forget the garden is there since it's been dwarfed by the twin juggernauts of the DeYoung Museum and the California Academy of Sciences. But here it is, all five acres of it, and it's still the bucolic retreat originally developed for the 1894 California Midwinter International Exposition. It was converted from a temporary exhibit into a permanent park after the fair's conclusion thanks to the efforts of Makoto Hagiwara, a Japanese immigrant and gardener, who approached Golden Gate Park superintendent John McLaren with the idea. Hagiwara oversaw the garden's construction and became official caretaker, a role be played for three decades until 1925.

Hagiwara specifically requested that one thousand flowering cherry trees be imported from Japan. His family lived in and maintained the Japanese Tea Garden until 1942 when Executive Order 9066 forced them to leave San Francisco and relocate to an internment camp. The garden was then renamed the "Oriental Tea Garden" at which point it fell into a state of disarray. The name "Japanese Tea Garden" was officially reinstated in 1952. Over the years, it has gradually come back to life with the semi-circular Drum Bridge still its decorative, foot-unfriendly centerpiece. Several circuitous paths lead to the other key attractions like the hilltop pagoda, a monumental Buddha, a miniature waterfall, and a Japanese-style tea house overlooking a koi-filled pond.

In 2009, a controversy erupted over the café ownership when a Japantown café owner won the contract to run the operation with a $500,000 grant for improvements in order to move it away from "a tourist spot that serves Chinese fortune cookies and sells generic souvenirs". The departing Chinese-American vendor claimed racial discrimination. The brouhaha has since been settled, and now is a good time to visit with a cascade of wisteria covering the café. The cherry blossoms show up briefly in a mercilessly short season with a full bloom reached about one week after the opening of the first blossoms. Regardless, the Japanese Tea Garden is well worth a stop if just for the tranquil beauty it achieves amid the throngs of tourists that visit. Clip-clop. Clip-clop. Clip-clop...
author: Ed U.

description:
I have not been to the Japanese Tea Garden in a very long time.  My cousin had never been inside, so I figured today was the day to remedy that.  We were celebrating his birthday after all.

Admission is $2/6/8 for child/youth/adult non-residents.  But on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays it's free if you enter by 10:00 am.  You can't beat that price!  They are open 365 days a year.

After strolling through the garden, you can sip a cup of tea and have some light snacks at the Tea House.  It gets crowded at times, so you may have to wait.  There is also a gift shop to visit.  I picked up a chopstick rest in the shape of a stretching cat for my sister.

If you feet hurt from all that walking around, just have a seat.  Relax and take in the scenery.

Don't forget to bring your camera!
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description:
This is my favorite part of the bay area. I love it here.

It's beautiful~! Untainted, clean, serene and all that crap.
author: Christopher H.

description: Beautiful, but over priced for such a small garden. Shop is charming, but again over priced.
author: Teresa B.

description: This place is gorgeous. The tea gardens are well manicured grounds, with plenty to see, koi fish, birds and Japanese greenery. They do have a separate fee from the botanical gardens across the street. Took my little friend there on a Monday, which was extremely crowded. Probably due to winter break, and kids out of school. Difficult parking. Those are the only complaints. Other than that, it's a beauty. Will go back.
author: Ninfa S.

description: We went in Golden Gate Park today and someone told me I must absolutely go to the Japanese tea Garden. I absolutely didnt regret it! It was by far the highlight of my trip and I went in LA before my couple of days in San Francisco. The entrance isnt expensive and worth it. It was so beautiful inside and peaceful too. The japanese ambiance was really there. If you have a chance, go to look inside te gift shop. There is a lot of pretty things and it's isnt expensive. Worth all the travelling we did today to be able to go there today.
author: Christine G.

description: Inside Golden Gate Park you will find one of the famous attractions in San Francisco: the Japanese Tea Garden. It doesn't cost too much to see the Gardens, $8 for non SF residents and $6 if you can provide proof of an SF address. The gardens themselves are beautiful and well maintained. There is a zen garden that I liked and a koi pond with lots of fish swimming around. The walk through the garden is much shorter than i expected, taking us a under an hour total to see the entire garden while walking at a slow pace and posing for pictures. I also liked the Japanese pagodas that were in the garden since they were placed amidst nice flowers and a waterfall. The best picture had to be at the top of the Japanese footbridge that they had. The bridge is high arching, so you will have to help the youngins getting off of the bridge. The other cool thing to do while at the tea garden is to actually have tea. We got a cookie platter as well with the tea and everyone seemed to enjoy the experience of hot tea on a drizzly day. Overall, the gardens could be bigger, but for something like this in a large city it is a perfect way to escape and relax. Sidenote: there are no maps provided, but you can buy one at the gift shop, although I really doubt you need one.
author: Vats A.

description:
Absolutely beautiful. The tea, pastry, and musubi cafe in the center is neat. My genmaicha was scalded and I found that to be very disappointing coming from such a place. Too many tourists, I suppose, and I was playing tourist today. 

Beautiful walk to and from the park, too. It's not surprising that San Francisco has such striking filth. When a place as beautiful as this exists, there has to be an underside.
author: Julia D.

description: Been to golden gate park only for outside lands. This trip decided to take a rainy afternoon in at the Japanese tea garden in golden gate park. It's true...it is very small. The tea house has great service. Being from Las Vegas, Japanese tea gardens don't exist. Be thankful for what you have people...even if it is smaller than you'd like. We got to witness a proposal from the top of the bridge. So young and in love...it was perfect for them. It was a relaxing, beautiful afternoon spent in this serene environment.
author: Terry B.

description: I had a wonderful time visiting the garden. It was calming and relaxing experience to walking through and sit to appreciated the beauty and serenity it provided as I get a different vantage point each time. It is $7 to get in and allow an hour or 2 to visit the garden. I would recommend visiting and taking beautiful photos at the attraction.
author: Gerry B.

description: The green tea ice cream and free tea cheesecake were divine! I loved that the tea garden was tranquil but the price to enter the garden was a bit absurd.
author: Megan Y.

description: I brought my girlfriend out here on a quite fun midday date not too long ago. She and I especially enjoyed a fantabulous time out over an exquisite luncheon of sushi and ice-cream overlooking the pensive serenity of the babbling waters and below the majestic forest canopy. I wholeheartedly recommend this serene place of peace for anyone who wants to enjoy a romantic afternoon or evening out. :)
author: Richard R.

description:
Great experience, really enjoyed our time here and the tea was wonderful.
Consider weather when visiting as the tea house is OUTDOORS and a cold windy day will ruin the experience.
Take your time and walk through their beautiful garden, beautiful, any photographer's dream.
Great location and a must for anyone visiting san francisco for the first time.
author: Zildheam D.

description: If you are in San Francisco visit this beautiful place , the entrance is 8 dollars it's small but the pics you can take there in the garden are amazing also they have a tea shop ! I tried  the matcha tea and it came with a matcha cookie ! Nice place if you want to get out of the city craziness
author: Yoanka V.

description: Of the course of my livelihood, I had never been to the Japanese Tea Garden, not until showing around a friend from out of town.  Residents admission is currently $6 and non-residents are $8, and it is a self-showing garden.  Not many signs or explanations.  There is a cute tea room.  Definitely a tourist spot.  Some Koi fish, some lily pads, a few structures, lots of weaving spiders!  I think that spiders were the most exciting.  It's one of those places, you go in to "smell the roses" (although there's a rose garden and the Conservatory nearby) and appreciate life.  I do think that the SJ Japanese Tea Garden was more aesthetically pleasing, but this one was built in an area where a Casino once existed.
author: Janet T.

description: We're in Love with this place, absolutely beautiful! Wish we would have had more time to spend. Don't miss this gem!!
author: Lori L.

description: What a gem. Very lush. Exquisitely manicured. Cafe has great teas, soups, etc. highly recommend!
author: Jared J.

description:
When you walk in, it's easy to forget that you're in the middle of busy San Francisco. I really enjoy Japanese gardens. Lots of ponds, waterfalls, bonsai, bamboo, rock garden, and even a pagoda in the middle. Everything is well crafted with lots of detail.  And of course, there's a place to get tea and admire all of the intricate tea pots. 

Lots of amateur photographers, Instagrammers, engagement photos, and general photo taking happening too. I enjoyed peeking around the corners and photographing the bonsai. 

The $7 price is a bit steep for "nature" but if you consider the amount of effort put in to keep the garden looking the way it is and can appreciate the attention to detail, it's a steal. 

--
PHOTOS: 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/japanese-tea-garden-san-francisco?select=1BdWKiiIfhL-zmSbcM6gLw#1BdWKiiIfhL-zmSbcM6gLw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/japanese-tea-garden-san-francisco?select=eRItw3rF3vZVR_AxSkG6Sw#eRItw3rF3vZVR_AxSkG6Sw
author: Kevin L.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden was a nice small garden inside Golden Gate Park. It was very well decorated, but appeared very artificial to me. The space is not large and they tried to fit the entire garden with too many paths and plants. While it was a pretty garden, it did not seem as attractive to me as other more spacious Japanese gardens e.g. Portland Japanese Garden. 

Inside, there is a tea house where they sell tea. Tea was nothing extraordinary, but it was relaxing to sit down and enjoy the view as you immerse yourself in the garden.

The admission price was not too bad ($8) as well, but the garden is pretty small!
author: Steve MoungJin K.

description: Oh how I love the Japanese Tea Garden! Nestled in Golden Gate Park, the Japanese Tea Garden is a blissful spot that will relax you from the real world. My friend and I stopped at the tea stand and ordered some tea, and some petit fours for an afternoon nosh. I ordered the ice green tea and it was quite refreshing for the warm day. The petit fours were good, but they were packaged that are pulled out earlier in the day to thaw, next time I will order something more authentic for the accompanyment. The tea gardens are perfect for pictures, gathering your thoughts and seeing the beauty nature really has to offer.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
This is a beautiful gem located in the Golden Gate Bridge park.

We enjoyed walking around and viewing the beautiful flowers and Japanese influenced buildings. 

They do have seating in the middle of the garden if you'd like to have tea service. 

Afterwards, head over to King of Noodles for great Chinese.
author: Kelleigh M.

description: Great place for pictures with the family or even just taking pictures of the scenery. Went here with my two boys so they could practice their photography and so we could take a few new family portraits. The admission price was just very inexpensive and we had a great time taking in the sights
author: Daniel S.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend sometime last year and thought I'd finally go about reviewing this place. I'm not a tourist or anything, I've actually lived in San Francisco a couple years back, and I'm pretty much a Bay native, but going here just seemed like something I should cross off my bucket list. 
The admission was pretty pricey, but it's in the heart of touristville, so that's understandable. As soon as we walked in, I was in such awe of how beautiful this place was. They really took proper care of everything here. The size of the place was ok, I wish it were bigger so that I could walk around endlessly, lol. The scenery made me never want to leave, but alas I had to because I was already back at the entrance.

We decided to prolong our stay by checking out the cool little cafe in the middle of the garden. They had some tea, and Japanese snacks like mochi and ice-cream. I wish I could live here... Lol They also had a little gift store as well for souvenirs and such
author: Lisa L.

description: Such a great place to visit, especially in the morning. Supposedly the place is free before 10am, i think every Monday, Wednesday, and Fridays. Very calm and relaxing with little people during the mornings. Also try the tea, it was very nice to drink tea with the scenery around you!
author: Kathleen O.

description:
Incredible. Beautiful. Tranquil.

As a tourist you will have to pony up 7 bucks, but this one is worth every penny.
author: Mike F.

description:
I only had 2 and a half days in San Francisco and spent all most ALL day here!
It was the most beautiful Japanese garden I have ever been to. I had tea there, and was lucky to get a spot with the view out over the gardens and pond. The tea was wonderful and I had mochi which was great. It was mostly the experience. 
I could go here everyday!!!
author: Jean K.

description:
If you're sick of the city stuff, take a trip to the Japanese Tea Garden. Such peaceful. Much koi. Japan. *_*

Ouch is that the garden is relatively small. You can walk the entire property in about 20 minutes and for non-SF residents, you'll have to fork over $7. It's cash only + they don't offer student discounts. But if you're a glutton for little bodies of water, sakura flowers, cute bridges, and hundreds of koi then you'll find its worth a visit at least once. It's just so cute and asian.

Yes, they actually serve tea. At the center of the property, they have a little tea hut with a patio area of chairs so you can soak up some Vitamin D and relax by the ponds. Tea runs about $8 a cup.
author: Yuhi K.

description: Beautifully manicured garden. Perfect for a quite and calm walk or reflection. Even on a holiday weekend and it being crowded, the garden was zen. Grab a tea or snack in the tea house and make it memorable, well worth it.
author: Lyn A.

description:
Built to celebrate the Japanese population settlement in SF for the 1894 World's Fair and later converted into a permanent garden, many highlights draws tourists to this small but delicate garden.

Five tier pogoda, 1000 cherry trees, arching bridge, giant goldfish, and many different types of plants puts this small garden on everyone's map. 

In comparison to Vancouver Island's Butchart Garden, it has a lot less in variety, but the fact it's in the middle of Golden Gate Park gives it that much more ambience.

The snack bar in the center of the garden makes the place even more commercialized than the entry fee itself, so that was a turn off.
author: Richard Y.

description:
I love this place, came here at different times and it is beautiful. No first time visit to GGP is complete without a visit the JPT. If you cannot afford to go in you can still see it from the outside. I really like how there is a lot of nice things to see here. 
Drawbacks: do not let the name fool you because if you actually get something to eat or drink it is not worth it.
Either way it is okay if you keep your spending in this place to a minimum.
author: Michael W.

description: First timer here! Admission is $8 per person... The vibe is pretty peaceful and zen. Lots of trees and ponds with fish! Overall a very stunning environment. There's a gift shop and a cafe inside. Parking can be a bit of an issue. I parked about 5 minutes away walking-distance.
author: Dominique E.

description: Really fun way to spend an hour or so in the afternoon! Entrance is $7 for adults and tea ranges from $3-4 but it's really good quality tea. Like the best sweet green tea I've had. The garden is beautiful of course too.
author: Kelly G.

description: Scenic but a lot smaller than I expected. We were able to walk around the garden twice within an hour. The gift shop was fun to look around in, but I thought they could provide more educational books about Japanese tea gardens. We visited the cafe which had a very nice view of the pond (you have to hunt for a seat along the sides of the cafe to get a view). It was a bit pricier than I expected and the desserts were nothing super special, but the view made up for it!
author: Brittani C.

description: Very cute park! Great place to visit especially it's free on Mon, Wed and Fri if you enter before 10am. Very neat Japanese architectures. There are also a Japanese shop and tea place. Have a cup of Japanese tea while enjoying the sunshine is a wonderful experience. The small shop is worth taking a look too. My friend got a cute little ceramic cat there.
author: Cecily W.

description: '$9 for non resident. We went on a Monday morning. Weather was breezy and not a busy day. It's small. The ambiance is great. Ate at their mini garden. Nothing special, same taste as your ordinary udon,miso and mochi. The green tea ice cream and drink taste weird for me, taste like a toothpaste. Hehe! Im not used to it.
author: Adam S.

description:
Tourist. 

$8 entry adult. Free Mon Wed Fri 9a-10a. Really nice tea garden, and the tea was quite good as well. I also ordered the fukadachi (sweet rice cake with powdered sugar) and it was a little too sweet for me. The landscape is beautiful and it's not too big. I think I would have found it more relaxing if it were quieter but both the staff and the other guests were speaking loud enough to be disturbing (I found that it was louder than normal volume). I wanted to find a slice of quiet but found this to be rather irksome. This would be a definite go to spot at a quieter time. 

7/10 would recommend if quiet
author: Alex Y.

description:
It's really nice and beautiful, but man do I have to say the $7 admission for non-SF residents is a disappointment about this place. I do see though via their website(plus didn't know this, at the time of my SF trip) that they have free admission between 9 to 10am on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, so that probably is the secret to getting around the admission issue. And of course, perhaps also the crowds(or at least some of them) I noticed, at the time I went?

That said, it really is a great place to walk through. All the other reviews are right that you can literally walk the whole grounds of this place in less than an hour, and my recollection is that I saw just about all of it within 30-45 minutes. Loved the drum bridge, and the other buildings on the Tea Garden grounds were also great to see. I guess I was hoping there'd be a little more to see and/or on site activities/events to do, to justify the $7 admission fee. Didn't get a drink in the tea room part of the place, or eat in their cafe, so no clue how the tea drinks or cafe food is like.

If only not for the pricey $7 admission fee for non-SF residents, I would've gladly given this place 4 stars. Nice to see someone mentioned Hakone Estate and Gardens in Saratoga(southwest of San Jose), which I'd never heard of till now. Guess if I ever travel west to this part of California again, I should check that out to see how Hakone compares to here?
author: Allan M.

description:
I came to San Francisco with the purpose of exploring Golden Gate Park. This place was on top of the list of things to check out. I arrived  If it's been there since 1894, it's got to be impressive. After taking the various buses and subways to get here, I entered the park and found the nearest map. I followed it's instructions to get to the Japanese Tea Garden.  $7 got you inside their big front gate. I began to wander around the paths snapping photographs of various things. It was very scenic and relaxing. The trees reminded me of giant bonsai trees.  The gardens, statues and sculptures reminded me of Asian things I had seen in other places. There was a Budda statue, there were a few of those tiered house-thingies.  There were also Koi ponds with sculptures in and around them.. After I wandered around for a bit, I decided that  I really should get some Tea while in the Japanese Tea Gardens. So I wandered around and found the line to wait in. Wow. This is a popular on a Saturday.  I chatted with the people in line ahead of me. They were also tourists, visiting San Francisco for a concert tonight. I didn't know who it was, even after they told me who it was.
   After waiting in line a bit, I ordered a 6 piece kuzumochi & an iced green tea for about $7.  I then went to find a place to sit. That was a challenge in itself. Lots and lots of people, not many places to sit. Eventually I got lucky, and found a place. I sat down with my number and waited for my things to arrive. Before too long my items arrived, and I ate.  The iced tea was tasty and cold, the kuzumochi was mixed. I didn't particularly care for the grey ones. But the yellow & pink ones were pretty good.
   As I began to finish up the food, I felt a presence behind me. I turned to discover a family awkwardly hovering close to me and my bench seat. They were eyeing my spot hungrily. I quickly finished up, picked up my trash, packed up my stuff and cleared out.

     Well, now I've seen the Japanese Tea Garden everybody was raving about. Meh? It was okay? While it was beautifully landscaped, soothing and calming and all that, I don't really feel the overwhelming desire to go back.  Maybe if your trying to impress a girl on a date? There's plenty of other stuff in that Golden Gate Park.
   
FYI: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_tea_garden_at_Golden_Gate_Park
author: Scott B.

description:
This is a tough one to call. While walking through here was very enjoyable for the price it does seem to fall short on delivering an unforgettable experience. But then again what is one to expect? A  dragon creeping behind every other tree? I think not. 

Since I was on vacation the extra $7 sort of got absorbed by larger costs but if I were being very budget conscious I would skip the Tea Garden since GGP offers a lot of other great places to check out. 

I came here when it wasn't the cherry blossom season so my experience was not the best it could have been, but it was still very peaceful to walk around here and get to sample a mini Japanese experience that does not involve sushi. 

The "tea" portion of the garden was a very pleasant break from a full days walking around the park. I think that too was overpriced (I originally hail from Sri Lanka so paying a high price for tea does not sit well with me regardless of how amazing it is). 
But I have to admit the quality of the tea here was good but it came second to the amazing Kuzumochi which I can never have enough of. 

If you have a lot of time to kill in the park, and you have never been to Japan or just love everything Japanese this would be a great accessory to your day. It gets a solid 3.5 stars from me.
author: Dishan W.

description:
A beautiful little garden that's almost hidden away next to the deYoung Museum. There's free admission Monday, Wednesday, and Friday mornings between 9-10 AM. I couldn't make it at that time and paid the $8 regular admission. In my opinion, the garden is not really worth $8 because it only takes about half an hour to walk through the whole thing. However, I do think the garden is very nice and would love to go back during the free hours.

There are a bunch of benches around the area to sit down and admire the many ornate structures like the pagoda and the statue of Buddha within the garden. While I was there, I also encountered a guided tour group where the guide was explaining some of the historical stuff behind different parts of the garden. It sounded interesting! The main attraction is obviously the tea house, but I didn't go in there this time. But I did go into the gift shop and they had a lot of cute things and nice ceramic stuff. Next time I'll definitely try the tea though!
author: Karen T.

description: The door was closed and no longer accepting people at 5:40 pm. We arrived on foot from the Botanical Garden. We were not the only ones at the doorstep sort of disappointed that it closed so early. Womp. This is a really historical spot, built for the 1894 (not a typo) world fair and just never destroyed, similar to the Eiffel Tower in that respect. It is the oldest Japanese tea garden in USA.
author: Attossa C.

description: Not very friendly, workers @ the entrance were really lazy & rude.  I was planning of proposing there but I was running a little late. They were closing the front gate 10 minutes before actual closing time, so I didn't make it. Beautiful place just not so great staff.
author: Gustavo C.

description:
As a local, I've never went to the Japanese Tea Garden, but was pleasantly surprised.  Make sure you ask for the resident discount... The lady charged us full price since she assumes everyone is a tourist.... It'll save you a few bucks.  

Garden was nice and peaceful... Even on a busy hot Sunday.  The tea room was okay.. They were pretty much out of everything.  And we were there at 11am.  How can you be out of everything to eat?!!  

This is definitely a good spot for a relaxing stroll date.
author: Vicky T.

description:
Simply Amazing!

It sounded like a nice place to visit, but it didn't sound like it would be worth the price of admission ($8 per non-resident adult).  That all changed when we found out admission is free (FREE!!!) if you arrive before 10:00 Monday, Wednesday, or Friday.  Since we were going to be visiting the Botanical Gardens on a Wednesday morning, this became an easy addition to the day's itinerary.

After spending even just 30 minutes inside, we quickly realized it would have been worth paying the full price for the visit.  The job they have done establishing and maintaining the gardens is nothing short of amazing!  We visited in January, so it is easy to imagine the gardens being breathtaking in peak season.

No matter what time of year it is and no matter what you pay for the entrance, I cannot recommend the tea gardens enough!
author: Ted Q.

description:
Wanting to check this place out when visiting SF with my bf. It's a total different world once you go in. My secret garden feel, huge, and just beautiful. It's hard not to take pictures every area has it's own character just leaves you is a gasp.

There's a little cafe where you can order cookies, teas, little sushi samplers, and few sweets. We had a little sushi sampler with tea and just sat and it was just a gorgeous view.  After biking around the area its a nice top to just relax and have a little snack. There is also a little gift shop where you can buy beautiful hand made cups, tea cups, and few plates. 

Definitely a hidden gem you MUST check this place out if your in the area.
author: Vanessa M.

description:
What a wonderful gem tucked away in the Golden Gate Park! A little pricey admission, but the scenery is worth it. Great gardening, serene koi fish, and raked sand populate the space. It was wonderful and relaxing and great for photos.

Definitely get something to eat too. Although I always put sugar in my tea, the jasmine tea was so delicious it didn't need any. Plus, it paired wonderfully with the mochi (definitely recommend, soooooo good). Stop by when you can!
author: Zak C.

description:
Zen and chill Japanese garden in San Francisco next to the Golden Gate Bridge.
*Entry fee rate depends if you have a CA ID or out of state ID.

Ambience: Relaxing, clean, and open atmosphere. The garden is beautiful and very well kept. There's a pond with several koi fish, some bridges, and a Buddha statue.

Food:
1. Lychee, mango, and kinako mochi: The best mochi I've had in the States and I'm a mochi fanatic especially for kinako.
2. Dorayaki (azuki bean pancake): This was just ok. The bread was a little dry.
3. Sesame Azuki Mochi: Very tasty and great texture of mochi and azuki.

Drink: 
1. Hot Matcha Green Tea: Very authentic. Unsweetened and has the naturally bitter taste of green tea. I love matcha and this was delicious.
2. Iced Green Tea: Slightly sweetened and very refreshing on a summer day. I would recommend.

Customer Service: Not the best and they simply take your order and deliver your order.

Overall I would recommend. This is something you should definitely see as a visitor or eventually as a local.
author: Krisha A.

description:
Admission is $8 for non-residents, which is extremely high for this incredibly small and crowded tourist attraction in Golden Gate Park.  I was able to slowly walk the entire park in around 15 minutes.  And slowly I walked because the place was incredibly crowded at 4:30 on a Tuesday afternoon in August.  If people weren't there, I can imagine that the park would be incredibly relaxing and beautiful but when I was there, it was loud and too many people were trying to take pictures in the middle of the paths.

There is also a tea shop and gift shop near the entrance, but I didn't go in because a cup of tea was $5 and a ramune is $3.25 (i.e. overpriced).
author: Sean C.

description:
Lovely walk around this morning at 9 am, free admission, not crowded, beautiful sunny day.

Perfect!

Enjoyed jasmine tea and the tea sandwiches in the tea house,

Walked over to the observation tower in the de Young museum and saw a great view of all of San Francisco.  (This is free, too)
author: Foodlover B.

description: This place is simply beautiful and serene.  I regret that I had a full day of touristing so I did not have the chance to sit down someplace with a book or to simply reflect.  We did partake in some soup, snacks, and tea in the tea garden.  Our server explained how one must drink matcha tea so I followed his directions and really enjoyed it.  It was fun to think about balance and how monks would drink that tea.  The gift shop was nice but so, so pricy that neither my friend or I bothered to buy anything since we were able to acquire nice goodies elsewhere at a lower price.
author: Patti M.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is a welcome oasis of zen and a fair representation of a much smaller version of the grounds of some of the famous temples in Kyoto. If you need some serenity in your life, do yourself a favor and find a way to come here on a weekday, early in the day and soak it in. It's hard to let the peacefulness overcome you when it is crowded, but there are a few hidden spots where you can find the time, even with the crowds.

At $7 ($5 for SF residents), I find it to be a bargain. It is small and if you don't take your time you will be done in less than an hour.* The landscape is overwhelmingly manicured and it provides a nice set of levels throughout the garden. Some smaller versions of temples provide a break in height and color that only add to the overall ambience of being inside this place.

You are in the middle of a feng shui dream - water, plants and buddha to guide you through a short break from the monotony and over-connectedness of your life.** Follow the paths, sit on a bench and definitely visit the gift shop and the small restaurant. I am still kicking myself for not knowing there was food inside.
_________________
*Take your time. I'm not talking to you, I'm talking to the person always on the go, rushing through everything and forgetting to look at what is right in front of you and enjoy it. You, take your time.
**It seems ridiculous to be in the Tea Garden hoping to get a good shot to Instagram, but there is no shame in capturing some of what is given to you here - just don't hold me up from getting past you on the path.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
One of the highlights during my trip to San Francisco. Walking in here, I instantly forgot I was in the busy urban jungle of San Francisco, and for a moment, felt as if I had been transported to Japan. Admission was $8 since I was a non-resident.

The garden is simply stunning and houses plenty of ponds, flora, rocks and bridges. I imagine the garden being even more breathtaking during Spring when the cherry blossoms are in full bloom. There's also a Buddha statue, a pagoda tower and a place to try some hot tea. You can tell that a great deal of care and attention goes into these grounds, and that makes it worth the admission price in my book. It's a wonderful place to take a break from the city, inhale some fresh air, and stroll in a calming haven for nature. If you're a photographer, you will love how photogenic this place is. And for fans of Japanese culture and movies, you will be able to live out your anime dreams here as well (I channeled my inner Chihiro from Spirited Away and kept thinking the whole time how cool it would have been to see Totoro).
author: Tony H.

description:
Pleasant

Nicely done pleasant atmosphere.  I think adult admission was a tad too high for what was there though.  Some of the buildings could use some new paint too.
author: Daryl C.

description:
So peaceful and lush. Here are some tips:

If you go before 10 am on MWF it's FREE!

This is kind of a scary place for small kids with all the ponds and stone walkways, but totally manageable.

This is not a good place for strollers.

Bring a lunch and eat at the Music Plaza across the way. Or go to the Indian food truck. Awwwwesome!
author: Ashley E.

description: The grounds are beautiful, however they are quite small. If you are going to go to the gardens you definitely must sit in the tea room area and enjoy some tea and snacks. Going only to the gardens alone I would give a three star rating. It is a beautiful area and reminded me of being in Japan, minus the noisy tourists who are there to get their instagram pictures and be rude and loud. There was not a lot about SF that I enjoyed but definitely enjoyed the tea gardens. The tea and food was hot and delicious. Worth the visit if you're in the area.
author: Maggie S.

description:
Absolutely stunning! I'm so glad I had the opportunity to visit this place on my trip to San Fransisco. 

We arrived at about 9:50 am and spent a good two hours taking pictures and relaxing on one of the many benches. It's free admission before 10 am, so I would definitely try to get here before then. It's also less crowded and gives you an opportunity to find parking close by.
author: M. A.

description: Super adorable place!!! The gardens were done beautifully. There was a delicious (but bit overpriced) teahouse in the middle of the gardens where you can sit and sip tea and enjoy the lovely weather. So much better to be outdoors in California than in Texas.
author: Anne L.

description: So I heard so many people raving about this place and so we checked it out. I just really thought it would be bigger. My husband and I made about 10-15 rounds just to get our money's worth. It is a very nice and zen atmosphere but maybe I didn't feel it too much because there were so many people and we kept on bumping into them. Overall, it was decent but if you want a really garden experience, go to the botanical garden across the street.
author: Rashmi P.

description: Visited this place once when i was younger for a field trip. I don't remember anything really except the pagoda. Came here again Saturday with a friend. Wow...It was beautiful! Nice place to come for a walk and relax. Great place to bring someone on a date too.
author: Joann P.

description: Good place to visit with your better half and even better when the place is empty and quiet. Good layout and seems to be well-kept. Walk slowly and enjoy the view of the grounds as it's a good place to reflect on things. Parking is easy in the mornings but likely hard on the weekends. There is an underground parking lot nearby for $2.50/hour. Entrance is free before 10am on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. There are a few Pokestops in here.
author: Hagow C.

description: Enjoy an enchanting afternoon here away from the city. I definitely recommend taking a uber ride to avoid the traffic congestion and parking challenges. This is an oasis that is a must see when you visit San Fran. I fell in love!
author: Lauren R.

description: The Japanese tea garden in SF's golden gate park is nothing like the pagodas you can see in Japan. Though the greenery seems to be maintained effectively, the buildings, on the other hand, don't seem to be well kept. The admission price ($8) isn't worth it for a small tea garden. The tea offered in the tea house isn't exactly great either. Pricey tea and pricey souvenir shop.
author: Tunaidi A.

description: If I were to have a "See SF on the cheap" list, this is definitely the first thing on it. Come early on certain days and you'll get in free. It's not very big, so a slow pace would take an hour to walk through. I recommend taking that hour & be with nature. Play with the fishes, pose with the bridges. It's definitely serene in there.
author: Pham D.

description: This tea garden is beautiful and relaxing. Wander around and meditate over the tranquility of the sunken garden, search for fish in the koi pond, or just sit in the tea house to a warm cup of genmaicha (green tea with toasted rice) and some kuzumochi (fluffy jelly-like rice cakes). This is the oldest tea garden in the U.S. and the fortune cookie was invented here! It's definitely worth admission ($8), but if you come Monday, Wednesday, or Friday between 9 and 10 AM, admission is free.
author: Ross L.

description: I like walking through the Japanese Tea Garden whenever I happen to be in the area at Golden Gate Park.  It's peaceful and a very good spot to test your new digital camera and photography skills!  The garden landscape is breathtaking and of course you have to check out that bridge I like to call the horseshoe because it's shaped like one.  The only thing that somewhat ruins the tranquility is that it costs $7 if you're a non-resident like me, but if you live in the city it's not too bad a deal at $5.  If you're in the area, it's definitely worth checking out.
author: Rodney H.

description: Me and my girlfriend visited this tea garden in the summer of 2014. I really love this place so much to see here. This is a nice place to go and take your significant other with you. This place is ver peaceful. I would recommend this place to visit to anyone one visiting San Francisco.
author: Isaac H.

description: This beautiful Japanese garden is well worth a visit.  Admission is free the first hour.  We took the 9:30 AM City Guides Tour which lasted a little over an hour and was really interesting.  Really enjoyed the visit.
author: Terence D.

description: Cute little Japanese garden! There were a ton of other people around so it was hard to get a good photo without someone walking through your photo in the background. The garden is pretty small though so you probably won't spend that much time inside. Overall, a nice place to stop by while you're at Golden Gate Park.
author: Jennifer W.

description: This place is pretty awesome for $8/person. The views are gorgeous and everything is laid out nicely. Stop by the Tea House and buy a green tea drink. It was so refreshing after walking and looking around.
author: Diana L.

description: A beautiful serene place to practice zen.  Admission is pricey, $7.  I don't have anything else to compare this Japanese garden too but to me it's beautiful, with pretty pagodas, serene small water falls.  When I was there, a couple was getting professional engagement photos taken.  I think it's a perfect place for it.  Do drop by when you're in S.F.
author: Maria S.

description:
When we lived in San Fran we took all our visitors here.  It is simply amazing.  It's a beautifully kept Japanese Tea Garden - "it's the oldest public Japanese garden in
the United States located inside Golden Gate Park in San Francisco, California."
This zen sanctuary is especially magical in the spring during cherry blossom season  and made me nostalgic for when I lived in Japan. 

TIP: 
Mon, Wed, Fri: FREE admission if entered by 10:00 am 
- take advantage if you can!  We always got there early so our visitors didn't have to pay entrance fees.  

Otherwise Adult:  $7.00 entrance or $5 if you are a resident WITH PROOF - they checked my address the last time I went.
author: Melissa T H.

description: This is a relatively small Japanese garden but very well manicured I must say. I think the entrance fee is alittle pricey for a small garden like this (8 bucks for adults) they have pretty pagodas like those in Japan. The whole place is beautiful and clean and very easy to walk around. It would be nicer if they have bigger grass patches for picnics. They do have a small cafe that serves awesome tea and it overlooks the lake.
author: Qianqi L.

description: Small but beautiful place for some chilled walking and nature enjoyment. 8$ to get in. There is a tea parlor which is cool but definitely a bit expensive.
author: Alexander P.

description:
Embrace your inner Samurai amidst tranquility, peace, and harmony! Buddha would be so proud and I hope Japan would as well.

I've been to many Japanese or Chinese Gardens and I must say that this particular one reigns supreme over all of them.

The venue is large, beautiful, not overly crowded, peaceful, ornate, well groomed, well themed, and seemingly authentic. I couldn't say for sure as I've never actually been to Japan... Guess I'll have to ask my buddy upon his return to the states (he's lived there at least a total of 6 years!)

Despite being disabled with a walking/standing disability I still found this place very complete and easy to navigate.

I loved all the various decorations that make up this place. This place makes for a great spot to snap a bunch of shots for your collection!

If you live here or are visiting SF then I highly recommend a visit to the Japanese Tea Garden!

They do have a store if you'd like to buy Japanese inspired goods!
author: Chad A.

description: we visited in the spring and it was just lovely
author: Rhonda W.

description:
My family and I went to San Francisco this past weekend to celebrate my birthday. 

We ended up in Golden Gate park and decided to check out the Japanese Tea Garden. Kids under 5 are free, 5-11 pay $2, & adults pay $8. 

This place is beautiful! We were there for about 2 hours. My kids loved the koi fish. 

A must see place if you're ever in SF.
author: Denice E.

description: This is amazing place . Every one who interests to nature should go there . There are many kinds tree it was there and I love them
author: Mahnaz S.

description: Not worth $16 to get in plus the $12 parking cost. Yes it's cute but too small, save your money.
author: Diane A.

description:
If you've visited the Japanese garden in Portland, this one will be a bit of a disappointment. It feels more touristy, isn't nearly as big, and isn't well kept. However, it's a nice place to spend an afternoon, especially if you're a resident and can take advantage of that $5 admission. 

Drink some tea (several green varieties to choose from) and check out them koi.
author: Jon T.

description: I was expecting it to be bigger and a lot more flowers or at least cherry blossoms. Their was just a lot of bonsai trees and bonsai trees and yep, bonsai trees. It was a very small place which disappointing. We went around 3 times because it was so short but we wanted to stay longer so we could figure out what else was there to do in SF. They had a gift shop and a little restaurant inside the garden. It was quite and peaceful.
author: Nina F.

description:
Lets get all the cons out of the way first (a forewarning). Yes, the tea garden is rather small, there is an admission fee ($7.00, free before 10 a.m. certain weekdays) and it can get pretty crowded. I was a little surprised about the admission fee -- but it also makes sense. Keeps the weirdos at bay and the money is used for upkeep, preservation and maintenance. 

The Garden is a sight to behold. It is the oldest public Japanese garden in the United States and has quite a history behind it. The garden is very picturesque -- very peaceful, calm and naturey. There are native Japanese plants, ponds, statues, bridges, pagodas and koi fish throughout. Stone walkways wend there way through the serene garden and take you to a large buddha, tea house and gift shop. 

Tried to get into Golden Gate Park on a Sunday and it was nuts and left. Went again the following Friday and it was great -- parking available and much lighter crowds. 

I definitely plan on strolling through again and want to check out the tea selections.
author: Nicole D.

description: I thought this place was great! I had read reviews about this before coming here and I saw many people said it was expensive to get in. I didn't think it was expensive at all. I was with 3 people and admission for all of us was only $20. It wasn't expensive and if you are a person that loves nature and the Asian style theme, you'll love it! Staff was very friendly and this is a great place to take pictures. Sure, you probably don't want to spend more than an 1-2 hours there, but it's worth the experience. You don't see something like this everyday and if you need something to help pass time. This is definitely a good place to go!
author: Gen D.

description: Small compared to other japanese gardens I've gone. No student discount and the lady at the door was not polite when I asked about it. I think $8 is too much for such a small place. They don't even have a lot of plants with different colors, it's mainly green which is nice but I can get that in any park for free.
author: Vii L.

description:
I've lived in the Bay Area for nearly ten years now. I had lived in San Francisco itself for about two of those, making several trips to Golden Gate Park, yet I had truly never "seen" this place until the day I toured the Japanese Tea Garden with my sweetheart.

Some people don't like doing "touristy" things within the cities they reside in. That makes sense when you're talking about Fisherman's Wharf or other cheezy places you'll find your average "Touron", (as my Yelp buddy Cherylynn N. would call them) meandering about. However when speaking of beautiful landmarks such as this, it's one of the many reasons SF is my favorite city in the world. If you haven't been here, you are truly missing out on a fabulous "only in SF" experience.

From the well manicured gardens to the traditional Japanese structures, everything is beautiful without feeling fake or cheezy. We had an awesome time exploring all the various plants, koi ponds, and statues. Everything is so perfectly landscaped you can see the love that is put into it's design and upkeep.

The gift store is admittedly touristy but they did have some pretty cool unique made in China trinkets that were tempting, but probably can be found for several times cheaper elsewhere. If you happen to come here with a loved one, be sure to stop off at the actual Tea House to share a tea together. It's a beautiful setting for which to do so.

If you live in the area, you owe it to yourself to check it out. I'm sure it's even more gorgeous in the spring months when the Cherry Blossoms among the other flora are in full bloom. I have to say a special thank you to my babygirl for showing me a wonderful time in this marvelous location.
author: John B.

description:
Must-see for nature lovers and those interested in Japanese culture and aesthetics. This is probably the best Japanese Garden in the United States, on par with Seattle's. It is amazing how well-cultivated and florid this garden is despite California's often hot and dry air. If only this garden were better appreciated by visitors.

Unfortunately, most Americans do not understand the purpose of a Japanese garden or how to enjoy one- to quietly view, think, savor, reflect, pause, sit. In Heian times the colors and types of plants and rocks would evoke famous poetry and people would put it all together in recognition. Viewing gardens can be a spiritual if not religious experience. Our culture today is nowhere near as refined as that. Maybe it's just the times we live in, but on busier days, there is constant stream of people imposing themselves in front of each view, taking selfies. I thought to myself- "why not just tear up the trees and take them home with you as adornments to your magnificent self?" They seem obsessed with capturing the beauty of the gardens as accessories to their own faces in pictures. I picked up litter and candy wrappers left by visitors, and some young instagram-generation 20-somethings were playing awful autotuned R&B music in the tea pavilion as the rest of us tried to enjoy the otherwise serene surroundings with matcha and food pairings. Sorry if my review of the garden ended with a critique of our cultural idiosyncrasies- but perhaps this garden is the antidote. Perhaps more education at the front gate would help people know what they are looking at.
author: X S.

description: A wonderful place to visit, especially if you can appreciate a peaceful view and some delicious tea. Bring a camera, if you're into picture taking, and definitely check out the tea house and all it has to offer.
author: Nicole K.

description:
If you arrive between 9:00am and 10:00am on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, it is free admissions.  Other than that, it is $7, but $7 admissions is inexpensive.  I think for those who appreciate cherry blossoms and koi fish ponds and pretty bridges, this is the perfect place to be.  It was pretty to experience for me, but other than serving a visual purpose, it did nothing else.  I did not learn anything during my visit.

As everyone has already mentioned, visiting their onsite tea-house is a must.  It was a very warm day so I opted for their iced green tea and requested it "to go" so that I could walk around with it.  The iced green tea was more expensive than what I'd usually pay at $3.75, but it was the smoothest iced green tea I've ever had and well worth the splurge.
author: Crystine W.

description:
In planning a trip to the city, my 12-year old daughter expressed interest in seeing the Japanese Tea Garden.  Since we were already planning on visiting the nearby California Academy of Science, we added it to the list.  As an added bonus, we were going on a Friday, which has free admission from 9am-10am.

We hit some traffic, but managed to arrive about 9:30 so were still able to benefit from the free admission.  We strolled around the meandering paths and climbed over the stone and rock bridges.  There were huge koi fish in some of the ponds.

My daughters climbed over the moon bridge.  Not to be outdone, I also climbed atop the bridge.  The climb up wasn't so bad, but coming down, I felt like I was going to slip and fall; it's pretty steep.

We only spent about an hour there, so I was glad we were able to skip the entrance fee; not sure it's worth the price of admission, but it is definitely a must-see during the free admission time.

All in all, it is a beautiful place.
author: Richard G.

description: Great place to decompress.  Worth the admission price ($7 non-resident).  Did not want to leave the serenity of the garden and return to the real world.  Ordered the Dorayaki ($3.21) at the cafe, was not worth the money.  Total price $10.21
author: Jeff W.

description:
Went here as a tween with my parents and brothers to give us some culture while visiting our Aunt and Uncle in Berkley. Remembered it being cute, kitschy (loved the tall bridge!), charming spot where we sat outside in the tea garden and had tea. Being a 12 year old wasn't too fond of the tea or appreciate that part of the experience, but as an adult now that perception has changed. Went back last summer when I visited my brother who had newly moved to Palo Alto. 
Did it have the same charm? Yes! 
Was the tea even better? Yes!
Being a adult, I appreciated the fresh loose leaf tea I had (Green Jasmine) and being a green tea conssisuer (or at least a regular green tea drinker) remember saying this is the best green tea I've ever drank. I also noticed that they had prepepared sushi and ice cream bars! along with cookies and other snacks. Although we didn't partake at them just eating lunch. Gosh, if they had ice cream bars when I visited as a tween maybe I would have enjoyed that experience even more! Maybe they did and my parents didn't let us get any back them. 
I think there is quite a charm to sitting outside looking around at the beautiful scenery and drinking tea.
author: Lisa P.

description:
$5 residence $7 adult

It's a real small garden but has a lot of interesting facts in there. Go on a sunny day during spring when flowers are in bloom. They have koi fish and squirrels that they take care of. 

If you're lucky you can be there at the time the feeder comes to feed the squirrels.

The staff is friendly and so are the animals. They also have a tea house. It's pricey but it's perfect for a first date. They only have teeny snacks but its all Japanese.

It's all about the experience. I wouldn't come again though. Entry is too much.
author: Lynn C.

description:
I hadn't been here in several years, but not much has changed with the Japanese Tea Garden in San Francisco. Still a great gem within Golden Gate Park and plenty of photo opportunities and things to see withing the gardens. The admission-free hours are 9-10 AM on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday (I can't ever come during that timeframe, however), otherwise admission is $7 (last time I came in 2009, it must have been $5 or something like that). Still, $7 is worth the cost ($5 if you reside in San Francisco)! It's certainly a popular tourist spot, so expect plenty of crowds anytime of day, year-round.

The garden has its own tea house where you can order various Japanese food products like edamame (soy beans for those who don't know what edamame is), mochi, and so forth. I didn't actually purchase any food or tea as it was really over-priced, but I'm sure it would've tasted good in any case.

I'll certainly drop by from time to time, hopefully when it's a sunny and clear day (these past two times were foggy and cloudy!).
author: Paul N.

description: Park itself was ok. But it was way too pricey for what you get, the price is like 8 dollars per person.
author: Isak R.

description:
If you've ever been to Japan and experienced actual Japanese tea and the ceremony/process involved, this can probably give you an idea of what it would be without ever having to book a flight over to Japan just for tea (well, you should head to Japan for many reasons!!!!!). Just a side note: Careful walking up the slippery rocks to the tea garden.

The ambiance of the gardens compliments grabbing a hot tea and trying the various Japanese treats available. They servers here are even dressed in traditional Japanese garments, which I love!!!!  The kuzimochis here were not bad, and the edamame here, they don't schrimp! A tiny treat that won't break the bank to round our your experience in the gardens.

A must try if you're already in the gardens.
author: Sophia C.

description: The grounds are absolutely beautiful!  The pavilion,  stone lantern,  zen garden, bridge, stone path and buddha were all highlights.   The food was good.  I had the tea sandwiches,  one was a little spicy.
author: Mary F.

description: This place is a joke- 8 bucks for a bunch of dead looking koi fish in a dirty pond. Don't fall for this trap the rest of the park is way better and guess whT FREE!!! Would not recommend to anyone unless you want a bunch of half ass photo ops
author: Jake B.

description:
My boyfriend and I visited the tea gardens at the end of March 2014. We actually were supposed to come on one day, but couldn't, for the life of us, find parking. So we did something else and came back the next day. Since it was my first time visiting San Francisco, I read that this was a place that had to be visited. I'm glad I did. 

The place was lovely. When we got there, it was quite gloomy. You have to pay $7 to get in, I believe, and $5 if you are a SF resident. There were a number of paths, a rock garden, and a bridge that you had to climb. By the time we had walked one of the paths, it started raining. So it made it kind of difficult for me to climb the bridge and walk across the rock path in the ponds. 

I spotted a little teahouse that had a number of people sitting at. I got the sencha tea, which came in a little pot, and my boyfriend got the hojicha. We also got miso soup and the green tea cheesecake, which I found awesome. By this time, it was pouring, but the perfect setting for enjoying my tea. The little pot with my tea had enough to fill three teacups, so it made it worth the $3.75 that we paid. The hojicha was $3.50, cheesecake $5.50, and miso soup $3.95. 

Afterwards, we decided to go to the little gift shop near the teahouse. There were two little old Japanese ladies who were just sweet as pie. The shop had various items, such as tea sets, chopsticks, post cards, and origami jewelry. We ended up only getting a couple post cards before we left. 

Overall, it was a great experience. I kind of wish it hadn't rained so hard since it made it difficult to see the entire garden. I also wasn't too fond of the admission price considering that most of the teahouse things were more on the expensive side. But I could understand why it had to be done that way. 

I can't wait until the next time I visit SF. This was definitely one of the highlights of our trip.
author: Reneesha R.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is a great spot in the Golden Gate Park to relax in a beautiful atmosphere.  Tranquil koi ponds, stone bridges, and delicious hot tea.  Would be a perfect spot to take a date if you are out for a walk in the area.
author: Paul W.

description:
My husband and I have been living in San Francisco for 7+ years and have never visited the Japanese Tea Garden...that all changed today. 

Our experience of the Japanese Tea Garden was amazing. We got there around 1PM on a Saturday and as soon as we entered, were approached by a woman doing a free tour courtesy of the SF City Guides. We just learned that SF City Guides has leads 60 tours a week all around San Francisco, all of which are free! We really enjoyed our tour guide, Christine. She did a great job of getting us through the different gardens fairly quickly and made the information/background of interesting and relatable. I'm so glad that we were able to take part in this tour. We learned so much about the history and the intentions of the aritsts. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND going to the garden during the time of a tour. It makes the experience so much more worth it and you'll end up appreciating the gardens so much more.

The gardens themselves are beautiful. It's amazing to see how much thought went into every piece put into the gardens. Although there were a lot of people visiting, we were still able to really enjoy our experience and take in the tranquil beauty. It's so peaceful and visually pleasing, we felt we could stay there all day long. 

We also visited the tea and gift shop. We had some tea ($4) and ate some mochi ($6) while we enjoyed the view. Tea was just okay but the mochi was pretty tasty.

I would definitely recommend going to the Japanese Tea Garden. But remember, go on a day of a tour!
author: Kaydee D.

description: Always a must stop for us when we visit San Fran.  The Japanese garden offers a tea garden.  Assortment of teas and light lunches and snacks are offered.  The Botanical gardens the day we visited were open to the public at no charge... not sure how often this happens.... but we did roam freely and enjoyed the main lawn to basque in the sun.
author: JP S.

description: Little pricy for a relatively small Japanese garden. Although it was pretty nice inside, the price should be about $5 to justify coming inside. Not much highlights aside from the Pagoda tower and the random semi circle bridge. There are colorful fishes throughout the ponds. Come here if you really have time to kill as there's not much going on inside.
author: TianChee S.

description:
The Japanese tea garden has been on my list of places to visit in SF forever! Finally made a trip up on a Friday morning and squeezed in just in time for the free admission Friday morning between 9-10 AM. If you miss the free admission, it's $7 to enter or $5 for SF residents. But they have free admission three days a week (Monday, Wednesday and Friday mornings from 9-10 am). 

Street parking was not very fun, but because we went early, we didn't have to park too far away from the park. There is a parking lot available, but we saw lots of free spots on our way in so we decided just to park a bit further for free. The street parking is for 4 hours which will give you plenty of time to visit the garden and explore some of the other neighboring parks as well. 

The tea garden is quite small, we finished wandering around in about half an hour. It was a lot of fun wandering around, the bridge is fun to climb, but is quite steep so make sure you're wearing appropriate shoes so you don't twist your ankle! 

A very nice small park, it has a cute gift shop and tea shop inside too.
author: Angel K.

description: We loved it. The gardens are amazing and the tea is wonderful. What a pleasure to visit!
author: Rick S.

description:
One of my favorite places from childhood, it's a must stop for visitors in San Fran.

The grounds are incredibly peaceful and picturesque. 

We stopped in the cafe for tea when we arrived, which I recommend. 

Don't forget the barrel arced bridge. Very fun.
author: Aaron S.

description: A must see garden when visiting S.F.; at least once. The grounds are beautifully kept and the koi fishes are interesting to watch. I struggled a bit climbing over the drum bridge. Unfortunately, I had forgotten my camera on that day, because every inch of the garden is very picturesque.
author: Nary L.

description: Came here to take my siblings and the guy at the front cashier/supervisor Chris (skinny, white, shaved head) charged my underage sister as an adult.  I asked for a refund in which he denied and I asked to speak to a supervisor which he said he was. I asked for his supervisor's name which he wouldn't provide.  His co-worker kindly provided me the name after he stormed off leaving his co-worker to manage a long line of guests.  This kind of service is uncalled for especially dealing with the public daily.  I'm calling his supervisor tomorrow and hope that actions are taken so that other tourists do not have to deal with his unkindly manner.  I know there are plenty of people deserving of his job.  Thank you.
author: Vanessa H.

description: Very bad cashier. Bad hospitality..... The garden too is waste of money. Not worth 8 bucks. I wouldn't recommend at all.
author: Shilpa H.

description: The Japanese tea garden is a nice place to walk around and relax. It is very cool to see the Japanese architecture and I loved the lily pond. We had a cup of tea at their cafe, which was okay, but the cafe area is nice and open into the rest of the garden. I recommend visiting here once as once is all you really need to take it all in. Not to mention, it's in golden gate park and surrounded by a bunch of other cool areas.
author: Sarah K.

description: Beautiful place! I love the scenery here. It is a pretty big place to walk around and explore. If you are also getting hungry, there is a place inside where you can eat and drink tea while enjoying the scenery.
author: Doris H.

description:
This place is incredible!  Absolutely stunningly beautiful.  It was one of my favorite places to visit in all of San Francisco.

My boyfriend and I spent a very LONG time here taking lots of pictures, admiring the beautiful scenery, and browsing the gift shop.  The garden is a lot bigger than I expected and we walked around it many times.

I loved all the colorful koi fish in the ponds, the unique sculptures, and, of course, the perfectly manicured bushes and plants.  The place gets pretty busy, but it wasn't too bad for a Sunday.  Even with all the visitors, the place is extremely peaceful and relaxing.

The $7 entry fee (for non-residents) is a little steep, but this place is *definitely* worth visiting.  I wish I could spend a little time here every week!
author: Sonya L.

description:
Can I get my $8 refund and 20 minutes spent walking around? 

This isn't anything extraordinary than going to a friend's backyard and seeing a few flowers.
author: Q L.

description:
This is a beautiful garden to walk around.
The cafe is nice to and had good miso and tea.
It's funny if you want to just go to have tea or a snack you need to pay to enter the gardens even if you don't walk around.
author: Cecilia B.
