description: Lovely relaxing place!! Enjoyed tea after the walk the ponds for the fish could be a little cleaner, bathrooms are clean and well kept. We had one of everything in the menu. From green tea, tea sandwiches, green tea ice cream, and the rice candy
author: Bee C.

description:
Definitely a favorite during my trip to San Francisco- I loved this Japanese Tea Garden. It's a hidden sanctuary within the sanctuary of the de Young park. 

After walking through the beautiful grounds, my friend and I sat down to have some tea and house cookies at the little tea house. It's tradition. I also HAD to have a miso soup because I was starving and it was freakishly cold. In July. To quote Mark Twain, "The coldest winter I ever saw was the summer I spent in San Francisco."

Oh well, I can't complain too much about the weather. I just sat there, sipping my hot green tea, and kept wishing that moment would last forever. I felt peaceful, calm and happy. 

If I'm ever super wealthy, I think I'll have a Japanese style garden complete with koi in my backyard. Oh and some peacocks. I want some peacocks.
author: Leslie D.

description:
Although it has become more of a tourist spot, the Japanese Tea Garden is still a nice scenic walk for couples or visitors from out of the the city. 

Admission is $7.00/person, which is reasonable if you decide to spend more than 30 min to an hour here. The walk only takes about 10-15 minutes to venture through though, so an hour is considering the fact that you are reading the information on each statue, taking pictures, and hanging out at the tea shop. 

The tea cafe is at the center of the garden, with different traditional japanese teas such as the genmaicha and the sencha, or even a different touch of strong green tea shots (described to be much like green tea espresso shots). There are also snacks to pair with the teas, such as mochi, green tea crackers, tea cracker assortments, or sesame crackers. The mochi actually ran out on the day I was there, so I am assuming that this is a hot commodity. It looked pretty good from the box, but sadly, didn't have the chance to try it for myself.

Overall, the Japanese Tea Garden for some reason reminded me of a mini golf course, but it did have the nice koi fish pond or the extremely arched and high ladder that you have to monkey across. It's a great place for a date, or to walk around with a girlfriend, assuming that guys wouldnt like to come alone to places such as this. Would I come back again though? Probably not. This is more like a one time in your life thing, but it was worth the bucks.
author: Luby H.

description:
I love this place, I want to live there.  It's $5 bucks and you can wander around all day, heck you should bring a book and just stay.  To be surrounded by that level of beauty is good for anyone.

It is not wheel chair accesible fyi.
author: Sarah S.

description: Absolutely one of the most gorgeous and tranquil places I've been.  The gardens are truly breathtaking and most definitely worth the $7 admission fee.  It doesn't take more than 30 minutes to an hour to get through if you are just checking out the garden and not sitting down for tea.  This is great because you get to see a fantastic part of golden gate park without investing a ton of time.  I would have loved to sit and have tea in the tea house because the whole experience was just so calming and authentic.  Definitely a place worth checking out and they actually have free admission on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 9am to 10am, which would have been great to take advantage of had we known.
author: Sapna D.

description:
If I lived in San Fran, this would be a frequent stop for me. It was incredibly beautiful, pristine and aesthetically beautiful to look at. I was with my husband so our visit was shorter than it would have been had I been by myself (not a whole lot of patience). 

I would love to go back and quietly stroll through it at my own pace and take three times the amount of photos. Not too big and I got lucky since it was not too crowded and the weather was perfect! 

We stopped in the little shop and brought back some kitschy stuff that I actually still have! 

If in town for a short time, I would make room to visit the garden for sure!
author: Brenda P.

description: The teahouse is so peaceful. Especially during the week. Make sure to grab a bowl of miso soup and iced geeen tea!
author: Alexandra E.

description: Enjoyed the Japanese tea garden. It was way smaller than expected but beautiful nonetheless! I love nature and being outside so I especially loved being out there. The only thing I absolutely hated were the groups of tourists everywhere! You could barely walk anywhere without having to wait for people to take all of their selfies, pretty annoying if you ask me. I got stuck with some awesome Norwegian people on top of the bridge because some people would not move because of their selfie taking, after so long we all decided we'd just push through, (you could feel the hate burning through our bodies) but come on guys, have some respect and let others enjoy the place too! Aside from all of the ridiculous people, I loved the scenery! Would visit again despite the groups & groups of people.
author: R A.

description: Very beautiful garden and a nice relaxing walk. I had a great time looking at the scenery and the koi fish in the water. It was quiet and not very crowded when I went. I had plenty of time to check everything out without feeling rushed. There's also a gift shop and somewhere to get some tea!
author: Gabrielle T.

description: Great place to visit while in San Francisco. I went here with my sisters. Pretty small grounds but very peaceful. I know it's important to take photos of the visit but don't forget to take in the atmosphere. Put your phone down for a minute. Find a spot to sit, and just watch. An absolute must is having a cup of tea while you are there. I had the matcha tea with a confectioners sugar treat. $8.50 for that alone but hey it was a once in a life time experience for me. My sisters had the jasmine tea and the hojicho tea. I tried both and they were both great. We also ordered a small tray of tea cookies and the matcha ice cream. It's best to dip the cookies in the tea. That's the best way to have them. 8 dollars for one adult ticket. On Mondays Wednesdays and Fridays its free to get in from  I believe 8am-11am. No student discounts, but I think there might be military. Best parking was underground across the way for the de young museum. No parking validations. No first hour free. $4.75 each hour. But they have multiple places to visit since it is located in the national park. Very shaded within the tea garden so you are nice and cool the whole time. Beautiful place to visit.
author: Krista P.

description: The tea took 20 minutes to come out and cold and I paid $9 for half cup
author: Alvaro B.

description: Okay so it was $8 to get in! It's a decent size of a place not very big but if you take your time and actually take in every moment of it then it's worth it. It was beautiful and peaceful. Also a great place to snap some pictures on a trip. Parking was free on the street in certain areas so that was helpful. Cool place to visit
author: Destiny J.

description: This is a must if you were in San Francisco.   There's so much history here and wonderful things to see and experience.  Are you taking a lot of pride in the garden.   We had a nice light lunch here and enjoyed our time wondering through the gardens exploring.
author: Grey H.

description: This place was a little pricey for an entrance fee. I thought the garden would be a little bigger but not. It was still pretty to wall around it. But wasn't amazing....
author: Connie L.

description: What a huge disappointment! The structures are rotting and need paint, there were at least three dead koi and not many living in the pond, and $8 a person to walk through an unkempt garden? I do not recommend this. Stick with the museums.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Ornate, botanical, unique, beautiful.. so many words to describe this trail. Well worth the $8 entry fee if you appreciate relaxtion and nature. There are so many rare plants and trees to see here and there's no better location than Golden Gate Park for such a place.

They have a gift shop as well as a sit-down tea cafe with traditional options to enjoy. I never get tired of coming here and it never seems to get too crowded.
author: John I.

description: I've been here a few times and have enjoyed it each time. Be warned, it gets packed on weekends and in summer, and I'm not sure it's worth $8 per visit for more than one visit. The gardens aren't huge but they're lovely and relaxing. There's lots of flora and fauna, my favorites being the bonsai trees and the koi fish in the pond. While most of the garden is quiet and relaxing (depending on the crowd), the moon bridge is always packed with tourists taking turns climbing to the top to pose for photos. The tea house menu is not extensive but it is expensive.
author: Gabrielle L.

description: I was impressed with the free city guide by Kimberly.  Wealth of knowledge and bright character, she made this visit one of my most memorable tours in SF.
author: Sa B.

description: Completely loved my experience here. Sadly some of it was under construction but other than that the scenery was stunning with history. Would definitely come here again.
author: Alexandra J.

description:
BREWING THE BAY: Abbreviated Japanese chakai ceremony (macha tea)

UPDATE: Regarding the Japanese tea ceremony that is offered here, it can best be described as a sort of "nodate meets chakai" ceremony without the traditional awning of cherry blossoms over you (since the ceremony is performed under the roof of the cafe). However, if you are less interested in authenticity and more interested in just experiencing hot matcha tea, Japanese sweets and a friendly Japanese hostess in a kimono amidst the gorgeous garden, then this is right for you. 

The ceremony more or less follows the rituals of a chakai, with both koicha (thick matcha) and usucha (thin matcha) prepared. The koicha is poured into one bowl that is passed along and shared by all the guests. The usucha is served to each guest in an individual bowl. The entire ceremony lasts less than an hour and at $25, isn't exactly cheap. However, the hostess's enthusiasm for Japanese tea traditions cannot be questioned. It is very clear that she loves what she does. Plus, participants get to keep a cute little Japanese paper fan as a souvenir. 

Overall, I enjoyed the ceremony (we had some great, funny, British guests in our group), but I definitely prefer the real deal. 3.5 stars

..........................................

I first visited the Japanese Tea Garden four years ago on a trip to San Fran with my college friend. I remember being awed by its stunning yet simple beauty. There is something about Asian gardens--the exotic flora, the unusual shapes, the different foliage, the overall ambience, that makes them so different from "Western" gardens. I will also note that I am the world's most un-photogenic person (I tend to look like an amorphous blob in most pics), but I actually thought I looked decent in the pictures my friend took of me in the garden. Of course, it's pretty much impossible to take a bad photo in this place.

I'm delighted to find that, four years later, the garden is still as beautiful as ever, if not more overrun by tourists. However, if you are strategic about your visit and go during off hours (my suggestion would be a morning/early afternoon on a weekday), you can usually avoid a lot of the crowds. Sipping hot tea while looking out over the garden is surely one of the simplest, most serene pleasures in life.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Took my mom here for her bday in the middle of the week. I have to say it's really beutiful! We arrived around 12:45pm noticed they had a freee SF city walk tour and we signed up.. After paying $7 pp at the entrance. Our guide was real pleasant. Very knowlegable.. but really.. I wanted TEA!!! However.. I did learn Memoirs of a geisha had a scene here.. Of couse we took pictures..
There are some steep steps.. going up or down.. they say you get rid our karma..
 I sure did walk those steps.. Careful not to fall.

Wonderful.. Made my mom happy? yes! quality time? yes!! Smack in the middle of GGP..
author: Veronica S.

description:
This place is very beautiful. A oasis of tranquility so close to the bustle of San Francisco. Very peaceful and very beautiful. However, it is also very popular, and the park in general can be very crowded on weekends, which takes away from the introspective mindset induced by the sights and sounds of the the gardens. That said, don't miss it. Go for a walk, bring your camera, experience cultivated nature right in your own back yard! 

While you are at it, be sure to try the tea. There isn't a traditional tea ceremony here, but they do serve a limited menu of very tasty teas. As well as some authentic Japanese snacks. Don't worry, for those who have heard stories of Japanese snacks, these are all very benign and tasty. I tried the cookies, the sesame was my favorite. I also tried rice candies, and really enjoyed the cool sweet rice jellies (mango, green tea, and strawberry.)

I look forward to visiting this place again! :)
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Nature at its best. I came here when in San Fran on vacation.  From NYC so we have the best of the best.....Central Park so I wasn't really expecting much based on my experience with our park. I first went to the museum and went to the free observation deck on 9 th floor, then spent some time at the cafe before I came here. 

It's such a breathtaking place. I loved every minute of it and took lots of pictures. I wanted to purchase some Japanese ornaments but the people at the store were 1) very slow 2) very unattentive - even after I asked to check out, nobody looked at me or even paid attention that there was a customer at the till. The male was busy counting cash at the register, there was another lady busy behind the counter but I wasn't sure what she was doing because there were 3 customers behind me all waiting to be served. There was an old lady in the back room but she also looked like she didn't care. Even after I left the ornaments on the counter and started to walk out....slowly....still nobody cared. Maybe it's a San Fran way of doing things but coming from NYC, If I don't receive a good service or wait more than 2 minutes (when no one else is been served) we just walk out and find the best good thing.
author: Amanda G.

description: Prices went up $8 for non resident and $2 for our kids. We were there less than 30 minutes but it is very pretty and worth the money to me. I like to take photos, and meander along slowly as my kids pull me along " Hurry UPPPppPPp!!"
author: Ash F.

description:
My little niece was visiting from out of town and I wanted to do something a little different with her since she is now a "tweenager" and able to enjoy the beauty in life.

We found street parking after looking for only maybe 10 minutes on a Saturday afternoon. We were pretty lucky! Made the short walk to the Tea Garden and didn't have to wait in line. Paid our cash and in we went. 

She had so much fun exploring the area and taking photos of the beautiful flowers, Cherry Blossoms were in bloom and it was a simply beautiful and funny day. 

After exploring every single inch of the garden we went into the gift shop to pick out a keepsake and then back out we went to re-explore and take photos. 

I love this place. It's calm. It's beautiful. It's fair priced. 

They have done some renovations since the last time I visited. The tea/ snack area is very upgraded. We did not stop to have tea this time around since we had reservations elsewhere, but I would like to stop in again soon and test out their tea to see if the service it better.
author: Meghan L.

description: Perfect tea house inside the Japanese tea garden. Their green bean and green tea ice cream are the must tries! We buy tickets to taste them every time we go to San Francisco!
author: Carl Y.

description:
MWF, 9am-10am... it's FREE, after that $7pp.  Took Fri off and took Bart to Embarcadero Station, then took Muni (get transfer to save .25c off $2) and took the N-Judah Outbound train.  Time spent: 1.5hrs fm Bart & Muni to get to GGP.

Got there by 9am and walked around by myself, it's pretty big for a Japanese Garden, but still doesn't take more than 20 min to see everything.  It's good for photos.  Then I walked around again, luckily I saw a group of people w/ a guide so rushed over there.  It was a CityGuide tour at 9:30am:
http://www.sfcityguides.org/desc.html?tour=105
or this one I didn't go on:
http://www.sfcityguides.org/desc.html?tour=102

Saw temples, a sitting Buddha, a pyramid thing near the entrance on the Rt which the guide call "Mt Fuji": 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/JcVzpOTp7OH6l8AsM_wGdQ?select=hoPthJNjaTnznExZz9m1uQ

guide call Sunken Garden, man-made waterfalls, koi fishes, Moon bridge (cool to walk/take pics over that crazy looking bridge), gift shop, & tea house to get snacks.

I didn't do the 2nd half of the tour, and instead got the Sen-Cha Set $3.95 - it's a small one person tea set w/ a teapot that can serve about 3 small cups of green tea & 3 tiny mochi cake.  I also got a Lg Hawaiian mochi cake for $3.  Total $7.61 paid in CASH, credit card u gotta pay at the gift shop.

Separate bathrooms available on the Rt after entering.

Recommended.
author: Ann L.

description: Great place to walk around get to know. Got in for free before 10am which always good :) took about 15 minutes to walk around entire garden
author: Luis O.

description:
Beautiful trees and carp ponds--a wonderful place to take photos and a
must for tourists to San Francisco. 

Plus, there's a small shelter where lovely teas & traditional snacks are served. There is something about this oasis in Golden Gate Park that exudes calm and encourages peaceful thoughts. Not much for small children to enjoy because of the rather narrow paths you walk.
author: Lynn S.

description: Its nice, but small. Especially as you pay 8 bucks yo get in and youve seen everything in 20mins, including frequent blockages on the bridges as people want to touch the koi fish.
author: Peter K.

description:
It is so nice to wander around this place. It was only $8 to get in and I spent ages wandering through the gardens. The little gift shop is super cute with some nice items, some cheap and some more expensive. This is where I bought my paper crane earrings (yes, they are little paper cranes that have been lacquered) and I love them. Everytime I am in San Francisco, I make sure to stop in. 

Be sure to check when they have free entry - from memory, its Monday and Wednesday morning but don't quote me!
author: Cat W.

description: Oh, what a place to be a koi! To be a fat, slippery koi fish gliding under the water, looking up at the tourists and their guide books, picking up spoken bits of Italian and Korean under the cool water and mossy rocks. And to be a koi in such a place would require no entrance fee, a bit pricey at $9... But the koi have a beautiful place to swim filled with more shades of green than you could count. Worth the visit, to bring a book and drink one cup of tea with fish of Golden Gate Park.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
The Tea Garden is beautiful, but the admission price is seriously inflated. Officially, I believe the grounds run about 5 acres, but the visitor paths let you see a narrower swath of that. If you stop for a lot of photos, you might spend 30 minutes walking around the grounds; more realistically, exploring the gardens will only occupy 15 minutes or so. $7 ($5 for city/county residents) is pretty steep for that, especially when it's surrounded by all the free-to-access beauty in Golden Gate Park.

The tea service isn't bad, but when you're being jostled by a crowd of tourists it's a pretty far cry from the contemplative tea garden experience you're probably hoping for.

Well-worth it to come over during the free hours (as of this writing: MWF from 7:30-10:00am, but check the website for up to date info), but I can't recommend paying the entrance fee.
author: Sean T.

description:
Me and my boyfriend were looking for the conservatory of flowers, got lost, and ended up here.
First of all, this place cost $16 for admission, $8 per person. And all you do is literally walk around a garden. Whhhat? 
It's a tourist trap for sure. I picked up a key chain that was the size of a thumb print and it was way overpriced. The other items were little charms you grant wishes on, blah blah blah.
The tea shop was also overpriced. It's just literally $4 a cup of tea, and itty bitty snacks. The table next to us got a platter of fortune cookies. And they serve tiny tea sandwiches (looked like ham and cheese) that wouldn't even satisfy the appetite of a 2 year old. Shout out to the cute older worker who worked there though. He gave this woman her tea and then said "would you like to know the story behind this brew?" Thats the type of stuff tourist love. I think they hired him because he looks like the type of guy to serve tea in a small tea shop.
There was a lot of older people there, and this one couple sectioned off an area so they could take engagement photos, which was in inconvienent to the rest of us. 
There's also a rock zen garden that was combed, I thought "hey maybe we can comb it as part of our expirence" but it was gated.
If you want a visual representation it's kinda like the movie Mulan when she's walking around her garden singing. 
Overall, it's Pretty, but i think it should be open to the public for free.
author: Tina P.

description: Came here at 9:50 on a Friday morning to get in for free, and I am so glad we took the time to explore this place. It is such a gem. A place of serenity that you still feel even though there are lots of tourists around. We spent about 35 minutes here as we walked through all the paths and took photos. We didn't have any tea but it looked like the people there were enjoying themselves.
author: Ashley P.

description:
Super nice, really peaceful, fun to be in, fee to enter and theres some free days.
If you're a tourist like me in SF, come visit the Japanese Tea Garden!
author: Hong H.

description: I love this place it is so peaceful and relaxing. We went here and had a blast we snacked at the tea house and drank Macha after Macha so you know after a few we so hyped we went up and down the park and some. Defiantly the place to come and explore.
author: Vikm P.

description:
MWF, 9am-10am... it's FREE!!!!!

After breakfast at Arts, I walked over to Golden Gate Park. I finally came to the tea garden on a day when it was free!!! wheee!!! :D

This garden is definitely not as big as other tea gardens I've been to. You could easily go through it in less than 30 minutes. But if you're taking your time...taking pictures of the koi fish, pagoda, buddha statue, and plants, and then drinking tea at their tea house I'd say you need about 1.5 hours here. hahaha

Coming this early in the morning, it was difficult to take pictures. The sun was super bright and I was always taking pictures in the wrong direction. :P

I enjoyed drinking some green tea in the tea house overlooking the pond and garden. I got the classic green tea with some sweet rice cakes (mango, strawberry, and lychee). The mango felt the freshest and was the softest. The other rice cakes were a bit harder and almost felt dry and old? =\ The green tea was very soothing and relaxing. They give you a white tea cup and a small teapot with about 3 cups worth of tea inside. All this for only $3.95! Pay cash at the register, or pay with a credit card up in the gift shop!

Loved the zen garden and just walking around the Japanese Tea Garden!!! Can't wait to bring my parents when they're in town! :)
author: CeCe C.

description: I had a great escape from this crazy world. It is so hard to find quiet and peaceful place in  the big cities. I came one hour before closing. It was almost empty. I enjoyed it so much! $7 is nothing for the break that you are getting from your everyday routine. I would love to come back again and again and again( left all my coins in the little ponds :))
author: Katie B.

description:
I had not visited the Japanese Tea Garden since my days of grade school in San Francisco.  That was many decades ago so when one of the tea garden's chief gardeners offered us the opportunity to walk through the gardens last Sunday many of us were happy to oblige.

I was among a group of nearly 30 One Brick volunteers who cleaned up an overgrown area of weeds and blackberry behind the Japanese Tea Garden.  Working side by side with three gardeners from the San Francisco Recreation and Parks Department we dug out a huge section of assorted weeds, non native plants and overgrown grass exposing the dark, moist soil underneath where some volunteers replanted new plants and trees.  Once replanted we covered up the newly exposed soil with fresh bark brought down from a huge mulch pile nearby while those same volunteers created a fence line using discarded twigs from some of the nearby elm and sycamore trees.

Since I rarely back down from an aerobic challenge I, along with a few other hearty volunteers took on the task of pushing the pulled foliage up a hill via wheelbarrow to a compost pile, discarding our plants and refilling our wheelbarrows with mulch to take back down the hill.  It was a great workout and for over two hours I felt the incredible burn on my arms and my legs.  As is usually the case with One Brick work parties we finished our project in record time.

The gardens were fairly empty that afternoon.  I think several days of rainfall played a role in keeping many park visitors away, but the sun came out in full bloom that morning / afternoon, and I really enjoyed my time inside the tea garden.

Despite the presence of a few small groups of visitors the garden was relatively quiet while I was there.  I enjoyed the peace so much that when a core group of our volunteers walked away to grab some lunch nearby I stayed behind in the tea garden.  The hot sun felt good on my tired muscles, and I loved the sound created by the two little waterfalls inside along with the chirping birds and the occasional rush of wind.

Most of the visitors seemed respectful of each other by speaking softly and moving around slowly.  During my visit, I took a load of photos entirely without the presence of other visitors in my compositions.  

Some things like the Japanese Tea Garden I take for granted having lived in San Francisco all my life, but it's times like I experienced last Sunday that helps me realize what a special city I live in.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Japanese inspired garden with japanese maples, bamboo, bonsai, koi ponds, and pagoda...nice place to take a stroll when it's actually sunny.

Took engagement photos here and it proved challenging because of the crowds and kids, but for just enjoyment, I'd say it's a nice spot to visit.  Admission is $7, I believe.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Cute garden here, you do have to pay to go in.. $7.00. Me and my bf took some DSLR pictures and they all came out excellent. Super clean area and people are relatively nice. It is a great stroll in the park. bring your gf here for a date, I bet she will be impressed. I definitely enjoyed it here and I have never discovered this place until recently.
author: Yuri Y.

description:
Great garden to visit!

When you first walk in, and start walking around, it seems like a small garden, but what you really don't notice until later is that there are lots of little paths that wind around.  In every corner that you turn to, you'll find something different.  Whether it's the statue of Buddha, a pagoda, temple, zen garden, pond, waterfall, bridge...  I don't want to spoil any more secrets (hopefully there are a few left).

Just steps away from the hustle and bustle of the city, you will find your inner peace in this garden.  Everything is so calm and serene.  Even if there are a lot of other visitors around, you won't feel crowded.

This is a great place to walk around if you want to clear your mind, or if you want to find a pretty place for a photo shoot.

I definitely need to visit more often!
author: Audrey C.

description:
Want to take some one on a gorgeous, thoughtful, fun, conversation-inspiring, affordable, and absolutely adorable date?  Take them here.  

I found this place to be absolutely beautiful.  A manicured fantasy garden, flowing waterfalls, a pair of koi swimming leisurely under a statuesque bridge.  Fun little places for photo-ops that make everyone look hotter by virtue of the flattering scenery.

Japanese architectural masterpieces include pagodas, a tea house (which I need to come back and try!) and an adorable gift shop where you can get a little trinket that reminds you of just how pretty this garden is.  The staff was busy but very friendly.  

I just wish it was MY garden and nobody else was walking around and taking pictures there too.  I kept seeing all the other people and thinking "What are you doing in my fantasy garden?  What do you mean they didn't build this for me?  You're kids don't need to learn about plants!  Mine!"
author: Susan C.

description: It's hard to believe such a beautiful garden is hidden in the middle of the park. So elegant and peaceful inside the garden. Even thought we went on a holiday weekend full of visitors, we still were able to enjoy the beauty of the garden, the architecture and design.
author: Kyoko T.

description: Very relaxing place, quiet with beautiful scenery and good tea. Downsides are that it's expensive ($8 for a non-resident to get in plus $5ish for tea) and long lines/wait for tea if it's busy. That being said, not many places you can enjoy a cup while looking out over manicured trees and coy ponds.
author: Andrew S.

description: It's absolutely beautiful here, but I would like to note that I have been in the summer time (totally gorgeous) where as the weather hasn't been all that and the plants didn't seem as plentiful. It looks like they had some work going on in the ponds (is that what they're called?) so hopefully more is planted. I've eaten at their little cafe in the past which was cute and I watched an older woman with her squirrel friends. It really is an adorable place, but take it slowly and romantically.
author: Vannessa C.

description:
Walked through the Golden Gate park in order to find this garden. Had a beautiful walk! It was a Saturday afternoon and it was lovely. 
We finally arrive and its only $7 to get in buuuut you can see the beauty from the outside as well and hear the serene music. 
If you have time, pay and check it out!
author: Harlow H.

description: It's a beautiful and clean garden. Good experience for couples and elderly people. Not much of a walk. I've been with kids and teens they don't seem interested except for the kids did enjoy the fishes in the pond and taking picture imitated a statue. I was expecting a lot more, but I won't take stars for that.
author: Shimmy S.

description:
San Francisco residents, slap that ID on the ticket kiosk counter with pride, this is a true SF gem. 

It's a small but valuable space conveniently located near the 9th avenue Golden Gate Park entrance. (7 minute walk). I'd recommended amending it to your "tourist day" itinerary, (we all take these days, right?) preferably on a weekday to avoid those crowded weekend days. Walk about, breathe the air, admire the green, snap photos next to the pagodas, and puppy-talk to the koi fish who seem to have a most relaxing lifestyle. 

It's a nice way to spend $5 (city residents, $7 for non residents). My Japanophile tendencies and trinket-cravings brought me to the gift shop eventually, but after a quick peek I stepped right out due to the expected priciness. 

After you leave for more touristy adventures, may I recommend the De Young Harmon Observatory Tower? It's nearby, free, and you get an amazing 360 view of all the stuff!
author: Chelsea B.

description:
$7 entrance fee was not reduced when we wanted a quick tea 1 hour before closing, and guess what? They serve you tea and snacks in to-go cups and containers starting then as well. If I wanted overpriced tea in a paper cup, I wouldn't pay an extra $7 for the experience. 

But, the garden is much more empty than usual 1 hour before closing. It doesn't mean other patrons are any less focused on taking 50 pictures and making you wait, making a nice walk through the garden interrupted and touristy. 

The gardens are pretty and the tea and snacks are good (if you get there before they stop serving them in real ceramic tea cups and plates...), but for having an entrance fee, this place is crowded and not very peaceful.
author: Sara A.

description: I honestly expected the jap tea garden to be much bigger. Even though it was really pretty, I thought there were more to it!! They also charge non residents 2$ more.
author: Linda C.

description: Visited here before going to the Academy of Sciences. A little on the steep end price-wise...$7 because we're non-SF residents. The garden itself is really nice but not somewhere I'd go back only cause of the price and we pretty much saw everything. I'm glad we stopped by...took a lot of pictures and enjoyed the scenery. Very peaceful!
author: Tina M.

description: Peaceful, but like all things SF-- expensive. But worth it for me. Have been to Japan once and this place is spot on in terms of creating that vibe!
author: J H.

description: Loved it! Beautiful and a nice time to walk around and enjoy. Had a nice light lunch and purchased a few things in their gift shop. First time but loved it!
author: Allen O.

description: I love love love this place, especially the delicious mochi and unending lush and green foliage throughout the garden. A little expensive for admission for non-residents, but a beautiful treat for the eyes and fun place to visit with a date or friends/family. Definitely stop by the shop and look at all the cute chopsticks(rillakuma chopsticks!!), stuffed animals, and tea sets; they're quite cute:) Also I tried the fish-shaped red bean pancake and that was really good, too!:) 5 stars food and beauty, 3 stars price and size of the garden so it averages to 4 for me:)
author: Jenny L.

description: Super cute little spot inside Golden Gate Park! Great for a rest stop. The seating area was very picturesque. The staff were very polite and service was quick. I ordered green tea cheesecake and miso soup, and both were tasty. The walk around the garden was also very pleasant. I would totally recommend it!
author: Joanne H.

description: Not worth $8 - but it's a relaxing spot to walk off a meal. $3 tops for entry would be ideal.
author: Don W.

description:
A place of sanctuary within the city where you can feel tranquil or simply recharge. 

Sure it's geared towards the tourists but it doesn't mean the locals can't enjoy it. Why not enjoy this gift to the city once in a while with a peaceful walk around the place? Besides, it also provides an escape and you can imagine transforming yourself somewhere in Japan.

The Moon Bridge and Pagoda are worth seeing and exploring. They even filmed some scenes here from the movie Memoirs of a Geisha....but that novelty can quickly wear off as it has a lot more to offer, and more authentic.

If you wanna get your Zen on, then a trek here would do your mind some good.
author: John G.

description: Very beautiful... Not worth $8/person though... We expected something much bigger, however, it can be walked through in under 5 minutes(Assuming no pictures are taken).
author: Ricky D.

description: Nice little cafe for tea and snacks inside the Japanese Garden. The place isn't very big but it's a nice place to hang out for an hour or so.
author: Fei Z.

description:
Is there a more perfect Japanese garden in the US?  

The Japanese Tea Garden is well worth the entry fee.  Every blade of grass, every twig, every rock is in the exactly right spot.  The bridges, the water fall, the teas house, the statues, the pagodas, and the Buddha are perfectly placed.

Golden Gate Park is a wonder.  The Japanese Tea Garden is the epicenter of its wonderfulness.
author: Charles S.

description:
Our family has been to Japan and we visited this garden many years ago, so we went for a reunion on a recent visit. 

The grounds are beautiful. The buildings are cute and fun to walk around and have a peaceful visit. 

Things I wish were better. No student discount so a little pricey for us and our three college aged kids. No map available without paying (we already paid $35 to get in). Seating area for tea was congested and impossible for us to get a seat. And the focus was more snacks than tea. And I didn't see any/much options for tea desserts
author: Dave D.

description:
First time experience.

Japanese Tea Garden is another great place to visit when you're in Golden Gate Park.
The only drawback that I would complain about is that it is too small and on days it can seem like it's crowded. 
And will take a little longer to get those picture perfect pictures of the landscape.

There's lots of great landscape to feast your eyes on. Very pleasant.
It's a very relaxing way to spend your time.

Also look up in one of the Japanese towers and you will see a black bird.
I actually thought this was a decorative statue but it's real.
Plus you will also hear it in the distance.

Make sure you don't miss this place when in Golden Gate Park.
author: John S.

description:
If you have an hour to spare, lose yourself in this pristine garden which features koi ponds (I saw only one koi...), bonsais, bamboo trees, zen garden, shinto pagoda, bronze and stone sculptures intermingled with aesthetically pleasing greenery. 

My mom and I decided to go to the teahouse and sit for a moment.  We were ignored the first 15 minutes because there was just so many people there!  This part is really not essential to your experience, as I overheard the servers speaking in Chinese!  but if you're curious, tea service is $3.95 per person, which includes a pot of tea (choose among green, jasmine, oolong and the toasted rice. This is the loose leaf kind) and a bowl of crunchy assorted cookies and Japanese rice crackers. I don't get this, but you'll find fortune cookies in there too. 

On Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, plan to arrive at 9am. Not only will you get in for free, you'll find less tourists at the garden, which means more zen for you.
author: Janice C.

description: This place is fairly small but worth checking out. It doesn't take more than maybe 45 minutes to walk around depending how quickly you move through it. Be sure and check out the giant koi in the ponds.
author: David H.

description: The most romantic place ever!!! Always thought of going to check it out but never got a chance to do it. Today was the day we finally went there. Out of all the gardens I've been to this one is the best one!!! $8 admission is worth it. The scenery is beautiful. I recommend it for everyone
author: Paul O.

description:
The japanese tea garden has a nice and relaxing atmosphere...except for the fact that there are too many people here.  Okay I came on a saturday and it was pretty packed with people.  When I think of a zen garden...I think of of large garden where I can get lost with no noise and complete quiet and peace.  This place would have been awesome except its not that big and there are just too many people to really sit down and enjoy yourself.  In fact, its hard to even sit down and just absorb the beauty of the garden due to the sheer number of people walking through the paths. 
 
This garden feels too touristy, there are very nice picture taking spots where you can snap shots with your family.  They have nice ponds with koi fish and very unique trees.  But the place is very small, and I felt like I was just following the crowd walking down the path to the next "photo taking spot."  The admission of $7 was high since it took all of 15min to walk through the whole garden.  

This is one of those been there done that kind of spots, i am sure there are better japanese gardens in other parts of SF.  I wouldn't go out of your way to come here, you are better off walking around stow lake or just wandering around the golden gate park.
author: Terence N.

description:
Smaller than I remember from childhood visits, but isn't that always the way?

My boyfriend and I stopped by on vacation during the free hour on a rainy Monday morning.  Living in dry SoCal, it was lovely to be in the garden during a cold, light rain!  We stopped in for some hot tea and then walked to other parts of Golden Gate Park.  

I appreciate supporting places but I would not have wanted to pay $7 each.
author: Wendy B.

description: One of the quietest and most respectful places of nature I found in San Francisco, this was easily one of my favorite places visited on my trip. Located in Golden Gate Park, this spot on recreation will make you think you are in the Orient. The grounds are flawless and pristine, the trees and flowers native to Japan are everywhere in between statues, koi ponds, pools, bridges and temples, all gorgeous to look at. I could have easily spent more time here experimenting with photos, if you're a photog it's a place you could spend a few hours at least. I highly recommend it.
author: Darren F.

description: This place was amazing! Absolutely beautiful. I loved the koi and the zen garden. A lot of photo ops and the price is extremely reasonable.
author: Heather S.

description:
Came here after a trip to the deYoung.  I hadn't been in over a decade.  At first, I was somewhat surprised by the price to enter.  If you walk in with a large group it can be a bit pricey.  But, I figured why not. 

 It is quite well kept up.  I love the design.  It's really quite a small area in reality, however with the way the path and garden is set up, you can really walk around for quite a while enjoying it.  Very zen.  I love the huge Buddha.

Plenty of photo ops.  Plenty of chill time to catch up with an old friend or a new one and just chat.  Lots of tourists, but just ignore them and relax.  

The gift shop has some fun things but nothing that you couldn't find at a good Japanese store or market probably.  

Overall something fun to do if you haven't,  Or a fun place to take someone if they've never been.
author: Sean M.

description:
Very nice on a summer day!

It's a picturesque, lush forest of sensory delights.

Find a nice place to sit and relax, meditate on the beauty.

Tip: bring some refreshments, due to the lushness, it can get hot n' humid.

Tip: bring your close-up and wide angle lens.

Small entrance fee.

Tip: just south of the park, about a 15 minute walk is Inner Sunset, a charming neighborhood of varied casual restaurants.
author: Bert K.

description: There are two things this place could do to get a solid five stars. 1. Reduce either the price or the maximum allowance of people and most importantly 2. don't allow photos, especially noisy group photos. The entire point of this tea garden is to observe, meditate, feel at peace and most importantly shut your mouth. Where there's kids running around everywhere and people using selfie-sticks, it ruins the vibe. At the very least put up signs telling people not to talk. I won't blame people for taking photos because hey, it's permitted, but at least keep the noise down.
author: Clay C.

description: the Japanese tea gardens I will never forget . Everything is so beutiful here and the plants are bright green and it made me stress free and it was so relaxing . There was a feeling that felt like I was in accient Japan just looking for a sushi , I wish I could go back . The tea there is very good and authentic and so is the green tea cheese cake it's so yummy for my tummy . Great place for children and couples on a honeymoon . I would Recomend this to anyone under 70 I like it I love it and also the water is really fresh like pure 100%
author: Lucy C.

description:
One of my dreams came true - I've been to Japan without leaving USA :D
It was INCREDABLE!

I made a photo session for my company over there :)
Perfect place for beautiful and outstanding photos of posing little princesses ^^
All the attention was OURS! :)
Pond with fish, waterfall, statue of Buddha, stone bridges, fountains, sculptures... 

MUST SEE!!!

... The only thing that I was regretting I've missed was that sakura wasn't blooming :(

P.S Hours: 9AM - 5PM

Admission is around 5$ for residents and 7$ for non, for children it's 1.5$ for resident and 3$ for not. You can get free admission if entering before 10 AM on Monday, Wednesday, Friday though :)

NO holiday closures (+)

DON'T FORGET! to treat your family with tea and cookies at the bar :)
author: Olga B.

description: Nice day out with the family. The zen bring piece to you. Too bad it was overcrowded.
author: Wendy D.

description:
I think the Japanese Tea Garden was my favorite part of my visit to San Francisco. It's beautiful, relaxing, green, quiet, green (did I mention that already?), and serene. 

It's not a very large venue, but it is exceptionally maintained and landscaped. The bridges, pagodas, ponds, streams, and statues are all beautiful. In the middle of the afternoon on a Friday it was not busy at all. There was plenty of room to stroll through the gardens, hop across the stone bridges, and have a seat on a fence for a bit. 

There is admission to the garden ($7) which just gets you in the gate, but it's worth it. Certain times of the day are free, before 10 am on certain days I believe. You could spend anywhere from 15 minutes (speed-walking) to a couple hours here (taking some time to soak up the greenery).
author: Kate M.

description:
The Japanese tea garden is amazing. It's always an adventure exploring the winding pathways and staircases.  There's really no other place like this is San Francisco. Once you enter the garden gates, your in a magical Japanese paradise. Huge koi swimming, squirrels peaking out of trees and fresh blooming flowers. 

I always get a cup of tea with some rice crackers. Totally worth the price.
author: Andrew V.

description: Tranquil, Stunning, Breathtaking are just some words to describe the Japanese Tea Garden. There is a little place inside where you can grab mini snacks to munch on and they, of course have some tea. I went on a week day and it wasn't so busy. The place is a great for intimate dates and if you need some peace and quite.
author: Melle B.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is a great place to go and relax when the stress has gotten the best of you. If you are going to golden gate park don't miss this part of the park.
author: Paul D.

description:
Peace and landscape architecture preserved here.

Free admission Mondays-Wednesdays-Fridays from 9AM-10AM. Otherwise a little over priced for the "non-SF resident" who visits in my opinion (four stars instead of five for price). Its cheaper for those who live in city of SF.  (Way to generate revenue SF!)

Admittingly, I would pay to venture back. There are a number of niches throughout the garden where one can sit & meditate.  Surroundings of tall trees, earth engulfed bamboo shooting high, percolating waters and koi fishes.  

The garden is only one of many awesome places to see in Golden Gate Park.  Art and exploring enthusiasts will especially enjoy the neighboring museums and featured exhibitions.
author: Tina V.

description:
I'm in love with this place!!!
If your life seems too hectic, too insane, just too much please find your way over to this place and just find a good spot to your liking and sit, just sit and look.
I guarantee a feeling of peace will instantly fill your overworked soul.
This Japanese Tea Garden is absolutly gorgeous!!!!

The Garden isn't huge but all of it so well maintained and the atmosphere is exactly what a hectic chaotic soul begs for!!!!

So many photo opps- just take a look of some my pics - I had to narrow it down cause easily I took over a hundred pics....

Gift shop has cute stuff but over priced so aside from a magnet I'd save my money to shop elsewhere in the city - it's not like you are limited in the city for your shopping needs!!!

I can't remember what time it was - either 8:am or 9:am on a certain day (or days) you can get in for free - please check on that cause it's so worth it (sorry I can't remember- we took advantage of that offer but my inlaws who live in the city knew when to go)

Every time I go to SF visiting the Japanese Tea Garden is a must - I never get tired of it - I never have that feeling of "Oh, I have already seen that place so let's do something else" - Nope I'm always up to visiting the Japanese Tea Garden.
author: Ursula U.

description: This is such a peaceful and beautiful setting, and a great place to have tea and something light to eat.  It was so relaxing.  We enjoyed the Jasmine tea and sandwiches, along with the view from the small patio.
author: Lisa C.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden has been on my sight seeing list for as long as I've visited or lived in San Francisco. I love the relaxed feel and the oasis that temporarily protects me from the outside world. 

The Japanese Tea Garden was originally built as part of a sprawling California Midwinter International Exposition of 1894. It's the oldest facility of its kind in the US and is apparently where fortune cookies were first introduced in North America. This quaint 5 acre complex features many paths, ponds, tea house features, sculptures, bridges, as well as various native Japanese and Chinese plants. You'll never really see it all in a single visit and I certainly learn something new each time that I return.
author: Eric B.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is a nice unit among the museums however it is rather expensive to visit for a short stroll around a "smaller park".  This place is great for kids or for sipping tea, but unfortunately you can do more for your buck.   To be honest there is very little Japanese that you won't find elsewhere.  Cost of admission is $5.00 for S.F. resident and $7.00 for nonresident.

Inside you will expect to see a lot of perfect shaped foliage, along with 2 temple like structures, archways, Goddess statue and mini-lake - all you can find elsewhere for free or take advantage of the free admission days Monday, Wednesday and Friday mornings from 9-10 am.  They provide tours and a orchestrated drummers to entertain.  

The best thing to visit is the incredible arched bridge a lot love to climb on.  Like I said, great for kids.
author: K G.

description:
I treked an 8 hour drive to SF to go sight seeing and eat. One of my MUST GO-TO places was this--Japanese Tea Garden. I had high expectations but.. I hadn't realized how almost un-Japanese this is!

I went during my spring break from school with a few other friends and drove from Westminster (part of Orange County) to San Fran. It was rainy the day we came so we went a day after. (Long ago review but I remember it like it was yesterday.) We came on a Saturday and scourged for parking. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND YOU COME SUPER EARLY. Parking was IMPOSSIBLE. People were even parking illegally because there was not enough room to park! 

The garden entrance fee costs 7$ for non-SF residents and 5$ for those who are. The fee booth looks pretty similar to the toll booths in Japan but slightly modern--this is speaking about parks that is. I've honestly never seen so many rude, misinformed and irresponsible parents and tourists in my life. Actually I have but this REALLY bothered me. 

First off, the water in the supposedly koi ponds was copper yellow. Which in returns mean, probably many years ago they had fish. Until the idiot who threw pennies and coins into the pond came along. You don't do that! A traditional Japanese garden will have fish in it, and because people are so.. "LETS THROW PENNIES IN BODIES OF WATER" there aren't any. I was looking forward to seeing hundreds of koi fishes. Shot down. 

The walk ways became packed and parents can't seem to watch their kids. There was trash in a couple of places that I saw and it really irked me. So being a person that I am I picked it up. Only to see the parents littering as well (F word). 

There stone garden was well-kept for such a busy place as were most of the greenary that most tourist didn't touch or have their kids throw things there. 

The tea-house itself is pretty much mediocre. The tea is soaked in such hot water that the tea tasted bitter (which means improper preparation of tea). Ordering was a hassle because you never knew who was taking your order and didn't know if the person taking your order knew what you wanted. Pricy tea as well. I'd prefer you go when it is nearly dead-early morning- or on a weekday... early morning. 

Bah it saddens me to see such a beautiful garden not in it's pristine condition; however, there are some good photoshoot opportunities here. There's a few replica "castles" in the garden as well as a kick-ass bridge.

Next time in SF.. I won't come back. I would love to but... that experience really left a sour taste in my mouth. :(
author: Monique N.

description:
A classic tourist spot in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. I couldn't remember the last time I was here, even though I've grown up in the Bay Area. If you're lucky enough to live in this city, there's certain FREE days... Otherwise, it's $5 for SF residents. Everyone else is a couple dollars more.

There's beautiful streams, waterfalls, flowers, trees, Japanese structures, etc. It's definitely worth a visit!
author: Leana L.

description:
So pretty, even on a not-so-sunny day. However, when we got there, the guy at the ticket booth was persistent about me showing proof of residency. My boyfriend had his ID with our current address, but I haven't updated my ID yet, dude could have just trusted us, but I guess it's policy. Anyways, it kind of was a bit troublesome pulling up a utility bill on my slow phone. haha. After finally getting in, we had an enjoyable time. There are free guided tours all over SF, and we went on this particular day at this particular time to catch one of those said tours. 1pm Saturdays. Donations welcome! They're great guides. It's nice to get a little backstory to all of these sights. There was even this guy meditating in one part of the garden! All of the detail that goes into the garden is really amazing. I was reading that they also allow professional photos to be taken there without charge; engagement photos perhaps?

At the end of our visit we enjoyed some tea at the cafe there. I had the Matcha Green Tea, my boyfriend had the Iced Green Tea, and we both shared some tea sandwiches. A lovely end to a lovely visit.
author: Mariel A.

description: Let's get the admission information over with first: $5 SF residents (yay me), $7 non-residents, and free on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 9-10am. I enjoy doing touristy things so this was one of my favorite dates with my boyfriend. The garden just exudes zen and everything is so lush and beautiful. We walked around for a little under an hour and took a bunch of pictures by the pagodas and on this steep little bridge. There is a pond with many koi fish here as well as a tea shop where you can take in all the scenery. The food at the tea shop is a little pricey for what it is.
author: Charlotte Z.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is a nice place to go to get away from the hustle and bustle of things. I came here after visiting the Golden Gate Bridge, so the quiet and peaceful atmosphere was very relaxing.

The garden itself was quite a bit smaller than I was expecting, but it was lovely nonetheless. Lots of pretty greenery to Instagram :P

There is a really cool bridge by the entrance. Cross it! I didn't because I was wearing a dress (d'oh!) but it looked like a lot of fun!
author: Wendy T.

description: Yes, another early Wednesday morning and a stroll around the garden. It was beautiful with all the wisteria in bloom. They just repainted the rails of the curvy bridge, so unfortunately that was closed (but looked fairly temporary). They also do tea ceremonies at 10:30am in the tea house area, which looked pretty cool. (I didn't participate, since you needed a reservation). They have removed the udon noodles from the menu which was disappointing and I guess I was there too early (10-ish) for the ochazuke (rice and tea with flavorings) but the guy sitting next to me got to order it less than 15 minutes later... (I was willing to wait if she told me.) But it's worth a sit, overlooking the pond, pretending it's peaceful (ignore the loud tourists) and to sip on some tea ($3 for a pot).
author: Naomi K.

description:
Decided to take a day off and take a trip out to SF to spend the day.  

We really had our day set on going to MOMA but to our dismay found it to be closed :(  So we ended up here at the Japanese Tea Garden and am I sure glad we did.  

The garden is breathtakingly beautiful: so green and just lush with ripe vegetation all throughout.  I found myself literally stopping to "ooh and aah" at almost every crazy oddly-shaped bamboo plant, bonsai and fountain.  I felt like a kid again.  

Before leaving we stopped off at the Tea House.  Can't imagine a trip to the Japanese Tea Garden being complete without experiencing it.  We ordered from a list of teas that were available and each had a dessert to enjoy along with the tea.  It was absolutely perfect.  Definitely coming back again.  Oh, and admission was free!  It's free M/W/F before 10am...a total sign our day was intended to be spent here ;)
author: Cat V.

description: The park itself was cute but underwhelming, perhaps it was meant to be small. I really liked the tea house though! Miso soup sand jasmine tea were my favorite. The matcha was way too strong for my tastebuds!
author: Basima L.

description: This is the most amazing garden I have ever had the opportunity to behold. It is such a peaceful and tranquil place. Be sure to walk all the paths and find somewhere to sit for a moment. If you get there between 9am and 10am there is no cost of admission. If you are planning a day in Golden Gate Park this is a "Must Stop". Enjoy!
author: Trent P.

description: Stunning. Really peaceful on a week night. It's $8 to get in which I wasn't expecting and then you can actually buy and sit to drink a variety of teas for an additional cost. Not sure I'd make it a weekly thing with the admission costs but it's deathly worth going once or twice
author: Kat E.

description:
I absolutely love coming to the Japanese Tea Gardens to enjoy the nature, the flowers, plants, the wild animals, & all of the beautiful hortculture. I love the fountains & ponds; Japanese Architecture, Historu, Temples, Structures, . This is, a lovely place to browse for hours. The Japanese Tea  Gardens also offers free admission to SF Residents which is brilliant. The Gardens are tranquil, calm, and absolutely fascinating - year round, in all of the Seasons. I have lots od favourite spits and places but there is something for everyone and having these beautiful gardens in San Francisco does make me proud to live here!

Their Tea house is also lovely & having proper Japanese Tea at the end of a tour of the Gardens is not only essential but its fantastical. I recommend somethink milky. They also have tea sized foods & a lovely gift shop for authentic souvenires!
author: Julian I.

description:
Driving 2,700 miles across country to SF, I demand the best sights to see in the short days that I am here; my guide, and personal friend, has suggested coming to Golden Gate Park after our morning coffee. The pair of us, one from out of town, one live in SF but rarely venture out, found that even during weekday (Thurs) road side parking can fill up quite quickly. It's all fine because the weather was good enough for a short walk to the Garden.

First thing I noticed was the free entry sign, but didn't know it was only for Mon/Wed/Fri, so I had to pay $7 to get in. Okay. I'll bite. But you better be worth it.

Within a few minutes, I realized the entrance fees was sort of justified. The garden ground and vegetation and buildings were kept in neat and good shape. Since it's still week day, we didn't meet a lot of foot traffic, which made the visit peaceful and tranquil. Almost feel like growing up back home oversea. I could have sit pond side looking at koi swimming for HOURS, and I almost did! We ran into some people that were using the Garden to do some photo shoot, with a toilet(?). Also met a really friendly couple that let me took a shot of them sitting on the high arc bridge. I forwarded them the picture later, totally loved it.

The Tea Garden also has a gift shop and a tea shop, mostly for the Asian-fawning tourists, but I digress. So overall, I love the visit. Was it worth $7? perhaps. I will visit again next time I'm in SF, but perhaps on the free visiting hours.
author: Kuanyu C.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is so cute.
Great place for a date spot, great place to hangout with friends.
They have a cute little gift shop and cafe if ya get hungry.
I bought two of these little ULTRA cute kimono girl keychains.

Love the bridge you can climb over, makes ya feel like a kid again.
Maybe also because I did come here for the first time way back in kindergarten, lul.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Went here with my sister and have three recommendations:

1.  Give yourself time.  We were here for about 90 minutes right after our exhibit window at the de Young.  It was a nice block of time to just relax.

2.  Take the tour.  You are going to learn so much more about the history of this garden, which is of course tied up with our unfortunate history of Japanese internment, but in turn you are going to be so much more grateful for what you see and experience.

3.  Stop at the cafe.  Leave your tour a little bit before it ends so you don't get caught in a bit wait, as the seating space is limited.  Order all kinds of Japanese tea, sandwiches, ramune....you name it.  I got stuffed.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Very beautiful and clean!  You get immersed into the Japanese feel of the area the moment you walk in.  I was a little thrown back at the cashier's area by the front gate though.  They were not very nice older women, but it's okay.  We read that it was free on Monday/Wednesday/Fridays, and of course we were there on a Thursday.

There were certainly a lot of people around.  But it didn't seem so crowded as the paths are quaint.  A lot of scenic photo ops, and a lot of koi fish to watch.  However, I was a little annoyed about the moon bridge dilemma.  It was hard to get a picture on top of it, when everyone else decides to join in too!

We also visited the tiny gift shop, and the service there was so cute!  The cashiers always had a smile on their face and it made my experience there heartwarming.  The tea house was a little crowded and the menus are a little stale, but the service was pleasing.  They brought the food to you, restaurant-style.  I had the green tea ice cream and a taiyaki (fish cake), which was amazing.

Overall, cute place.  For me, this is a first and last visit, because I don't think the garden will change as much.  But it was a wonderful first-time experience.
author: Ivy N.

description: Such a beautiful and peaceful garden. It is free to enter Monday, Wednesday  and Friday before 10am. Allow yourself at least an hour to really walk the grounds and take in the serenity.
author: Monica B.

description: Beautiful place to take a stroll through (takes about 45 minutes to see everything and read all the signs). $7 admission for adults. Located right by the California Academy of Sciences. A few Japanese structures to admire. An abundant amount of water with koi fish swimming through. Peaceful & serene for a nice, quiet afternoon. Stop in to their little restaurant for some authentic Japanese food while you're there.
author: Kelley S.

description:
$7.00 for adults. Very relaxing atmosphere. Very polite servers. Tea is not overpriced. Lots of tourists but still plenty of space to move around. There's a little store where you can buy variety of Japanese stuffs from tiny key chai to extra large yukata (summer kimono) to japanese slippers to chopsticks, and oh yes, fork chop. Fun!

Great tea. Great service. Great view.
author: Virlie B.

description: WOW! This is a must, this place is just beautiful,admission is free Mon.Wed.and Fri.before 10:00am they are open at 9:00am and daily with no holiday closures,$7.00 for non residents and $5.00 for residents,there is a tea house and a gift shop which the staff are so very nice and helpful,inside this garden you will be so amazed of the sculptures,zen garden,waterfalls,bridges,trees,plants,rocks,stepping stones,and the huge koi's in the pond,,fountains, it is so calm,and relaxing.
author: Tommy M.

description:
I was the loner here.  My friend whom I was visiting had class so I walked around the park.  There is an admission fee...I don't remember how much but someone said $7.

I've been to Japan so obviously this wasn't super new or amazing to me, but it was nice enough.  It wasn't very crowded since it was a Friday morning so I had a nice leisurely stroll and took some photos.  It reminded me of Japan!

It probably isn't even one of the best parts of Golden Gate Park.  The admission is a little steep for what is is, but I just considered it admission for the entire Golden Gate Park and it seemed a little less painful that way!

3.5 stars
author: Ninette C.

description:
I love it here. It's so serene and calming. There were so many attractive things to look at and so many wonderful things to take pictures of. I felt like I was in an actual Tea Garden --- the ones you read about in a book. I made sure to walk and search every nook and cranny, so that I didn't miss anything.

The price to get in is inexpensive, considering it's such a nice place to tour around (cash only by the way).

The only thing missing are Japanese people walking around in their kimonos =) I would've loved to see that and loved to take pictures of and with them.

Unfortunately, I did not get the chance to go into the restaurant inside the actual garden, because it looked so busy and the line was long. Hopefully, next time I come back I'll get the chance to.

I would recommend this place to anyone who loves tea gardens or appreciates Japanese culture and the peace.
author: Jorgess M.

description: great photo spots for those who love to take pictures. admission is only 8 dollars and its worth the experience. There is also a botanical garden across the street from this place that has a lot more to see for 8 dollars as well. Both are worth visiting.
author: Daniel W.

description: Family visited here summer 2015, it was beautiful garden to take pictures with family and friends and we definitely return again if we visit California. Good price.
author: O. B.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco mon  tues wed 9 am to 10 am free other times $7.00
author: David W.

description: My favorite place to go in SF.  It's relaxing, especially in the middle of the hectic city.  I like to go have tea, walk around, and chill out.
author: Chris P.

description: This is definitely a must when visiting San Francisco... located in the Golden Gate park area.  Beautiful Japanese garden that make you feel like you're actually in Japan.  Mornings are best - less people and it will give you time to enjoy the serenity of the place.  We have some of the Jasmine tea and it was great as well.
author: Jeremy P.

description: Great tea. Sandwiches were pretty good and the cookies were fun.
author: Heather L.

description: I recently visited the Japanese garden recently with my family and we had a lot of fun. It's a small serene area offering background information about Japanese artifacts. Great spot for unique photography!  The cafe is located right in the middle which is convenient.
author: Samia J.

description: We LOVED this little oasis. Quiet and calm with the occasional gleefully giggling child, this garden was peaceful, and beautiful. We did not mind paying an entrance fee as it must take a lot of financing to upkeep this little beautiful garden. Happy to support them. We began our visit with eating tea sandwiches and drinking hot tea before we ventured out and I really could have spent all day there! -Mariah Dallas,Tx
author: Johnny K.

description: This place would've been cool if it was free. I mean $8 per person just to spend 30 minutes in a small crowded garden?! The reviews are misleading, I thought this place was a must see in sanfrancisco but honestly, it was a waste of time and money.  This place doesn't even give off  much of a Japanese vibe, I'd rather walk around Japan town for free. The parking is terrible near this area and I had to park 15 minutes away. Go spend your $8 at the De Young Museum or come at 10am on Monday, Wednesday or Friday if you really want to see this place.
author: Aidan S.

description: I absolutely LOVED the scenery, but I'm not sure if I'd pay that much admissions just to go in and finish within an hour. =(  The food/restaurant inside was quite expensive as well.. Straight taxin.
author: Nhu-Quynh N.

description: Come here for a peaceful time! You will love the scenery! The admission is fair and if you are a SF resident, you get in for a cheaper price.
author: Victor L.

description:
This place is stunning.

Wake up and come here first thing in the morning. Admission is free MWF 9-10am. The well-manicured flora, water features, structures, koi fish, and "sub-gardens" all amount to a delightful experience. If this place wasn't usually so packed with tourists, it would be a fantastic meditation spot. 

Also, get the mochi at the tea house! Best I've ever had.
author: Wesley N.

description: I remember going here when I was a little girl back in the 70s and thinking it was a cool place to be. I decided to bring my teenage son as we had visited one of the famous Japanese garden  in Portland many years ago. This one is also a beautiful place to be but it's hard to top Portland as that is known as one of the most beautiful Japanese gardens in the United States. i thought it would be free but it was only abou ten bucks for two of us.  We had some tea and hOuse cookies and called it a day.  Check it out if you have the chance, worth it for real.
author: Virgo M.

description:
Yep, cash only.
But a peaceful tranquil place. Lots of memories. Had to meditate. Too much going on.
 We ate at the little hut. I had Doranaki (?Pastry stuffed with bean curd. YUMMY) and Hoja tea. Hubby had miso soup and tea. We enjoyed our outing today!
author: Cindi W.

description:
The grounds get a "4" but the staff gets a "1 or 2" - I'm being generous w/a "2." Every time I come here (like once/week since I live close by) the staff in the front greeting area seem miserable and depressed. Who can be miserable and depressed working in such a beautiful setting? I try to engage in casual chit chat  as I walk in and they want nothing to do with this. The other strange thing - why are there 2 people in the tiny entry box? Clearly dollars are not being spent here well as the job requires one person only. 

I attempted to ignore this for some time so to focus on the gardens instead but it is hard when you treated poorly as you step in the gate. The people working the tea area are fine and the docents of course cool, it's the front gate entrance that needs drastic help. If you read my reviews, you will see I mostly review when happy/pleased so this is atypical for me so clearly I'm disappointed. I'll continue to go and will probably continue to get a smile or response out of the front gate staff (ok, maybe I'm a bit motivated by this game a bit!) but at the same time be completely baffled why these bitter people work the front entrance. Come on - smile be happy people!
author: Amy E.

description:
If you've read my reviews, I'm a total fan of Japanese gardens and this one hasn't changed my mind! I loved it! :)

I would've given it 5 stars if it weren't for the fact that it was so packed! It was ridiculous how many people were in there...but nevertheless, I enjoyed myself. There was a really cool bridge that was more of an "O" shape that was fun to climb. It gave great height for photos, which I took full advantage of. And despite the garden being so packed, it did not lose its sense of serenity. I could stare at the waterfalls by the pagoda for hours if I were allowed, but we came close to closing time. I was just happy to see it during sunset. I love sunsets, especially in botanical gardens. 

It was definitely worth going out to see and I loved walking around the koi ponds and climbing up random stone steps. Hopefully next time, I'll get to stay longer. Granted, it would also need to be a bit bigger for that as well.
author: Priscilla K.

description:
I probably would have ranked this place a little higher had I not come on a crowded Saturday afternoon.  Trying to find parking in the streets of Golden Gate park on a weekend is challenging.  You have to get lucky to find a free spot that's close to the Tea Garden.  I parked in the underground garage for the Academy of Science which cost around $3 an hour to park.

There was a minimal line getting into the Garden; the entrance fee for adults on the weekend is $7.  The cost feels steep when you take into account the grounds itself isn't that large.  Even with taking pictures and visiting the gift shop, my family spent less than 45 minutes there.  

The garden is very well kept and the scenery breath taking.  Again, I would advise to go on a weekday as large crowds tend to detract from the scenery and ambiance of the place.  There is a small gift shop in the middle of the Garden but as you would expect the items are over priced.  There was also a small tea house but it was crowded and we didn't feel like waiting for a seat.

All in all it's a good place to visit but I will probably come back on a weekday to have a more enjoyable experience.
author: Dennis P.

description: I had always been wanting to go to San Fransisco. I recently had the chance to go during my summer vacation and it was so amazing. The people were friendly and there were so many places that make you feel at ease but this place was the best! It was so beautiful. The nature and the environment was very nice. Unfortunately it is a small place, but its so beautiful. There's a gift shop and a coffee shop as well. It was a little pricey, but its all worth wild.
author: Becky R.

description:
Day 6 of MWLAWMBF:
I loved the ponds, pagodas, and bonsai trees - I just wished I didn't have to pay $7 for it. 

We did end up getting tea. It's tea served in a beautiful setting - it's great, but not worth everything. I can find the same thing in China where everything is more authentic for much less. I loved the mochi though. One tea set is actually enough for like 2 cups for 2 people. It's super nice to sit there and just see the surroundings and be at peace. 

I would probably only go back when the Japanese cherry blossoms are blooming and for free! I think they're free on Mondays, Wednesday and Fridays from like 9-10am? I'll be back then!
author: Nina Y.

description:
I have been going here since I was about 5 years old and it never gets old. 

Every time I have a date or a friends who is visiting SF for the first time, this is a must. It only takes a short time to see everything, there are a few adorable picture opportunities (like watching your date climb the same rainbow bridge which you scaled as a child, except in hot leather boots) and you finish off the tour with warm tea and cookies. 

Definitely a great place to take someone you enjoy talking to at length. 

PS: if you are trying to make inroads, you can sneak in a romantic handholding as you guide your date across the stone bridges. If she doesn't let go at the end of the crossing, you've succeeded.
author: Mike V.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden in San Francisco is beautifully maintained and very peaceful. Well worth visiting and incredibly photogenic if you are into photography. Is it worth the admission cost, absolutely. Finding tranquility among the busyness of San Francisco is well worth the $7 admission price.
author: Sam S.

description: Nice Japanese garden, and a nice place to take photos. Wish the little outside tea house had some outdoor heaters as it was pretty chilly the other day. I tried some matcha here, can't say I'm a fan (tasted like swamp water, lol)... the rice bun (I don't remember what it was called) was tasty though.
author: J P.

description:
Swung by the tea garden while in Golden Gate Park and I absolutely loved the atmosphere! The garden was lush and green, with a lovely stream bordered by cobbled pebbles. There was a giant bridge that spanned the garden, which was really fun to climb as well!

The highlight of the tea garden, however, was the cute little cafe in the center of the garden!
After stumbling down the rocky cobbled steps, I walked up to a cute wooden shack with an Asian girl in traditional dress. I ordered a pot of Sencha tea ($3.50), 6 pieces of kuzomochi (green tea, strawberry, mango), and edamame ($3.75).

The Sencha tea was nice and sweet, as well as very light! The pot was enough for two people, so I felt that it was very good for the price and well worth it! The kuzomochi was a powdery mochi. While the green tea flavor wasn't the best, the mango was absolutely delicious and the strawberry was a tad sweet. The edamame was also a nice addition and we received a really good amount for the price! I do wish we could have bought some miso soup too!

Overall, I had a great time in the Japanese Tea Garden and I highly recommend it to anyone visiting Golden Gate Park!
author: Lucy C.

description: It's a beautiful garden, but a little over priced. They use every corner of the garden and it's nicely groomed, but it's kinda small. It only took us an hour cuz we took a bunch of pics, or else it would probably take only 20 min.
author: Terry M.

description: The food and drinks are ordinary but the garden itself is spectacular! We ordered iced green tea (not as sweet as I thought this would be), green tea cheesecake (yummy! Recommended especially if you have a sweet tooth), and other two hot teas (can't remember what it was). We wanted to see the tea ceremony but didn't get to... I'll make sure to check that out next time.
author: Joanne S.

description: Was really disapointed in the tea options.  No green or white teas on offer.  No blooming teas or specialty teas at all really.  Plus they were serving earl grey...EARL GREY  really.
author: Megan B.

description:
A beautiful garden to behold and an experience to indulge in!

Just gorgeous walking around - you must go to see it!  Not a HUGE garden, but enough for a good walk around to observe the beauty.

Have tea.  Great deal - you get your pot of tea plus a plate of Japanese crackers and cookies  Very cute.
author: Steven S.

description: The garden is stunning, well taken care of and the little shop is great. Their tea is amazing and so is their food.
author: Valeria S.

description:
Beautiful.

I love stopping by on a warm SF day and I take my time walking through the garden.  I enjoy the ambiance and love taking pictures of the greenery.  

On my last visit, I lingered and had some tea and snacks.
