Even though I could buy those snacks at any Japanese market at half the price and receive twice the quantity, I wouldn't be able to enjoy it in the serene atmosphere that the Japanese Tea Garden provides.  I love just sitting in the open cafe while basking under the warm sun.  Coming here is such a great way to relax and unwind.  

If it were free on the weekends and if SF had more sunny days, I'd go there more often.

We need more places like this :]
author: Peggy L.

description:
You've seen one Japanese Garden, you've seen them all....right? 

Nope. 

I was expecting it to be much smaller, and surprisingly it wasn't....we kept strolling and taking pictures and there was still more to see....pagodas, rainbow bridge, bonsai, koi pond, buddha, zen garden, the list goes on.

And at the end there's a tea house overlooking the garden that serves a small selection of food and treats. And a gift shop with some gorgeous local artist's earrings that I loved. 

However, at no point during this little excursion did I feel any peace....it was over crowded and felt like a zoo. The tea garden was elbow-to-elbow packed and the gift shop kind of takes away from the "serenity now" monk feel:-) 

Regardless, the garden is beautifully structured and it gets 4 stars for that....if I was there alone, I know my thoughts would have wondered in a different direction....I guess I just haven't transcended into Zen yet since humans still annoy me;-)
author: Barbara D.

description: My friend told me that this place was nice so decided to go and take a look. Waste of my time and money, in my opinion. My hubby and I literally just went around the garden and that was it. I would only go for free otherwise, save your $8 if you aren't a resident and go somewhere else.
author: Elaine C.

description:
I'm so glad we checked out this lovely garden in the beautiful Golden Gate Park! We had traditional Japanese tea and strolled around on a recent afternoon, admiring the nature, the monuments, the bridges, and of course the colorful Koi fish in the ponds!
We were surprised that there would be an entrance fee, but then I realized how much detailed maintenance a traditional Japanese garden needs.

People should not be allowed to throw coins in the ponds, though. The chemicals in coins have bad health effects on the fish, as it pollutes the water. We noticed several Koi fish were visibly ill.
author: Mariella Z.

description: One of the worst people I have ever met works here. Just walking up to the counter he had the worst attitude. And when I asked him why he was being so inappropriate, his attitude doubled ten fold. I asked what his name was and he just responded with "what's yours!??" And when I asked for his manager, he said he was the manager. Just unnecessary.
author: Katarina K.

description:
What a beautiful garden within Golden Gate Park!

Entrance is about $3 for adults, but come here on a less busy day (weekday) and you can spend a good amount of time inside. I was pretty surprised that you have to pay to get in since all other Japanese gardens I've been to around the country have been free and open to the public. Don't forget your camera since it's really pretty in there! The pagoda's are beautiful, the garden is well taken care of, and it's nice if you are strolling through the park and spending the day in there.
author: Akvile D.

description: This is a lovely Japanese garden tucked inside Golden Gate Park. Even better, it has free entry before 10am three days a week. The garden isn't that big so you can see everything quite easily but I imagine it can get crowded on weekends. On weekday mornings, it's tranquil.
author: Jane C.

description:
We combined our visit here with the Conservatory of Flowers last week.  It was a beautiful day to do both.  Although it was too early in the season for anything to blossom such as the maple tree, nevertheless a great little walk throughout the garden.

As stated by other Yelpers, it's free admission every M,W,F during the 1st hour between 9am-10am.  

Even though there have been rec & park budget cuts throughout the City, there are visible signs of ongoing maintenance within the garden.  

Great way to enjoy a morning walk for locals and tourists alike.

Major pro:  his & hers bathrooms on premises!
author: Shirley N.

description:
This was such a lovely place to spend an hour.  We came in the morning when admission was free.  (Not sure if it would be worth the $7 admission; come between 9am and 10am.)  It was rainy when we came, which really just made it that much more beautiful.
There is a tea shop and a gift shop.  The tea was about $4 and a plate of cookies was around $5, which I thought was a bit overpriced but I did want tea.  :)  It was a great experience and very relaxing.  I would come here all the time if I could.
author: Meg B.

description:
What a beautiful garden. It's quite peaceful here even at it's busiest weekends. Try avoiding weekends if your looking for more solitude. 

Check out the cool bridges and architecture and enjoy the cherry blossoms. 

If you have tree allergies, avoid spring.
author: Justin C.

description: If you are in the area this is a must visit. From the tall red woods nearby to the giant koi fish in the pond. Very nice view especially if you love taking pictures.
author: Nic C.

description: What a beautiful garden! We feel immersed in the greenness. The Japanese tea house provides a variety of comfort snacks. My personal favourite is the Matcha.
author: Ke D.

description:
This place is very well-kept and there is a very nice collection of dwarf trees.  That being said, I thought it costs entirely too much for what it is.  You pay something like 7 dollars per person at the door to walk around a relatively small area.  Not only that but besides the garden with the regular fare of shrines and the tea house, there really wasn't much to it that would make you forget you're in San Francisco.  A temple with a local sect of shinto or buddhist monks would do wonders for this place as a learning experience in addition to the aesthetics of the flora.

I was also at the tea house inside the garden and was surprised at the lack of authenticity and freshness.  Their food is pre-made in exact portions and refrigerated/stored away.  You can tell this because their rice crackers stick to the bottom of the bowls.  This tells me that they just sit there in the bowls all day.  The rice in their onigiri is also a telltale sign of being made long before serving because it's dry and hard.  Their matcha latte is not bad but I was startled to find that they do not have freshly made matcha tea itself.  If there's one kind of tea a Japanese tea house IN a tea garden must have, it's gotta be traditional matcha.  The prices were also a bit more than they should be.

This place would get another 2 stars from me if:

1. Demonstrations of shinto or buddhist customs.
2. Some kind of demonstration or seminar on the garden itself / zen gardens.
3. Tea ceremony demonstration or hands-on at the tea house.
4. Freshly prepared snacks at the tea house.

I know this is a tourist spot but I really feel this garden lets down the entire culture and spiritual nature of Japanese gardens.
author: Chris C.

description:
great place to go when you just need to get away from it all.  quiet and contemplative, obviously lots of tourists but everyone seems very respectful.  maybe the buddha statue keeps everyone in check.  

Anyway, great to come with a friend, with a date, or alone with a camera or sketchbook.  I think entrance was $7 or so, but it's worth it.
author: Philip H.

description:
I took my mother here when she visited.  It is beautiful and very calming. We went on a Friday and it wasn't too crowded but there was a fair number of people.  I thought it would be bigger.  It only took about 30-45 minutes go walk slowly around. I thought would be a little more photographic as well. All in all, it was a nice place to visit.  The $7 price isn't too bad but if I had to choose only a few of the places to go in Golden Gate park, I don't think this would be at the top. However, Mon, Wed, Fri has FREE admission if entered between 9:00 am and 10:00 am.  
If you can find parking on the street, I suggest that. Otherwise there is a grage nearby that charges about $13 for 3-4 hours.
author: Brad C.

description:
The Tea Garden is a very nice spot to stop if you are in the area visiting the De' Young museum or on a date and just enjoying the park. Its on the small side, but it is very serene and beautiful. I wouldn't go to Golden Gate park just to see the Tea Garden, but is worth a visit i you are there for something else. Avoid going on the weekend if you can because it can get quite crowded. $7 entry fee is you aren't local, $5 if you are. 

If you are there on the weekend, go grab a Lobster Roll or bowl of chowder at the Chowder truck behind the amphitheater. Most people say the Lobster Roll is the best roll on west coast.
author: Ari L.

description: GORGEOUS! Absolutely gorgeous! I loved walking around it. The only reason why this is a four star instead of five is because it seemed a little over priced to both enter the garden and buy some tea and a snack.
author: Sarah T.

description: it was not worth for the price you pay.kind of small place.it takes 5mnts to see all around the park.nothing special to see.you can spent more efficient somewherelse
author: Huseyin G.

description: Just amazing.  The food place inside is a total "meh" but everything else is awesome.  The drum bridge was a favorite.  After going to the Cal Academy and DeYoung and being disappointed in both, this place redeemed the day for me.  Awesome.
author: Joe I.

description:
The entry fee of $7 is a bit much if you ask me, considering the place is a bit small. But it's hard to do upkeep on such a beautiful place so it's worth it if you can come here when it isn't insanely crowded, good luck.

The best part besides the beauty is that you can get tea and Japanese food on the grounds in their little outdoor restaurant area. Sure it's not the best food or the best tea service but it's fun to sit in such a nice place and enjoy yourself.
author: Christopher Steven O.

description:
Nothing spectacular, $7 per person to enter? Quite an exorbitant fee especially since there's not that much around.

Food took forever to prepare and the people taking our order were quite rude, boo! Had the food tasted good, I'd be fine with it - but my bf and I are allergic to MSG, so the udon basically poisoned us. 

The "misubi" was just a triangle of rice that didn't even taste fresh. The chicken looked way too oily.

The only good part was the fish filled with chocolate - tasted like a pancake with chocolate basically. Wouldn't recommend coming here, money and time can be better spent elsewhere.
author: Kristie C.

description:
This place is pretty damn good. Very serene, calm, and has this soothing energy about it. Doesn't all thing Japanese. Jk... but ya... super great date place. Love their gardens, flowers, gorgeous trees, friendly people (visitors and staff alike). 

I came here a few ago and it was getting kinda cold so my friend and i ordered hot chocolate and a Hawaiian cake. $8.00 for two items. Next time I'll cancel the cake... unless they start serving red velvet. 

Onward... as always, parking is tricky and irritating to find. That sums up SF for you. However, after we found FREE parking (sorry, I wont disclose my secret - don't want competition for the next time I visit) and went inside the Tea Garden... it was pleasantries all the way thru. Perhaps it was my gorgeous company as well. 

See you soon Tea Garden. 

Ohhh, and they have super cute fishes in the pond!
author: Neil R.

description:
I gotta admit, the 4th star is all about the memories we bring with us to the tea garden.  I fondly remember trips to the Japanese Tea Garden with my grandparents.  The moon bridge, the carp and the tea and are all still there, though grandma and grandpa have been gone for many years.  

My dad, son and I recently popped in for tea after the Academy of Sciences.  It was nice making new 3 generational memories, and having my son pose for the requisite moon bridge photo.  But now they charge to get in the front gate (with the exception of certain days/hours), charge a lot more for the tea (and serve a wider variety of food) and you no longer get those flat little Japanese tea cookies that I loved as a kid (you can pay $5 for some tiny but tasty other cookies).  The gardens themselves are not particularly impressive.
author: Linda M.

description:
My friends and I came here on July 4th at about 4pm (they close at about 5pm).  We were told it would only take us about 25 mins to walk through which was exactly right.  It's not a huge garden, but it has some nice features to it.  I liked the rock garden and some of the bonsai lookin trees.  We didn't try the restaurant area that serves tea so maybe I'm missing out on more from this place.  

It's cheap, $7 for admission ($5 for residents).  If I'm in the area with people who haven't seen it before I'd take them, but other than that I probably won't be back here on my own.
author: Kevin W.

description: Awesome place to visit. Took a lot of pictures. The store that sells souvenir was very expensive though. Didn't have a change to try the tea and snacks at the restaurant but I had a great time here. It does cost $6 entrance fee but it's worth it if it's your first time :)
author: Jenny L.

description: Not worth the admission fee.  Disappointed.  Head across MLK Blvd and go to the Botanical Gardens.  A few good statues and pagodas but very little exotic plant life, a cloudy pond, no Bonzai and a surprisingly small garden.
author: John H.

description:
Based on my first visit I would have given a 4.5 because it was beautiful, quiet, serene, and free (check for their times).

I went last week while I was in town (again during free hours thankfully) and was sad to see that the garden appears to be in some disarray. I was only there in March, so I'm not sure what happened within 4 months. There was clover and long grass growing on the hillside that had previously been only moss. The ponds also looked dirty.

I don't want to be a stickler and all that, but the garden looks worse than it did previously. When I went before there were a couple employees who were doing some landscaping by hand, and the detail did show through.

If I had paid, I would have been pretty disappointed, but since it was free it's still alright. I hope the upkeep is kept up, and that the loud tourists learn to quiet down. Just because you're speaking a language I don't understand doesn't mean I don't hear you anyways.
author: Sydney K.

description:
Definitely a beautiful place but not worth your money! 
My first impression about the place was GREEN! Lots of giant trees and "dwarf" trees. But when I came closer, I saw a lot of people come in a minute ago were leaving. That's because they ask you to buy tickets for visiting! $8/person. We were curious so we still decided to buy them. However, it was disappointing. There was a souvenir shop but locked because it was closed. We turned to the cafeteria next to it thinking it was for free but no... So we kept going to see if there was something interesting. There was a lake with a school of koi fish. Nice place! But just worth 2' of taking pictures. The rest of the place: trees, trees, and trees. There were some other things though but not outstanding. It took us 15' in totalwalking in and out.
I think this place is ideal for you to bring a book and grab a cup of coffee, enjoying peace, but not a recomended place for tourists!
author: Linh N.

description:
This is a worst place 
Not worthy
I guarantee that youd better go to the golden gate park
author: Ja Yoen G.

description: THIS PLACE WAS A JOKE!! Please don't go!! There was negative garden!! Didn't even have Japanese blossoms! It was a 5 minute walk around a backyard. 8$ per person. Don't get me wrong the tea was delicious. So if you want to pay 13$ for tea and okay service go there.
author: Jocelyn M.

description:
Free on Monday, Wednesday and Friday if you're in by 10AM!; Otherwise, it is anywhere from $3-$7 depending on age and if you are a resident.

I was here to visit family and this was one of the must see places; not only because we just like gardens but because my mom has been here many years ago and was excited to see it again.

The garden was very nicely set up and you do get a little Japanese feel to it.
We did not stop in the tea house but saw a few people enjoy the tea, scene and weather.

We did visit the gift shop and spent a good amount of time and money here. There are plenty of fish in the tree! Literally! There is a tree in one of the corners that hangs orniments of the cutest red fishes and cats. We bought a fish but I now wish we bought 2 :(

There is a cool water wheel kind of thing that you get to climb on but be reasonable, of people are on it taking a picture, wait until they are done before you get on.

The next time I'm in San Fran I will very much like to visit again and maybe stay for tea.
author: Jo L.

description:
Walking through the Japanese Tea Garden in the middle of summer is a wonderful thing. The big and tall trees offer shade while you walk through beautiful sections covered with both domestic and exotic brushes and plants.

I must say it was a lot smaller than I expected. Having been to the Japanese Garden in Portland not too long ago, I was a little bit underwhelmed when I visited it here. However, I loved how well the trees and brushes were kept, and how easy it was for everyone to navigate the different areas.

I also loved the Taiko bridge. It was unique and truly a piece of art of its own. Visitors like to climb (because of the bridge's unique shape) up onto the bridge, enjoy the view up high, and maybe have their photos taken, but sometimes a few visitors would climb up there, sat down, and stay up there for quite a while, causing little "traffic jam" and it was really hard for us to take pictures of the bridge without someone else's kids in them. :(

With that said, we did enjoy the tranquil moments roaming around the garden.
author: Yiching P.

description:
As others have said, free admission on MWF from 9-10AM, but otherwise... I mean it's a pretty garden, but there are other pretty&scenic places to walk around in Golden Gate Park [that don't cost anything to enter].

I went with my family awhile ago, and my dad was surprised that there was an entrance fee. I guess it'd been awhile since he'd visited, but anyway, we paid and walked in. Took us.. maybe 30 minutes to walk around? My brothers and I ran up the bridges and such, and we took pictures with the trees, but.. maybe it was because we didn't take the tour, because honestly, there is a lot more to do around the Golden Gate Park. The cherry blossoms ARE gorgeous, but I don't think I'll be back often, unless it's during their free hours. Otherwise, I'd rather save my $7 [I'm not a resident] for food :P
author: Amy L.

description: Fun little garden in Golden Gate park between the museums and the Botanical Gardens....
author: Mark B.

description:
Another cool place in Golden Gate Park.

When I went they only accepted cash at the door, so I had to pay a crazy ATM fee at the Academy ATM. 

The park is smaller than I originally thought. I was expecting a place grander than Morikami Japanese Garden in Florida. However, this Japanese garden is not as great, which i thought was odd since this is SF. Onto the garden.

My date and I decided to grab tea at their cafe. We asked the waitress what tea she recommended and she was clueless. She recommended Lipton!! Lipton, you must be kidding me. We just settled for their green tea. It was A-ok.

The garden itself is a nice 30 minute stroll. There are cool pagodas, buddha, and bridges that make for some nice kodak moments with your date. For $5, it is a nice day date.
author: Richard K.

description: Disappointed. It's tiny. I will choose San Jose Japanese garden in the future. not worth $8. Spend less than 10 mins inside.
author: Joy L.

description:
Since it was Spring Break, I wanted to take my daughter somewhere nice.  The Exploratorium was closed because it was Monday, and the Academy of Sciences was too expensive, so we took a little walk to the Japanese Tea Garden.

Cash only, eh?  Yeah, I wasn't too happy when I found out that the admission was only through greenbacks.  Everywhere else from the gift shop to the tea area took my card.  I had to walk back down to the garage, go to the ATM, get the money and get nicked $2.50 by the machine, then walk all the way back.  You know what?  This may have been a bit of a pain, but my daughter really had a good time, so I can't complain too much.  I had tea and she had a hot chocolate.  I can officially say that I SUCK at tea leaf readings, but that didn't stop me from trying.  Our drinks and little crackers were tasty.  We then got up and took a walk around.  Her favorite thing was the drum bridge.  After getting over a short period of fear about climbing over it, I soon couldn't stop her from getting on it time and time again.

I love going here every once in a while, and it was nice to bring my daughter with me.  Next time, I'm going to bring my wife.  If you have never been here, you gotta do it.  Bring your whole family.  This is a wonderful, peaceful place in the city to relax, sit down, meditate or just enjoy a nice family-friendly outing.
author: Matthew D.

description: Beautiful place to see especially if your just passing through the area. Me and my wife got in for free (it's free on certain days between certain times, see someone else's review). They have a little shop, a tea place, little ponds and waterfalls, and everything you need for a nice date or relaxing afternoon with a book. -1 star for the price they charge (it should be around $5 for everyone, I think they charge $7).
author: Drew M.

description:
To be clear I am only reviewing the Japanese tea ceremony not garden itself. Three of us went with a native Japanese friends experienced in tea ceremonies, and all the detailed formal exchanges that go with it. At $25 per person is was expensive, and instead of a quiet house to perform the ceremony in, we performed in the middle of the public tea house. Instead of being quiet and peaceful the instructor asked us to take photos several times, which we considered very rude. In the background were construction workers fixing a bridge, so we had to speak very loudly in order to hear each other. 

Overall it was expensive, loud, and unauthentic.
author: Nick C.

description: Very beautiful and peaceful park in Golden Gate Park. The tea is not free, you have to pay for it in the tea area. There is a little gift shop inside as well. The statues and structures are cool and the plants you can see here are amazing. You in one of the ponds you can see tons of koi. Don't feed them though all you need to do is put your hand over the water and make it look like you're going to feed them and they'll come to the surface. The kids liked this place which I didn't think they would since it is a garden.
author: Dan M.

description:
Free to enter from 9-10am M,W,F. Teahouse usually has a few small things going by then, so it's a nice morning walk and stop for breakfast. 

Overpriced the rest of the time, if you don't intend to be very leisurely about your walk and stop a lot. It's great for kids, they love watching the koi, so for them the money to enter is probably worth it. It's cheaper for locals other hours, so be sure to bring a piece of mail if you haven't updated your license like the rest of us.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I think I dropped my heart somewhere along one of the garden paths. I seriously am still that happy from having visited this place.

I highly recommend that you:
-Come before 10 AM, because it is free until then!
-Take the volunteer guided tour. You will appreciate the history of the garden and all of the statues within it. The volunteers are really well versed and fun to listen to.
-Grab some sencha tea at the adorable tea house and watch the koi pond! 
-Take your time and really explore. The garden looks small, but this gives you more opportunity to appreciate everything.
author: Allyson D.

description:
It's not that big, and you have to pay about $7 to get into it. I remember going here as a young child and been unimpressed. Now it's a little better, but I wish it was free. 

Nothing too impressive, however, I can't deny that it isn't gorgeous. Quite a beautiful spot in the park. You will finish walking around before 45 minutes is up. 

We did not stop at the cafe place to get anything,but it looked cute. You should go if you are in the area, but don't expect big thins, just to walk around and take a few pretty pictures.
author: Kathryn P.

description: I love this place! It's absolutely beautiful, has a perfect location, and is reasonably priced. I always try to take out of town guest out there. Judging from the reviews, I'd like to try out their cafe next time.
author: Natalie W.

description:
Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park is a truly great place to spend an afternoon. Swing by and check the seasonal days where admission is free and if your there not on those days it's $5 for SF Residents and $7 for non residents. I believe the prices vary by season as well. 

A great place to walk and wander and take pictures. Oddly enough the Tea is not what I expected it to be, but perhaps this is soo traditional I've become spoiled with restaurant and café style tea's and tea houses.
author: Walter M.

description:
I have been sort of a tour guide to my friends to this garden and I just loving going back. It's so beautiful that it calms my mind and makes my heart sing. 

It's beauty is in the heart of the tranquility it provides. Come visit me, I am waiting to take you here!
author: Harsha G.

description: Between beautiful gardens and delicious tea at reasonable prices, this is a great way to spend some time in Golden Gate Park. I wouldn't recommend coming on a cold or otherwise inclement day because everything is outside.
author: Jon M.

description: So serene and peaceful. The tea house is absolutely calming and when it's not too busy, finding the right seats overlooking the garden is priceless. The new item takoyaki is a ball wheat base with minced octopus and seafood paste drizzled with Japanese mayo and ponzu like sauce; sprinkled with lavor (green leaves). Miso soup was hot and steamy with a side of hojicha tea.
author: Irene D.

description: Came here on Friday before 10am since admission is free. It was empty and very peaceful. It was smaller than I thought but it had beautiful landscaping.
author: Angela L.

description: Loved this place...its beautiful.  The trees!  The fish ponds!  People were lounging throughout the adjacent green lawns on their picnic blankets reading, or eating/socializing.  I really enjoyed it.  And there's a little tea house/cafe where you can stop and refresh too...very beautifully incorporated into the garden surroundings.  I would go again in a heartbeat.
author: Myia B.

description: For a little piece of urban zen in San Francisco, stop by the Tea Garden (discounts for residents!). There is a tea house inside to order some traditional Japanese sweets and various teas. Green tea matcha is my favorite but the tea tasted a little watered down. Staff was friendly and attentive. The gardens and tea house get busy in the afternoon hours. Gift shop has a variety of great traditional gifts. Well maintained grounds and frequented by visitors to SF. A definite stop if you're in GGP!
author: Cindy A.

description:
$5 for SF resident. good enough! Really affordable, and serene. Fav part? That rounded bridge that you literally have to climb up and then slowly come back down from. 

Tea there? Didn't try. However it was cold, so I had the small bowl of Udon soup. Broth was good, definitely can tell it wasn't powdered stuff with hot water, however there are definitely a lot of other places in city with better udon. Does the job. Stay away from taiyaki, it's not fresh - reheated via microwave. The spam masubi was good, not too salty which is great. Pricey...but that's generally how tourist things are.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Neatly kept garden. Was slightly underwhelmed by the size - takes about 10 min. to walk through. Because of the small size, the garden can get quite crowded, which detracts from its otherwise tranquility. Admission is steep.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Very nice place; peaceful.  They maintain the place very well in the garden.  They have a gift shop & things are pricey in there too. The food/teas were a little pricey. Also, I don't like the fact that they charge a lot for entry.  Honestly, it should be like $3 a person.  But it is worth going to at least once in your life, because it is a beautiful place.
author: Jocelyn C.

description: The garden is a pleasant place to get some peace and quiet.  There is a tea shop in the garden which is a pleasant place to sit and gaze after walking through.  The tea itself is OK, nothing special.
author: Matthew A.

description: First of all, parking in golden gate park is RIDICULOUS. It's always busy and it takes a good half hour to find a spot remotely close to the gardens. We went to the tea garden and saw that the signs said "no refund" which should have been a red flag. It was 8 dollars to get in because I'm not a San Francisco resident. 8 dollars for what? I was literally in there for 45 minutes and I was walking very slowly. It's very kept up and well managed, but it's a waste of money. There are hundreds of people in there which makes it extremely crowded. They could still make a bunch of money if they lowered the prices. At least on weekdays. I won't be going again.
author: Rose F.

description: This place is nice.  $7 dollars per person however for a 30 to an hour wasted. It is nice and peaceful and you can take many pictures.  You can get $2 dollars off for being a resident in san fransico.  Anyways they have this bridge you can stand on, but the problem is it is accident prone and you have to be careful especially when it is raining.  Anyways there is a tea cafe as well which is okay. But other than that it is beautiful.
author: Keven W.

description:
Not worth $7. It is very small, very crowed.  There is nothing really to look at, impossible to take a picture without other people in the frame. The restaurant (or whatever it is)  that they have inside is disgusting. They reheat  some stuff in the microwave, everything look more like a dog food. 

The only cool thing I liked were local squirrels. They took food from my hand & were not afraid of me at all. One squirrel even climbed on my leg to get the treat. So get some nuts before you go there!  

When we left the place we gave our tickets to other couple who were going to visit this garden. At least we saved them $14 =]]
author: Olga B.

description: Really nice place to take the wife on Valentine's Day. Really scenic and tranquil, except for all the other people walking around. Parking was a nightmare though, and the tea tasted a little funky. We ordered 2 different types and it tasted like hot pond water. Maybe Japanese tea isn't for us!
author: Danny L.

description: I've visited the tea garden several times while taking friends and family around San Francisco. I brought my mom and grandparents here for Mother's day and they all loved it. It was perfect for my mom because she LOVES taking pictures of flowers and her kids. Perfect photo opportunity at every corner.
author: Cindy A.

description: This place was okay. I don't really get why I paid $8 for it. It was pretty small. Ehhhh...I won't be coming back.
author: A L.

description: Nice place to sit down, relax, have some tea, and watch squirrels wander all over the place.  For an additional $1.95, you can get 3 pieces of rice cakes with your tea.  The green tea rice cake was super soft and went perfectly with my tea. The strawberry and lychee rice cakes were too sweet for my tastes.
author: Tina W.

description:
I wish I could live here. A bucolic nook in the midst of the city. 
Perfect setting to enjoy a cup of genmaicha.
author: Joan P.

description:
I have so many nice memories from here. It's always a fun time exploring. 

When you walk in, there are plenty of pathways leading to different areas of the garden. Each area has beautiful plants, sublime flowers, ponds and bridges. You'll get a feeling of relaxation from coming here. It's a pleasant place to go to if you need to collect your thoughts and unwind. I enjoy coming here to catch up with a friend or two as well as take photos.
 
They have a neat little area where they'll serve you a tea of your choice, with crackers and yummy cookies. You can sit down at a small table and chat with a friend while enjoying the wonderful scenery. It's especially nice when it's a sunny, warm day. I'd recommend ordering the green tea; it's amazing. 

The tea garden is located at a great spot. There's street parking as well as garages. The museums are right around the corner so you can make a day of touring. 

I had to knock off a star due to the ticket fee. It's a tad pricey.
author: Linnea H.

description: There was an entrance fee for about $7 and, to be honest, the garden was a little bit small compared to what I had expected. However,  I would still recommend it because the pagodas are beautiful; the layout is gorgeous and allows you to appreciate the garden and pagodas from all different angles; the bridges are super cute; and when I went it was Spring so the cherry blossom trees were in full bloom. It was gorgeous. There are little (koi) ponds and streams set through out the garden and a nice, little food and patio area within the garden. They were serving limited but traditional Japanese food and green tea ice cream.  There was also a small gift shop nearby. During my visit, it began to rain so hard that I had to go find shelter under the pagoda, but the garden is so colorful that the reflection of the rain only emphasized it's vibrant colors. My only wish is that it was bigger (even Fresno's Japanese Garden is bigger, I think) but if you are in the area, definitely go check it out. I don't know if it would be worth it to make a trip there solely for the garden but if you are in the area, it is definitely a nice complimentary trip.
author: Hu L.

description: Beautiful place to go, bring out of town friends, visit every few months.  Just all around an out of body experience right in the middle of the city.  I, like probably everyone else who visited this place ever, took a great photo of the giant Buddha statue, and enlarged it in black and white, and it is the centerpiece of my mantle, and I've actually seen a friend with the same idea.  Just a great place to go, even when crowded it feels like a zen, peaceful sanctuary.  Kids love it, teahouse is cool, beautiful plants that are like no where else in the City - I can't wait for my next SF trip to bring my younger kids for the first time!
author: Lilly R.

description: It was my idea to visit the Japanese Tea Garden while we were in San Francisco this summer. I really liked the idea of it, which leads me to believe that I created this dream in my head that it would be better than what I experienced. It wasn't a bad visit but I would have rather gone during one of the free admission days. The $8 is a bit overpriced for what we saw. It is a small garden and unfortunately, one section of it was closed due to construction. The greenery was very beautiful and the architecture was nice to look at, but that was it. We went through the garden in about 30 minutes or so, maybe one hour tops. I suppose I imagined there would be a sitting area for visitors to lay around, drink tea and enjoy the nature. The gift shop was very cute. We bought some mango chews (like Starburst but better!). The tea house didn't offer much in terms of variety for tea or food. I was a bit disappointed but I think it's because I was expecting something else, expecting more. Definitely worth a visit on one of the free admission days. I'm glad I went but there wasn't anything that would make me do a return visit.
author: Sasha P.

description:
3.5 Stars

I had high expectations for this little garden but after 3 bucks for parking, 4 dollar admission, and we circled around the garden twice, we were done so quick. The garden is nice but I only saw about 6 koi fish compared to San Jose's Japanese friendship garden where I saw over 40 koi fishes. In addition, The place is too crowded and it is difficult to get shots of you and your honey when there are other couples fighting for the same Kodak shot. Overall, not too bad but wish it was bigger and more koi fishes.
author: Danster L.

description: Sorry, it was beautiful, but after traveling the world I've seen a lot of beautiful things. Maybe I missed something important or magical?. It cost me 7 dollars to get in and it took me about 20 minutes to walk around 3 times trying to figure out what was so amazing about this place. There aren't that many benches and some of them are in locations that aren't even overlooking anything beautiful. For a TEA garden I also expected a bigger selection of teas, there are like 5. None of which looked that appealing. Unless you don't mind spending money on tiny garden's this really is a place you could skip.
author: Megan E.

description:
There was some sort of noisy hammering when we were trying to enjoy our tea.

Its a tourist trap now with huge buses of tourists inundating the area...Sad!!!

The aquarium , planetarium and natural history museum is way expensive  $35.00 for everything, they should have a separate price to choose one of these and not be forced to pay for everything!!!!

There should be a package deal to visit the museums etc...
author: Carolyn H.

description: We went there on Labor Day. My girlfriend loved it. It was very peaceful and scenic. It was great walking around the pathways and over the bridges. There is a bridge that is a must for a picture. Looks like an inside upside down "U" took many pics of Julie there. We had a great time walking around. Very scenic. You could get lost in the beauty.  The gift shop is small but there is something for everyone. My girlfriend bought some chop sticks for her 1 year old niece. They had little animals holding them. Very cute. I enjoyed the Japanese architecture a lot. The koi fish swim around the stone steps as you walk over the water. We got here on a tour bus. And was picked up later. If possible drive up. And fully take in everything. There is a tea place inside. The line was long so we missed out. But it smelled great and the line tells you that it's worth the experience. Will try that next time we go. There is also a big Buda in the back. About 15 foot tall. Great for pictures. This place is a must visit. I'm glad my girlfriend wanted to come here. I highly recommend it.
author: Juan E.

description: Nice place, beautiful pond with koi fish, this interesting and tricky bridge. But it so crowdy here on weekend that even hard to take a photo...
author: Mila H.

description: I came here on a day/time it was free, which was good. It is a relatively small garden and there wasn't that much to see. There were koi, bridges, and rock steps, which was nice. However, I do not think it is worth the entrance fee. I went to a Japanese Garden in San Jose, which I thought was much nicer (except for parking price, but you can park somewhere else and walk a little).
author: A V.

description:
Talk about photo opportunities galore. Unfortunately, most people aren't real photographers. So don't let the unflattering photos on Yelp dissuade. The garden looks so much better in person.

There is a mad rush of people entering on Monday, Wednesday, and Fridays from 9A to 10A because it's free. If you can wait it out, they leave pretty quickly and the garden becomes more peaceful and enjoyable. 

It's large for a Japanese garden, but still small for a botanical garden so it took only 30 minutes to enjoy. They also serve food and offer tours, but we tried neither.
author: Brian U.

description:
I would rate it 3.5 if I could.

The garden itself is nice but nothing extravagant so an entrance fee of 7 bucks (non-residents) is so-so with me. Maybe if it included a free green tea or something, would make it more worthwhile. Lots of photo-ops with mini pagodas, bridges, flowers and squirrels.

I tried to pet a squirrel and it scratched me. the shop owners thought i had rabies or something, but i said naw, i got superpowers. The tea and snacks were good but a bit overpriced in my opinion.
author: David C.

description:
I am really "in like" with Japanese Tea Garden.

I have been here several times and have yet to be disappointed and hope to never be disappointed.  The garden is beautiful all year-round.  

Serene, beautiful, and lost (in time and thought) is how I think of the place.

This place is a must-see if you are in GG Park.
author: Pritika C.

description:
I give the park 10 stars!!! Amazing beauty you can roam around in for hours. Nice place for a romantic date. I dont recommend bringing children here. i dont think theyd appreciate the exquisite beauty. there are some great history pieces in here and I recommend going between 9 and 10 am on a monday or wednesday since you can get in free. gardeners keep this lovely space up to date and maintainted. 

on the contrary I give the TEA HOUSE A 1 STAR!!! WHAT A RIP OFF!! Its beautiful to look at and sit in and that is it!! the tea: genmai set. was just a cup of tea and some stupid crackers. over $4 for that!?!?!? i can buy a whole box of dried tea and a tons of crackers for $4. they were all out of mochi and the guy at the counter was super rude about it. just cuz you work in a beautiful garden in a tea house doesnt mean you need to be snobby or racist, and i thought was was getting a cute tea pot with cups. WASTE!! 

other than that it was so lovely. i reccomend bringing your own tea and munchies. the tea house staff are not very attentive and i doubt theyd notice. next time ill come back with my own tea and snackies.
author: Katie F.

description: So beautiful, serene and lovely! There's actual tea inside and little snacks as well as a gift shop with some pricey but too-cute-to-resist items to empty your wallet. It's a fairly small park that costs $8 but if you enjoy flora and are into Japanese culture, it's a must. Love the crazy bridge, the koi fish and the wonderful cute Japanese caretakers here. Also, if you have an SF ID, you can get $2 off!
author: Lulu P.

description: Really cute, something different to try... I think my favorite part was just sitting and drinking tea. Overall, kind of a tourist trap, but still something to experience at least once.
author: Diana K.

description: This extremely tranquil setting and gorgeous horticulture was a great respite amidst a big city. We loved wandering through and sampling a little bit at the Tea House. I would wander here again and grab a few more photos, but I'd probably skip the tea house. Though the lavender tea was amazing, I'd equate the food to grocery store sushi. Sorry. But the gardens.... beautiful.
author: Deb S.

description:
Sitting back in Golden Gate Park , you find this little Japanese Garden.  The garden is covered in lush plants with walkways and ponds that can make you forget you are in California.

The landscape is perfectly maintained and a calming presence to walk through.  The tiny Pagoda that sits at the top of the hill and the giant Buddha statue help to completely immerse you in the area.

At $7, admission is a bit expensive for how small the gardens are.  If you check their website you can find free admission times (usually if you go in the morning).  The gift shop was overpriced, but all gift shops are.  People do not expect bargains in gift shops.  

It's a bit small, but the time you spend visiting here will be amazing.
author: Miss L.

description: The Japananese Tea garden is very scenic and a great place to take pictures. The places to hide in the corner of the pond in case you want to see them on a bunch. The tea house is quaint not all that authentic but is a nice quiet spot to enjoy the garden. You must see the Buddha and take a picture on the drum bridge.
author: ANJ A.

description: I love it here! Came here after the San Francisco Botanical Garden. Cost 5 dollars for SF resident with ID and 7 dollars for non-resident adult. It is extremely pretty here but I don't like the crowd. It made it less romantic. =[ The tea area was really packed. Maybe its better on a weekday.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Pretty place to take pictures.  I would imagine that a girl would have more fun here then a guy but it was still a pretty nice place to see while we were in town.  When I first looked around, I thought to myself, "This would be a lot nicer if the ponds had koi fishes in them."  Next thing I know all the koi fishes come out of the corners.  It's $7 dollars per adult.  Stop by for a little bit next time you're near.

OHHH!!  Before I forget, there is this really cute squirrel that hangs around the gift shop.  It is the cutest thing, friendly too, and the lady who runs the gift shop has a box of treats that she is always feeding him.
author: James N.

description: Came here for My 19th B-Day and loved it !! Its such a beautiful well kept Japanese garden. It can take up to 30 min to explore the entire garden or an hour if you take your time and take lots of pictures. I say its worth the 7 bucks, especially if your going to sit down at the bar and enjoy a beautiful view of the garden while sipping on a nice soothing cup of hot quality jasmine tea. If your into flowers, tea, Japanese style buildings, gardens and a peaceful environment then this is an amazing place to go!
author: Meg H.

description:
With all the taxes they steal from us, they can't make this free? 

That being said, I realize it's expensive to maintain and it does show in the detail of the garden. It is pretty. Not $7 pretty, but pretty. 

The other thing is - A Japanese garden is supposed to be quiet and tranquil and zen-like, which is not possible with all the tourists.
author: Nick F.

description:
I have been wanting to come visit the Japanese Tea Garden, but my family is never fully up for going. I was finally able to go today with my boyfriend and I must say, it was worth every penny at $7 dollars per non-San Francisco-addressed adult. Otherwise, it would be $5. We arrived at the garden around 4PM and the sun was still beaming, a perfect San Francisco day for an outing.  
 
This place is actually a lot bigger than I anticipated, enough for you to venture to every corner of the fenced establishment.  Within the Japanese garden, I would say this one is a lot better than the Huntington Library in Southern California in terms of having more lush plants and several ponds and small trickling waterfalls. In addition, they have a blood-orange pagoda, a extremely curvacious bridge that you are able to ascend by climbing, and several decorated entrance pillars. 
  
Surprisingly, there is a little shop within that sells little trinkets, figurines, snacks, and wind chimes. I thought this was an adorable touch to the Japanese garden. 
  
Furthermore, the tea garden of course has a tea room which has an outdoor-patio seating. Obliging to the sign, you grab a menu and seat yourself. They will come take your order. We ordered the masubi plate which was about $6. It came with one dumpling, some diced teriyaki chicken, and three rice rolls. Small proportions. 
 
We also ordered the Sanyeo tea that comes in a pot. If you get the combo for another $1.95, you can get those japanese crackers or three pieces of mochi (not the ice cream kind). 
 
I had an exceptionally great time here for my first time. I highly recommend stopping by if you are in the Golden Gate Park.
author: Becky Q.

description: If you're coming here, bring a camera, snag some epic clicks! San Francisco residents gets discount on entry ticket.  Keep in mind you can definitely finish the tour in 1hour.
author: Kevin Z.

description:
Oh emmm geeee! Such a gorgeous garden! Peaceful and well groomed plants, and ponds. 

We came here on Tuesday morning; we paid $7 pp since we are non-residence. With proof of SF residency, it's $5. However this place is free on Mon, Weds, and Friday before 10 am I believe.

My bf and I came here and was able to get many picture opportunity. 

Their gift shop was pricey; however we sat down to get a light snack at the tea garden. My bf had their miso soup and I tried this calpico non-carbonated soft drink. Taste pretty damn good; I would imagine it would taste pretty bomb with vodka (oh the alcoholic in me!)

Gorgeous garden; must visit if you're in SF.
author: Rachel T.

description:
$7/ adult which is fine. The tea garden is beautiful. They had a few really nice monuments. I also enjoyed the flowers, ponds, giant koi fish, and overall scenery. They also had a cute gift shop which sold many cute souvenirs and knick knacks. They had a small cafe/restaurant also which a lot of people seemed to enjoy.

I saw a few people (couples) taking professional pictures there which I can see since the place has that serene look. It is a nice place to walk around.
author: Vicky Q.

description:
I came to the Japanese Tea Garden last weekend with my girlfriend, her brother, and her dad. Her dad loves trees. So this wasn't a bad place to go. It's also got a few beat up pagodas and a ton of tourists. A few gorgeous koi in the pond. Memorial Day weekend probably wasn't the best time to visit, but what can you do.

My previous visit must have been something like 25 years ago. It only cost 50 cents to get in. And everything seemed so much bigger. I remember coming here with my dad. I can't remember if it was once or a bunch of times, it was that long ago. Now, the high arch bridge doesn't seem as high. And the little nooks and crannies feel more like a photo op than a hike. But this could still be a nice place to come on one of the days with free admission, when there aren't so many people around.
author: Tony L.

description:
Fantastic! A must see!

The best way to experience the tea garden is to join up with a free tour guide (www.sfcityguides.org/) on a Monday or Wednesday morning at 9:30am. Free admission, free tour! Then sit and have tea and sweets in the tea house. A real treat!!
author: Julia S.

description: This review is just for the Tea center. Tea itself is about $4 a cup. There are only a couple options for food. I was expecting a bigger Japanese tea cake selection. Most everything comes out of prepackaged bags, sadly. There are only a couple fresh made options. However , the tea is quite good, and the patio is beautiful to sit in.
author: Collin P.

description:
Love things like this.  Anything that exhibits the beauty of nature and a culture's identifying themselves with some of nature's precious gifts is a great time to me.

Very peaceful.  I enjoyed some of the fake "stoneware" that was around... there is a line that they could have crossed, but they didn't cross that line, it was all tasteful.

I got some excellent photos out of the trip... I spent more time here than the Academy of Science today.
author: Jessica P.

description:
It was really nice, but WAY too expensive for what you pay for. It's $7 per person, and seems like it should include maybe the botanical gardens next door. However, Mon, Wed and Fri before 10am it is free. 

The garden is beautiful but I did expect more. At least a 30 min - 1 hr visit. You could stroll through the whole thing in 15 mins. 

It is very serene and read the plaques that tell you more about the things you see, like the Drum Bridge, the Buddha and The Pagoda. 
However, with a huge Run happening in the park the peacefulness was overpowered by loud shouting in a megaphone. 

Worth a visit, but only when it's free. The rest of the park is beautiful and free as well.
author: Laura C T.

description:
Even though SF residents get a discount, this place isn't worth the admission to me. There are some reasonably well maintained gardens and a few Japanese styled buildings here.

Beyond that it's about 15 mins. to walk around completely.

Save your money. Not worth it.
author: Nick L.

description:
If you ever want to see how it is to be in Japan....to see how wonderful and precise they are in their gardens, with their food, and their daily lives, you should, well, go to Japan.

For those that enjoy the beauty and peacefulness of a nice garden (it's peaceful despite the tourists), then you should come here.  It's not Japan but it'll make you want to go there sooner.  (push to #1 on the "to visit" list).
author: Sanket K.

description: Very beautiful to look at and soothing to walk around.  I went with family and I must say it's tough to bring kids along unless they can appreciate the garden.
author: Nani V.

description:
Best way to do it on the free mornings.  SF residents get there right at 9 so you can enjoy the tea garden in peace!  The morning air is fresh, a few ppl doing tai chi, and it's nice and quiet.  I love sitting in the back by the Zen garden and breathing.

It can get a little overwhelming when the tourists start arriving, but it's my favorite place to breathe in the city.
author: Maggie M.

description:
Whoa did I somehow get transported to a magical oasis of Japanese structure and beauty? Where did all of this incredible greenery and architecture come from? 

Why are there other humans here?

These are just some of my thoughts as I remember the lovely lovely day I spent in this park with boyfriend. The park itself is quite charming and very well done. 

Unfortunately, it was a little crowded (Saturday afternoon rush), and that certainly detracted from the experience. 

That being said, I'll be back on a weekday morning and soak up all the wisdom and green I can. No student discounts (scrooges).
author: Emily D.

description: I am truly in love with the Japanese Culture and have lived in the bay area my entire life but have never been here. I now live in the Sacramento area and decided to play tourist with my kids one day in SF. First stop: Japanese Tea Garden. I was so excited I could hardly drive. We get here and pay like $7 a person to get in plus parking. In and out in like 15 minutes. Wait ... thats it? We are done? Noooooo ... what a bummer. It was nice and all and the tea was good but I guess I just expected alot more than what it was. It was beautiful and all that but again... not much. humph!
author: DeAnna H.

description:
It was my best friend's birthday and I was looking for something different. I sprung for the tea ceremony inside the Japanese Tea Garden. It was $25 and limited to six people, so be sure to make reservations. We were lucky because we were the only two attending that day. 

The woman leading the ceremony has been practicing for over 20 years. She was very friendly and easygoing while conveying the sense of importance of the ceremony. I felt comfortable enough to ask questions and even joke with her. It was a great introduction for a novice and made me want to know more. 

You still have to pay the $7 admission to the Japanese Garden. I wish that had been included. You do get a discount card for the gift shop and a free fan. People sitting nearby were really interested and able to watch, so if you're looking for a super formal ceremony this probably isn't the place for that, but I found it to be fun and well worth it.
author: April D.

description:
This is not the greatest Japanese garden, and the ambience leaves much to be desired.

First, the clientele deserve note. They are mostly a bunch of tourists who like to take photos of the same things. This means there are clumps of people at various points, and you lose the relaxing, wandering mentality you might have been seeking. A half-dozen tourists gawked at a squirrel as it wandered through the grounds. Apparently that was the biggest attraction.

The place itself has pleasing landscapes but nothing truly inspiring. While it's relatively small, they manage to confuse visitors by offering myriad branching pathways. This non-linear experience is confusing rather than exciting. Did I miss anything? How do I get over there? Usually, GPS comes optional at these places. I have no motivation to come back and visit again.

The price is also absurd. For a relatively small and underwhelming garden, I thought $5 would have been fairer. Not that it matters to them - tourists pay anything for "authentic," whatever that means.

The Japanese garden in Portland is much more impressive and authentic. Go there. It's a nine-hour drive from San Francisco, and worth the trip.
author: Casey P.

description: I just wanted to say, this is a Tea Garden. Not an amusement park. If you come here expecting to do anything other than admire the simple beauty, peace, and quiet of the garden, frankly you're an idiot and obviously don't understand what the point of a Japanese Tea Garden is.
author: Angela M.

description:
I understand maintenance costs and I'm gladly willing to pay and even donate some money, but 7 dollars (non-resident) per visitor seems a little overpriced. I may have just been underwhelmed by the size. You can walk through all of it in 10 minutes if you're doing a quick stroll. 

It is a beautiful garden, and an exotic gem in the middle of a dense city. It also feels authentic and not like some Disneyland manicured set meant to take you to Japan. It's simply a place for quiet reflection in nature's beauty.

Unfortunately, my experience was disrupted by the amount of people. I almost wish there was a lower maximum capacity number, even if that means waiting outside in line for a little. Tea gardens are supposed to be tranquil, but with everyone  stopping to take millions of pictures all the time, it can get frustrating and obstruct the quiet. Stop trying to possess and capture the surroundings and just live it! That's not to say it's overcrowded -- it just wasn't the ideal circumstance. If I were to come again, I would come back early morning on a weekday when it might be less congested as opposed to a sunny Sunday afternoon.

I do recommend stopping and getting some tea. A lot of the seating faces outward towards the rest of the garden, and it's a nice way to take in the scenery around you, as opposed to trying to maneuver between people. The koi fish are fun to watch as well.
author: May I.

description: Too expensive for what it is. It's a tiny garden with a few ponds and flowers. Looks and feels super artificial. Person at the register did not accept any of the documents I showed to her to proof my residency since I forgot my ID for the local discount. She was super rude.
author: Chris S.

description: The beauty of the gardens is so exquisite. Lots of pretty koi fish. They have free admission times. I enjoyed the view from the little restaurant and sipped on jasmine tea (wasn't offered any options to sweeten it with), edamame, and sushi. I learned from a tour guide there that Golden Gate Park is larger than Central Park in NYC!
author: Lemon C.

description: Nice japanese garden situated in central park, it's super easy to find. I went on sunday, which might be why i didn't find the tranquility i was looking for. I also thought there could have been more seats for people to read a book or sketch there. The pond IS beautiful though and you can watch the feeding of the fish if you come during the weekday. Overall, decent garden but come during the weekday when there are less kids running around to fully appreciate it.
author: Vivien S.

description:
Yes, it's a bit pricey, and touristy, but it's worth at least one visit in this lifetime. It manages to exude a certain degree of serenity even when inundated.

A lovely garden...
author: John D.

description: Beautiful grounds. They advertise free admission before 10 AM on their website but be warned--it is only on M, W, F. My husband and I as well as the family in front of us believed it was every day as the website alludes. We went on a Tuesday so we ended up having to pay. This information needs to be made clearer. Also, they don't provide any brochures. It would be nice to know more about the traditions and plants within the garden. Despite the lack of transparency on the "free" admission, we still enjoyed our time. We are glad we got there earlier as when we were leaving more tourists were pouring in. The Japanese Tea Gardens is something that needs to be enjoyed in tranquility, so go close to opening time.
author: Cassie C.

description:
I basically begged the boyfriend to take me to the Japanese Tea Garden because, in my head, I pictured beautiful sprawling grounds filled with flowering cherry blossom trees, stylized pagodas and koi ponds. The reality didn't exactly fit my highly romantic fantasy image, but it's still a beautiful place to visit. I would definitely recommend that people go visit during the free hours (between 9AM-10AM, Monday/Wednesday/Friday) rather than pay full admission though ($7/adult).

It's relatively small (the boyfriend and I walked the entire thing within about 30 minutes, and that was at an extremely leisurely pace with plenty of stops to take photos). The ponds are filled with beautiful (and extremely well-fed) koi fish, there are a few large and weathered pagodas scattered amongst the trees, little stone shrines tucked away in every corner and a large Buddha statue. There is also a tiny gift shop filled with Japanese knick knacks -- everything from chopstick holders to wind chimes to kimonos. We chose not to buy anything (tourist traps, man, they overcharge you on EVERYTHING).

We did, however, check out their little tea shop -- we each chose a different tea to try out (the Genmai and the Sencha; both of which were delicious but not exactly worth their $7-9 price tag) and they came along with your choice of salty rice crackers (looked straight out of a bag of Japanese trail mix) or mochi cakes (delicious but sticky). We also got the miso soup (nothing special) and a spam musubi (large, but also nothing special). I had wanted their cookie platter initially, but had been told that they were out of cookies that morning. The tea shop is lovely overall, with the open-air dining experience and all that, but it's not really worth the price tag they stick on it (though we were surprisingly full afterward).

I would go again, but not until the cherry blossoms are in bloom and definitely only during their free admission hours as well.
author: Anna W.

description: After reading the great reviews about this place, the Japanese tea garden left us so disappointed. It was $8 to get in and once inside it was tiny. There's only a few pagodas and greenery to see so each part is swarmed with people. One of the pagodas was in terrible condition. You don't even get tea included in your entry fee and when we went there were huge queues to buy it. Really didn't see what the fuss was about.
author: Marie S.

description:
The Garden is filled with many different stunning Japanese structures, which makes it a great place for photography.  

Lots of street parking if you come before 9am and no entry fee (MWF Only). 

Don't forget to climb that Moon Bridge, pretty fun. :D

Overall experience: B+
author: Karen P.

description:
To me, the most beautiful site in San Fran! Not only is Golden Gate Park amazing but this little gem of greenery is simply tranquil.  We went at 9:30AM on Friday and it was peaceful and quite.  The fog was just starting to roll out.  It was FREE and there was a tour guide who knew quite a bit about the place and it was a great tour.
We dropped off after about an hour and got a cup of tea and a treat.  LOVE this place.  So happy we made it part of our trip since it was the highlight.
author: Melanie B.

description: This is one of my absolute favorite places in San Francisco. It's just gorgeous. It's a great way to start your day. Walk around the beautiful grounds and then treat yourself to some fresh tea and mochi. So yum.
author: Parisa T.

description: This place is absolutely beautiful. So relaxing and inspiring. I loved reading about the history of the bansai trees there, structures, statues, looking at the koi ponds, drum bridge and landscape. Really nice place to visit. They did charge admission the day/time we were there. There is free street parking everywhere in Golden Gate park.
author: Katherine H.

description:
Neat if you're into Japanese gardens. I'd almost say save your $7 and look at pics of this place online, especially if the season isn't right. The guy at the gate was kind of a dick. He wouldn't give my friend who was a SF resident the local discount because her driver's license wasn't renewed yet. That's bad service. It's a goddamn garden, not the DMV.

I much preferred the nearby botanical gardens which is immensely bigger and way more diverse in it's offerings.
author: Jeff O.

description: Came here with my wife, 9-month old, and family from out of town. The price is actually $8 for visitors (non SF resident), not the price shown on their website. The place was nice, tranquil, and green. It makes for a nice stroll. I am not sure if I would go back. It's a bit overpriced in my opinion. It is a recommendation on a lot of website so my expectation was probably too fight.
author: George H.

description:
The tea is great and the mochi (assuming you like mochi) is as good as I've ever had. The prices at the tea house are reasonable as long as you don't count the $7/person entrance fee to the garden. Lastly, and most importantly, the view while drinking the tea over the koi pond is the most amazing you'll find.

The $7 admission means that you're going to want to plan to spend at least another 30-60 minutes walking through the gardens and soaking up the peaceful calm.
author: Colin D.

description:
Not to be a negative Nancy, but this place is pretty skip-able, unless the following applies to you:

A.  You're a tourist
B.  You've never been to Japan
C.  You've never been to San Francisco
D.  You've never been outside of Iowa
E.  You spend a large % of your disposable income on Naruto comics, Dragonball Z bootleg DVD's and Faye Valentine manga

The grounds crew does do a good job of getting the shrubbery trimmed, the garden groomed, and the faux Japan persona upheld.  If you visit early enough, you may get a few moments of peace before the inevitable rush of tourists descend upon the ground, snapping pictures and talking about how cool of a movie 'The Last Samurai' was.

The tea itself is a bit overpriced, but comes out fresh and hot, accompanied by oddly chosen accouterments in the form of a small bowl of stale rice crackers and fortune cookies.  However stale as these snacks may be, try and restrain yourself from feeding it to the local water fowl, as they've grown quite bold (and foul tempered) from the frequent feedings from guests.

Fun fact:  Not that it really matters, but the ladies working at this joint are actually of Chinese descent.  Ditch the kimono's gals, your act is up.
author: Chris H.

description: If you like nature and/or Asian culture, this is the place for you! Located in centrally in Golden Gate Park walking distance from both the de Young Museum and the California Academy of Sciences, this place is a must for anyone visiting San Francisco, especially if you're already exploring Golden Gate Park. Of course all the foliage is kept perfect and the year round cool weather is perfect this kind of place, but what doesn't make the Japanese Tea Garden perfect is the huge amount of tourists (including myself) who come in in such large numbers (especially in the summer when I was there) which makes the whole experience less "zen," but it's understandable. They have this cool bridge that is so steep that you practically have to climb up to the top and then climb down. It's like a bridge/ladder hybrid - and yes, it's a good photo op. I love animals so having the Koi fish is a nice addition to the bodies of water throughout the garden. They have a good selection of souvenirs in the gift shop and I didn't eat at the restaurant but it was very crowded.
author: Michael G.

description: This place is beautiful, it looks like a real tea garden you would see in Japan. I was just disappointed that they removed the man-made waterfall. But other than that, this place is very peaceful and beautiful to walk through. The bamboo plants and the Japanese bridges gives it a nice touch.
author: Cindy W.

description: Great place to play hooky!
author: Nikki N.

description: The Japanese Tea Gardens had to be one of the highlights of my trip to San Francisco last April. It was my second trip to the city and since I had spent the majority of my time downtown, it was refreshing to see this particular side of San Francisco. I had always wanted to see a Japanese Tea Garden, especially being a nature and photography enthusiast; I had a lot of fun exploring all the paths and landmarks of the gardens. This is truly a photographer's haven. Absolutely beautiful and worth the time and admission.
author: Nikki I.

description: This is such a beautiful, serene escape tucked into Golden Gate Park.  It is usually teeming with tourists, so that can be a drawback if you're trying to come in here and take pictures.  It's a lovely place to walk around and enjoy the scenery.  The cafe is a great place to get some good tea and snacks (best mochi everrrr) while sitting an chatting or looking out at the landscape.  While prices for admission are a bit high just for a place to walk around for maybe an hour, if you come in at the right time, admission's free.  All in all the garden is a definite must-see in San Francisco.
author: Christine W.

description:
It's a must see for the average tourist, but I would say skip it if you're a local.  I only say this because it costs $5 to get in and it would only take you about 5-10 minutes to see everything.  You could save your $5 and see the rest of Golden Gate Park instead.  If you end up coming here, remember that this is cash only.

The best part of the whole experience was the tea itself.  After hopping from one tourist spot to another, it was nice just to sit down and mellow out for a while.  We ordered the toasted rice tea because it was something different from the standard green tea they serve.  It came to us piping hot and had a warm nutty flavor.  We paired the tea with some Japanese sweets which complimented the rice tea.  

The garden was lush and the koi were plentiful.  There are a lot of great photo-ops available by the bamboo, the tiny waterfalls, the Buddha, and the steep bridge.  The only thing that took me out of the "zen" were all the signs in the wonton font.  It looked more comical than anything else.
author: Xuan T.

description: Place is quaint and peaceful. Small and sometimes loud with all the tourists, only complaint. Some people need to respect the atmosphere! Tea house has awesome mochi, expected more a traditional tea setting but it was more like a fast food place with a nice setting. I was looking forward to sitting on the floor and watching them do the green tea match ceremony but I was disappointed. Worth a visit but onece you've seen it once, you've seen it all!
author: Ariele L.

description:
Amazing and beautiful small garden with delicious tea options. 

The tea house is what really takes the cake! Venturing around the garden was great but I wished I could have shooed everybody away and had the garden all to myself :) It would have been much more calming without screaming children running all over the place.  I think the sign out front said that there was no entry fee if you arrive between 9am-10am so bonus if that is accurate (and maybe the garden would not be as busy). 

The tea house was beautiful with a good variety of affordable delicious tea and snacks. I could have sat in the tea house, drank tea, and stared at the peaceful garden all day!
author: Hollie W.

description: Absolutely beautiful. So quiet, serene and just nice. Enjoy a walk with your family, loved one or friends.
author: Yaya L.

description: It was such a disappointment going here. I had such a high expectation. The garden is like any other ordinary view from someone's backyard. There wasn't much koi fish swimming around not how dirty the water was. Paid $7 dollars for entrance. I would  recommend any tourist not to come here and waste their money and time.
author: Mimi N.

description: Public school kids on a field trip have to pay full price to view the small gardens.  This is lame for a garden in a public park.  Even the Cal Academy and museums offer discounted rates and even free planned field trips.  The garden does offer "free hours" that are not very convenient to get to.  And if you just miss that free hour, too bad - full price. By the way, this is for public school kids in SF who wouldn't be able to afford it either way.  If it's in a public park, they should work with the public schools.  Lame.
author: sonrisa m.

description:
My memories of this place is strolling alongside my grandfather back when he was living in a shady Asian retirement home on Masonic. We were right near Golden Gate Park, and every Saturday we drove up to San Francisco for our weekly ritual of walking around the park and ending the day with a trip to McDonald's for a filet-o-fish. 

What I enjoyed the most was the time spent with family here. We were all trying to keep a tranquil and harmonious feeling when we spent time with my grandfather, so there was none of the usual bickering that is common amongst my family. Just quiet and peaceful walking, enjoying the sights, and vocalizing pleasantries with each other. 

It's a beautiful little spot, and it's not about the size or the amount of things that are here. Like the Japanese tea ceremony, the garden is about the process, and not the destination. Enjoy the walk, savor the company that you're with, and take the time to appreciate the world around you. We don't have many quiet moments in our life for reflection, and here is one of those places where you can attain it, if you quiet your busy mind and concentrate on the here and now. 

Now I sound like a damned hippy. Thanks for that Yelp.
author: Grace Y.

description:
My fiance and i went here this past weekend and absolutely loved it.  The place is perfectly manicured and is so beautiful.  a wonderful place for photos and you appreciate the landscaping.  very cute that they also have a tea house in the middle where you can order an assortment of tea and light fare to nosh on.  

We look forward to coming back, maybe in the summer.  I feel like you can get a different experience when visiting during different seasons.
author: Brenda H.

description: Even after 20 years of occasional visits, I still like this place. See the awesome garden and stop for some tea. What's not to love?
author: Michael S.

description:
This is a quiet microcosm, a monument to the Hagiwara family and the Japanese history of San Francisco.  It's a favorite retreat for all the San Franciscans I know.  

It's always fun to walk among the trees, to feel the wateralls and rivers, to watch the koi as they huddle up close hoping for some treats.  The gift shop is a trip all by itself.  The lanterns, the pagoda, the gate, the bridge, all represent the real Japan, although they are but samples of glimpses of allusions.  

This visit we noticed that the tea house staff was Chinese.  The cookies were Chinese.  The tea was Chinese.  

Ssshh!  Don't tell the tourists.
author: David D.

description: Another foggy day in SF, just looking for some place to take a nice walk. After strolling through Golden Gate Park, my husband and I decided to check out the Japanese Tea Garden. It's a beautiful garden, even for being gray/dreary out. With the ponds, koi, and greenery, it feels peaceful despite being among a crowd of tourists. Definitely worth seeing! I only wish there was more of it. Would love to keep walking through more beautiful scenery.
author: Riz W.

description: I visited the Japanese Tea Garden with my family for my birthday. I LOVE this place! It's so beautiful and relaxing! The architecture, design, stepping stones, and ponds are just amazing! There is a little house in the middle of the place and they provide tea and stuff to eat with it. I just wanted to go there for the atmosphere. It's a like a quick walk in the park! We had to pay $7 for adults and my little brother was 15, so he was charged $5 (for ages 12-17).
author: Sharanpreet D.

description: I went to the Japanese Tea Garden with high expectations and while most were met, I felt like it sucked that I could not change the tea sandwiches. They come pre made which sucks for people who do not eat one or two of the sandwiches. The green tea was amazing and the people were friendly. It may have been busy but the service was prompt.
author: Alesha C.

description: $6 to get in. Tea runs around $3.50 for a cup...and various snacks from $2-$8. Very cute and relaxing place.  If it didn't cost $6 to get in I would go all the time.  It is a lovely place and worth going to check it out
author: Daniel A.

description: Stunning location, peaceful and service was delightful.  A must see when you're in San Francisco
author: Lynne S.

description:
Am I missing something? I have to agree with the few other reviews speckled here and there that the Japanese Tea Garden isn't large or fascinating enough to justify the cost of admission. 

I saw a sunny, serene meadow beside water . . . that visitors couldn't go near (except for an inconsiderate couple who hopped the little fence to take pictures because sometimes adults are horrible). I saw a zen garden . . . that visitors couldn't go near, let alone rake.

The trouble is that GG park is itself so majestic, stunning, and filled with beautiful, varied nature, the Japanese Tea Garden doesn't blow me away. It took half an hour to walk through and explore, tops, and that's with taking our time, stopping to look, pausing to sit and enjoy the sunshine, etc. Nothing blew me away, and a lot of time was spent awkwardly trying not to get in people's pictures. This might be a nice spot to look around, then sit down and read somewhere for hours on end, but not as a fascinating tourist destination. All the kids I saw inside were bored, and many of the adults liked it for pretty photo opportunities and nothing more. I agree that the gift shop isn't much to look at, but I actually highly recommend the over-crowded, over-priced café. I grew up drinking tea, and I thought the hojicha (roasted green tea) was great and the green tea cheesecake even better. Perfect creamy texture, with the green tea taste emerging once you swallow, so you have to eat slowly. The one thing I tried and didn't like was the mochi, which tasted bland and thicker in texture than other mochi I've tried, though I'm by all means no authentic mochi expert. It was an okay experience, but I wouldn't go back a second time or highly recommend it unless you happen to be there during the free hours.
author: Marie L.

description: Well, if you are lucky then you can get free admission during certain time.  Otherwise, you pay a small admission to see this wonderful place.  The landscape is beautiful and great use of space.  You soon realize that less is more.  With carefully placed stones, you will feel at ease and peace here.
author: Phillip Y.

description:
