Henry L. planned a co-worker's DSLR trip here, and it was such a great day. Unfortunately for us this place didn't allow dogs in and Laurie K. had brought her pooch. Nevertheless after we got that squared away and paid 4 bucks at the front door we ran around the area take shots of everything. Sadly enough there weren't much cherry blossoms still on trees as they usually are in blossom more in March. But it was fun to take pictures and see how we all view the same things in different ways. 

I have lived in the bay area my entire life and never visited here. I'm glad I did and with good company and I have some great shots to remember it by.
author: Jessica C.

description:
We happened to be in Golden Gate Park and decided to visit the Japanese Tea Garden.  Luckily for us, it happened to be when the azaleas were in bloom.  Best to go when the azaleas and rhodies are blooming for maximum color.  

We spent about 45 minutes there and easily saw it all.  Very inspirational Japanese gardening design.  Lots of dwarf trees, blooming shrubs such as azaleas, rhododendrons, magnolias, etc., cool koi ponds, ferns, and bamboo.  Japanese gift shop and casual restaurant inside.  

Located near the museums.  $7 for adults.  Check it out.
author: Doctor G.

description:
I'm fairly sure that visiting the Japanese Tea Garden was the best thing we did on our San Francisco trip. 

It's really quiet here in the early morning, which I love. We came on a Monday, so it was free to enter (before 10am). They have this deal on Wed & Fri as well. 

After spending awhile looking through the garden, we had some tea and mochi, and it was also fantastic (albeit a bit pricey, but I expected it to be). 

Unfortunately, this place got a bit noisier around 10-10:30 when lots of people with their kids & entire families in tow came in...

But it'd still be worth seeing, just not as peaceful! :)
author: Carrie O.

description: It was absolutely beautiful but way way smaller than I thought, especially for the price of admission.  It took us all of less than an hour and that was taking out time and walking through twice.
author: Tina E.

description:
Zen Tranquility at its finest! Stop by often as the seasons change to enjoy the beauty. Spring and the cherry blossoms are a delight for the eyes and soul!
Make sure to give yourself enough time to relax, sit,and enjoy all the views
author: A Z.

description: The perfect place to have mochi ice cream, green tea and takoyaki balls. as you enjoy the warmthness of tea, you meditate on a gorgeous view of bonsais and japanese art decor enchanting overall  experience.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Things that they have in here are beautiful. it was very nice got a lot of pictures.

Being from hawaii i will compare this to Valley of the temples.
If you been both places they are close but the structures are more at Tea garden but smaller. but the plants are mush mroe a the garden. 

like them both but worth the time to check out if in the Park.
author: Brett A.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden is beautiful, especially in the spring when the cherry blossoms are blooming. Very relaxing, and just $5 for local SFers. I like to come here and plop myself down on a bench and read.

The "restaurant," however is a total rip-off. $10 for 2 Trader Joe's mochi ice cream balls and a cup of hot water that has a faint hint of jasmine to it? You've got to be shittin me. Also, it's a packed tourist trap on weekends so avoid those shenanigans at all costs. Wish I could go before 10am M,W,F when it's free, but I have this thing called a job. I know, it's totally crampin my style.
author: Elise A.

description:
Extremely Disappointing - From far away, everything is a "wow," when you get up close and personal, that changes to an "eww"

A lot has changed in the fifteen years between my first and second visit to the Japanese Tea Garden. It isn't as grand and beautiful as I remembered it to be. The garden looks dated and in desperate need of a facelift.  If you look at each building, gate, or pagoda, you can see paint chipping off and things that are broken. 

The garden is not bad by any means, but there are dozens of Japanese gardens in California and most of them are probably newer and nicer than this one.  It also costs $5 to enter (and no discount for WF employees).

On a positive note, the garden is well-located next to the De Young museum and the Academy of Sciences.  Street parking is not too hard to find either.
author: Yi Z.

description:
If you're looking for a "cultural" (quotations explained later) experience in a slow/peaceful environment, Japanese Tea Garden is for you. If you're looking for a fun, loud adventure, stay away.

My friends and I were in the mood to explore the city and perfectly enough, the stars aligned and there wasn't gloom in the Bay. From a list of top 100 things to do in SF, we decided to check out the JTG. I think we expected a crazy Japanese cultural experience and an eye-opening take on TEA (aka high expectations) but we were confronted with an expensive entrance fee just to take pictures ($5 SF resident, $7 non-resident). Literally, there's nothing to do there expect walk around plants and take photos in front of what seemingly looks like a Japanese temple, statue, .. bamboo. 

If you're looking to actually try tea, I'd suggest you go to a tea house in Japantown; food prices are highly over-priced. There was a cute gift shop inside but most of the trinkets could be found in a cheap Japanese store like Daiso in Japantown so I would save my money. 

My friends and I ended up heading to a tea house near California St. for 1/2 the price. 

Note: Parking is horrendous on nice weekends because this garden is conveniently located in walking distance to the CA Academy of Sciences and the DeYoung (two museums I highly suggest over this garden).
author: D S.

description: Such a serene and magnificent place to spend a couple of hours just gazing around, taking pictures, drinking tea or just pretending you're actually at a Japanese garden. The size is alright, it would take around 30 minutes to see it all that's with taking your time to stop, sit, look around, and take pictures. The price is $7 for non san francisco residents unless you go on Mondays at 9-10am when admission is free. The gift shop is cute, kind of expensive tea seats but Im not surprised since they're really nice quality. The Koi fish were very friendly and I swear they even posed for pictures haha.
author: Natali Q.

description:
My parents always took me to the tea garden as a kid and then for years I stopped going.  The first time I went back as an adult was on my first "real" date with my current boyfriend about two years back. Since that time, we pretty much make a point of visiting here everywhere time we visit Golden Gate Park.  It costs like $5 to get in, and another $5 to sit and enjoy a pot of tea and some little treats while looking out over a big coy pond. 

We stroll around the gardens eating japanese candies we've purchased from the little store. The guy in the this store is a TOTALY jerk, but I'm a sucker for gummy candy so it is what it is. 

 The botanical gardens right across the street are FREE so yea, it does seem kind of expensive to come to this place. But at the same time, it's totally worth the good vibes and tranquil sounds. Come in the off season for less kids and less tourists so you really can enjoy the peace of it all.
author: Laila P.

description:
CASH ONLY!  Free admission Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays.  Subject to change.  Admission fee for non-resident adults are $7.00.

Gorgeous place to stop by when you're in the area.  If your camera hasn't been played with for a while, take it out for a spin in this garden.  It's pretty quiet and it's overcrowded with screaming babies or the smells of an amusement park.  Fun for an afternoon stroll.
author: Anne N.

description: I went here for the first time 2 days ago and it was soo beautiful. The garden explains the archdecture and history behind the place very well. The entrance was $7 adults residents of SF. I love Japanese landscaping. This place is definitely a great stress reliever and good to take someone to.
author: Kayla G.

description:
What a sad little tourist trap this is. Luckily I went at 9AM on a Monday so the $4 entry fee was waived, but still there were a lot of annoying French and German tourists there. 
Everything about this place made agitated and annoyed rather than relaxed and at peace. Especially when I went into the gift shop and saw that the Yan-Yans that they sell are $2! That is extortion. The person that I was with says that they are preparing me for when I actually vacation in Japan so that I won't be so price shocked about everything. 

Another thing that bugged me was that there were only like 6 koi fish. Was there a mass die-off or was that all that they could afford?

Oh and don't forget to bring a map or iphone or whatever. I got lost for hours because I wondered up some mountain and followed randoms trails around.
author: Drew T.

description: It's missing the Asian vibe. Should have some small Asians running around with happy faces cleaning the place and greeting people. Was too dirty, overpriced, a lot of coins in the water that stupid throw and are dangerous for the fish.
author: Ben F.

description:
I think the world is shrinking.
When I was 5 this place was H U G E !
The super bridge was an mountain to be conquered and the paths seem to run on forever through lush dark green forests with little houses with no doors and doors with no house.
On an October dusk the sun sends beacons of light through the garden, softly highlighting features that should not be missed.
For a tranquil stroll, don't miss this tiny gem.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
Wish I could give Japanese Tea Garden a good review. I love Golden Gate Park and it would have been spectacular to have a peaceful place to have tea and snacks. However, there are a few problems with the Tea Garden. The first is the admissions price. It's $7 or $5 for SF residents (adults). I normally don't have an issue with entrance fees if you get what you pay for and in this regard the Tea Garden sorely disappoints. The grounds aren't very nice. In fact, I would say that the overall landscaping in the park is done better than what's inside the Tea Garden. For those visiting or residents that want to check it out for themselves I would highly recommend coming during the free hour after they open at 9am to 10am, 3 days a week. 

For the Tea Garden itself my wife and I sampled the udon noodles, Mochi cake, green tea cookie platter, Jasmine Tea, and another tea (I forgot the name of her tea). The udon noodles were subpar. The broth was good but the noodles tasted like the run of the mill freeze dried out of the package kind - in other words bad ($9). The green tea cookie plater comes with 3 green tea cookies with nuts and 4 small short bread style cookies ($5) - the short bread cookies were good but the green tea cookies were too dry. The mochi cake was excellent ($3) - moist, flavorful and not too sweet. My jasmine tea was steeped too long - tasted astringent. My wife liked her tea. 

I would not recommend the Japanese Tea Garden - for those who must go save yourself some money and go during the free hour and skip the tea house itself 

Food: Mediocre at best. 2 stars

Service: Quick but don't expect anything like a true tea house experience. 3 stars

Ambiance: Sadly not what was expected. Nice ponds but the landscaping is subpar. 2 stars

Overall: Not recommend. 2 stars
author: Sam P.

description: I am so happy the Japanese Tea Garden is in Golden Gate Park.  It is really beautiful, and some of my favorite highlights included: the really steep bridge across the pond (you'll know what I mean when you see it), the pagodas, and the big fish in the pond.  Joe and I also stopped in the tea room for some jasmine tea, which was restorative and delicious.  My only minus would be the fact that we went on Saturday afternoon, when it was packed with tourists -- so if we went during a calmer time, my rating of this place would be off the charts!
author: Mel G.

description: Not worth the $7 entry fee for adults (I would probably pay the $5 SF resident fee). I thought I was a nature-y type person but maybe not? I've walked past the Japanese Tea Garden during previous visits to Golden Gate Park and have always wanted to check it out, so finally got the opportunity last Friday. We got there around 2pm, and the park was busy but it wasn't as crazy as it is during the weekends. I was able to find a parking spot on the nearby street right away, and there wasn't much of a line for the Tea Garden. We walked around for 10 minutes and basically covered most of the garden! This is one of the smallest tea gardens I've ever seen, and they didn't have a Zen garden area that visitors could rake. I didn't feel like I saw that many coi fish, and I really wish they sold coi food so that you could feed them. The garden was really pretty, but the scenery wasn't so gorgeous that I felt compelled to take any photos. I wish I had checked out the tea and mochi in the teahouse, so if you end up at the Japanese Tea Garden, make sure you don't miss out on that!
author: Amy D.

description:
This is just NOT worth the money or hassle to visit.  I am not trying to be mean, but just observing.  Many many parts of the garden are not even tended to that well.  It's all very sloppy.  I have been to other Japanese Gardens all over the world and THOSE were spectacular.  This San Francisco version is just not very interesting and is very small.

Yes, if you are local go right at 9am to get in for free...After 10am, it costs.  I had to prove I was a local and what they mean is that your DRIVER'S LICENSE says that you are from SAN FRANCISCO.  East bay doesn't count, Sacramento doesn't count, not even Daly City.

Again, I know it might be something that people have recommended for you to see, there is a VERY old Buddha with an interesting history and there is a pagoda structure displayed at the Pacific American International Exposition in 1915.  Those you can see pictures of online.

They of course want you to stay and buy from the gift shop, buy tea, and buy sushi lunch.  Honestly, without rushing, you can walk on every path and be out of there in 15 minutes, and that's with a trip to the bathroom.

...there are big fat coy in all the waterways...which are really algae full and cloudy, wasn't really tranquil at all.  There is a lot of green, but that again goes with the generic part.  Sorry!  If you check out, even pictures online, of Butchart Gardens in Victoria British Columbia, you will understand my standards, but just their Japanese Garden section (one of about 20 areas of the Garden) makes it worth admission.  Everywhere you look, there is attention to detail, constant grooming, beauty, flowers, rock gardens, structures, bridges, stepping stones across crystal clear creeks!

Sorry San Fran, but this "Local" has brought her last tourist to the garden...but if someone really begs me, I'll drop them off at 9am, they can get back in my car at 9:15am and then we'll go to breakfast...
author: Lacey P.

description: The Place is Beautiful.. I enjoy taking pics and I went on a sunny day. The food was kind of expensive but it taste good and the tea blends with anykind of food u order... Its a nice place to clear your head if your stress out :)
author: Cess V.

description: The other reviews have it covered. Tea served in a beautiful setting, an SF highlight indeed.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
No doubt a beautiful gem in Golden Gate Park and one of the top tourist destination, but if you've been to Kyoto, where you visit these gardens one after another until your feet drops, perhaps you won't be impressed.  When I visited here as a tourist, I didn't mind paying an entrance fee, but as a resident, three of us were not thrilled to paying nearly $10 to just get in, and another $10 for three to share a pot of tea.  We were also disappointed by the quality of their tea.

Regardless, tea garden is still a treasure, therefore it's a must visit.  If Japantown could somehow steal this garden and plant it at Webster & Pine, it could lead to revival.
author: トモ T.

description:
JAPANESE?  Questionable.  The kimono clad tea servers were speaking Chinese - funny!

TEA.  Gawd awful.  It was a tea bag not loose tea.  But hey you can get Doritos or Pocky to go with your tea if you would like.  The tea house area itself was really nice as it looks out over part of the garden.  And speaking of the...

GARDEN!  Gorgeous.  I was completely blown away.  You'd never guess it was so picturesque from the outside.  Definitely one of my favorite spots in Golden Gate Park and well worth the small $4 entrance fee.
author: Amy C.

description: Well, it is not as clean as the ones in Japan, but to have a place like this in the City is really, really nice. The flip side is the size ( very small ), the cost, and the tea ( grim ).
author: George T.

description:
It's JUST a Garden and It costs $4 JUST to get in..... 
But you know what? if you think it is too pricey then you just circle it around couple more times then you can get your money worth!! 

I was with my JP friend..... and you know, when you are in a JP Tea Garden and if it is nothing like my friend's 'hood back home, my JP friend would be the first one to shout out! 

Two of us end up circling the garden in multiple times, and i snatched gazillion photos for my JP friend. YEAH~ this JP dude came all the way from Japan and found himself lost in awe at this Magnificent  Garden setting. 

Again, if a JP place is approved by a JP man, it is worth our time!
author: Andrew W.

description: After reding all reviews we went with family and Enjoyed a lot! Thank you so much for all review really appreciated.
author: Firuz N.

description:
Mmm......

Tea served to you by a geisha, to be sat at a wooden table with little wooden chairs surrounded by trees and birds and the sound of trickling water just a ways over seems to hit the mood right on the dot. 

After tea we headed into the garden which had pathways upon pathways filled with different types of trees. From bamboo to bonsai trees. Little pagoda statues here and there. It's a great place for picture taking as well. 

I'm sure this is another one of those tourist traps but I do have to admit, it's somber and serene. Great place to spend a day and unwind.
author: Irma E.

description:
$4 entry fee (cash only).  This is a cute little Japanese garden but it goes by quickly because it really isn't that big.  I really wanted to try the tea/restaurant place near the entrance of the garden but it was super packed so we didn't get to try.

Very cool place to come just to wander around and relax on a lazy weekend afternoon.
author: Angela C.

description: The tea garden in Saratoga is so much bigger!! My bf & I were so disappointed by the size :(
author: VanLam N.

description:
Stopped by here with my girlfriend after the academy of sciences. 
There is a steep bridge, some pagodas, streams and feng shui shrubbery. Kind of neat. Its as exciting as it sounds. 
We sat down and had mochi cakes and green tea in the tea garden. Im not recommending it. 
Go to chinatown for something way better tasting and half the price. Or if you like pond water and sticky odd tasting rice take a seat and bask in the serenity of the garden. 
I would go if it was free however we paid 7$ each. I probably would not come back unless they started having crouching tiger hidden dragon aerial string fighting days.
author: Nick D.

description:
Beautiful place. ^^ Not over the top like a rose garden, but elegant in its simplicity. Simply elegant. There are tons of places to take pictures. I felt like I was back in Japan. ^^  I went here with a Japanese exchange student and even she said she felt like she was back in Japan. That was a good sign. X") 

Entrance is $7 for non-San Francisco residents ($5 for residents) but it's free on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays between 9 and 10AM.  

To the ladies: PLEASE wear some pants or bike shorts under your skirts, especially if you're planning to climb up that incredibly fun-looking half-wheel bridge thing. I was at the base of that bridge when a girl in a short skirt started climbing that wheel. No, it was not sexy. I almost puked onto the kid in front of me when I saw her white-pantied crotch and dimpled bare butt jiggling furiously at me. XP

Other than that nightmare, I loved the garden.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
We had visited the free Japanese tea garden in Central Park in San Mateo a couple of weekends ago...our two year old was fascinated  by the number of koi in the pond and walking over the comfortable bridge there. Yes, it was small.. yes, it looked like it needed a bit of pruning but it was utterly charming for all of us...

The last time I had been to the tea garden was 15 years ago when I was a child and had really pleasant memories of the experience.  It was zen like...  

Now, I wish we had saved our $5 admission fee and avoided this place.   It really felt like a bit of a tourist trap..yes, we went on a particularly busy day (the 4th of July) and the grounds were mantained well but it was extremely small considering the fee and crowds and really just seemed like a place people were going for photo ops.  The tea house also seemed really crowded and took away from the calming influence as I hoped.   And there were such few koi in the pond!

If you're in Chicago, I would highly recommend going to the Chicago Botanical Gardens and their Japanese garden...  or just head to San Mateo and their free one which is much better!
author: Tani S.

description: Wow! Best way to Describe the Japanese tea gardens! The Landscaping here is Flawless! Everything here is just beautiful. You can't help but feel so peaceful & down to earth. I love all the tea's they have to offer here. Wonderful place to go if your visiting Golden gate park! HUGE TOURIST SPOT!
author: Alexandra A.

description: visiting the tea garden brings me a peace of mind, clear my thought and often times a little time travel back to the old days, it's a bit sentimental for me since people come and go after the college years , really enjoy the cherry blossom in march or maple leaves in late autumn, sitting in the tea house enjoying a cup of hot jasmine tea and just let the old memories flow through my mind reminded me how wonderful bay area truly is
author: Jerry S.

description: I loved this place, though I did not have tea. I was there to see the gardens. They were beautiful. My son and his best friend (both 10)  also enjoyed taking pictures and watching the large Koi. It's a great experience for those not used to this type of experience and how amazing to see gardens maintained and managed for 60+ years designed by plant architects from another's time.
author: Jason H.

description:
Tossama C's review summed it all up for me.

For being a tourist attraction they should have a discount for "bay area" residents instead of just SF residents. 

Basically I wouldn't pay another $7 to see:

- 2 Koi fish
- 2 Pagodas
- A handful of rocks and bonzais
- a few broken down buildings (seemingly in process of a remodel).

And I was really dissapointed at how small this garden was.

Cash only.
author: Kat S.

description: Not all that much to see for the price of $7. The gate attendants were rather rude about the lack of a student discount. Go across the street to the much larger botanical garden for the same price (and a student discount). There's also Cherry Blossom Trees right between the botanical garden and tea garden so you don't have to worry about only being able to see Cherry Blossoms in this garden.
author: Alan C.

description:
The tea garden is fantastic.  The grounds are beautiful an the rose garden was a nice touch.  Melanie and I also loved the unique bridge in which you have to climb up and climb down, and the large goldfish swimming in the ponds.  

The only downsides for me were the large crowd (not relaxing) and that it's not very big.  After experiencing the huge Tea Garden area in the Huntington Gardens in Pasadena, I was a bit surprised that we saw everything there was to see in about an hour.  

With that said, we really had an enjoyable time here.  The jasmine tea was awesome.
author: Joseph Z.

description:
I still love this place!

The entry fee has gone up now, $5 for residents.  But for a break from the madness it can be worth it.

I came here after weekend celebrating my birthday as a way to wind down and have some quite time with a few friends.  Its so relaxing to sip tea, maybe have some mochi and watch the koi swim, listen to the waterfall and enjoy the breeze among the flowers.

Take advantage of the free admission 9-10 AM Monday, Wednesday & Friday if you don't want to shell out the $5.  It will do your soul some good.
author: Jen K.

description:
$4 admission, plus $3 for tea... it just didn't seem worth it to me.  The landscaping is pretty and the waterfalls are nice.  It felt very touristy to me - the tea shack and the big store in the middle with very overpriced souveneir crap.  I wouldn't race back here.

I much prefer the San Francisco Botanical Garden at Strybing Arboretum, right across the street - free and stunningly beautiful year-round.
author: Shannon N.

description: Beautiful garden! Peaceful and relaxing. Very friendly. My experience we parked on the street and their was lots of cars and our car got broken into. Don't leave any valuables or luggage if you check out early from your hotel to tour like we did.
author: Roseanne S.

description:
I can't believe that this past Monday was my first time visiting this place! I've lived in California since I was six years old, and it took me THIS long (don't ask!) to get my butt out here!

My hubby, sister and mom came out here after my birthday, and had a really lovely day taking photos and sipping tea and eating cookies at this gem in the GGP. It didn't even matter that we originally wanted to go to the Conservatory, which isn't open on Mondays, because once here, we were very happy!

All the blossom trees were in bloom, and the azaleas and camelias were also all blooming... it was quite a sight for sore eyes! We lucked out on the weather, too! The sun was shining, the air felt like it was about 70, and it was supposed to be a high of 63. So much for the weather report.

The cost is only $4 per person, and you get in and out priviledges. You aren't allowed to picnic here, though. So if you bring a lunch, just go on over to the outdoor benches across the street by the California Academy of Sciences, and take a load off while you munch, then head back over to the Tea Garden. The various garden vignettes are very lovely to look at, and the paths are fun to walk.

I overheard a boy of about nine tell his mom that he wasn't ready to leave yet, and a girl of about 12 say, "I LOVE this place! I never want to leave here!" Very cute! They know what it's about.... :-)

So get your butt over there and spend a few hours roaming around this spring in the Japanese Friendship Garden. You won't be disappointed!!
author: Shari D.

description: This place is one of my favorite places in SF. A beautiful stroll and a lovely Japanese tea shop. Be prepared to wait for a table since this place gets busy, but it is a great experience.
author: Naomi S.

description: Unfortunately, I did not receive this great customer service that some people have mentioned in their reviews. The man that sold us our ticket was very rude and put a huge damper on my group's mood from the start. He really ruined the calming atmosphere. On the bright side, despite how small the garden was, it was pretty, and the woman working in the shop was absolutely adorable and sweet! She almost made up for the bad attitude of the man that sold us our ticket. Not sure it was worth the price though ($8 without residency).
author: May P.

description:
Ok, I was impressed because I thought it would be alot smaller, but 4 bucks to walk around? :/ come on. I guess I was just expecting the food and stuff to cost something. 
But it is a beautiful place. Lovely for taking great pictures. And I love the architecture. I didnt try the tea, though I shouldve. (But I dont think it wouldve been better than Uncle Gee's VitalTea.... )
Actually, come to think of it.... I didnt even see any tea bushes. hmmm...
Plus its right next to the Museum, which is beautiful as well. Thats cool too.
author: Katie P.

description:
Okay, firstly this park is HUGE! so many little things to do and see but we went for the tea garden. $7 pp which I think is a bit much, you can do the whole thing in less than 15 mins really but its cute and great to spend a hour there just driving around the park is amazing. About 2 miles away is the windmills and another 2 miles from there is north point beach and 'the cliff house' which is over priced coffee but nice all the same :)
Tea garden is full of lovely statues and lush greenery, its shaded and all flat to walk around. Lots of huge building/ statues and fun little fish ponds too. Gift shop and tea house - obviously. Enjoy! Free parking throughout the park.
author: Rachael S.

description:
What a beautiful place - and free admission after 5 p.m.! Highly recommend to everyone. It's a serene garden with ponds, a cool wooden bridge, pagodas and a zen garden. You won't see koi fish in the ponds, but little craw-fishes!

The tea house is a great place to relax after walking around the garden. They serves a variety of tea for $2.95/person and they also bring you a little bowl filled with yummy Japanese crackers and cookies. 

I also like to browse in their gift shop. I bought a squished penny collector "passport" when I was there. :-)
author: Gladys C.

description: It's a beautiful area in the park, but I expected something more elaborate. The entrance fee is $7.00 for non-San Fran residents. I finished walking through it in just under 30 minutes. I did not stay to eat, although I did see the menu and it seemed very affordable. Sadly, I was just not impressed.
author: Yvelisse L.

description:
I love this place. I would love this place MORE if there were less people all the time, but they're there because they love this place, too.

Picture it: You walk in. Pay your tiny admission price, and you're met with a little waterfall, the distant sight of people drinking tea somewhere behind it. To your left, you can just barely catch sight of the giant bridge that children eagerly climb up, some parents urging them to pose like they're on Everest, others concerned that their precious babies might fall and hit their heads.  Even adults want to climb it, though. A childish eagerness.

The squirrels are courageous and fearless, following you about. You're afraid they might eat your face, but again! Childish curiosity gets the better of you and you wana interact with it.

Stone bridges over little channels of water. Statues. A stone with an engraving on it. Ornamental cherry blossoms hanging pink and beautiful in the air.

Makes me just want to wander. And then you reach the structures, those structures of fascinating shape and size and colour. A red that pops against the partially cloudy sky and the green trees. You look up as you pass through one, staring at the floral paintings above your head.

Watch as people take pictures of their children. Watch as someone takes a picture of parents taking pictures of their children. Spot the tiny hidden buddha hidden in the grass.

Wander and enjoy.

Ah, so nice.
author: Cate T.

description: This is a beautiful Japanese garden in Golden Gate Park. It's more expansive than you would expect, with several different sections hidden away. There are several notable landmarks with descriptions, including a zen garden and a shrine. There's a lovely tea house with plenty of seating where you can get several types of tea, sandwiches, and pastries. We were there on a beautiful summer Sunday, and there were a lot of people visiting. It felt a little cramped, but not too bad.
author: Carolyn S.

description: This garden is great! An sf gem!! It's free on Mondays before 10am. Well maintained and great trees. There is also a tea cafe in the garden $3.50 for tea which is so affordable. Free parking around the park. They also have a gift shop and a bathroom yay!
author: Diane S.

description: Cool that they serve tea here and have a gift shop. Can get pretty crowded though. Been to many Japanese gardens in the US and this delivered what my expectation  always was from architecture to plants to atmosphere. The arched bridge is an accident waiting to happen, so make sure you have real shoes on and can handle the climb up and the decent.
author: Amanda P.

description: The Tea Gardens were a lot smaller than they look from the outside. My husband and I expected a lot more, especially me living in Japan for almost 3 years. It was a really good representation of Japanese culture and environment, but for the price I don't see it worth it at all. It was beautiful, but small and overpriced. If you could get discounted tickets somehow, I would recommend going - but don't pay full price just to go here. Not worth it.
author: Brittany H.

description: Free hour 9am-10am however it is a small place so don't expect to spend more than 30 minutes max here.
author: Joe B.

description:
GORGEOUS PLACE!!!!  A nice place for a walk, cost a few bucks to get in, but its really nice to check out.

A great place to have tea and take pictures as well.
author: Roger A.

description:
It's been about 5 years since we last went, and while enjoyable, it'll probably be another 5 before we go back. It cost us $5 to get in. The grounds are very well kept and lend themselves to photography - I think we shot 50 photos. There were about 500 people milling around, all with the express intent of capturing the moment on SD card. Personally I liked the Zen Garden the most, but the bridges and pagoda seemed to be more popular. I'm sure this project has been done before but it makes me wonder what it'd be like to look at all the photos different groups take in front of the same landmarks. 

Definitely worth checking out if you haven't before - bring a camera.
author: John M.

description:
Darn you ticket prices!

Though a bit expensive, this place is great for just sitting down and relaxing. There are certain parts of the garden that the tourists don't horde themselves around. Try and go find those places and just enjoy how peaceful it is. 

To be honest, I felt at peace being here, it brought a great calming sensation. 

ALSO, there's this bridge that goes up really high in the garden. Climb it! It's nice to sit up there and look around as you relax.
author: Andrew P.

description:
When I was younger, a visit to Golden Gate Park wasn't complete until I went here. I have heard people complain of the entrance fee, but I often and easily overpay to sit in a Starbucks. Why not pay to escape the city where natural beauty has been so well enhanced by good asian taste?

Don't bother with the gift shop. And make sure you get some tea and cookies!
author: Ari M.

description:
I love, love, love the Japanese Tea Garden. 

However, a lot of weirdos must like it too. 

When we went there, we noticed this man taking pictures. Sounds harmless enough, right? We were walking around and taking in all the beauty, but every few minutes or so, we'd turn and see Mr Photo snapping pictures. And upon closer inspection, we realized that he wasn't taking pictures of the beauty that surrounded us, but some CREEPY doll. He'd place the doll somewhere and take pictures. 

Not sure if he's a regular or what these pics are for, but it surely gave me the willies. 

Anyway, this place will give you a great workout. It's so huge. It surely showed me how out of shape I was (and unfortunately still am). 

Just watch out for creepy dudes with Canons.
author: Allyson M.

description:
Enchanting. The barrel bridge is a fun challenge for kids and adults but the architecture, sculpture and grounds are something San Francisco can be really proud of. 
I suspect but have not verified that one or more of the structures was designed my Julia Morgan, the architect who designed San Simeon for Hearst. Splendid.
author: Lori C.

description: really beautiful place! i like how they have a tiny gift shop and a snack place :) although i wish the place can offer more variety of snacks!
author: Ru C.

description: Critical question: Would you go as the Last Samurai or Karate Kid? However if you do go again and decide to stroll please try the TEA! For some reason it feels a whole lot more fulfilling drinking tea in a Japanese tea garden than anywhere else.
author: Brandon H.

description: Very beautiful garden, started with tea overlooking the pond by the entrance.  Some interesting bits of history make it much more than just a pretty place, and even with a crowd it helps you feel peaceful.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Came here the other day because every time I pass this place I want to walk in. $4 for admission which is an okay deal to me. There were many different spots to get some photo opportunities from. The whole place wasn't very big, but it was big enough for me to spend a good 45 mins walking around and taking pictures.

The souvenir shop is a rip like many others have said, and the crackers and tea don't look particularly appetizing. 

Although I cannot vouch for the authenticity of this place because I haven't been to Japan, I did see an older Caucasian gentleman say to his younger Japanese wife, "Looks like Kyoto." He must know what he's talking about right?

- Cool buddha statue
- Cool mini-bridge that goes over a stream
- Cool mini waterfall

Overall 4 stars.
author: Colin H.

description:
I couldn't wait to walk through the gates to see the beauty of the memory I've held so dear these many years. But wait, $7 admission....but of course that includes tea and cookies right? No. Okay, I admit it's been a good long time since my first visit here as a small girl in the 60's. Maybe my recollection is a bit fuzzy. Weren't there many coy fish swimming freely in the ponds? (only observed 4 yesterday) Tea House looks pretty much the same as I remember but, I thought tea came with the visit as well as it being delivered to your table-pipe dream? I think not. Standing in line at the concession stand for a tiny little treat and teapot of tea with a limit of 2 cups loaned per pot please. This too I'm a bit fuzzy on. 
Families, beware, this could be a deal breaker if your tourist dollars are limited. Family of 5, entrance about $30 bucks, snack of mo chi and tea, $25-35. You may want to save your money and go out for a nice meal instead, that is unless money is no object. 
Don't get me wrong, I love the park and everything it has to offer. We have a small Japanese garden in our little corner of the world and it's nestled in the beautiful and expansive Micke Grove Park in Lodi, CA. Admission, free. Coy, more than you'd be able to count. Rocks to cross over the pond, several spots you can test your skills, Japanese Tea house, unfortunately no. But, if you'd like to hold a wedding in the garden, you can reserve it just for that purpose.  I know, apples and oranges, but, I'm just sayin'!
Overview of the Tea Garden experience, definitely worth one visit, preferably when you are small and dreams and memories are being made.  Climb the bridge even if you're old, it's a great picture spot with your honey and you'll get a good laugh at yourself, maybe even feel like a kid again!
author: Maureen G.

description: Beautiful tourist attraction.  So many places to take photos.
author: Lauren T.

description:
I visited the Japanese Tea Garden recently and found it calming, albeit somewhat filled w/tourists. The Koi fish seemed somewhat lethargic, and there were coins throughout the pond area as well as other water areas. I will however give the garden props for a number of things:

1) A ridiculously steep curvy bridge. I enjoyed watching people trying to climb/lower themselves down it.
2) Pagodas dating back to the early 1900s
3) An impressive Buddha statue 
3) The Zen Garden area--This was by far my favorite part of the JTG. I was reading about how the slopes of pebbles represented mountains, and other areas represented water. I definitely felt the sacred nature/calming serenity of the place and could see how monks would use such areas for meditation on the path to enlightenment. It's a great place to center and be present in the moment.
author: Beth F.

description: A small but breathtaking garden. Beware of the exit that drops you off in the middle of nowhere, go out through the way you went in if you can.
author: Yoni D.

description:
A tourist ripoff.
There is an entry fee. We paid $10.
Then tea and snacks are about $10 per person. There were no costumed servers as in the past.
The grounds are pretty if you enjoy that.
author: Alice R.

description:
This is a decent place to come to once, if you're walking around SF's Golden Gate Park. It's expensive ($7 / out of towner $5 / SF residents) for what it is and lacks what I normally look for in a Japanese garden: tranquility. It's packed with tourists (obviously) yammering away on their cell phones, yelling at their kids, having dumb conversations, etc. and due to the size of the place, you just can't get away from them.

I've been here a few times in which it wasn't so crowded and it was just fine. I don't know what I'm really expecting, SF is a crowded city, but I guess I just wish for one of the normal large, quiet Japanese gardens where you can actually hear the water falling and sit by the rock garden and contemplate.
author: Josh H.

description:
I visited the Tea Garden this past weekend when family was in from out of town. New to the area myself, it was definitely a good "tourist" thing to do. I was a little shocked at first by the $5 charge to get in but it was well worth it. A beautiful world lies inside these walls with plenty to explore.

We enjoyed tea at the tea house with lots of almond cookies and snacks. (We went on a good day. There was an event schedule in Golden Gate park that kept people away from the gardens so we didn't wait long for seating.)

The gardens and ponds were beautiful. I will have to go back one day with a good book and enjoy staying there for a longer amount of time.
Oh, and I can't forget the tall bridge. I felt like a big kid on a playground!
author: Cortney F.

description:
An outdoor Oasis...
Beautiful Bonsai Trees...
Koi Ponds...
Wooden Bridges...
Artistic Pagodas...
A Little Tea Hut House..

Take a deep breath, escape from life, inhale then exhale... 
A little Peace and Tranquility in San Francisco 

and Delicious Teas
author: Vee R.

description: Nice tea garden, zen ambiance, this is a nice place to stop after visiting the Japanese Garden.   We tasted two different teas, and also had the Green tea ice cream . Fabulous and tasty. Prices are reasonable.
author: Sylvie C.

description: Real nice. Didn't expect fine quality at the teahouse, and didn't receive it; but it is a nice place to sit and sip for a while. Lots of very pretty things to look at throughout the gardens themselves. 100% worth a visit.
author: Victor C.

description:
I finally took a day off from work to enjoy the beautiful spring weather and headed out to the park.  Actually I had to rush to the park because I wanted to get into the tea garden before 10am so that it was still free on a Friday.  

Aside from the many tourists in the garden during the free hour, the place is still stunning and serene.  It felt a little bigger than I remembered, although it's definitely not a huge place.  It's a perfect place to go when the weather is gorgeous.  Honestly, as a person who lives in SF, I probably would never pay to enter this place because it doesn't take you long to go through it.  Having it free three days a week for an hour seems pretty fair.  

On a side note, even the people who came in right at 10am were able to walk right in without paying.  Maybe they're laid back at the garden and you might just have a grace period after 10 if you're lucky.
author: Stacey C.

description: My boyfriend surprised me on our 5 months by taking me here. It is such a beautiful park, breathtaking at the least. The cafe is nice as well, freshly served tea and light snacks to have. Their gift store is just beyond amazing, I have a fine taste in tea pots and cups. The design/architecture really makes you feel like you're actually in Japan.  Most definitely going to come back!
author: Tammy D.

description:
Best Japanese Garden I have been in the US.
Their gift shop is going downhill though.

Their flora/fauna is well maintained.
Appealing landscape design.

The tea house on a rainy day is pretty worth it.
I had green tea and mochi squares. the orange flav mochi are pretty darn good : )
author: Cadence C.

description: Likely much better during the week... But way too crowded with tourists and screaming, unsupervised children on the weekend. Not exactly peaceful constantly bumping into others and trying to navigate tiny footbridges while people stand in the middle to take a really important photos of koi fish... The garden itself is beautiful and maybe if it was possible to walk around slowly & quietly it would feel worth $8. As it was we hurried out of there in about 20 minutes.
author: H. K.

description:
Ok place you know.  Not really THAT beautiful.  Full of tourists walking around kind of wondering why they are and just taking photos because everyone else is.  Babies crying, couples kissing.  People drinking tea.  Ehhhh, it's ok you know?  

It was the most fun when I came here in elementary school on a class field trip.  I guess it was more magical then.  Perhaps I have been too many times or perhaps I am just jaded.  It's a worthwhile tourist attraction.  It has an interesting history also.  Spend 45 minutes there and you probably won't regret it.
author: Cynthia B.

description: My first time to the gardens was on my fifth birthday and I've have been returning ever since then. I had so many great memories being at the Tea Gardens growing that I will remember them forever. A must see when vacationing in San Francisco and a great place for awesome photo opportunities as well.
author: John O.

description:
It's kinda like finding the Garden of Eden. Beautiful, peaceful, relaxing. I wish it were a little bigger.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Yes the entrance fee, of $7 now, is a bit pricey, the tea room is ridiculously pricey and the gift shop is a bit pricey as well

The gardens are beautiful and totally worth a visit!  I love the Buddha statue and during Spring with the all the cherry blossoms the gardens are splendid!
author: Caroline D.

description:
This is a nice place to come if you are looking for something different to do or if you have family in town.  My bf and I came here for part of our date day and we were not disappointed.  The garden was beautiful and has many great picture opportunities.  I recommend bringing a camera.  There is a small tea house that over looks the garden (outdoor) as well as a tiny gift shop.  We had a mochi tea set and it was delish.  Best Mochi, I have ever had.  We took some home as well.  The price for tea and mochi (3 pieces) was 4.50$.

Admission to the garden was 7$ for SF non residents.  $5 for SF residents.  I believe it is free on some days as well.  They only take cash so be prepared.  Plan on spending about 60-90 minutes.  Parking can suck so I suggest off peak times (not weekends if you can help it.)
author: Courtney R.

description: This is a review just on the tea and mochi that you get at the tea house. The jasmine tea was just like any other jasmine tea. I guess what made it more phenomenal was the fact that I was drinking it in a freaking Japanese garden in San Francisco. The mochi was so soft and delicious. They give you a piece of green, yellow, and pink mochi that has flavors to match the color. The green is green tea, yellow is mango (or something tropical) and the pink is strawberry. I would go back just for that mochi and tea!
author: Justine T.

description:
this is one of my most favorite places in the city... probably because i have very fond memories of coming here as a child with my dad.  he and i would cruise through golden gate park with a bag of peanuts and feed the pigeons and the squirrels.  my mom hated that part so she and my sister would stroll elsewhere and then we would all meet up in the japanese tea gardens for a little peace, quiet, and japanese tea and cookies.

i took an out of town guest here over the memorial day weekend and it was somewhat busy but the gardens are generally pretty quiet with the exception of a kid here and there.  we walked the grounds, climbed the bridge, and then had tea and crackers.

golden gate park is charging for things now that they didn't before and even though it's kind of annoying to someone who grew up in the bay area, i don't really care because i like supporting my beautiful city.
author: Lauren P.

description: This is the strangest place to me. It's like a little offshoot at Disneyland. Basically you walk around a bunch Japanese style hedges and structures... Not much to see. Maybe I'm missing something. I've been three times and always leave wondering why I ponied up the entry fee again.
author: Maureen B.

description:
Beautiful. The garden is exceptionally well maintained!  

Although I would have donated $3, in actuality, it cost $5 .  But I guess the bushes doesn't cut itself, or the tea prepares itself.  

Go on a sunny day- during almost closing time (4:00pm-4:30) to capture beautiful lighting around the ponds and mini bridges.  

About the tea hut.  It was overwhelmingly filled with people with nowhere to sit.  Of course I went on December 29, Tourist holiday rush.  But it's not anything too amazing.  They have traditional Japanese waitresses serving tea, while guests can enjoy the garden scenery.

Anyway, it is a great one time must-see!
author: Moua L.

description:
I just realized I never reviewed this place. This is very overdue.

I had been wanting to come here for a long time after seeing pictures. We got there around 11am on a Saturday and there was a ridiculously long line. 

Thanks to Yelp, I knew that they only accept cash (minus a star! I never carry cash.) so we were prepared for that.

The whole garden was much smaller than I'd originally thought it was. Or maybe it was just the huge masses of people that made it seem that way?

They have very nice clean restrooms when you first get inside, so that's a plus (or a star!).

I really enjoyed everything but was super bummed about not seeing any koi! There's a nursery here in Fresno with more impressive ponds and massive koi. And you don't have to pay $7 to get in, either. Anyway, I don't know if they were going through koi maintenance or something and they were somewhere else, or if they just don't have any. But I was really looking forward to seeing some.

The tea house was nice and I liked that it was outdoors. What I didn't like was having to wait and hope that people would start leaving. Then when they did we had to cram uncomfortably close to strangers to eat our lunch/snacks. I'm a germophobe but luckily we were close to the edge so we could enjoy the view of the ponds (that remember, don't contain koi).

The food was good but the mochi ice cream was maybe one of the best things I've ever eaten! I'll go back just for that! 

One other annoyance was that there was some concert going on right next to the garden, and all we heard the whole time was the boom of bass, so it totally killed that tranquil feeling of the garden.

Overall, it was nice but I don't know that I need to come back. I do need to find that mochi ice cream somewhere, though.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Next time I'll take the advice of others and come during the early morning on MWF for the free admission and QUIET!

I actually really love this spot.  In the rare moments where I wasn't avoiding a running kid or circling around groups of tourists, I found the garden charming and could almost feel the zen.  The grounds are immaculate and very well maintained.

Careful on that steep bridge!  Climbing up was fine, but I was clinging to the sides trying to work my way down.
author: Maryrose S.

description:
When it is cold and snowing and awful in NY, I like to think of warm and wonderful and happy places that don't make me want to curl up in my snowsuit and die. The Japanese Tea Garden is one of those warm and happy places! Yes, probably it's a bit of a rip off, but whatever, I can do touristy things when I am not in my own city. And it's not that heinous of a ripoff (under $10 is a-ok by me). 

It's really pretty, and definitely uber-Zen-Buddha-happy place (clearly, I am good at the Japanese thing). The tea is..meh, whatever, you can have it or skip it, I guess it's all about setting the mood. I recommend a weekday, definitely less packed than, say, a warm Saturday (I know, I am amazing with the tips and tricks). Good for meditation, happy thoughts, and possibly romancing someone if you're that type, but I have a feeling native San Franciscans (Franciscaners? How on earth do you pluralize that?) probably think it's kind of cheesy.
author: Irene F.

description:
I Love coming here!!! 

perfect picture opportunities...except on busy holidays like the day my date and went on... well definitely bring her back on a warmer day when the little lakes are all full with all the coi and fewer people visiting, and especially to enjoy some tea at the quaint little tea house nestled inside the garden.... 

This place really takes me back to the actual country side in Japan where I spent some time when i was stationed in Okinawa, during my time in the Navy....it's hard to believe this place is in San Francisco... but this breathtaking, picturesque landscape easily transports you to another place and time... makes me wanna dress up like a ninja and run around... :) 

My date and I got lucky cause there happened to be another couple there who had an expensive camera.... rule of thumb most people with expensive cameras take good pictures... 

so i asked them if they could take a picture of my date and I at one of the many photo spots with her iphone...which they happily obliged... have to say that was a great picture, so glad we took that opportunity... 

bathrooms convenient but i'm sure hard to maintain although the grounds keepers did a great job being such the tourist attraction that it is!!!! 

Last stop... the gift shop... where my date fell in love with the cutest little tiger collectibles... and being that she was born in the year of the tiger i just had to get them for her... plus every time she looks at them she will remember that day.... 

needless to say we had an incredible time, most in part to my date who was like a little ball of sunshine.. :) , can't wait to go back with her!!! 

Oh the price can't be also...
author: keith p.

description:
a nice place to take a stroll and just totally forget that you're in the city for a while. 

kind of expensive to have tea here,but  it's worth trying a cup.  it was really nice to just sit down and take in the scenery while sipping on some tea.  

FEELS GOOD, MAN.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
$7 dollars a person, NO REFUND. 
They were renovating and cleaning the ponds when I went and still may be doing so. There was no water in the main pond and I only saw 3 koi fishes. The place looked rather bare. It also was a lot smaller than I expected. I wish I could have gotten a refund and went back when there was water in the pond or they should at least put a sign up.
author: Tossama C.

description: Seven bucks?  I felt like I could've went to the movies -this place is soo small.  Not worth it.  Go to the Botanical Gardens instead.
author: Kristina P.

description: Breath taking and beautiful.  The garden is well maintained and clean.  If you're a photo junky, this is definitely a place to hit up.  The bridges, the tower, the koi, and the walkways are all great photo opportunities.  The tea place is a bit crowded, but worth checking out.
author: Richie C.

description:
Small, but very pretty. The $7 admission fee may seem steep if you are not a fan of Japanese garden design.

If you are a fan, do not miss the miniature tree collection. They are not quite Bonsai, but they are stunning.
author: Megan B.

description: This place is very serene and calming, helps you appreciate nature and the beauty of it. If this is what Japan looks like, I definitely have to plan a trip for the future. The only time I have ever seen anything similar to this was on Karate Kid and leaving there made me want to watch it again. We came here when we were first dating and he actually suggested places for us to go, oh how I miss those days that more effort and thought were put forth lol. This was a good spot he took me to, it was very romantic. Grant it you just walk around and see the beautiful flowers and Japanese architect, it was still fun. The best part was the little "tea house" where you can stop and sip tea which can be accompanied by some savory and sweet Japanese items to snack on. Although not you can walk around the entire place within about 30 min, its a great place to at least experience once, and guys if you want to win some points be sure to take your girl here.
author: Candice B.

description: Great place. Amazing views. Enjoyed walking around the gardens.
author: Scott H.

description: Great garden.  Great food.  Except that the green tea cheesecake tastes exactly like a regular cheesecake.  It is green though.
author: Paul W.

description:
It's a beautiful place, but very small and totally overpriced for what it is. 

I've only been a few times, whenever I have out-of-town guests who want to see this place - and every time, I walk away feeling like there should've been more to see. The gift shop is overpriced as well - you can buy the exact same stuff in Chinatown for a quarter of the price!
author: J K.

description: SF MUST SEE. I've been to the garden at least 50 times, and discover something new each time. It used to be free early Sunday, but I think that's changed. Still worth the visit.
author: Wade M.

description: This place reminds me of the secret garden because it's a whole 'nother world once you step inside.  It is very serene and I always forget how big it is.  The tea is decent and they have a lot of snack options.  I really love all those little cookies.  They are soooo yummmmmy! I like to walk around first then end with the tea and cookies.
author: Britt B.

description:
The Japanese tea gardens are beautiful and one of my favorite places in the world.  I've been going here since I was 10 months old, and the serenity of the place still captures me.

I love the tea, I love the half moon bridge, I love the pagoda tower and the stone work from Japan.  It's a fantastic place to just stop and breathe.
author: Tasha D.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is very cute, although I think the admission fee is a bit overpriced given its size.  The tea house in the garden is expensive, especially for the portions that you get.  I tried the Taiyaki and Hawaiian Mochi Cake; the Taiyaki was yummy (it's a cake of red bean inside a pancake shaped like a fish), but the Hawaiian Mochi Cake was too sweet.  The gift store is also quite expensive but has a lot of adorable tea sets.  I bought a very cute owl mug while I was there.  Overall, the Tea Garden is a nice and essential stop if you're in the Golden Gate Park.
author: T T.

description:
This place was really beautiful. There is this awesome Japanese bridge that is just really cool and you definitely should go up it's kinda scary to go up because its very steep but definitely do it!

$7 for people who do not live in San Francisco
$5 for residents
Free if you go in before 10am

I would really try to go in before 10 am because it's kinda not worth the $7 especially since you have to pay for the food and beverages at the little hut/cafe thing. I would def recommend getting the Miso soup and the Moshi balls they were really good but I've never had either so I don't have anything to compare them to. 

What you should do is get to the Golden Gate Park early enough to beat the 10am thing and then explore everything else, especially the Academy of the Sciences because it is so close and closes at 5pm so you will have plenty of time to see it.
author: Jess K.

description:
The grounds are well cared for, but on one of the temple roofs the wood is rotting and needs some reconstruction.  The zen garden is very peaceful, even with many people walking by.  Stay away from the tea room.  The service is awful, as we waited more than 10 minutes for one of the waiters, and when we called to him, he came over with an attitude.  We just left.
The gardens are nice, but not really worth $7 per person to see.
author: Chris E.

description: THE BEST PLACE TO TAKE PICTURES!! my friends and i went to this place and our pictures came out amazing! its a fun sight seeing place :)
author: Amyyyyyyyy T.

description: Absolutely gorgeous garden. I come here pretty much every day for my morning meditation. Peace.
author: Margaret C.

description:
I LOVE the Japanese Tea Gardens!!! I have been here several times and have been captivated every single time. If you plan on going, try not to go on a Saturday when its super packed with tourists. 

The gardens are expertly maintained. You can literally take a seat on the bench (or bridge) and sit there all day long.

It gets better! Have tea in the garden, stay a while and hang out. They serve you tea and snacks. 

It only costs $5 to get in. $5!!! Come on? I mean it costs almost that price for a latte these days and people are complaining about $5 to get in and enjoy the view? Its definitely worth it. I guarantee you will not see anything like this place...anywhere in the bay area at least.
author: Catie N.

description:
Japanese Tea Garden is free before 10 AM on Mon, Wed and Fri.  It's rare that my husband and I plus the baby all have the same day off and can get up early enough to not miss the 10 AM window.  But we made it there twice this past week.  Yay for the Holidays!

We weren't the only ones taking advantage of the free admission.  The garden is quite full of people, especially families (who else can get up this early?)  

Clean water in the ponds, trees are nicely trimmed.  The garden is quite adorable. 

The tea house has a pretty view of the pond and I like that it's very open and you can sit facing the pond.  It's really a perfect date place.  Serene, casual and comfortable.  My husband had a hoji tea and I had a genmai cha.  The tea set is $4.50 which comes with three pieces of mochi.  The mochi was not bad.  I wasn't expecting an awe-inspiring culinary experience here, given the touristy nature of the location, and reading about the controversy over ownership changes made me realize that it's not owned by Japanese.  Even the waiter was an older white gentleman who thinks genmai cha has a lot of caffeine.  So if you are here trying to immerse yourself in authentic Japanese culture, you may face some disappointment.

But still, it could have been a whole lot more gimmicky than what it is now: simple and nice.  As long as they don't end up with a Benihana here, I am happy enough.  And I don't really care if the owners are of Japanese descent or not.
author: Candice B.

description:
From what I hear, this place has changed but I went a about a year ago and loved every minute of it. My "date" and I took the tour of San Fran and it brought us to the Japanese Tea Garden, and after a night of drinking and partying, he and I both enjoyed the peacefulness of the garden. Got our tea, and took in the scenery. It really gave me the illusion of being in Japan, it's like a vacay in a vacay. This place is just beautiful, especially if you are the type of person to love culture. 

I didn't find it to be overpriced at all, at least not that I can remember, it really is a place to just recharge yourself. If you are going to be in san fran, take a walk through the Japanese Tea Garden, well worth it.
author: cassina Q.

description:
I love the idea of a Japanese Tea Garden in San Francisco Park! 

My first visit was very tranquil and serene. We savored the peaceful and natural sounds of the trees, birds, water running through and occasionally the sounds of the Japanese women serving tea.

At this visit, I wasn't as impressed as the first time. There was a very loud couple with an incredible laughter of  a hyena, which took away the savoring sounds of the peaceful and natural environment. And I noticed that the tea garden is missing cherry blossoms and the Japanese air and energy which would remind you that you are in Japan.  There are no words to describe, but for those that have been in Japan, will know exactly what I am referring to.


I still give it 4 stars because of my peaceful partner was again beside me.
author: Honey T.

description:
One of my favorite places to have chill out and take pictures.  There are some seriously gorgeous irises there that I love to photograph in macro.  If you don't like getting as close up to your subjects, you may have to wait a bit for people to move out of your shot.  

The tea house itself is meh. Not a very large selection of tea or snacks.
author: Hilary K.

description:
This is a very cool place to visit when you're in Golden Gate Park!  The gardens are wonderful to walk through and are only complimented by the fun teas that you can try...

There is a lot of artistic beauty tucked into the garden - such as statues and little shrines...

This is the type of place that tourists should see at least once...and locals too :)  Theres a certain time frame that you can visit and get let into the park for free, too! Check it out!
author: Ryan L.

description:
Make that 3.5 stars. The garden really is pretty, but NOT worth the money!
So if you really want to see it go on a Monday, Wednesday or Friday morning between nine and ten o'clock, it's free then.
author: Bekkah R.

description:
This is a beautiful spot, but I think it's over-hyped and the admission is pricey given how small and crowded the tea garden seems to get.

The obscenely over-priced tea shop right at the front with the tacky gift store behind it made me feel like I was entering a tourist trap.

Given the natural beauty of the park surrounding it - and the many FREE parts of that - I don't think the Tea Garden is particularly worth it unless you've never seen anything of the sort.
author: Darrien A.

description: A real treasure in San Francisco - great for tourists and locals alike.  Great scenery, a pagoda and plants and a "zen" garden feel.  Don't miss it!  (And you really can have tea there!)
author: Karen F.

description:
CASH ONLY admission ($7). 

The Tea Garden has gorgeous, serene grounds; meandering paths, lush trees and fascinating Japanese gates and sculptures. There are little ponds, a Zen Garden and a really cool, almost circular bridge (you'll see). I think there's a tour also, which focuses on the various plants. 

I enjoyed the teahouse itself too, which serves delicious tea and dainty snacks both savory and sweet (like mochi). You can sit, drink your tea, chill out. 

A nice slice of a park within a park. Come here, relax, enjoy.
author: Rita E.

description:
This place is a pretty cute tea garden. I've been to a few, but this was one of the bigger ones. Its a nice little place to walk around with a date or check out during the day--and its admission is pretty cheap ($4?). There's one free morning a month (some Tuesday or Wednesday) which is worth looking into...

I think besides the pleasantry of the garden itself, the tea house is my favorite thing about this place. On a cooler day where you are walking around the park but can still see your breath, getting tea is so relaxing. Chatting with friends in an exposed outdoor tea house munching on cookies overlooking pagodas, koi ponds, and manicured trees... its really amazing that in SF this snacking experience is only 3 dollars.

Definitely a fun place to check out...
author: Samantha R.

description: The food sucked and was expensive but that's not why you come here. Bring your stress and worries then leave them at the door when you leave. I sat on a bench and stared at a rock garden for a quite a while. I even got my ADD son to stop talking for almost 10 minutes. That alone is worth the price of admission.
author: Thor S.

description: Horrible! Extremely boring and overpriced. This is not really a garden its more of a place with trees and shrubs. Not worth $7.
author: John S.

description: This place is beautiful and very relaxing. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because its $7.00 to get in. That is stupid, $5.00 I could understand but they have to get those 2 extra dollars.
author: Alex M.

description: I have to admit I was a bit disappointed when I came here. I expected it to be big, but I should have known better looking at the map of the Golden Gate Park. It cost $7 per person to get in and a friend and I went around the place in probably 15 minutes? Yes, it's that small. We did spend a considerable amount of time in the lil tea place in the middle of the garden. I also liked the very high bridge that one could actually cross over (unlike the one at Huntington library in socal). Overall, it was okay.
author: Jane J.

description: I love this place, but I wish the entrance was free for San Francisco residents
author: Mary K.

description: Photogenic fun in a miniature, manicured setting, the Japanese Tea Gardens can be either a local place for repeat visits or a one-time tourist trap. It will refresh your senses - if you let it - or just make you frustrated at the crowds and gift shop. Sadly, most people come to consume things here and to hide behind the lens of their cameras. If you actually look at the plants, ponds, stones, and bridges, listen to the wind and the water, and allow the tranquility inherent in such a place of beauty to wash over you, then you will forget the rest. After leaving, stroll through the free admission botanical gardens in Golden Gate Park as well (although donations are appreciated, and definitely appropriate).
author: Bradley N.

description:
Great place...absolutely gorgeous.

BUT, $7 admission? I'm not saying $7 breaks the bank, but it's definitely too much for a place you can literally get through in 20 minutes....

With that said, I'd definitely recommend checking it out at least one time...and definitely get the jasmin tea with mochi.
author: Farbod D.

description: It makes me happy to walk around this beautiful garden. There is a nice gift shop, and cafe area to relax and drink tea as well. I liked the peaceful atmosphere, and the koi fish and the cool bridge/wheel thing to climb. It's a great place to take pictures. (There was even a wedding couple taking photographs there the day I went.) I'm glad that such a beautiful place exists here in San Francisco.
author: Christina G.

description: One of my favorite things in this amazing city. The scenery is to die for. Wish I could go there daily. Pagodas, koi fish, and a beautiful buddha sculpture that is pretty spectacular. Not to mention the lush gardens. Ah-mazing. Friendliest, plump squirrels as well. This is a MUST SEE.
author: Shawna Q.

description: Beautiful place! I really felt like I was in Japan. Very zen and relaxing. We checked out the tea lounge and ordered tea and snacks. Good food! We saw many people taking pictures such as engagement pics. I wish this was in my backyard.
author: Kirsten L.

description: I've always loved this garden.  Serene, beautiful, calming, zen, whatever you want it call it, it's well worth the $5 entry fee.  You walk around, you see the coy pond, you walk up that huge bridge, you take some picture, you leave happy!
author: Denis S.

description:
This is my favorite of all the Japanese Friendship Gardens that I have visited. I LOVED the awesome bridge, it is a drum bridge and you have to really climb to get to the top. Warning: If you are a female wearing a skirt, do not attempt to climb this bridge, otherwise people will laugh at you.

A lot of different pathways, a temple, and a cute store. I didn't try the tea house, but it was pretty crowded. On Saturday mornings until a certain time it is free...so you can avoid paying the fee if you time it correctly.

Definitely worthwhile to checkout if you're in Golden Gate Park.
author: Glaciala A.

description:
I love everything Zen and kawaii -- I even studied Japanese  -- so I appreciate this garden so much.

This place is serene, peaceful, with well-manicured plants and lawn. Our  kids love this place!
author: Thea T.

description:
The garden is beautiful and reminds me of parks in Asia.  Definitely try to go for free on MWFs before 10 AM because my 3 friends and I don't think that this place was worth the $7.  If you walk just into the entrance before you pay your entrance fee, you get the gist of the place already.  It's just more of that, pretty green plants and stone paths.  There's also some full-grown koi, which are cool if you've never seen that before.  There IS one cool bridge in the back which is shaped like a wheel, which kids love climbing up and down to.  Great photo spot.

But really, save your money for the DeYoung Museum and other more worthwhile places.
author: Rona H.

description: I love this place! It's well worth the inexpensive cost of admission. I've been here 4 times so far and I will definitely go back!
author: Mrs. B.

description:
One of the best Japanese gardens in the United States! It's very small, but entirely worth it, especially if you're at all interested in gardening or the Japanese aesthetic, both of which are maintained to the highest degree here.

The Tea House serves a great variety of teas and small desserts which are all delicious and fresh. I think the gift shop has been recently remodeled because unlike one of the reviews here, it is now looking very sharp and has a great variety of good quality gifts, including Japanese Tea sets, books and toys.

I love this garden very much, and try to go as often as I can. It's extremely peaceful and relaxing. It might be a bit boring for some of the younger kids, as it isn't a place to run around and scream, but I think older children (10-15) would probably be able to enjoy it very much.
author: Betsy W.

description:
I love this place!

I've been here twice and it seems to always be the perfect start to a foggy San Francisco day. Walk the gardens, snap some pictures, end your trip with a stop by the gift shop and of course some tea.

I am bummed that the gate does not take credit cards, so don't forget your cash to cover the entry fee!
author: Todd W.

description: The tea garden is absolutely lovely. I really felt like I was in Japan the structures and plants were that authentic! It's very peaceful and there are beautiful ponds with friendly koi fish everywhere. The structures are amazing and make for great photo opportunities. It's not crowded, so you can take a relaxing and leisurely walk throughout it. The only downside is that I didn't find the tea to be out of this world delicious and it's crowded in the tea hut itself, so you have to snag seats when you can. The gift shop next door has lots of great things to buy as well, but you can find lots of similar items for cheaper in Japantown. Overall it's a beautiful place and I highly recommend visiting it if you're in Golden Gate Park.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
So calm and relaxing...

I love going here whenever I'm in San Francisco.  Just walking around the little garden feels nice.  Looking at the Koi fish, walking across the tall bridge, then finishing off the walk in the tea house for the wonderful tea and crackers.  It's great!

However, there is an admission fee of $7, which is a bit much for what you're seeing.
author: Tanya T.

description: Last visit was over 30 yrs ago. I shouldn't have stayed away so long.
author: Mark M.

description: I am pretty convinced that this place is magical. Absolutely beautiful and the jasmine tea was yummy! I will defiantly be back.
author: Christina V.

description:
The architecture is stunning and the garden is of course beautiful.

The walkways here can get a bit narrow which can make it difficult to compete with oblivious mommies and strollers. It was difficult to truly relax here given the obnoxious patrons and their need to scream at each other for the perfect photo atop the bridge or beneath the pagodas. There was also an extremely loud Yo-Yo event taking place next door and all we could hear was the pounding base.

The tea service was better than what I've experienced at tea gardens, but alas it is pricey. (17 bucks for tea for two, a single bowl of miso and misubi) Especially considering it is all around CASH ONLY.

It was a nice visit but personally I would want something a lot quieter and maybe even a grassy area to sit down and relax. It would be interesting to compare the ambiance to a weekday.
author: El P.

description: Pretty garden. It was a little smaller than I thought it would be. We got in free because it was almost closing. We walked to this place because Parking was hard to find in the Golden Gate Park on the weekends.  We found one really really far away.
author: Sandy N.

description: Touristy but so calm and peaceful. Lots of ideas for those interested in landscaping. I could spend hours there.
author: K C.

description:
Having family in town and not wanting to go to work turned into going to the JTG for the day!!
I love how peaceful it is here, the minute you walk in you might just forget you are in SF. Although it's not huge, this is a perfect for a break from city (or work) chaos. Bring a camera because you will want to take a picture or two.... 
:-)
author: Hilda Z.

description: As a child, wanting to be Mary Lennox, I considered the JPG my own secret garden. And in pretending to be British/Mary Lennox-like, I would drink delicious hot cocoa in the cafe as though it were tea.
author: Mairead J.

description:
Nice place - but $7 cash-only admission.  Really?

I didn't try the food or drink here.  It really is a nice garden.  I wouldn't mind paying $3-4 dollars, but $7 is a bit of a stretch.

Quiet and pretty, but expensive for about 15-20 minutes of walking around.
author: J K.

description: I usually avoid Golden Gate Park since I can't find anything and get lost but I was pleasantly surprised by all the cool hidden treasures throughout the park.  The Japanese Tea Garden was a nice stop in our day long walk and I stuffed myself with mochi ice cream and iced green tea.  It's a nice little stop and relatively cheap and peaceful.
author: Suz L.

description: The GGP Japanese Tea Garden is an excellent example of art and architecture from Japan, and the care and skills of the local landscaping crew are really highlighted in the way the garden is taken care of and in the way the different structures are located, including the buildings and the sitting buddha.  There are shrines everywhere inside the garden and the reverence for the atmosphere and quite serene surroundings is evident in every detail, and shows as well in the respect most visitors have for the place.  It is not surprising that local Japanese visit this place as well.  Really nice!
author: Thomas H S.
