description: Beautiful garden-a pity about the $7 per person charge - so it was $28 4 of us on top of the cost of tea! They should offer an option of cheaper( or free) entrance fee IF you get the tea at the little restaurant in the garden. The tea was good although it's strange that they only offer tea for one person - you cannot order a pot for 2  or more people!Also, had the assorted biscuits which came with fortune cookies since the family who ran the garden in the 40s were the ones who invented the fortune cookie. Good place to visit if you time it to coincide with the free entry times!
author: Renuka V.

description:
This place is GORGEOUS!!  I wish this place was my backyard, however without all of the annoying tourists. I highly recommend going when it isn't crowded, which I presume would be during the weekdays.

I went on a saturday and the place was packed. Taking pictures was a bitch! Everybody wanted to take pictures of all the same things, which quickly became very annoying to deal with.  

I also saw this half naked chick with her boyfriend/"photographer" taking pictures in the middle of the pond. Very disrespectful and very weird.
author: Robin K.

description: One of the highlights of our San Francisco visit!  We went here after going to the Botanical Gardens, which were a little disappointing.  The grounds were beautiful, we could have taken a picture of everything.  It only cost $7 a person, which in my opinion was worth it.  The grounds were larger than it looked from the outside.  We also had some cookies and tea at the tea house which was a real treat!  The Japanese Tea Garden is not to be missed!
author: Keely D.

description: Really cool place, very interesting pagodas. If you want to eat at the tea house expect a long wait, it took almost 2 hours to order, eat, and pay, I went on a Sunday. But the garden is worth visiting.
author: Melinda F.

description: It's actually much bigger here than I thought. My friend and I got here before it closed and we spent so much time taking in the scenery, we got lost. Literally lost...we had to follow a family out of the exit. If you're looking for a peaceful, calming and serene place in the city, this would be it. We spent hours wandering around and looking at everything. It's almost like a work of art, only in a garden. You can even grab a cup of tea if you'd like. It's definitely a fun place to snap photos and relax at before going back into the bustling areas of the city.
author: Amy J.

description: It's a little overpriced, but it really is an experience.  Much like paying for a waterfront restaurant, you're paying for the ambiance/view.  Great if you're trying to spend a day outdoors at GGP or just having a different experience in the city.  I'd bring visiting friends here, maybe before or after a bike ride in the park.
author: Erika C.

description: I had never been here before, but we went there for my wife and I's engagement photos. It was beautiful, down side is we had to pay for a paper map (less than $1). I also was sad that the arc-bridge (I don't know the name of it) was under repairs (it was the main reason for us going to the Japanese Tea Garden).
author: Michael B.

description: It's sad to hear what Jeff G said about the gardens. It's still a beautiful site. I could spend all day there just wandering and meditating. The whole vibe of the gardens is very peaceful and Zen. I took my family who was visiting from Santa Cruz, I dont like how you have to pay to get it, I think it should be a free place to enjoy for the public. Don't go there on a holiday or possibly even busy weekend, there is so many people.
author: Danielle K.

description:
How can people hate on San Francisco's Japanese Tea Garden?!? A tourist trap? Well, yeah, you're probably going to find some tourists there because, you know, it's in San Francisco!  But most locals also love this historical SF must-see and don't mind paying a measly $4 to enjoy some time in a beautiful garden. This is the oldest Japanese Tea Garden in the United States and, I'm sure, the most beautiful. I've been visiting the JTG since I was a kid and would stop by a few times a year when I lived in San Francisco. 

The JTG is a Tsukiyama garden, reminiscent of a garden you'll find in Japan. Filled with gorgeous flowers, trees, pathways, bridges, a pagoda, a giant Buddha, and ponds, the JTG is a sanctuary inside Golden Gate Park.  After walking the garden, stop by the tea house for delicious tea and Japanese snacks. 

Oh, and here's a fun fact about San Francisco and the Japanese Tea Garden: the fortune cookie originated here. Strange, but true. Makoto Hagiwara, who was the original caretaker of the JTG, created the cookies and served them to guests of the garden.
author: Aimee G.

description:
Hari kari.

Asphalt pathways with fences?  Pagodas-R-Us?  Sno-globes?

Now all this may fly in Peoria but in San Francisco I demand honest-to-god Nipponese authenticity dammit, not some Disney-esque ideation (yes I know it was Mid-Winter's Exposition of 18** but who cares).

Aficionados *must* trek to Portland Oregon for the best set of Japanese Gardens outside of Japan.  That is the real deal.
author: Jim W.

description: A great place to spend an hour in semi-tranquility, sipping a cup of tea. It just depends on how crowded it is.
author: Scott M.

description:
I know it seems silly to some of you to pay $4 to get into this place. 

That is a beer, I understand.

Add to that another $5 cup of tea, that comes with a few rice crackers and some really tiny cookies.

That is a shot to go with your beer, I understand. 

But you can't put a price on a good memory, and I have had a few here. Plus, lets face it, it takes some cash to keep up with the gardening of this little slice of Zen. 

It also has a fantasitic history. The struggle that the landscape designer, Hagiwara, and his family went through in the time of WWII almost rendered this place no more.  Yet it, many of its structures, and many of its plants have come full circle so we can enjoy them again. Take the tour if it is available, its fascinating. 

I am totally willing to reduce my beer intake for a stroll through this garden. I would like it more if it wasn't so touristy, but tourists are people too. Plus I can make funny faces and bunny ears in the backgound of their group photo. Always entertaining, in a completely regressive way (though it was much more entertaining before digital cameras and photoshop ruled the photo world). 

But this is a relaxing place anyway, not meant for jokesters. Go, enjoy.......and keep an eye out for me if you bring your camera along.
author: Drue C.

description:
Love, Love, Love.  And now I volunteer here!

If $5 is too much to pay to enjoy the beauty and work put into this garden, you can get in for free Mon-Wed-Fri from 9-10 am.

And please bring your respect with you.
author: Jessica H.

description:
This is just a review for the park as I did not have any tea. The park is pretty large and definitely beautiful. There are a variety of things to see.

It wasn't very busy when I visited, I appreciated being able to take my time to photograph interesting things without feeling like I'm blocking someone's shot. The curved bridge was the most interesting thing there--it was pretty tough to climb to the top if it, I was deathly afraid of losing my footing. 

A word of advice to any visitor: pay attention to the small stone bridges! Some are not straight-edged, so if you are not paying attention while crossing, you might fall into any of the many ponds! No, I am not speaking from experience... *whistles*
author: Janny W.

description:
$5 entrance fee for a small walk around the tea garden. No thanks.

Otherwise, it's pretty cool. Makes me feel very Asian. The structures aren't amazing spectacular, nothing I've never seen before. The most awesome thing though is the bridge. You may be thinking, "A bridge? How awesome can a bridge be?" Well, to find out, you're just going to have to go and see! And trust, it's pretty damn cool.
author: Ivy W.

description:
I always take my grandmother with me when I go to the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park.  She has been gone for several years now, but her spirit is never stronger than when I am outside looking at a beautifully executed landscape and surrounded by nature.

She went to school to study landscape architecture at a time when that was a very unusual profession for women to persue.  And while she never practiced as an architect, she was very involved with the Chicago Botanical Garden and we spent many Sundays there looking at trees and flowers and especially the Japanese garden as the perfect example of man crafting nature to create a new and balanced aesthetic.

Tourists are usually fascinated by the bridge, the pagoda, the big Buddha, the tea house, and the gift shop.  These things are nice (minus the gift shop, which is overpriced and not that interesting) and make great pictures, but now that I have visited several times, I like to look at the different plants and the layout of the garden, as well as the intricate details.  I almost never go to the gift shop or the tea house any more - that is where you find the most tourists, and I like to have a more introspective experience.

When looking at the various sculptures, make sure that you read the plaques - many of the items were donated and their origins are interesting - rather than some places where they install copies to look like the real thing.

It's beautiful in any weather - during spring with the colorful blooms, on a foggy winter's day where it takes on a mystical quality, or at any time.  Dusk is especially enchanting, as the shadows created by the different plants take on almost a magical effect, and there are less people there.

And if I listen closely, I can hear my grandmother's voice whispering to me about the pattern formed by the branches or the Latin names of the various plants, and it makes me smile both outside and inside.
author: Liz S.

description:
The Five Dollar Restroom Break

Really not worth the $5 a person, it has some nice features but for the same price you could visit Hakone Japanese Garden in Saratoga which in my opinion is superior.  As we were entering and paying our $10 the kiosk man was yelling in a loud and not very nice way to many other folks if they had paid or not (they had) and very overall very grumpy.  The drum bridge was entertaining to cross, or rather climb up and down, and I did like the stone water crossings.  After a tour of the garden, tea house, and gift shop I felt a bit cheated like I had only paid the $5 to use the not very nice restroom.
author: Laurie H.

description:
With well over 200 reviews, you hardly need my two cents' worth, but, of course, I'll gladly offer it up anyway. We were tourists in our former city since we didn't do this sort of thing when we lived here...those living in major urban tourist destinations understand this implicitly. Seriously, I had been by here hundreds of times, and had even gone in & strolled around a bit on one of the boys' field trips. This was the first time I came here, as a grown up, and truly enjoyed this garden for all its' loveliness.

Stuart & I strolled over when I determined that $25.00 a head was waaaayyy too much dough to drop at the Academy of Science (even tho' it has a new cool roof, and all sorts of upgrades). Sorry, but this is too spendy for my working-class ethic, especially since we used to have to trek thru' here yearly on school field trips. And the whole school probably got in for $25.00!! Anyway, we arrived at the Japanese Tea Garden on one of the most breathtaking December afternoons I can recall...not crowded, quiet, and the ginko leaves on the pond with the carp floating silently along were just so amazing. Truly poetic. 

No stop is complete without a snack, so we availed ourselves of the tea house. We shared a pot of brown rice tea and a bowl of cookies & spicy crackers with nuts...Nuts?? Did someone mention nuts??! Of course we were joined by our furry-tailed squirrel friends who are quite aggressive! We shared our treats...They are fearless, jumping on the table, climbing up our stools, patting our legs & arms. They are so darn cute!

Anyway, the point is, $5.00 gets you loads of bang for the buck!! A highly recommended stop! Please give yourself a calm holiday treat & come here to relax.
author: Suzanne F.

description: Why do people complain about paying a fee to go here?  How else will the grounds keeping be funded?  Sure, free is always my preferred payment. But, we paid the $7 each, and I thoroughly enjoyed visiting this place, for my first time. Photography opportunities about here.  As an added bonus, we had some tasty Udon Soup and tea at the small restaurant, overlooking a lovely koi pond.  Lunch, plus admission cost less than if we had stopped in any other San Francisco restaurant. This was well worth the stop.
author: Debby F.

description:
Tourist and locals alike can appreciate the Japanese Tea Gardens! With only a $4 admission it's one of the most affordable attractions in the city. It's even cheaper than riding the cable cars! They have done a great job of cultivating the gardens! It may only take you ten minutes to walk through the grounds but it is really a lot of fun to poke around the gardens. I recommend going on a weekday when it isn't so crowded. After walking through the gardens you can puruse the 

Remember they are a cash only operation!
author: Marissa P.

description: This place is lovely to be sure but the price might not be worth the actual view.  There are similar gardens to be found in most major cities including San Jose and Saratoga.  It's a sight to see for sure but didn't last long enough to afford such a price-tag.
author: Alena B.

description: Lovely place for a stroll....but it can get pricey....the tea/snacks is not the best...but great if we have out of town visitors!
author: Barb L.

description:
Conventional wisdom holds that the Japanese Gardens at Huntington Library are the gold standard around here, but I think our garden holds its own quite nicely, thank you very much.  Sure, there's no definitive postcard vista point at ours, or a massive Japanese house, but I like the labyrinthine layout that makes it feel much bigger than it really is.  It's one of the few places that I can actually get disoriented in.

Plus, at Huntington you can't sip tea in the middle of the gardens.  Granted, the tea service is extremely basic: you get a choice of jasmine, green, or oolong, and it comes with a bowl of cracker-cookie snacks.  So don't be expecting Samovar or Lovejoy's.  But the fact that they actually go to the trouble of serving it at all is good enough for me.  I really must come here in the rain sometime and sip my tea while the water rolls off the roof into the pond.  Just be warned that, unlike most of GGP, this place *is* on the tourist radar, so on sunny weekend days it's a bit of a zoo.

Also, note that the trees are turning color right now.  Wear some tinted sunglasses here in late afternoon and it looks amazing.  (My wife says that's cheating, but hey, Picasa has spoiled me--it's all about warmifying).
author: Wes M.

description: A must-see on all SF tourists' lists. I was interested to hear that the fortune cookie was invented in San Francisco in 1914 by the designer and caretaker of this park, Makoto Hagiwara. He was fired a few years earlier, and upon return he served cookies at the park, each with a message inside. If Makoto had been more like me the messages would say, "Screw you guys, I'm back. And I pee'd in the cookie mix." And lo, the Revenge Cookie would be born. But he was a man of equanimity, and thus I imagine they said things like, "Never wear your best pants when you go to fight for freedom."
author: Bob G.

description: Went here in the morning so it was still a bit chilly. I enjoyed walking around in the quiet and serene garden. We were probably just a little early in the year for everything to be blooming so i would recommend going after March. We found it very interesting and educational to read all the little plaques around the tea garden so don't skip over those. We got a green tea latte at the little tea house and some cookies that were good and the service was good also. Overall it was a very peaceful and relaxing experience.
author: Kristin E.

description: The gardens are gorgeous.  It's perfect for photo-capturing, and you've got to love the free admission from 9am - 10am.
author: Cathaleya C.

description:
I cant really give this place 4 stars, the last time I stepped foot in here was probably when I was about 5 or 6, I still have fun looking at those pictures of me and my family...

So my lady and I came here recently just for the fun of it. On certain days they charge you $5 for admission. Which I have to say is not so worth it really.

The little pond in there is horribly dirty and should be cleaned out, I dont know how your supposed to clean it but I feel bad for the 3 or 4 fish that live in there. Some places that are supposed to have water doesnt have it.

It sounds like I'm bashing the place so why am I giving it 4 stars? Well I mostly because its got history. I know that this place at one time was not in this crap condition. Maybe one day they will decide to kind of fix it up. None the less it is still a beautiful place, it just needs a bit of TLC...
author: phillip w.

description:
I love this place. I have been coming here since I was a little kid with my mom and to this day I still get excited to come back. I know some people think that 5 dollars is a bit much to view the (relatively small) garden but I think its worth it. It's a very tranquil setting with beautiful manicured plants and a nice little coy pond. 

I always like to conclude my visit with a stop at the tea room. Not sure if its the best tea in the world but its a good place to relax and have good conversation.
author: Jeff P.

description:
this is one of my favorite places to decompress in SF. it's almost magically easy to find a quiet spot in the winding paths where you feel like you're alone in the whole park.

that being said, going on a weekday or early on the weekend are the best times to avoid the busloads of tourists.
author: Sasha R.

description: Amazing, im not sure what else I can add.  There is definetly calm feeling when you go in.  Views are amazing and photograph opportunities are fantastic.  Only suggestion I would have if you are a parent and planning on bringing a stroller, leave it in the car.  There are a lot of steps and narrow walk ways.  The garden is small enough you will be better off carrying your kid/kids or getting them to walk if they are big enough.
author: Jerod M.

description:
This garden is so beautifully designed that even the hordes of tourists - and locals - who come here don't take away from the serenity of it. 

It's a great way to spend some time catching up with a friend, or taking in the beauty of the park, while enjoying some wonderful tea service. Hightly recommended.

Nish fun fact: Makoto Hagiwara (part of the family who took charge of the garden in 1895) is credited with inventing the fortune cookie here. Ironically, the Chinese now get credit, but that is another story to tell...
author: Nish N.

description: I walk away feeling like there should've been more to see. The gift shop is overpriced as well - you can buy the exact same stuff in Chinatown for a quarter of the price!
author: Yi T.

description:
A wonderfully designed, fairly well maintained, and postage stamp tiny Japanese garden.

Every North American city of 100K or more has one of its own by now but ours is unique and one of the first.  Wonderfully designed and built for traffic, it's a dumping grounds for the city's publicly owned Japanese treasures - a pagoda from the 1915 Pan Pacific exhibition, an old moon-shaped bridge somebody sold his rice field to finance, a massive 200-year-old iron Buddha, etc.  Each has a thick bronze plaque to remind you how incredibly cool it is to live in San Francisco.  The curio shop and tea room are a 70s style effort to introduce folks to things Japanese, odd and dated considering how many real life japanese born people you meet every day in this town, but they're kind of neat too.

What you won't find are wise old koi (there are a few young ones in the large pond, you wonder what befell the rest), peace and quiet, raked rock gardens, bonzai trees, meditation or zen consciousness.  It's a noisy, bustling place too close to the De Young tower and incessant car horns, frequent weddings, shutterbugs, etc.   The paths are wide and asphalt-paved, too fussy and cramped to be "meandering."  Upkeep is vastly better in the last 10 years but there are still dead leaves, poorly pruned trees, and wood needing paint and cleaning.  Yet it all comes together perfectly.  Maybe that's the only thing truly Japanese about the place, a casual perfection.
author: Gil S.

description:
Enter the massive wooden gates and be transported to a world apart from the hustle & bustle outside.  Plan to spend about 1-1/2 hours here, and definitely enjoy the tea and cookies/rice snacks served in the charming tea house.  Find a secluded bench to meditate after you've walked the meandering paths and crossed the koi-filled streams and ponds.  

The Tea Garden has held a special place in my heart from my early days at Jefferson Elementary School, when we would walk here on frequent field trips.  In my mind, I imagined that we had been instantly transported to Japan, and I was always shocked when we left to find myself back in GG Park.  

Tips:  

-- Get there when it opens -- make your way to a quiet bench and let tranquility flow over you before the hoards of bus tourists arrive.  

-- OR, arrive after 4:30 (when the entrance fee is waived), and let the gardens provide a quick refreshment of peace in the brief time you have before it closes.   Something about it being free makes it even more enjoyable!  

-- Don't plan on picnicking in the Japanese Tea Gardens -- it's not really set up for that.  You can walk across the street to the Band Concourse where there are plenty of benches or lawn patches for picnics.  

-- Although I make it a point to avoid tourist traps, be sure to visit the gift shop -- it's a wonderful hodge podge of all things Asian (most of the stuff is definitely not Japanese, but it's fun).  You will never forget the sensory experience of the cherry blossom incense and the smell of all the imported goods -- there is really nothing like it.  

-- Buy some of the Botan Rice Candies -- the gooey, chewy orange squares, wrapped in rice paper that dissolves in your mouth (be sure to remove the plastic wrap on the outside of each piece -- it will never dissolve!).
author: Bevy M.

description:
This was a cute, small garden, but I've really been to better Japanese gardens in California.  Though the signs out front said that entry that day was free, we were charged $5 when we got in (not much, but still the principle matters) and walked around for about 20 minutes before ending up at the tea shop inside.

The tea shop was over-priced, and their green tea wasn't even that good.  It ended up going bitter really fast, and the leaves looked like the chopped-up remnants of some other, better tea.  Seeing how it's supposed to be a tea garden, I'd figure they'd put a lot more effort into their actual tea.  I guess they just cut down on costs by buying the cheap stuff, figuring that most of the people in the gardens are tourists and won't be returning anyways.

Bad experiences aside, the actual gardens are very well-cared for, and were definitely beautiful.  This is a great stop for people visiting San Francisco, but probably isn't something to return to after having been once.
author: Garrett P.

description:
I think it's fantastic that the city has someplace like this.

It's historical, it's beautiful, it's relaxing and you get a spiritual feeling as well. I went here yeaaars ago as a youngun on a field trip. My teacher was very into Asian culture and I never appreciated his thoughtfulness till now. It's nice to bring kids to this kind of place to learn how to slow down in life and smell the flowers.

This is really a place you can slow down and smell the flowers. You can go inside the little house and drink tea as well. They also sell various Japanese snacks and candy. Cute! I wouldn't mind going on a date, it would be incredibly creative
author: Rachel T.

description:
I feel really bad giving a poor review of the Japanese Tea Garden. I know it's supposed to be beautiful, but it's a damn tourist trap. The tea/refreshments were expensive, the entrance fee of $4 was way overpriced for what you get, and there are way too many people to make it a relaxing experience.

There are a couple good things though. I like the photo op bridge, I like the stupid tourists sometimes, and like watching people spend money for crappy souvenirs.

But I don't like a lot of things about it too. Mostly, I hate the landscaping of the place. It takes all the stereotypically characteristic points of Japanese architectural design and jams them all into one place without any consideration for layout, space, or atmosphere. Japanese landscaping flows comfortably from one area into the next, and meanders like a river. It does not rush and jumble together (like the tea garden makes it seem). There are much better places to spend your money, but it's worth going once or twice.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I tell everyone I know about how the guy who designed the garden invented the fortune cookie. For some reason, it's invention is a big achievement to me...

I believe the entrance fee is around $3.50 for adults. I think it's worth it, given the quality of the garden's design. It's pretty small and can be enjoyed thoroughly in about an hour (two if you decide to drink tea and contemplate why you paid $6 for it).

Take your pictures quick if you see that no one is around the moon bridge. It's only a matter of time before tourists and kids swarm the thing.

Admission booth accepts credit cards. I'm assuming the food area and gift store do as well.

I used to come here when I was a kid. The moon bridge was so big back then.
author: Keane L.

description:
This garden was smaller than I had imagined.  I had read all the yelp reviews that hyped up the beautiful scenery but I wasn't that impressed.  The gardens were well kept and had lots of small waterfalls and a pond area.  There is a unique drum bridge near the entrance.  Cheesy "chinatown" gift store and similiar tea area.   I guess the best time to visit this location would probably be cherry blossom season when all the flowers are in bloom (mid April), otherwise you will be viewing lots of trees and bare branches.

Admission: $5
Tea service and cookies $8
I have to admit that it was pretty relaxing overlooking the pond and taking a break for the tea service.

Will be back again during cherry blossom season
author: Cathy L.

description: It is free to come in the morning on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.  It's only $5 for residents and $7 for non residents.  It is fairly small, but a good way to spend a rainy day in San Francisco.  I have only been here when it is either raining or very foggy and I hope to keep it that way.  The tea is meh, but it is a great atmosphere while raining.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
Avoid weekends.

Not worth $5. 

Having a gift shop in there is kinda lame, although I understand why it's there.

Crowded tea house. Not appealing.

Loud kids everywhere, running up and down the bridge.

Definitely not serene.

Surprisingly not that big.

Some spots and sights photograph well, but overall, I've seen much better.
author: Cheri R.

description: I love this place!  It feels like a hidden sanctuary in the middle of busy Golden Gate Park.  Well except when there are a lot of people at the Tea Garden... then it's just crazy.  It's only $4 to get in and it's totally worth it!  We went on a late Saturday afternoon.  The tea restaurant area was completely packed so I didn't get to try it.  You'd think a place like this wouldn't be good to go to during the winter season but it is!  Everything is still green and nicely kept.
author: Shannon L.

description:
In terms of landscaping and scenery, the Japanese Tea garden is beautiful.  It's a little (but surprisingly large!) place to sit down, relax, and take in a wonderful view, especially if you have just finished going through the other museums in the area.  The garden itself is a very calm, 'zen' place to see what things could be like if you had some extra cash and a backyard, and is close to 'tranquil' as you're going to get in the Sunset District....

Assuming there aren't a bunch of punk kids running around.  I swear, when I went there there was this group of kids (I'd say around 14-17) just running around treating it like it was their yard!  Ugh!!! Complete way to ruin the mood and serenity of the situation. 

A little more disconcerting is the entry fee ($5, cash only, with some free days) which while not exorbitant, is kind of a small sting, especially if you get stuck paying for parking (we managed to find a space nearby).  Even more disconcerting is the tea shop.  This is going to sound bad, but at the Tea Shop, Cantonese can be clearly heard as the waitresses mill around.  It's not bad-- everyone's gotta get employees and with so many Chinese folks in San Fran, it's bound to happen, but for me (or anyone who doesn't lump us all together with a dismissive "them Orientuhls"), it's a moment of cognitive dissonance, made worse when you realize that the tea they serve you is CHINESE.  We passed on the $4 per person tea.

In addition, skip the gift shop unless you want something specifically from the Tea Garden-- most of the souvenirs are dinky trinkets from Chinatown, and you're better off driving a few blocks down to Irving street, enjoying some Chinese food and tea, and getting those knick knacks there.  

Overall, this is a great experience.  Stay away from the gift shop and tea store, and you'll find a lovely place to waste an hour or two enjoying some really, really, really, really, really (really!) good gardening.
author: John L.

description: I have to say as an avid gardener who is now in an apartment so far away from my own gardens this place was like HEAVEN !!! It is absolutely beautiful, peaceful and inspirational. We loved walking around the trail and the little bridges are so adorable as are the ponds. The tea house is cute, large and relaxing and the waitstaff  was fast and very engaging. I do not claim to be a tea expert at all but I do enjoy it and love trying new ones so the 3 of us that went each ordered a different flavor and tried each others and each had a completely different opinion as to which was the best. The only room for improvement I see at this place is the admission price is on the high side, but they are still getting 5 stars from me if for nothing else than the beautiful wisteria vines that remind me of my home and the tasty tea.
author: Edward B.

description: the Japanese Tea Garden was very interesting and beautiful. I loved the ponds and trees and the whole scenery was great! I just wanted to pet the Koi Fish!! (laughs). My friends thought the place was too small, but I was just pleased with what we saw and the experience of being there. There was also this one crazy bridge really cool :D
author: Monica L.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate park is one *obvious* place to take young first-time-from-out-of-town visitors with itchy camera fingers. It's *built* for picture-taking. 

Lush visually delightful placements of ponds, waterfalls, bamboo stands, maple trees, rocks, stepping stones, grasses, benches, bridges, gateways, stairways, and twisting paths -- an endless number of pleasing and varied sights for you to discover and enjoy any which way you turn your head, any ten steps you can walk in one direction, any little corner you round.

You can have your friend take a picture of you posing in one place and then realize that where your friend is taking your picture *from* is *also* a great place to take a picture *of.* 

This would be a great spot to have like a picture *orgy.* Like you could arm 20 of your friends with little miniature digital cameras and then just set them lose for twenty minutes to shoot anything they wanted, other tourists, each other, single shots group shots looking up the hill, looking down the hill, from atop the bridge, from the bottom of the bridge, in the bamboo stand, in front of the tea house, behind it, looking out from it, looking into it.. I mean the only direction you can shoot and *not* catch something is *maybe* straight up. 

Then, after you're all done, you could like upload and post all your shots onto one web site.. and then everybody could look and download the shots they liked for themselves.. like wouldn't that be a good thing to do?
author: Weide Z.

description:
My Opinion/Story:
I've only been to this place once to take my engagement pictures.  I'm glad my photographer suggested this place.  It's huge so you get to visit many locations.  It's also very clean and well kept.  They really take care of this place.  I really love all the different displays and it's something everyone in the family would enjoy going to.  Really BEAUTIFUL!!!
author: Cherryl D.

description: Hakone Gardens by Saratoga is better.
author: Usman A.

description: ehh I mean it is a really nice place to visit with your family....but every time I think of the Japanese Garden or anything I picture my family making me stand in front of things to take pictures lol The only reason why we went here is because the Museum of Science was SOLD OUT! What a bummer! lol
author: Wendy T.

description: Good for a one time experience.  The garden overall is small.  There are several picturesque landscape worth posing for the camera.  The koi pond has two nice cranes picture posing (sorry they're not real).  There are some nice miniature waterfalls.  A nice arch bridge to take pictures by.  I only wish this place could be larger.
author: Norcalscot L.

description:
Update for February 2009:

Fred Lo, who operated the junky gift shop and run down tea shop for more than 16 years finally LOST his extended mediocre running of the concession stands, pending approval March 30, 2009!!!!!!!!!!!!! Hooray....lets hope that the mediocre tea and stale crackers and cheezy slock he has been slopping out to disappointed customers finally ends. If one is looking for those things, try his other spot on GRANT Avenue.

The new concessionaire offers yummy french cakes and mochi goodies at her Murata's Cafe Hana in Japantown and I'm hoping to take my out of town guests there in August 2009. My treat if this gets approved.

She plans to offer "yokan" , "mochi" and "manju" at the teahouse.

For the past 16 years, Fred Lo has suffocated the former Golden Goose by feeding it stale crackers and forcing it to wear a polyester thong. Not a pretty sight on a 100 year old and letting it stew in unfiltered pond water...pond scum abounds in greed on his part of active neglect.

Waiting for another update in May 2009
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
The nice part is sitting in the tea house drinking tea and eating cookies, but why do they sell such hokey sheepie Made in Chinoise stuff? Seems like they could even be selling other items such as nice vases or appetizer plates from Japan, or sembei or arare or Japanese green tea and cute paper balls, or Japanese rice paper or books.

Why is the entrance fee as high as it is, it has already been paid for the past 70 years hasn't it? Sigh, sigh, sigh...oh well. one PMS cramp. Just enjoy the Cherry Blossoms from the outside and sit underneath them once the weather cooperates.
author: miriam b.

description: Lovely little proper japanese park with a tea house on the inside. A nice spot for photography, bird watching, people watching. Eye candy if you enjoy asian plants and architecture such as this.
author: Judi S.

description: We really enjoyed this! It's small enough that it's doable in less than an hour and we really liked having tea and taking a short break between all the museum-hopping on vacation. It's a nice interlude and a welcome break from all the busy aspects of a vacation. Highly recommend!
author: Sheila R.

description: Whether you are a tourist, or you just live in San Francisco, I think this is one of the best cultural places around. The tea serving with girls in kimonos is pretty awesome, while there is a ton of nature around for you to spend a day walking with a friend of a loved one. Photo spots are everywhere too.
author: Carlos H.

description: I want my backyard to look like the gardens at the Japanese Tea Garden. I spent the day walking the garden, sipping on fresh brewed tea and taking in all the beauty that surrounded me.
author: Meghan B.

description: Enchanting.  Great place to take some absolutely wonderful photos.  The gardens are well kept and offer a stunning back drop for photographing friends and family.  It can get rather crowded on weekends and some afternoons with the arrival of tourists so recommend an early morning weekday visit if you can make it.  Well worth the visit if you're on this side of town.
author: John F.

description: This place is wonderful. Very calm and relaxing. A nice place to spend a few hours on a weekend afternoon.
author: Scoot S.

description: If you wanna find a quiet place and see the Japanese architecture with ancient style and also wanna understand some japanese culture, Japanese tea garden is a good place to go~  it located inside the golden gate park.
author: Dana Z.

description:
Was in GG Park on Thanksgiving and decided to stop in. The garden is bigger than I thought it would be. And it is really tranquil, as it should be. It was a little more crowded, I guess since it was a nice day and a holiday. 

The one thing that killed it for me though was the cheezy gift shop. I mean, really, why???
author: The Sock S.

description:
I hadn't been here since I was extremely little, so I was excited to check it out over the weekend. It's easy to forget about all these tranquil spots in the city when you live close to the downtown area...and your life is taken over by cable car sounds and trips to H&M.

First of all, of course it's touristy. So you just have to let it go and act like a tourist yourself. Waterfalls! Tiny bridges! Exotic plants! Be sure to "oooh" and "ahhh" like the best of them and bust out that camera if you are really feeling it. 

The tea house is very cute and feels like something out of an old movie. Paper lanterns and an assortment of Japanese snacks tie it all together. Tea choices are limited (green, jasmine, etc.) but it will help you relax, even with all the chaos around you. And by chaos, I mean the crazy birds that fly so low you feel like you are going to get pecked in the head...

Be sure to check it out if you haven't been before. It's a great place for us San Franciscans to get away from it all.
author: lindsay w.

description:
This is a gorgeous place! Its kind of cheesy too. 

It was real fun to order tea (they have many types of green including my favorite-brown rice) and eat the complimentary cookies next to the creek. The tea house also serves different packets of Japanese treats (wasabi peas, this means you!) that you can buy too. There's also an ultra-corny gift shop with SF paraphernalia, fans and swords. 

The garden isn't very big, but there's all types of typical "Japanese" things to see all over. There's a temple, coi fish, brilliant flowers, and a giant wheel-bridge that is pretty impossible to climb over.

Its a very nice place for a stroll on a lazy day when you need a little peace or a simple-activity to do. Its somewhere you'll make your kid to go to in order to "get a little culture" they'll hate it 'till you get them  a plastic sword and then they'll come back ten years later to reminisce about the very same experience.
author: Ashley R.

description: I love this place. It is so nice and peaceful. The tea is good too! A good place to take a stroll with that special someone, but only when it isn't foggy. :)
author: Jordan M.

description:
The place is awesome, especially in the spring when you see all of these different flowers blossoming on the trees.I had fun climbing over a steep bridge that is in the tea garden. I used to come here all the time as a kid. You see a variety of Japanese plants and Japanese structures. The place is family friendly. 

The place is in the Golden Gate Park, and it is very close to the De Young Museum and the Academy of Sciences.This place is part of Japanese American history and part of Japanese culture.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: i really loved this place! totally worth it. i really liked the cafe too. the tea sandwiches were really yummy. got some new teas at the gift shop too. great experience!
author: T H.

description:
On my recent trip to San Francisco, the Japanese Tea Garden was one of the highlights.  Trying to find it though brought back memories of childhood, playing ZELDA and being lost in the forest, and coming back to the same place over and over again.  Hence, the signs leading there don't make a lot of sense, much like the floor arrows in Ikea. 

But once you find it, the tea garden is quite peaceful.  They have a nice little sit down area where you can order tea and Japanese sweets.  A great place to chill and read a book.  And I absolutely love the scenery - you can take some cool pictures here with Budhas.  I will we had something like this in Los Angeles.
author: Judd T.

description:
Yes, this place is cute and scenic for the tourist wanting to take photos to add onto facebook (which we all did, of course).  Other than that, it wasn't breathtaking, nor would I want to take wedding pictures here.  There is an admission fee of $5, what is this, a club or something?  I expected the tea place to be enchanting and you're-in-a-whole-new-aladdin-type-world, but really, it was just a bunch of dusty ole' tables thrown together in a cramped up place.  Nothing was genuine or sincere, but I guess that's what the whole wannabe fantasy world is for.  But don't places like Disneyland offer that escape and succeed in achieving such a grand dream come true?  

The location is great, though.  It's right by the historic science museum, golden gate park is amazing and a landmark to see, and when the weather's nice and beautiful, everything seems to follow suit.  The tea garden itself just didn't meet my standard expectations, and they could do more with it, especially when in such an inviting location.
author: Lili K.

description:
Nice, but been there, done that

If you're a fan of botanical gardens, I think you probably seen similar things before. Maybe it was just me, but I wasn't too impressed by the all the Japanese architecture. The $5 admission fee made this place even more overrated. The only good thing is that it have a really high angle bridge that is fun to climb and take pictures on, if you can fight off all the other tourists and their kids.
author: Jack N.

description:
A few friends and I decided to have a weekend adventure in Golden Gate Park. We started off in the Japanese Tea Garden where we hung out with Buddha, climbed a crazy bridge, meditated next to the beautiful coy-less coy ponds, and waited quite a while for some not so great tea. The $5 entry fee was worth it to see the peaceful spot, but I think spicing it up and calling it a $5 "donation" would have been a better strategy. This is the perfect place for photographers to spend the afternoon getting some Japanese inspired landscape shots.

Check out the other spots we went to in GG park during our adventure and see some pics we took here http://www.sanfrancisconoobs.com/09-08-2009/golden-gate-park-adventure-japanese-tea-garden-sf-botanical-gardens-the-conservatory-of-flowers/
author: Casi C.

description: I want Makoto Hagiwara to come to my house and make me a Japanese Garden. Established in 2011, welcome to the newest Japenese Garden with "Turning Japenese" playing on repeat, ducks, swans, plants, trees, cherry blossoms, ponds, little bridges for oompa loompas, and squirrels. It's only $5 for locals and $7 for tourists, and little ones FREE, but warning to children: don't kick the furry little animals, throw rocks at them, and step on the plants. Tourists: if you can't climb, don't get on the wheel bridge and tumble down, arigatou. Come enjoy an afternoon of sencha and miso soup for $6.75.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Possibly my favorite place in all ofSan Francisco. So beautiful, so peaceful. On my short list for everyone that visits SF.
author: Devin D.

description: The garden is lovely but I don't think it's worth $7 admission price given the size of the garden.  I did enjoy the scenery even though it was very crowded the day we visited.
author: Angel S.

description:
I have always planned to check this place out and I finally had the opportunity on my last trip to SF.  It is a little smaller then I would have guessed, given the size of the entire park.  We skipped the tea and the gift shop and just enjoyed the tranquility.  I did see a few koi, but expected a lot more.  The grounds are very well maintained and there is something new and interesting around every corner.  

I think it is a great "add on" if you are already doing other activities in the park.
author: jennifer j.

description: beautiful park. drank tea in their cafe- was relaxing and great atmosphere. tea wasnt anything special. def must visit when in cali. but i wouldnt go again, for me one time visit is enough
author: Sasha H.

description:
Very well maintained garden. I like the fact that they decided to keep the grounds more compact and well groomed vs. sprawling with poor upkeep.

Make sure you visit at multiple times of day -- the angle of the sun will dramatically change the appearance of the garden, allowing for a huge variety of photo opportunities.

The wife and I also enjoyed the small tea / sushi deck -- very placid and relaxing.
author: D F.

description:
When I was about 10 years old, I got bitten by a squirrel here. I don't think I have rabies, but who knows...

I think I've been here about 4-5 times in my life, and I currently live about a 10 minute walk away. I was recently here on a Friday morning, and was surprised to learn that entry is free on Mon., Wed. and Fri from 9-10am. That's the perfect time to go to avoid the hoards of tourists that pass through here later in the day.

I saw an older gentleman planted on a bench with his morning paper, just enjoying the peace and quiet. Not a bad idea at all.

The tea is ok, but with far fewer choices than one might expect for a place called the "tea garden". The "tea lady" there laughed at me when I asked for milk and honey. It's basically just a hut that serves tea and a little plate of crackers and cookies. The squirrels are not the least bit afraid of people. They will come right up to you and take your food. Beware. They look cute, but I learned my lesson about these little creatures when I was 10...
author: Manisha M.

description: My wife and I went there and was kind of disappointed.  For $7 I expected a much better and larger garden.  The people who collected the admission were not helpful at all... we did not even get a ticket or receipt, because they claimed the computer was not working.  We initially asked for a map but none was provided at the booth (it is actually for sale at the gift shop)... but who needs a map when you can walk the whole thing in 30 min.
author: Simon K.

description:
I signed up to Yelp for the sole purpose of letting EVERYONE know that the Japanese Tea Garden is the biggest rip off I've ever been to PERIOD!
$13.00 for a family of four... we saw no Koi...sad.  The garden is  a piece of crap.  I've been to Japan and seen what a rock garden is supposd to look like, the rock garden here is a sham. a sad fake.  Honestly it should be a donation only park.   15 min walk if that.  It's maybe 1/2 acre park?  The giftshop takes up a huge amount of the park, and is full of gifts from China!!!  And they charge you to enter????
This is the biggest rip off I've ever been to.
author: ray m.

description:
I just LOVE the Jappanese tea garden. It is really pretty, the drinks are good. But $7 for admission? Yikes.  I recommend comming over here if you 

a) Like jappanese decor
b) like jappanese food
c) Like to be in peace

I would recommend coming here in your free time
author: Ryan M.

description:
I love coming here and just sitting down for a moment and taking in the trees.  It's quiet and relaxed considering the people that are filing by, but it's a great slice of Japan in the park.

Make the trip in May to catch some of the Cherry Blossoms!
author: Daniel S.

description:
Hearing the water droplets is so peaceful. It has a stress relieving effect on me. 

I love following the koi!
author: Amy D.

description:
This has always been one of my favorite places since I arrived in San Francisco.  My mother and I used to have tea here after visiting the De Young so, I followed tradition.  I had a 12 year old and 8 year old with me who were enthralled by the half moon bridge and loved the tea and crackers.
It was a very enjoyable day.
author: Holly L.

description: The garden is beautiful and enjoyable to walk around, but as someone who is on a major budget... it should probably be skipped.  The cost is $7 to enter, $5 if your a resident but the woman at the window would not allow my SFSU ID card to prove that I live here, she wanted a piece of mail!  So yes it is beautiful and relaxing but not worth $7 for about a 30 minute walk.  Golden Gate park has enough free areas that I will stick to taking my guests there.  Although if your willing to get up early it's free Mon, Wed and Fri from 9-10.
author: Megan L.

description: $5 dollar entry fee!!!  Definitely not worth it.  I would rather go to japan town.
author: Danny P.

description: Great place to visit while you are in SF! This is a beautiful and serene place that is well maintained. It is a small place not real big but a beautiful sight to see and great for pictures. They also have a tea house where you can get some food in drinks. It also have a cool gift shop with some great gift ideas. There is a charge ($7) to visit this. I think it is a little high because the garden is  small but it is worth it for a first time visitor.
author: Dominic C.

description:
I have been coming to SF for years now and this was the first time I have been to the Japanese Tea Garden.  There is actually a tea house in the garden.  The entrance fee is a bit much for what it is, $7.  I wish the garden was bigger than it is.  You can be in and out in 10-15 minutes (or less).  

Also, they do not have a student or military discount.  :(  My favorite part was the giant Buddha statue and the little squirrels running around.  :)

The garden is located right next to the de young museum.
author: R R.

description: Came here for My B-Day today and loved it !! Its a beautiful well kept garden. It can take up to 30 min to explore the entire garden or an hour if your going slow and taking pictures. I say its worth the 7 bucks, especially if your going to sit down at the bar and enjoy a beautiful view of the garden while sipping on a nice soothing cup of hot jasmine tea. If your into flowers, tea, Japanese style buildings, gardens ect, and a peaceful environment, then this is an amazing place to go.  But if not then don't waste your time.
author: Maytin C.

description:
You'll find peace and relaxation in the out doors while not leaving the city.  Best time to go, a "sunny" San Franciscan afternoon!

Not even the crowd at the tiny over-crowed Tea house bothered me!  Great tea selection and knowledgeable staff.
Why do I only go here with out-of-town visit?  It's an amazing place!
author: Yamil A.

description:
Wow! What a beautiful place. If I could just pitch a tent and live in there, I would do it in a second. The landscaping, of course, is the main attraction.   It was just so incredibly beautiful. 
Anyone who doesn't enjoy this place is either blind or stupid. 
The drinks are ALL $4.25. Even for a diet coke. So get your money's worth and buy a pot of tea...
author: Ashley G.

description: This is a good substitute for going to Japan !  It's great that they have a tea house so you could linger in the garden while having a decent tea service.  Noticed they've added elements to the garden.  It's getting a bit too busy visually.  Thinking they are trying too hard by jamming all elements of a Japanese garden into one property.  By doing so, you are bombarded by everything at once.  Even though this place doesn't quite inspire serenity like the real Japanese gardens should, it's still a decent experience.  Plus you don't have to fly 11 hours and spend $1000+ on airfare to see a good Japanese garden.
author: Nikko V.

description:
I've been coming to the Japanese Tea Garden ever since I was a little girl and I still love it!  It's probably one of the most tranquil and breathtaking little gardens that you will ever see... the coy ponds and the Japanese landscaping, it's gorgeous! Although the arched bridge used to scare the crap out of me when I was a kid. So if your kid tells you that they don't want to take a picture on that thing..listen to them! Please.

However, I love the tea service they provide they have serve some great jasmine tea and yummy little rice crackers and almond cookies. It's an ideal place to hang out and relax with family or friends and enjoy the scenery. It can get really crowded on the weekends so be prepared...
author: Suzette R.

description: Came here with the kiddies and folks visiting.  I enjoy these type of settings.  The grounds are very nice to cruise...lost of interesting scenery to view.  We also decided to grab a seat and try some tea.  The tea was actually very good (I had the Jasmine tea).  I was a little hungry and also tried the udon...also great and highly recommended especially when it's a little chilly outside.
author: Al C.

description: I've been wanting to go here for years and finally was able to coordinate a trip. The little snacks were good too. Nice atmosphere and fun to walk around the park.
author: Eva B.

description:
People are right when they say we don't even get complimentary tea! I was almost tempted to sit down for tea but thought it wasn't worth it since we had to pay an entrance fee anyways. 

Overall it IS beautiful, although it is small and I don't recall seeing koi fish either. That's not a big deal for me.. though. I still enjoyed my time just think this place should give complimentary tea to their patrons that pay a visit.
author: C C.

description:
What happens when you grow up in the bay area and have continued to live there for most of your adult life? Answer: you don't go into the Japanese Tea Garden until you have a friend visiting from out-of-state.

Which comes to my first visit ever to the inside of the Japanese Tea Garden, after having gone by it any millions of times over the years. 
A funny part of the visit was ordering. Besides tea, my friend got us some ice cream to share. One pink and one green little ball on a little rectangular plate. We could not figure out how to eat them! We tried to use the chocolate sticks they are served with, but they only proceeded to break when we tried to puncture the ice cream. Then we figured out that the ice cream part was covered by a doughy ball, not unlike the texture of play dough. To eat it, we had to squeeze the ball, peel away the dough to get at the ice cream inside. It was a messy endeavor without napkins and wasn't a treat we'd recommend, but it was an amusing adventure for sure. A much safer bet are the oriental cracker mix (tasted like it could've been that Trader Joes mix) and fortune cookies (huh?) that come with the tea. 

You have to get past the tourist trap $7 entry fee ($5 only if you live within city of SF, no bordering city counts), but it's worth it to hang out for as long as you want in the serene gardens. My visiting yogi friend and I met up with another yogi who lives across the Golden Gate, and we literally spent several hours sitting, strolling, taking in the ambiance, a Zen-like backdrop for some amazing discussions. Not everyone is as lucky to get knowledgeable yogis to accompany them in this beautiful space, but the combination of the surroundings and company made for a tremendously wonderful day for me. 

So whomever your company, soak up the peaceful environment, play the fortune cookie game, and enjoy!
author: Megan K.

description:
It's a small paradise, west of San Francisco. A serene and beautiful place, where the air is clean and fresh, and where a lot of tourist with cameras hold their cameras pridefully everywhere, flashing photos. Yes, my family was one of them tourist, but this tea garden was so peaceful even with the tourist. Exotic plants and a lovely atmosphere. 
       Definitely something you should do in San Francisco to experience Japan's culture. 
        The bummer:
The shop is pretty pricey. Simple little souvenirs for retail price, when I'm used to Chinatown souvenirs and such. 

The restaurant was also pricey. Though we didn't order the tea, which was 3 dollars, we ordered Tea Sandwiches and Udon. The Udon was pretty good, very simple though. Just the soup, noodle, and fishcake, which costed about 7-9 dollars. The tea sandwich was 6-8 dollars. It comes with around 8 sandwiches, with 4 types of sandwiches. It didn't taste very good. The tuna tea sandwich was too salty in my opinion. The vegetable egg thingy sandwich was too sticky. My mouth was slobbered with mushes of sandwich, The ham sandwich was pretty good, but it was just two pieces of bread with mayo and ham. Not worth my dollars.

You have to pay a small price to get admission. I would prefer free (because we are cheap :P) but it's just a few dollars per person.  

Summary:

     I would really recommend this place to anyone, it's an amazing sight to see.
author: Nell A.

description:
Been wanting to check out the Japanese Tea Garden for some time. My gf has also been bugging me to come here for about 6 months so finially checked it out on friday and it was okay at best.  We enjoyed about an hour of walking around the garden taking photos and for $5 it was fair and helps support taking care of the garden but I would not plan on spending more than an hour and not spending more than $5 on admission. If you can make it on friday between 9am - 10 am it is free.

And if you have never been you can grab a pot of tea that is charged per person and comes with a bowl of cookies and crackers but it way over priced for what it is and is def catered toward tourists as the cost for two was almost $9.
author: Robert S.

description: This place is a lovely place.  The fee to get in is a little steep, but if you can get in on a Monday, Wednesday, or Friday before 10am you get in for free.  The servers were friendly and the tea was priced ok.
author: Brandy H.

description:
Pretty little garden. 

A must for locals and visitors. 

If you're really into authentic Japanese gardens, check out Hakone Gardens in Saratoga, CA.
http://www.hakone.com/
author: kristen b.

description:
This place is a must go for anyone visiting The City or for cup-caking the significant other. You cant help but feel a sense of relaxation upon entering here. Big ups for the effort and detail out forth to make this place beautiful, tranquil and authentic. 

I dint mind paying $4 to come here nor what ever they charge for tea. I mean come on, places like this dint come cheap. I'm pretty sure it takes allot of maintenance due to the SF weather and hoards of tourist to keep this place the way it is year round.

Word to the wise. Try to come here on a week day to avoid the tourist noise and crowd @ the tea house.
author: Alfredo N.

description:
This place was really cool. It was so beautiful on the inside and it made me feel at peace...not really, but you know what I mean. 

Minus half star b/c they dont offer student discounts (bastards) and minus another half b/c there was randomly this dead skunk in the middle of this grassy area...wtf?

But overall, very Japanese and good to take pictures galore! Also good for a date ;)
author: Dustin H.

description:
this garden is beautiful.  it was a little smaller than i expected but it's got nice beautiful landscape.  It's very zen in here and makes you have a sense of peace in there.  admission is $4 but free on Mon, Wed, and Fri.  great spot for wedding or engagement pictures.  

they've got a tea house in here.  not sure how the prices are but i visited the gift shop and it's like the stores you see in chinatown.  the cashier is chinese and the items in there looks like it's from china.  yes, it's japanese style/design, but my guess it's made in china.  i remember seeing a few of the items in chinatown and on clement. 

i came here to shoot pictures and a lot of the pictures came out great.  if you're looking for a great place to shoot (photography), this is a good place.
author: Kapo T.

description:
Call me silly but didn't this place used to have Koi fish in it? I swear they did. 

I went there this past Friday with my sweetie and walked around. It's been awhile since I've been there. I guess the place seems different now that I'm older. 

We sat down and had some tea which was nice. $4 per person for tea on top of the $5 admin fee made this like stroll a bit expensive for what it was. 

Glad to have gotten to come here since it's been awhile..a very long while since I recall the place being better but it was still nice. I enjoyed the company I had.
author: Shana A.

description: This is the place to go if you just need to get away from the hustle and bustle of downtown and all the people... It is so peaceful and beautiful.  A MUST for anyone visiting San Francisco. Lots here worth snapping a picture or two of.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
This is a great place to come and clear your mind, as long as it doesn't need clearing on a weekend, and especially not on one of the free days.

I used to come here often in High School to enjoy the tranquility that is the Japanese Tea Garden. I think we almost always bring visiting family here, and enjoy the ridiculously expensive tea (seriously, $25 for 4 people for just tea?) and everyone seems to enjoy it.

bonus points is that they have some of the cleanest bathrooms in GGP.
author: Allyson S.

description:
The tea garden has both serene areas (separate beautiful spots along a winding path) and kitsch (the store and the tea house).

It's worth visiting, but don't expect high tea at the tea house. It's simple tea and crackers. The tea house (a roof over a patio) gets chilly but is a good spot for a pot of green tea or hot chocolate. It's 2.95 plus tax per person.

The store just up the hill from the tea house sells some decent Japanese nicknacks (wind chimes, figurines). It's not a bad selection, and the prices aren't too high, but you can do better in Japantown.
author: Pat T.

description:
Some formative afternoons of my courtship were spent sharing rice crackers with a pot of green tea and a lovely summer breeze.  Even if you're not a college co-ed in love, for a few bucks, you can take yourself away from the worries of the moment and pretend to be someplace else.

This is the kind of garden in which you'll force yourself to walk slowly.  Even though I'm incurably high strung, this is one place I can pretend to chill out for a while.  And with the other ammenities of Golden Gate Park within walking distance, you'll find other ways to have fun before you leave the area.  Whatever minimal entrance fee they charge is money going to support a really lovely gem in the middle of the city.
author: Quinn M.

description:
I have lived in SF for over 5 years and finally visited the Tea Garden today.  I recommend visiting the garden on a Monday, Wednesday, or Friday and entering before 10AM because admission is FREE.  

I took a San Francisco City Guide walking tour of the Tea Garden and would highly recommend it (http://www.sfcityguides.org/desc.html?tour=102).  Our tour guide, Charles, was excellent!
author: Stephanie F.

description: The Japanese Tea Gardens was a pretty place, but I am honestly unimpressed by it.  If it was a public park that didn't charge any fees, I'd probably give it a higher rating, but since they are charging $7 per person, I expected the place to be larger.  This place was walkable in 20-30 minutes.  The tea room at the tea garden was a nice addition to the garden, but it was pretty pricey for their rather lacking menu.  I would say that this place is worth a visit at least once, but overall, I wouldn't say it wasn't worth a second visit.  If you want to save money, I suggest going during their "free hours", which are Mondays, Wednesdays before 10am.
author: Jackie C.

description:
This garden is magical...I had a nice, holistic experience when I visited.

There are all sorts of odd structures to check out, all of them works of art. The plant and animal life there is diverse and wonderful. 

The tea area is quiet. The service is on point, and the waitresses wear traditional Japanese garments. 

The jasmine tea is comforting and delicious. All pots of tea are served with little cookies and crackers (which made me very excited...seeing as I'm a girl, and girls dig small things.)

Fun times at the tea garden...a perfect place to find a little peace.
author: Rachel T.

description:
What a great place to come and relax (and ponder). Wonderfully set up and just soaks you in a peaceful feeling. They could really just take all of Golden Gate Park and make it like this and it would be fine with me. Okay. Just leave the windmill and the buffalo.

If you come super early, you can get in for free. :-)
author: John S.

description: I say that this place is all right for a japanese tea garden. It's just like a getaway, of course when there aren't a lot of tourists going through mobbing the place with their cameras. Although, I probably would just blend in with everyone there if it were. I first went here earlier in the summer with my boyfriend. Just a random tour of the area, from the reviews I've read I knew it wasn't going to be big and we did stay away from the tea. But it was still fascinating for us to sea everything else you can find inside of the garden. There are places where you can just be alone and probably have a moment of silence for five minutes but probably no more. It just makes you feel like you're in a whole new world.
author: K Nicole D.

description: wonderful! relaxing, perfect for a romantic walk or study in peace ... don't miss it!
author: Andrea M.

description:
Space is a commodity in San Francisco so I think this garden is really nice.  Tranquil, clean, pretty, small, peaceful, well cared for.  

Should be free entry.  Or free with Academy of Sciences fee.  But at least you can re-enter with the receipt.  

There's free parking on the street during un-busy times.  

The area outside the restroom was clean and smell-free when I walked by, thank goodness.  

The gift shop was a glorified souvenir store full of Made in China crap, Chinese teas (wtf?), cell phone charms, fans, San Francisco souvenir t-shirts, and a cheesy Japanese video playing.  

The tea garden sold Chinese teas (again wtf?), with two ladies speaking Chinese in unkempt kimonos manning the place.  One was hunched over looking extremely bored, the other was checking her nails while leaning on the counter.  So unprofessional.  Very "un-Japanese Tea Garden-like."  
  
I was not impressed with the commercial aspect of this place, obviously.  No authenticity in the gift store nor in the tea garden.  Give those a pass!  But at least the garden kept its Japanese-ness.
author: Mrs F.

description: Such beautiful landscaping, really relaxing and peaceful on a sunny day. I wish you could drink tea among the scenery as opposed to in the specified tea area. $5 for locals, $7 for others...a must see but I wouldn't become a regular.
author: Paula B.

description:
At first I thought 4 dollars was a bit too much (yes you don't have to tell me i'm cheap, I know that already), but this place is so dorky and cute and darling. :D Definitely a one of a kind place!

Mr. Big Buddha is my hero there as well as my brother showing me around this "backyard" of his.
author: Monica F.

description:
I was in complete awe of this place.  It's breathtaking.  I was on a bus tour when I first moved here and we had 25 minutes at the JTG in GG Park.  It wasn't enough.  

There is a bridge... that is a semi-circle.  And I wanted to climb it so badly (yes, climb is the right word) but didn't.  Maybe one day...

There are so many photo ops here... take your camera!
author: Jessica M.

description: Cute date place. Cookie plate is lame, mochi are great.
author: L B.

description:
The garden was smaller than I imagined it would be. 

The gift shop felt like a tacky dollar store you would find in China Town, except nothing's a dollar. 

And there were too many fences here so, instead of a sense of serenity, I felt confined as I was herded down the cement walkway by other tourists, eager to get past.

You can't fault nature itself, though, as the plants there were gorgeous.
author: Andrew P.

description:
Beautifully landscape Japanese tea garden...walk along the trails, hop scotch across the stones, cross bridges, climb stairs...I never get tire of coming here.  

There's also a small tea house which charges about $3/person for tea and fortune cookies.  Kind of a ripe for tea but still attracts tons of tourists.  But a nice spot to sit, relax and enjoy the scenery.  FREE admission the last hour of the day starting at 5pm!
author: Mick S.

description:
I was amazed the first time I visited.  I liked the tea and nibblies in the pagoda area.

But it's over-run by tourists so on subsequent visits, it felt more staged and certainly not tranquil as I think it was intended to be.

Considering the other great offerings in the park, I see no need to be cooped up in the contrived setting of the Japanese Garden
author: Femita J.

description:
This is a beautiful garden, and there are lots of places to sit.
Try crossing the drum bridge, smell the flowers, look at the giant buddha.

The tea and crackers aren't worth the price, unfortunately.
author: James D.

description: After paying $7 to get in and walking around for a few minutes, commenting on the beauty and taking silly pictures we realized we had seen the whole thing. Smaller than I expected for sure, but not disappointing.
author: Amy S.

description:
I have been coming here since I was a kid. 

My mom would bring us here on a rainy day and we would enjoy the tea and watch the fish.

 To this day I still prefer to go when it's raining because it is empty and there aren't tourists in neon windbreakers to detract from your Japanese experience.  The tea is fine but it's not why you go. Also definitely try the japanese crackers and cookies if you haven't had them before. 

Especially if you have children this place can be wonderful and magical. It's a little bit pricey for an activity that will only last an hour or so. But take your time and make sure to see everything!
author: Holly S.

description:
It's a tourist trap.  First you pay too much to view the Japanese garden.  Moreover, it is rather tiny.  I have been to better Japanese gardens in Portland, OR and to Kubota Garden in Seattle (which is free).  

The restaurant is crowded, the service is slow and lacking, and all they serve are overpriced mochi desserts.  You could buy the same desserts at a number of asian grocery stores for a fraction of the cost.
author: Noah B.

description: I've only been to two Tea gardens before (excluding the microscopic one in my school) I enjoyed this one, it was not as large as the other one i went to but still big enough to get some quiet time before the next group of people came by took pictures and left. What i didn't like was the lack of Koi fish! i think i saw three of them and one dead random goldfish! The price was also a bit too much for such a small garden, but i guess most visitors are here for a one time visit. Overall it was a nice garden plenty of places to take pictures and set as your screen savers on your computer or phone...
author: Ricardo L.

description: This place is definitely a tourist trap. $5 for locals to see a miniaturized japanese garden along with a gift shop and cafe filled with OVERPRICED items is not the best way to spend a day in my opinion. I'd rather see the shit at Legoland, at least they have roller coasters there. Even if you're a tourist, there's plenty of other things to see. In no way is this a great reflection of Japanese culture, mostly just a westerner's perspective built in order to turn a buck (It's a worlds fair relic for Christ's sake....) For a fraction of the cost, you can make your own tea at home, buy a bunch of super cheap (under $.50) mochi, and sit at the Peace Pagoda eating and sipping away. Just saying.....
author: CHRISTIAN P.

description: Absolutely stunning Japanese garden.  I've been to a few Japanese gardens in various parts of the U.S. and they have all paled in comparison to this one.
author: Karen W.

description: I really enjoyed the tea garden. I recently went there my first time when my dad came to visit. He enjoyed it as well. For $3.50 each it's not a bad price to go to occasionally. Probably better on the less touristy times of the year. The flora is spectacular. A little sad they make you "stay on the trail", but I do understand why...My yelp photo was taken by my dad of me at the JTG, ohm...
author: Jennifer P.

description: Beautiful, peaceful and tranquil, parking is a pain though and it may be boring if you're looking for loud, cheesy or something more than zenning out.
author: Jon P.

description:
Relaxing, pretty place to go visit.  $5 is a little expensive to pay for enterance if you do just plan on going in to walk around real fast.  Though I have to say compared to what I've had to pay in NYC for certain little exhibits $5 is pennies.  We spent a good couple hours here though.  The landscaping is beautiful.  What made us spend a little time inside was the Tea shop they have where you can sit and have fresh hot tea and chat.  Plenty of picture opportunities if you're into landscaping.  

If I lived in San Fransisco I'd say this would be a good date spot if you planned a little extra time in the park as well.
author: N Marie R.

description: One of the most peaceful and serene things we've done in San Fran. Get your camera charged for some scenic landscapes. And then cap it off with your choice of 6 different teas and snacks. The gift shop also has some interesting items.
author: Mario C.

description: Nice place to seek respite once you get all the way out to the park and realize that the entrance tickets to the Science museum are $7,823 per person. The garden is small, but pretty. Little outdoor cafe is a good place for hot tea and little mochi/red bean snacks, but not much else.
author: Sabbies B.

description:
A wonderful small Japanese Garden located in the heart of San Francisco? How cool is that.

I visit here several times per year at various seasons (Autumn being my favorite) It is a fantastic place to just get away and reflect a little while wandering the various paths.

$5.00 seems like a pretty fair deal to me but if you can't afford it Monday, Wednesday and Fridays have free admission times and there is free parking in the park if you look around a little so you don't have to worry about that either.

There is a tea house as some others have pointed out the tea house is not similar to a real Japanese tea house in terms of food or type of tea served but that does not mean it is bad just a bit of a shame. I don't go there but many people do and enjoy it. I really go for the beautiful garden and I am always happy when I do. I have been to japan quite a few  times and visited lots of gardens and I can say that this is a quality Japanese garden.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Really beautiful and peaceful if you can find the few spots not swarming with tourists. The ponds were sparking and filled with koi.

I loved the tea and the treats they give you, and if you manage to score a seat looking out at the gardens, it's easy to visualize not being surrounded by people.
author: Tracy O.

description:
FUN!  Bring some props and take tons of pictures!
It is BEEYOOTIFUL!!!
Make sure you have some tea before you go!
Went on a thursday afternoon and it was not crowded at all.  
Admission I believe was $4.00
FREE admission on MON WED and FRI between 0900-1000 one hour window!  (if I recall correctly)

Great tourist spot!
author: Elisa O.

description: Oh this place is well worth the $7.00 non-San Fran Resident adult fee. First of all it was the most beautiful and relaxing 45 minutes I have spent in San Francisco yet outside of my husband's smile. If you go be sure to take a good camera and get pics of the Pagodas, the round bridge and the Gorgeous antique Buddha from Japan circa 1799 Also, the giftshop is super cheap having most items around $10-$15 It is well worth it to go here!
author: Jason M.

description:
For $4, this place is worth checking out. I wished there were more flowers, but it's a TEA garden I guess. At the end, there is a tea bar where you can get some really good tea and a gift shop with some cute things.

Don't forget to climb the tall ass bridge and take a picture, that was my favorite part, haha.
author: Amuse B.

description:
This place is SO cool!

Came here for Mother's Day so it was packed with moms and their kids, but it was great.  Really neat landscaping and little creeks and ponds galore.  There are plaques scattered around the area that explain the history behind specific bridges or sculptures.  But the best part of the place is the tea house in the center that serves some (mediocre) tea and snacks.  The gift shop is [obviously] overpriced, but all-in-all, its a great time and you feel miles away from the city.
author: Kathleen B.

description: Wow. Really well done, it is not that big but there is a lot of detail that goes into this. I really enjoyed my walk through there, although it was on a rainy day!
author: Nantas S.

description: I went there for the tea, but ultimately was more impressed with the garden. The tea room is outdoors (covered) with a few snacks. The real reason to go here is the beautiful plants.
author: Tamara M.

description:
It's zenful. Yet, you have to try REALLY hard to not care to look at the prices for both admissions or for tea. With the selected days a week were it is free is when you pray really hard you got the day right. 

And who doesn't like walking in a garden in general. Okay, minus the tourist who take up every nook and cranny. What really bit was trying to get tea and having to sit at the end of a table because there were so many people there. And $3.95 pp + tx for only three selections of tea and a bowl of cookies is decent but one cannot drink in peace when one is sitting in a crowded area. 

I agree with the other reviewers that $2.00 for Japanese snacks is just insane. Its fricken crackers for pete sake, why does anyone have to pay half of  a toll charge for crackers?!?
author: Jamie L.

description:
