Go early and on a weekday. It can be very crowded and busy here which limits your ability to take pictures and really enjoy the environment. It is so beautiful here and so much fun to wander the paths. 

The tea house is almost always full but a nice way to wrap up the visit. When done, exit through the gift shop for a vast array of cheap souvenirs! ;-)
author: Sarcastic T.

description: Gorgeous, peaceful and so well laid out, the Japanese tea garden in Golden Gate Park is a beautiful little sanctuary, one we discovered only recently and plan on visiting often. I've taken one star off for the steep prices of food and tea available there. If you're not eating/drinking, however, it's perfect--and entrance is $7. And right around the corner from the De Young museum, so it makes for a sweet post-museum wind-down. If you're not planning a trip to the actual country anytime soon, go visit this proxy one!
author: D B.

description: Absolutely Beautiful! I loved the steep bridge. It was a bit crowded - which was a bummer. It's really hard to take pictures without random people in it, and you had to pay $4 to get in, it is smaller than I expected (recently went to the free admission one in San Jose, which was a lot bigger). But overall, it's still a lovely place, the $4 entrance fee is worth it.
author: Kat R.

description:
$8 tea and crackers...really?!

Fine, we can bitch about how much it costs to get in and such...but this place is really for the tourist at heart.

It's up to you to really dive into the details of this place.  Just take a step back and enjoy it for once.


But most importantly, REALLY try to get here when there aren't a lot of people.  And I must say, this place is probably amazing when it rains.  Combined with the warm tea, I'm sure that's when tranquility really settles in.
author: Vince S.

description: we went on a day with perfect weather. the scenery was gorgeous and it was very relaxing and peaceful to walk through the garden. there are carp fish in the ponds and lots of beautiful plants. there were a couple of newlyweds doing their photos there that day too! we enjoyed a cup of tea and mochi's in the pavilion. the service was great. the mochi's were too sweet and the tea wasn't anything special, but i think the environment and the ambiance is what made it a great experience.
author: Betty W.

description:
I usually go here when it's free (after 5pm, I think?). The garden is pleasant and peaceful. Nice place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

And you gotta love how they give you complimentary Fortune Cookies when you order tea..
author: Zell C.

description:
A relaxing place to have tea and some nibbles in Golden Gate Park. I like it because it's like a smaller version of the ones you see all-over asia and the plants & sculptures are pretty authentic to Asia.

Great to pair with other stuff in the park but not necessarily worth a visit on it's own.
author: Valerie F.

description:
Absolutely Love this place. Coming here as a kid on school field-trips used to bore me to death, but now as I grow older, I have come to appreciate the beauty of a serene and natural Garden. The Japanese Tea Garden does a good job of making you feel like you're in a whole other world, away from school, work, the city, and all the other stresses in life. Its very peaceful, quiet, and is loaded with great Japanese statues, flowers, bonsai trees, ponds, and bridges.

 A bonus: The garden has free admission after 5pm, which is a great time to come, right when the sun is about to set. Great date spot!
author: Jessica h.

description:
The tea garden saved my stomach!

We wanted to go play some frisbee in the park and then maybe hit up the garden, but since my stomach was upset we decided to reverse the orders of those events.  We ended up staying so long we never had time to play frisbee, due to all the enjoyment taking place.  We didn't have to wait at all for a nice spot in the tea shack where we could watch squirrels and tourists.  Those cookies they give you with the tea are so good!  We got Oolong tea, yummers.  

So then wandering around the tea garden was great.  Bring yer camera!  All the treas are in bloom right now, which made for some amazing pictures.  

The only downside was that it is sad seeing coins int he coy pond.
author: Levi B.

description:
BEAUTIFUL PLACE!!!!  Of all the years I've lived in the Bay, I've never been to the tea garden.  Finally made it out on a day specifically planned to be a "tourist date day"...and I was such a happy little girl in this beautiful, peaceful, serene place.

It was pretty crowded and hard to get shots without a random tourist in the background...but hard to be grumpy and complain when you're in such beautiful surroundings with the person you love.  My recommendation:  take a seat at a bench whenever you can, take a few moments to reflect on the surroundings and take it all in...you'll leave feeling so much more relaxed and calm.  Well worth the trip.
author: Riza A.

description:
This is a nice little oasis away from all the hustle and bustle of San Francisco.  It really is a beautiful little Japanese garden and you can't beat the $4.00 admission.  It's fun to just stroll around for a bit.  We skipped the tea part, though, since it didn't seem all that authentic. 

This is a place that one must go to if they live in the city.  If you have visitors and they want to do a day at the park, you could totally squeeze this in with the museum or the Conservatory of Flowers.
author: Sean O.

description:
Boring boring boring boring, peaceful, but boring. I took my parents here while they were visiting and gave up a trip to the MoMa since it was one of the few glorious beautiful summer days in the city. It's a garden, but there aren't any flowers and the Japanese architecture is nothing special. I remember thinking "This is it??" I would rather spend time walking around Japantown. 

I don't understand how people are whining about the entry fee of $4 (how can you complain - that's the price of a latte!). I mean, haven't you gotten used to the fact that nothing is really free in the city??

We did stop for tea in their little tea house which was actually very cute. They serve you a pot and a little bowl of crackers/cookies. And some part of me does feel guilty giving this place a bad review, but there are too many other great things to see in the city that I wouldn't waste my time going here again. Or in the first place. Go check out the Conservatory of Flowers if you are in GG park - it is much cooler.
author: Alex H.

description: Took my two kids and teenage brother to visit today. Kids are free so i paid for me and my teen brother. I walked straight to the paying booth since no one was in line. I noticed as i paid there was a second woman in the  booth, she was board because she was playing a card came on her computer as the younger woman check me in. My children walked through then my teen brother when the older woman looked up and noticed him and stuck her head through the window and told us we needed to pay. She was rude and yelled at us as more people actually started to line up and got crowded. PERHAPS IF SHE WAS NOT PLAYING CARDS ON HER COMPUTER she would have realized we had paid as i told her and then she stuck her head back in her booth.  The poor customer service and rudeness affected our excitement walking in. The staff should pay better attention then to play computer games when everybody is watching them.  I would visit again because it was so nice taking pictures there but I hope this review will allow the Management to pay better attention on how they train staff to speak to people..
author: Moi M.

description: After lunch we decided to check out the Japanese Tea Garden in GG Park. Gosh, I have not been here since I was a little girl. It is very peaceful and very zen like here. I enjoyed the gardens and it did give me some peace and serenity. Of course the gift shops helps too. I end up picking a cute little turtle to add to my key chain. Its a great place to walk around and take pictures.
author: Donna Y.

description:
I think if I had never been to another Japanese Garden, I would have given this 5 stars.  It's pretty, quaint, and somewhat relaxing (we went on a Monday and it was packed with visitors).  

But since I've been to others that were more stunning in their size and more thought out in terms of the framed vistas, I have to give this place a disappointing 3 stars.
author: Gigi M.

description:
I love to climb to the top of the steepest bridge ever and take my picture.

Welcome to the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden gate park. This experience is fun and unforgettable.

If you like to view lush scenery while sipping on jasmine tea and eating crackers, then this is the place for you to go. Located next to the De Young Museum the Japanese garden is nestled behind an intriguing wall of wonder.

As you walk in you instantly feel like your on a different continent. You wonder around the gardens looking at the elegant ponds filled with Koi fish and lily pads. As you look around you soon see a large structure that looks like a large house. As you follow the maze of shrubs you soon see Buddha sitting peacefully on top of a rock. I enjoyed every moment I spent in bliss walking among the greenery in the gardens.

I will back soon to support my local gardens within the spectacular Golden Gate Park.
author: Kelli H.

description:
A fantastic little oasis in San Francisco.

I come early in the morning, put down the $4 admission fee and enjoy the serenity of the gardens. There are some really wonderful little spots here. My daughter especially enjoyed the koi in the pond. It's fun to have tea in the covered patio area, although I find the snacks with the tea a bit strange (and some of the crackers are surprisingly spicy). 

It's amazing that such a cool place exists only 5 minutes from our home.
author: J B.

description: Fighting over stale snacks with squirrels and pigeons has never been so fun.  The garden is serene and beautiful, and it fun for all ages.  The teahouse is an odd experience with, as I mentioned, the squirrels and pigeons, a decent pot of tea, fascinating people watching, and waitresses in traditional garb dishing out your tea efficiently in a cramped but bizarrely calming Californian oasis.
author: Frank W.

description:
This place has been around forever, and its always fun to spend some time here. Spend the money and have some tea and crackers.
Time seems slow here.
author: Tom S.

description:
It's OK the first time around. Going there more than once is seriously recommended against.

Update: I went once again and for some reason I was able to appreciate it more than the last time....I'll call it American culture at it's most Japanese. Boosting it up to 3 stars.
author: James J.

description:
OK,
So you feel like chilling and contemplating over some exotic Japaneze tea and snacks.
Yeahhhhhh,,, rigggght.
You pay 4$ fee to enter the garden, so you see that lil wooden cozy space where you supposta sit your butt and enjoy.
You coming in.. and u see... that there are like 50 people like u already sitting there, that makes it a TOURIST TRAP!
Tea was poor, snaks were just snaks :)
Waitresses arent even that friendly. Seems like these peeps doing their profit outta air. Literally !
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: Wow. This place is beautiful... but I was really sad because there was garbage everywhere! We picked up what we could, but it was like a trash can tipped over and it all blew everywhere or something. There was an abundance of animals, which was great - huge, splashing koi in every pond, ducks and geese and herons, turtles and squirrels and other birds! The plants and trees were beautiful, and the blossoms were just blooming on the trees. We didn't pay to go to the park, but parking was $6, so we opted to park across the street near the Bella Castello apartments and walk a block instead. Thanks to Jeff for the bit about the history of the place!
author: Sara W.

description:
What a beautiful place!  Not totally peaceful because it was pretty crowded, but we had so much fun walking around, taking it all in, taking lots and lots of pictures.  
Free admission on MWF before 10am, I think?  We missed it by 30 minutes or so.
Didn't have tea, but it looked lovely.
Loved this place.  We have one in Chicago, but it doesn't even compare.
author: L T.

description:
I'd give five stars but the gardens are very diffucult for folks who have any physical diffuculty. Narrow bridges. Bridges made of uneven stones that don't touch. 
Aside from that I'd like to spend all my time here.
author: Mer S.

description:
Go for the flora, not for the tea.  If you go one hour before closing, it's free! (Ooh, i rhymed)

On a side note the already completely mediocre film," Memoirs of a Geisha" was completely ruined for me when I realized that someone's palatial Japanese estate was actually the good ol' tea garden. There goes my suspension of disbelief...
author: D-E F.

description:
It's a very nice to enjoy the typical Japanese garden features, espeically after a trip to the modern De Young.  You can still find peace in mind if you avoid the most popular bridge and just walk along the path in areas with fewer attractions.

It's not so bad to have many tourists b/c garden in Japan may have the same amount of people too.   The only difference is how people show their appreciation for the serenity, with their eyes or by their mouth, staying on the trail or running on the greens.
author: Ile F.

description:
Such a gorgeous spot to visit on a sunny day in SF.  It's tranquil and beautiful.  After a stroll through the garden, sit and enjoy a pot of tea with japanese snacks.

And of course there are going to be foreign tourists here...duh.  However, all that aside, it's still a spot that locals can come and play.  Be a tourist in your own city.  That's the best part!
author: K N.

description:
okay, for letting two friends and i in for free in this beautiful place? Yup, five stars.

Thank you, ticket guy!
author: Jillian R.

description: Beautiful scenery and well maintained garden. I've been to others and this one is the best. It is located in Golden Gate Park, so after your time here you can walk to other places of interest. Ticket prices are very reasonable and there are certain days/times that you can get in for free. This is a must-see if you are on vacation in San Francisco.
author: Steve B.

description: I went a couple years ago and have been aching to go back again. Even though it's been a while since I last visited, the beauty is hard to forget. It's so serene there I have never experienced anything like it.
author: Mary J.

description: Serene, beautifully landscaped, getting lost in your private nook can happen here at the Garden.  I wish there were more pagodas though.  One star docked for the relatively high price.  I didn't indulge in tea, but I bet that's a lovely way to spend an afternoon with a friend.
author: Becca C.

description:
The Jap Tea Garden has been run by the same family (frealzy Jap fam) for hella years.

A lot of them have married white which is why they get minus stars, because it means pretty soon the garden will be run by whiteys!

It's a fun place to smoke a bowl and wander around.  Obviously not during tourist season which it most definitely is right now (July 5).

Oh.  You can't bring your own refreshments, because they want you to buy theirs (tea).

Mikey says, "Fuck tourists!"

Stephie says, "Dude, have we been walking in circles?"
author: Steph and Mike A.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden in SF has really gone downhill. Unless you get free admission, save your money. The garden itself is overrated. The open air tea house offerings are low quality. I found a curly hair in my order, obtained a refund and left.
author: Jay M.

description: Overpriced. In complete disrepair. No landscaping done. Only pro is it's relatively quiet.
author: Anya F.

description: Not as great as I'd hoped for, especially for that price. Was pretty small, and had people walking around on their cell phones. The two guys at the front gate taking money were a bit cold and snotty. Too expensive, and not as pretty as I'd hoped.
author: Matt S.

description: For a minimal fee of $4 you are transported to a world of beauty and serenity!! Very pretty flowers, lot of water element and colorful pagoda...It can get crowded...but a perfect place to unwind...
author: PRETTY D.

description:
Oh, man. Six stars. Garden bliss! 

My first visit here took place last year when the Chihuly exhibit was in its final weeks at the De Young. Based on the hours posted on the JTG website, I figured I could open the place up, enjoy the garden in morning dew (or garden sprinkler) mode then head over to open the De Young. But when I arrived, the sign posted outside the garden noted it opened a little later--by 30 minutes. A dear soul working outside the gate who could apparently tell I had my garden game face on, opened the gate and then closed it behind me. I enjoyed true peace and tranquility in the company of a few artists and photographers, who were spontaneously dedicated to giving one another their own piece of the garden. We all moved about unobtrusively, with appreciative nods, all without speaking. As a result, I blew through the memory card in my camera in about 15 minutes. An amused colleague emailed me his Chihuly shots the following day.  

On mnypny's Bliss Spectrum, this place rates right up there with a Dave Brubeck, Tony Bennett, or Hives concert--wildly smile-inducing to the point of frightening small children and animals. Sorry, Fluffy.
author: mnypny b.

description: GO HERE if you are in Golden Gate Park or even just San Francisco!! Go right when it opens on Monday, Wednesday, or Friday because it is free. This is a gorgeous place and perfect for pictures and just relaxing.
author: Melissa D.

description:
I had originally read about this place on Fodors and then came to Yelp to get more details. This place really is worth the $4 admission charge. The gardens are real peaceful with great picture opportunities. You can take great pictures without people getting in the way. I did come early in the morning so there weren't too many people, got there around 10:30ish. I'm not sure how busy is gets later on in the day, but it's totally worth it in the AM. Definitely go check this place out the next time you're in San Fran.

To see some of my pictures, check out my blog:
http://dog-droppings.com/japanese_tea_garden/
author: Kasia J.

description:
Looks nice from outside.  Accidentally didn't read the sign on the outside clearly and thought the entrance was free.  Before I even took another step forward, I hear a very arrogant and rude grunt "HEY" from inside the kiosk.  Mr. Fuji (If you guys remember from the WWF) calls me over with a mean, I mean MEAN look on his face and points out at the printed-out admission fee at the window table.  I said, "Thanks but no thanks, for a guy like you, I ain't giving you my hard-earned $5 bucks just to go in."  If you were more courteous and didn't give me the mean ole' Tourist treatment (I'm from Mountain View by the way, so I'm hardly a Tourist), maybe perhaps I would have paid for myself, wifey and kids to go in.  Seeing that it was very crowded, I'd rather opt to come back on a Wednesday when its free to get in and avoid Mr. Fuji and his mean stare.  I swear, when I looked back, he was still giving me the mean stare until I got outside the gates.  What a Dipshit!!  

If anyone else sees this guy, let me know if he treats you any different.  I'd like to bitch-slap that fucker if I had a chance to, but definitely not in front of the kids, that's for sure!!  I will make another review after visiting here on a Free Wednesday.  What a bad way to ruin the beautiful and serene atmosphere.
author: Bread S.

description: I have been here a few times. First when i visited SF years ago and then as visitors came when I moved here.  It's located in Golden Gate Park and is very picturesque.  It always makes me feel very calm when I come to the JTG.  If you live in SF and have not come here, make it a point to and if you're a tourist, you must come on your visit!
author: Ka C.

description: the ice cream mocha was my favorite part of this place and it was over priced. the tea is really bad. they don't even have real matcha green tea, its was a total disappointment. the scenery is also lame- I've seen way better japanese tea gardens
author: Lexi H.

description: We'll kept garden worth seeing once. But entrance is expensive and its hard to find a place to sit if you actually want to have tea.
author: R G.

description: Needed to return to the gift shop but was prevented re-entry by a very rude door person!   After visiting with my out of town guests for many years I will have say NO...never again!  The personnel in the gift shop are very nice however.  It is the nasty door guy who ruined it for me!
author: Charles D.

description: Beautiful and really feels like the gardens in Japan- if not slightly more beautiful.  A great place to walk around and catch up with an old friend.  Tea is not the best in the city, but the ambiance makes up for it.
author: Elyse C.

description: The garden is quite beautiful and the tea and sweets in the tea house are delicious. However there is a distinct lack of tranquility here as half the people in the tea room were talking at the top of their lungs about mundane topics and kids were running screaming through the gardens. It kind of ruins the whole atmosphere. I wanted to scream at them all to "shut the hell up", but then that would have ruined the tranquility wouldn't it. If you could come here when it was quiet then it would be a 4* experience.
author: Alex D.

description:
I love Japanese gardens.

Heck, I visit Tokyo multiple times a year for extended periods of time, but for my short stay in San Francisco, I knew I had to see the Japanese Tea Garden.

The Tea Garden, like all the Japanese gardens I've been to, is extremely relaxing and beautiful. I explored the place for a couple hours until I had multiple photos of every little corner of the place. I ended up with 150 photos in total. The Tea Garden is a wonderful place for photography and a great place to relax.
author: Chris L.

description: beautiful environment with great walks all around the space.
author: Tina F.

description:
Great on a beautiful day. I suggest going on a city guides tour:
http://www.sfcityguides.org/desc.html?tour=102
We caught up with them 20 mins. into the tour, and the guide provided a lot of interesting historical information. One thing the guide pointed out is that the garden is not completely authentic: the Chinese pagoda is from an exposition, many plants are unusual (such as a redwood and flowering plants), and the koi fish are dying in the ponds because SF changed the water treatment from chlorine to chloramine.  However, the garden is beautiful on its own terms. The admission is free Monday, Wednesday & Friday. With the price of parking (on a Sunday it's practically impossible to find street parking, so we parked at UCSF), and the admission price, it's not cheap for a visit that can take just about an hour. However, it's nice to relax after walking at the tea house, and enjoy miso, tea, and mochi.
author: Ian A.

description: The absolute worse five bucks I've ever spent! This tea garden was a ridiculous rip-off--and there was no complimentary tea. I saw no Koi and few plants when I went two weeks ago. My friend and I attempted to stay there for as long as possible to get our money's worth, but we left after we circled the place twice in fifteen minutes. Another sad tourist trap.
author: Liz T.

description: I was excited to see this place because the pictures people take from here are so breath taking.  After going.. I probably wouldn't go again unless I was having some type of photo shoot there like for a wedding.. because I did see that going on.  Its 7 bucks cash!  The place is pretty small.. shouldn't be that much but I understand the place probably needs a lot of maintenance in terms of making sure everything is green and pretty all the time.  I did enjoy the moon bridge, Zen garden, and Buddah statue.  The gift shop had pretty much everything that I could get from little Tokyo or China town.. nothing too authentic in there.  I'm glad I went to see it but ven, vedi, vici.. I came, I saw, I conquered.. movin on.
author: Anya R.

description: I love this place!  Go during the week when not so many people are there.  It's beautiful and relaxing.
author: vanessa c.

description:
+/- of the Japanese Tea Garden
- for bitchy customer service at the tea room (waitress slammed down two bottles of water + a bowl of crackers and demanded $8.57)
+ for photo op bridge
-  for overpriced souvenir store which carries the same crap as Chinatown for 3x the price
-  for fake animals (including frog) thrown into the not so impressive landscaping
+ for stupid tourists taking pictures of bamboo
-  for hot handrails (dark colors absorb heat...ouch!)
+ for Canadians at the entrance asking if there was a Canadian discount
- for charging a four dollar entrance fee for something that took us no more than 15 minutes to walk through

It was sixteen dollars and fifty seven cents better spent elsewhere.
author: H.S. G.

description: $5 entry fee for this place, methinks not! I was expecting to see a zen garden with actual sand instead of white pebbles and a pond filled with Kois. Nope, instead I got candid pictures taken of me and I could not get a photo without getting someone else in the background, foreground, etc. Def too many tourists! I would rather make my way and drive to SJ to go to the Japanese garden there where I see not ONE koi fish (like i did here, unless they were all hiding or dead), but MANY and I can feed them too. The only thing they have is a tea area, but there were too many people that I opted not to try it.
author: Tracy T.

description: The gardens are immaculate and much, much closer than Kyoto or Kanazawa. The tea is a bonus. Plus they serve crunchy Japanese snacks.
author: Brandon R.

description: Nice gardens. Tea is fun (can't vouch for it's authenticity as I spied a box labelled Lipton in the back kitchen).
author: Aki S.

description: Excellent tea service. The Japanese Tea Garden is a must both within Golden Gate Park and in San Francisco in general.
author: Ahu S.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden has the nicest public restroom I have ever seen.  The garden itself was lovely.  I used to come here with my grandma as a kid and in that case-of course-it was extra special.  It seemed a little too crowded to be perfect on sunday but I was glad I went anyways.  I'd like to go at sunset in a garden filled with Japanese lanterns...
author: Lauren S.

description:
"its like a little trip to japan..."

i heard some german grandmother exclaim this statement about 5 times as she perched on the bamboo railing to her drooling 2-ish year old grandson as he barreled down the steps & pulled on the bushes.  

there are signs all over this place stating "please do not sit on the bamboo railings" in a crappy asian-ish font. must be why NOBODY can freakin read them. i have a low tolerance for tourists. i avoid them at most costs. this day, however, with vacationing parentals in town, i was forced to become one.  

fists clenched, i proceeded into the tea gardens.

the crappiest overpriced over diluted tea with a handful of crackers served by surly kimono-clad various-asian ethnicity girls wasnt able to sway me from being in awe of the amazing landscape architecture that exists here. the fluttry cherry & apple blossoms made me smile & i caught myself taking silly pics with my parents all over the grounds.

i think i counted one koi in the pond. hiding quite efficiently.

i saw about 5 people sit on the bamboo railing & knock it over before we left to get lunch.
author: Gabby K.

description:
As a tourist I did enjoy it, however there were just as many tourists trying to enjoy it too.. Which made any sort of photo opp just about impossible.  

Overall it was very lovely and calming, a nice place to see to say you have been there but I wouldn't need to or necessarily want to revisit. 

Price was $7 for adults which isn't bad.
author: Stephanie K.

description: I'd go back just to see those little lobster thingies in the pond fight each other. yeayuh.
author: T L.

description: Created by an Australian as part of the California Mid-Winter Exposition in 1894, this intricate complex of paths, ponds, and a teahouse features native Japanese and Chinese plants. Scattered about its gently sloping five acres are beautiful sculptures, atmospheric bridges, ornamental lanterns, and ornate gateways. Supple and resilient bamboo is an appropriately prevalent plant. For many, this is the prettiest and most serene oasis of several in Golden Gate Park.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I came here last Friday with Mom after we balked at the $25 entry fee to the Academy of Sciences. We only had an hour. Sitting there drinking tea with Mom and looking at the garden and pond was exquisite. It was a rainy day so the crowds were down. It still cost us over $20 to get in and have tea, but it was worth it for us. I dream of this garden when I am low.
author: Terry F.

description: I love this place. Its beautiful. and of course relaxing drinking tea is one of my favorite past times.  I will be going here a lot more from now on.  Besides all of the tourists from all over the world snapping pictures, it's almost as if you step into another world.
author: Sonya D.

description: I am always more excited talking about coming to this place than I am about actually coming here.  It's always a little disappointing, but I think that's because I always expect it to be this massive place like Descanso Gardens in Southern California.  Well, it's not massive, but it's quaint.  It's also a nice place to bring visitors.
author: John S.

description: I feel bad reviewing this garden.  It is a place loved by many and viewed by San Francisco's many residents and visitors as a quintessential representation of Japan's landscaping artforms.  Alas, it is more akin to a mini-golf course than a proper Japanese garden, which normally would sprawl peacefully, offering vistas (shared and encompassed), and would contrast the large space with small, intimate spaces, much like the roji that leads to a chashitsu.  Again, I feel bad to rate this lower than one might normally, but I accept more from it.
author: Scott N.

description: $7 per person to get in, it's small and nothing much. If you love japanese culture maybe I recommend, but you gotta really really love the culture... It's cute but it's a "oh cute" let's move on cute... not quiet at all, lots of people so if you think you will relax there you are going to the wrong place... with the $7 you will save per person by not going there you can get a hot dog else where in the park and sit on a nice area for free!
author: Ma B.

description: I found this place serene DESPITE all the tourists which is pretty amazing.  Its beautiful on a sunny SF day.  Grab a ($6...YES $6...just deal with it, its worth it)  pot of tea for 2 and crackers (and perhaps buy 3 or 4 overpriced yet yummy bags of japanese candy like I did) and catch up with an old friend in the tea house.  $3.50 admission is well worth it.  Where'd the Koi go?  Maybe they were hiding, I was on the lookout but didnt see any :(
author: Cathleya G.

description: For about $10 you gain entrance and a lovely pot of tea. If it's around lunchtime, you can also grab a reasonably priced bowl of udon. This place had always been a fond childhood memory and returning as an adult, did not disappoint.
author: Britt R.

description: After entering the beautiful park I was more than excited when I saw for only $3.95 per person you could have tea.  Your tea comes with sesame crackers, sesame cookies and fortune cookies.  The tea seems to never end and there is no limit to how long you can sit in this beautiful place.
author: Megan P.

description: I agree with Dave--this place really isn't that cool, and it's one of the only places you have to pay for in the park. I don't think it's as nice as many of the free areas, like the botanical gardens. All three of us regretted giving up the $6 for the tea garden.
author: Anonymous P.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is located in Golden Gate Park next door to de Young Museum.  Beautifully landscaped gardens with cool bridges.  Best time to go is in early spring for the cherry blossoms.  Some of the bridges are steep so wear comfortable shoes so you can walk across them.  The garden also has a tea house and a gift shop filled with overpriced Japanese inspired souvenirs.  The tea house is usually full so expect a wait.  Bring your camera there are so many great photo ops here.
author: Rachel R.

description: I love sitting in the little tea house munching on sesame and almond cookies while gazing out at the little pagodas and koi filled ponds. ahh, tourist fun.  Don't play on the big rocks on a moist and drizzly day or you will end up sprawled out on your ass like my friend.
author: Rick H.

description: Beautiful little park, and, yes, the gift shop is sort of cheesy, but I always buy pretty Japanese watercolor cards there that I can't find at other places.  Also, and this just may be my complete ignorance about genuine Japanese culture and tradition, but I love having tea in the park, too.
author: J T.

description: $4 admission was way too much for this garden.  There wasn't much to see.  The grass was unkempt, there were hardly any flowers.  We walked it in 10 minutes.  The tea and snacks are overpriced.  They did have live music which was peaceful.  I gave it two stars because the highlight of our experience was a samurai walking around posing for pictures.  He had the full garb on with makeup and everything!  He was definitely way into it and awesomely wacky!
author: Blu n.

description: Frickin' cool!  This place is so unique and pretty.  A great place to frolic around and not feel like you are in the city.  Take a picnic and spend a day in the park, but don't forget to visit the Japanese Tea Gardens.  There are plenty of bridges and creeks and Buddhas, so go crazy with a camera and take tons of fun photos!
author: Vanessa Z.

description: A gorgeous place to stroll about the well manicured landscape within the gates of Golden Gate Park. A few dollars is all it takes to sample a warm tea with a side of light crackers to snack on in this lush environment. This is quite a peaceful and romantic spot near the De Young museum so if you have time to make a day of it, hit the museum first and then get some fresh air in the lovely tea gardens.
author: Jessica D.

description:
Um... Not so nice. Got there during the free entry. My child had an accident and needed a change of clothes but the Nazi doormen said no free return. I informed them of the situation and told them I just need to run to the car for our emergency clothes but they told me $5. Basturds! Child friendly my a$$!  
 
Good side was nice garden and friendly tearoom/giftshop workers
author: robert s.

description: Very calm, peaceful, and absolutely perfect when it becomes really warm in the city. Also, keep in mind that they don't take credit cards, so it's cash only. At first I thought, 'bummer'  since I am a "take Visa wherever you go" kinda gal, but lucky for me it's not really pricey here and I got by with the amount of cash I had. I love it here, it's very beautiful!
author: Narina A.

description: pleasing to all the senses.  lovely place to take your visiting family for tea.
author: Jen W.

description: A very cool oasis inside an oasis inside a bustling city.  It's easy to forget you're in San Francisco.  Nice place to take visitors.
author: Russel S.

description: According to my sister, this was the highlight of her trip to SF to visit me. This place is a gem hidden in the vastness of golden gate park. I am embarrassed to admit the first time I came here was last weekend at the request of my out of town guests, but now I plan to come back frequently. It is about 4 bucks to get in and 3 more for tea and cookies. Yes it is touristy, but it is also a place locals can enjoy. Plus the legion of honor is right next door.
author: Stacy H.

description: Can we just call this a Japanese Garden? This Garden is amazing! I have meditated here and felt deep beauty and calm. The tea here however, is lame. Both the experience and quality of tea leads me to reccomend you bring your own in a mug and focus on the garden.
author: Sari G.

description: As we were walking to our car after the museums, we decided to go in and see the Japanese Tea Garden because neither of us ever remember ever seeing it before.  We were just at a few Tea Gardens in Oregon last month so we thought we would check this one out as well.  Maybe it was the gloomy weather but it didn't look as nice as I hoped it to be but it was still pretty.  The koi pond is sad, theres like 3 kois and they are tiny.  The place is small too. There were people taking wedding pictures there.  We were done walking around in less than 10 minutes... and it cost us $5 each.
author: Kymberli C.

description: This tea garden is beautiful, tranquil, but it can get crowded.  This would be a great spot to take some engagement photos ;-).
author: Mercedes R.

description: Great photo Op. Only a few dollars to get in. The tea is good and they have Pocky. Instant win. And all the trees are blooming right now, which makes it even more amazing. A must see if you've never been to San Fran before.
author: Kimiko S.

description: I am half Japanese and embarrassed to say that it took me 10 years to finally make it to the Japanese Tea Gardens. I took my parents and my son one day during the week in February. I could see that it had the potential to be a stunning garden, but when I was there, they must have been doing some maintenance because the river wasn't flowing, there was just concrete. Also, Feb isn't a great time to go, the Japanese maples and the cherry blossom trees were both naked. I need to go back in Spring or Fall, I am sure it will be much better then. I was also a little disappointed there weren't more yummy Japanese snack options at the tea bar. My favorite part of the garden was the crazy bridge that is the shape of half a wheel and the koi fish.
author: Lynn G.

description:
Very nice place and kind of relaxing.  There were a lot of tourists when I went and it wasn't big enough to really get away from them.  The "Drum Bridge" was pretty neat, though I would have liked it much more if I could actually sit on top of it and just chill there; there was too much pedestrian traffic to do so, though.

Overall, the place looked quite... Japanese :D  However, the gift shop completely ruined the experience for me.  It felt like they grabbed one of those cheesy Chinese gift stores from Chinatown (you know... the ones where everything is 50 cents and looks like it'll fall apart when you look at it).  I was disappointed that they would ruin the atmosphere by having this there... at least get rid of the windows so I can't see all the tourists drooling over cheap trinkets that they'll realize they really don't want as soon as they leave.

The tea shop was neat, though much too small, and way too westernized.  I was expecting to sit outside, around a calm pond with large sitting areas and chat with my friends, but we all ended up smashing together in the corner of the shop (which was all just poorly painted brown wooden benches and stools) and tried (though failed miserably) not to accidentally bump into the other tea-goers around me.  I have to admit though... the Jasmine tea was quite good, though the snacks they gave us were too un-Japanese for my liking (it was something along the lines of trail mix/chex mix and fortune cookies.. what the hell??).  Where's my mochi??
author: Guy D.

description: This place is like so unique! The place is so beautiful and peaceful, there are some stuff you dont see all the time either.
author: sARaH s.

description: Even if you live in the city, you should visit here.  I had a photoshoot there last week and it was so very enjoyable.  There are a number of great places to just sit and meditate.  Of course, they are busier of the weekends than weekdays, but it is still worth seeing.  One downside is just how small it is - the pains of being in a big city.
author: Victoria K.

description: Breathtaking..... and so close to my house.  I truly couldn't wish for a more beautiful place to sit and think, or walk and explore.  Highly recommended for Sunset or Richmond locals as a nice walk during the weekend.... enjoy this city for all it's worth people!!  It is the best!
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: The pure crowds here take away from the Japanese Garden experience.  Its worth the entry fee of $4 and the tea cost of $4 as a nice place to rest as you're exploring this large park.  The staff at the tea garden is attentive and efficient.  The garden itself is somewhat underwhelming compared to Portland's.  But again its a nice way to break while in the park.
author: Brian M.

description: Man I hate to be a wet blanket here but this was not nearly as cool as I had expected.  Maybe my expectations were too high and time will give me a better perspective.
author: Dave M.

description: Probably nice and memorable place but they do not take credit cards. How retarded. Went with the museum instead. If you charge $7 per person and there is no ATM around you should be required to take cards.
author: Michael S.

description:
after a nice stroll in the park, SF can get a bit cold...we entered this japanese tea house/garden (5$ per person) to see what was up...

i wanted to compare this garden to the ones in japan...it was a nice experience... i didnt even know this existed in GG park... 
we sat down at the worlds most expensive tea house (8$ tea)... but hey, it was worth the experience...this is also no time to be a cheap bastard...just sit down, sip some tea and eat some arare... relax and become zen....

i gave it 5 stars just because its something different to do and its worth seeing it once...
author: Nic M.

description: One of the best places in the park and the city.  Beautiful, serene and enchanting.
author: Bridget T.

description: There are plenty of quiet meditative spots throughout the park that are FREE - everything on offer at the Japanese Tea Garden is available elsewhere with better service and much cheaper.
author: Quartknee K.

description: I was a little disappointed by the size the gardens...  It didn't take long to see all there was to see...  Go on a Monday in the morning to save yourself the entrance fee.
author: Tom J.

description: What better way to kill an hour or two on a beautiful day, than to go to the Japanese Tea Garden?  You get to take a leisurely stroll through meticulously maintained gardens, look at beautiful flowers and trees that you never get to see, drink tea, eat sticky-spicy crackers, admire the beautiful pools and zen gardens.  It's all very relaxing.....when it's not overrun with other people trying to do the same.
author: Heather T.

description: I totally don't understand all the bitching and moaning about tourists and high prices.  This place is an integral part of San Francisco history, that has delighted SF children (I was one of them) for eons.  I actually have a picture of my father as a little boy, posed in front of the red pagoda in the late 1940s.  As another wise reviewer pointed out, admission here is equivalent to the price of a latte, and worthwhile to keep a beautiful and traditional little slice of SF going.  The garden is lovely in April when the cherry blossom trees bloom and are reflected in the koi pond, and it's fun to climb over the moon bridge and have tea and cookies at the little teahouse, while watching the koi swim around in the pond below.  The garden is not earth shaking excitement, but it lovely and peaceful (at least on the weekdays) and a part of our history.
author: Stephanie D.

description: To this day I swear I saw a Koi Fish. Take your tourists here and unwind with a pot of tea as they are going crazy taking pictures of the moon bridge and the pagodas.
author: Han L.

description: Beautiful, peaceful and romantic. If I could I'd make this my backyard to chilax, read and enjoy the scenery, plants and ambiance. The store on site is a bit pricey, but sometimes I find interesting items that I don't mind spending the extra on.
author: Marie G.

description: really nice place to visit.  it was relaxing, and the tea served there was nice, and fairly inexpensive.  we've got to go back in the spring, when everything is in bloom.
author: Edward S.

description: I had no idea that it was $4 to get in and cash only. Of course I had $7 but there is an ATM at the museum next door. There were a lot of people inside and the tea restaurant was packed! We luckily found a little table in the corner away from everybody and just relaxed drinking jasmine tea with the rice crackers and cookies. It was $3.95 a person for that.  It's very picturesque and I took quite a few pictures. It was nice to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city and park. I definitely recommend it.
author: Glenn M.

description: I shouldn't be rating an attraction that we didn't even get into. $4 admission... CASH ONLY. We decided not to go find an ATM to get in... a lot of people sitting around the entrance with these absolutely bored and exhausted expressions on their face. The people walking away from it had these snarls. I am assuming it was a crowded day? At any rate, we have no desire to return and explore for ourselves. We should've Yelped it first.
author: RJ A.

description: This is a beautiful garden.  I'm willing to shell out $5 to visit as a tourist, but would only go back again if I was taking visitors who have never been to SF.  There are some nice temples and a nice buddha, and it's an overall nice walk.  There is also a tea place for people to sit down and enjoy some tea and crackers -- this is clearly created for tourists.
author: Diana N.

description: One of my favorite places in the world for as long as I can remember! The combination of beatiful Japanese gardens and warm tea is heavenly. A great, theraputic place to spend the afternoon alone or with a friend. Good for dates too!
author: Clare G.

description: It's a gorgeous escape especially when the sakura are blooming in the spring.  I try to go every year. The gift shop has definitely become much better recently. I heard they have a new owner.  In the past, it was packed with really cheap pseudo "Asian"  trinkets .  Now, it seems the store is beginning to have more of a real Japanese look and feel and so does their selection of gift items.
author: Mia T.

description: Rip off. I have an out of state lisense, so they charge extra. I've lived here for years.
author: Guiseppe W.

description: One of the parks coolest spots - for under $5 you can explore the beautiful tea garden walking hand in hand with your sweetheart as you pass streams and cross bridges. You can buy cookies and tea and relax by the lake.
author: Kavita S.

description: The day after I left Japan, my friends took me here.  It wasn't my first choice  of places to go but I enjoyed it.  It reminded me of touristy places in the kansai area (nara) but much much much smaller.    Okinawa doesn't look anything like the tea garden park so it didn't really remind me of home.  I think they should bring in some deer or a petting zoo.  Overall, it's a nice break from a walk in the Golden Gate park.
author: John B.

description: Your San Francisco experience would not be complete w/o doing the Japanese Tea Garden. You have to rock the green tea in SF. Now that doesn't sound too crass, does it?
author: Evelyn B.

description:
Plus: One of the stand-out features of San Francisco.  

Minus: Many many tourists.  Standing in front of you.  Taking pictures.  Asking you to get out of their shot.  Grrr.
author: Will S.

description: Really pretty. Didn't get a chance to sit down and enjoy the tea & cookies, but I really loved walking through it during the free hour!!! Woop Woop.
author: Anita C.

description: A cute way to spend a little bit of time in Golden Gate Park. Beautiful scenary if you appreciate asian structures and statues. A bit smaller than I had expected but stunning nevertheless. Lots of small pathways that take you around the garden ensure that you walk through every display so that you have the chance to take in the color and the detail.
author: Candy C.

description: Beautiful.  I imagine the tea is good but I didn't have any money to try it. For that reason I probably shouldn't review it...
author: Patrick A.

description: my sanctuary. This is the place I come esp in fall and winter...its been 7 years ive been coming here usually on sundays tho there are quite a few people (fewer in the cooler months) such a place of peace and quiet. sharing a pot of jasmine tea over the koi pond is recommended and other teas are offered. The walk around the park is beautiful and ever changing in the seasons be sure to keep going to see the transformation of this wonderous place.
author: Farrah S.

description: Beautifully landscaped section of the park...feels much like a park within..... if you get me.
author: Eugene G.

description: Five dollars pays your way into what could be a beautiful green garden in the city, but unfortunately, much of that beauty is overshadowed by tourists and annoying teenagers ditching school. Another 4.95 will get you a cup of Lipton brand tea, rice crackers and cookies, all served by a highschooler donning a wrinkled kimono and stained white tube socks. I expected something a bit more tranquil. I'll blame my bad experience on the dreary weather.
author: Brittany L.

description: Although this garden is a bit on the small side, it never fails to amaze me. The koi fish swimming around, the very large buddha staring at me, and the awesome wheel that everyone has to climb on and get their picture taken on. If you go on a week day you almost feel like you're no longer in the city :)
author: Nichole H.

description: The park was very nice. Very peaceful. Lots of good photo opportunities.
author: Jay T.

description: I take my kids here a couple of times a year at different seasons.  It's best on weekdays since it can be crowded on weekends.  Summer is lovely but also more crowded.  The kids love exploring all around it by themselves but it is small enough that they can never get lost.  We always agree to meet at the teahouse or pagoda at a certain time.  The tea house has yummy Japanese teas and cookies and the gift shop is full of fun Japanese and San Francisco-related sourvenirs.
author: Merry P.

description: Beautiful and serene gardens. Be sure to take a camera!
author: Lee S.

description: the spam musubi was made out of sushi rice, and as someone who has loved it all my life, i really really liked it. good pick me up. the green tea with roasted brown rice has turned my tea hater bf into a convert. and it really hits the spot to sit and look out at the gardens. so peaceful that i think im going to do the mid day thing more often. mochi was flavorful but not as soft as i hoped. all around pleasant experience.
author: Sydel S.

description: I love the Japanese Tea Garden in Golden Gate Park!  It is beautifully landscaped and I found the settings to be a relaxing escape from the hustle and bustle of downtown.  I was lucky to visit on a day with perfect weather and not many tourists, so my experience was very enjoyable.  A unique feauture in the garden is the high drum bridge, which is sure to put a smile on your face when climbing over it.  I also sat down to enjoy Jasmine tea, crackers, and a fortune cookie, but unlike some other reviewers, I didn't mind the higher price that was charged. I mean, c'mon, you're in San Francisco, you should expect to pay more... just like any other tourist destination.  Overall, I would highly recommend the Japanese Tea Garden to anyone who loves nature and is looking for something different to do.
author: Erin F.

description: Little gem in the park.  Take kids, take a date, take your out-of-town visitors.  Be sure to have tea and cookies overlooking the Koi ponds and climb the tall bridge.
author: Michelle M.

description: This is an especially good place to take the edge off for visitors.  I took my 80 year old mother here during her week long visit last fall.  It was a nice break from the sometimes overwhelming whirl of must-sees that the Bay Area almost demands of visitors.  Toss in a stop at the Conservatory of Flowers and you've got yourself a lovely, low key afternoon.
author: Kevin S.

description: This place is really nice   A couple of years ago we brought what was then my future mother and father in aw here.  It was December and the rain came and went and we sat down and enjoyed some nice warm tea and how beautiful the surroundings were.  I get along very well with my mil, and I credit this place and one of the ways we got our relationship off on the right foot.  Also, my MIL took what is one of my favorite pictures of my husband and me here.  You can't help but take a nice picture with this background.  Even if you don't have guests in town, stop by here and enjoy.
author: Kate B.

description: It's not as bad as the worst reviews, nor as good as the best.  It's a cute place to take tourists, or take yourself if you want a  change from the ordinary.  Go late in the afternoon, when it's free, that way you can save your money for the tea.  It's pricey, but of pretty high quality.  Take it in slowely, breathe in the heady scents of the tea as you gaze over the Koi pond.  Take just a moment to relax and unwind from your day.  Munch on the plate of various snacks they give you, and finish up the snack with your fortune cookie.    It's a rather nice change from the hustle of urban life, but don't overdo it.
author: Herbert S.

description:
i guess it's a pretty neat place if you've never actually been to japan or much around asia.
went here once but i wasn't blown away.
i think i had higher expectations of this place... but it's difficult to awe me with gardens like these after visiting say the botanical garden in singapore :)
author: charlotte s.

description: A beautiful place.  In Golden Gate Park there is a little spot that is tranquil and will make you forget about all the traffic that you had to drive thru just to get here.  Bring a camera or you will be sorry that you didn't.
author: jen n.

description: This is such a lovely place!! It's located by the botanical garden so you can literally spend all day walking around.  The park is very charming, small enough to enjoy in full in less than an hour.  They also serve tea and cookies, so it's a great way to spend the day.  If you are lucky enough you'll see birds and squirrels stealing the waiter's cookies lol.
author: Mrs. G.

description: Do not expect to get in here for free on the first Thursday of the month. The gardens are very picturesque and serene. The tea is overpriced and it can get crowded in the restaurant area. My suggestion, bring your own tea mug, sit on the side somewhere and be in your own Zen space.
author: Judy L.

description: Love this place! It's just so relaxing and fun to walk around this little tea garden.  My favorite is to try walking up the bridge...it's like climbing the mountain! :P I can't wait to go back there again when the weather gets better :)
author: JenJen W.

description: This is my second favorite place in the city!  The garden is just deightful - so peaceful and pleasant, great place to spend an afternoon date.
author: kerry l.

description: I love love love this place... But I could do without the tea part... LoL... It's gorgeous and amazing, and so much fun to wander though... But, as with alot of things in San Francisco, I could also do without the tourists... Ugh... Oh well...
author: Lindsey S.

description: One of my favorite spots in Golden Gate Park. It's just beautiful. Very serene (aside from the crowds) and welcoming. Just walking in you feel as though you are not in the city anymore and in this peaceful oasis. It's also a great place to take family and friends.
author: Barbs J.

description: The great thing about the Tea Garden is that no matter the weather, this spot will calm your nerves and render some serene contemplation (okay, well maybe not in a raging thunderstorm, but we don't have those in the Bay Area anyway). I love the single, big red fish you'll see living in the murky pond among the lillies, the numerous and intricate spider webs up on statues and in trees, and the overall wonderful landscaping and gardening work. Bravo.
author: Patrick G.

description: If you are bored on a lazy summer day, it is a pleasant way to while away a couple of hours over some admittedly pricey tea.  When not too crowded with tourists, it can be very relaxing.
author: John D.

description: Despite the tourists, I felt peaceful.  I love the landscape and pagodas but you expect it to be larger.  Skip the tea.  The gift shop could be better.  There aren't many sights to process.
author: Ai M.

description:
The Japanese Tea Garden itself is still beautiful, and is just a treasure of peacefulness.  

Sadly, I had a terrible experience today (Dec 30,2009) at the tea house, which is under new management. Here's a quote relating to the change of concession: 
"Supporters say the change will transform what is now mainly a tourist spot that serves Chinese fortune cookies and sells generic souvenirs i
"I am hopeful that the Tea Garden will return to a more authentic Japanese American tradition," said Douglas Dawkins, a panel member and great-great grandson of Makoto Hagiwara, who originally designed much of the garden."
DREAM ON Folks!  The tea house is now a 100& cash cow tourist attraction. My order was taken by a completely disinterested and fairly surly young white man, and served by another white man, who slammed down my single cup of tea and 3 tiny cookies very rudely.  He seemed outraged when I asked for sugar (I was sharing with a small child), and brought it with no stirring stick.  Then when I got up to get one, he started yelling at me.  If anything could be farther from the concept of having tea in a Japanese tea garden than their behavior and attitude, I do not know what it would be.  

Enjoy the garden and skip the tea is my advice.
author: Nana R.

description: It's beautiful, it's peaceful, and a good place to spend a day with someone special. It's not pricey to go into something you can't find anywhere else in San Francisco.
author: Michael C.

description: Worth the $3 admission, but don't expect too much - it's pretty small.  Very nice garden and has some nice structures on the inside.
author: nicole h.

description: Lovers of contemplative Zen gardens and serene spaces, I humbly suggest you make pilgrimage here. You may find the Japanese Tea Garden to be one of the most beautiful places in the city.
author: Shalom O.

description: It was kind of boring and small. But for $4 admission, I shouldn't have any complaints. It reminds me of one of those places that my parents used to drag me to when I was young for family photo-ops. I always stuck my tongue out in those pictures.
author: Christine N.

description: Having been to Japan, I have to agree with a couple of the reviews stating that it's not really like much in Japan. It's like really, really watered down Japanese lanscaping. It's one of those things that I think is nice to do, and take people to see. Maybe $4 is too much, but still it could be worse. It would be relaxing without the gobs of tourists, but really its more like walking around an amusement park (on the weekends).
author: Lindsey G.

description: kind of over-rated. The one in Seattle is much more stunning. However, they have some beautiful flowers and architecture. Not worth $7 though. Hit it on a free day.
author: Shawn B.

description: One day when I was super stressed and needed some alone time to gather my thoughts, I immediately thought of visiting the Japanese Tea Garden. With its statues and the plethora of flora surrounding you, your blood pressure would surely go down. It's definitely a great place to relax, meditate, and get a few "ohms" out of your system or you can even find some peace of mind by climbing the bridge which is always fun. After you've had your little slice of nirvana you can grab some tea from the teahouse, which is pretty pricey for a pot and a couple of rice crackers on the side. It's relaxing until the birds start flocking to your side. Then the squirrels. Then the other forest creatures. It was like being in a scene in Snow White where all the animals gather. I'll admit that this place is much smaller than I imagined it to be so I wouldn't go when it is super busy and crowded otherwise it gets pretty claustrophobic.
author: Leslie K.

description: Agree wholeheartedly with all the other reviews.  If you think meditation is for chumps and hippies, I challenge you to visit this place and not find inner peace!  You can't help it.  And hey -- the tea was good.
author: Deb T.

description: It is very nice garden, but definitely this place is overcharged.  Another tourist trap!
author: Ame k.

description: Peaceful.  Serene and quaint.  I took my friend, Tangie, on her visit to the big, small city.  Green tea and some treats.  We sat watching people frolic into the garden, mesmerized by the sound of trickling water from the waterfalls, and the incredible landscaping that adorned ensuring the beauty of this place.  Next time, we will have her out earlier to enjoy the cherry blossom.  I had her climb the arching bridge, and enjoyed helping her down.  Buddha!  Zen!
author: Benjamin B.

description: After getting lost in Golden Gate Park prior to an AIDS Walk volunteer gig, I decided to forego the volunteer work altogether and visit the Tea Garden.  I could've walked through in 4 minutes if I hadn't stopped by the gift store which totally amused me.  If you want cheap Jade buddhas and tea sets, go to Chinatown and spend 1/4th the price.  If you want CHINESE coinage, just walk down Stockton St, you don't need to spend $3.99 at the JAPANESE Tea Garden.  It was peaceful aside from the three groups of tourists I took pictures for and I got a little kick out of walking across the pond but if I come back, I'll make sure it's on a free weekday morning.
author: Katie H.

description: Tiny place for $5, but good for a fantasy-filled walk with your toddler. We watched the magical bugs which could float on water. We climbed an impossibly steep bridge. We searched for faeries around the little houses.  No one was home. And we watched the koi swim in the clear pond. It was relaxing and peaceful. My daughter seemed transported.
author: Monica L.

description: ahhh to live in a different time and place.... since we can not!  we need to explore,,,, and this is a great secret tucked in the inner folds of S.F. park, and you must drink tea hopefully for 2 when strolling through  the garden, and the half moon bridge is something you have to do even if you have to crawl. but don't take my word for it ;)
author: Amanda W.

description: If you've never been to the Japanese Tea Garden, it is definitely worth your time. Make sure you get a picture on the crazy horseshoe bridge. It is not a big garden but there is plenty to walk around and see. I wish they would give anyone in the bay area free passes but it seems you have to be San Francisco resident. Worth 5 dollars a person to see someone smile.
author: Dave Y.

description: What a great place to sit and relax, and take a break from city life.  Relaxing, beautifull, peacfull, what other soothing words come to mind...It's not important all you need to know it is a great spot that nead not change for a long time.
author: brian m.

description:
This place is good for locals as well as tourists. Well, I guess if you're a local and you come here you pretty much become a tourist. How else to justify paying 5 bucks just to get into a park, and then 9 bucks for a teapot? Oh well, it's all just part of the fun.

The tea is good and the people working here are definitely japanese. The garden is dope (the only reason my review is a 4-star ... otherwise it drops down to 2 just because they charge 9 bucks for something that would cost me 50 cents at home). But honestly who wouldnt want a few moments of pure zen brought to you by the people who take care of the park and keep it nice and clean for everyone to enjoy? And a few peanut cookies to top it off? That's golden.

I send my visitors there all the time and even drop by whenever I get a chance and am not feeling too broke.
author: Raphael M.

description:
This place is magical! It's so so beautiful, serene, peaceful, positively lovely. It's a perfect escape from the hectic city pace. 
I think it's a really great family place and even a date place. Yeah, it gets touristy. But it's just so pretty! I love taking a stroll through here, sipping some tea on a nice spring day.
author: Nicole R.

description: A really nice place.  We went on a Thursday morning and it was very relaxing.  Not too many people.  I wouldn't go visit on the weekends, just too many people.
author: D A.

description: simply beautiful...this place is serene heaven on earth.
author: Iman Taliah H.

description: Beautiful place aside from the tourist children running around outside of the designated walking areas, running amok. I didn't understand why they were selling license plates in the gift shop though. I figure its just some underground Japanese mob front.
author: Tam X.

description: It's very lovely but not worth $7/person (for out of towners, residents get in for $5). Nice, peaceful, and pretty, but it's just not worth the money. Go when it's free.
author: Heidi K.

description: Admission is $7, and that is just not worth it for this measly oversized garden. Everything is pretty and all but it only takes 15 minutes max to walk around and see everything if you are walking slowly. You are basically spending $7 to go to a Japanese novelty store where they charge you money for a black and white printout map of the place (I do not recommend getting this because if you are spending that much money to get in, you might as well explore it on your own considering its small size). The items are also way over priced when comparing to an average Japanese novelty store in Japan Town. You also get to eat/drink at their cafe located in the center right next to the gift shop, for more money of course. Honestly, if you want to experience some Japanese culture, shop, and eat, just spend the extra gas money to drive 10-15 minutes to Japan Town which is free to get in. I can understand maybe going here during a time when everything is in full bloom, however I went here in mid May and there was really nothing to look at except koi in a dirty man made pond. I'd also like to note that there is a cool bridge that you have to climb up that offers a nice view of the area, however there is usually a line of tourists trying to climb up so the wait time can be ridiculous. The place also looks like it isn't very well maintained because paint is chipped off and faded and many things there are rusted.
author: Jan K.

description: A delightful garden! On our second visit, we especially enjoyed learning more about the history and symbolism in the garden on a free walking tour with San Francisco City Guides (see www.sfcityguides.org for schedule).
author: Karen-n-Rick C.

description: This place is a Rip off for $7 a piece. Its better to go to Muir Woods and pay $2 and enjoy Nature walk and fresh air than going to JTG which has nothing inside.
author: Sam A.

description: a MUCH bigger garden than the one that is in san jose - and once youre inside, youll completely forget where you are... there is a little tea house inside that serves tea and crackers... its a beautiful photo-op... and you could sit at the tea house for hours, just to lose yourself.
author: Sharon T.

description: Haven't been here in years!  But was supposed to see the KING TUT viewing at the De Young Museum and the tickets were sold out!  I knew I should have ordered them online....anyhow, it was nice to go to the Japanese Tea Garden.  I belive it cost us $5 to enter, not that bad.  But then since we were starving and thought we could have lunch here a group of us were so very disappointed- cost us $5 a piece for tea and a small platter of cookies, and crackers some of which weren't even Japanese!!  The waitress there all had the most funkiest komono's I've ever seen.  I'm like for real?  Anyways, except for the overly priced tea/snack and no lunch items this is a very serene, beautiful place, with nice ponds, flowers, trees, and I always like to take pictures of Kyoto/shinto shrines, Buddha statues, the big bridge that you can climb on top, the Zen garden was ok- not much to see and can't just hop over and meditate there...Very touristy friendly!
author: cheryll t.

description: One of my personal Top 10 Places to take a visitor in San Francisco.  It's absolutely spectacular, especially in spring and summer.  The garden is full of surprise views from different places on the walks. It's small enough to not be overwhelming. I took my mother in a wheel chair and found it 95% accessible.
author: c p.

description: Never went here before but a visitor wanted to bike through Golden Gate Park (best way to see it). We ended up drinking tea amid crazy beautiful vegetation in the Japanese Tea gardens. Very, very beautiful.
author: Matt T.

description: i love this place. perfect place for a date or to take people visiting sf.  have some great tea and a peaceful stroll through the beautiful gardens...really a treasure.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: absolutely beautiful.   don't miss this place.  it's romantic, tranquil and a great place for pics.
author: Immer E.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden goes great with a visit to the SF Botanical Garden. It can get very touristy and crowded at times. One person was even smoking when I went =(. The garden itself is VERY well kept and beautiful. Perfect for photos. Don't forget to snap one off of yourself climbing the funky bridge. Go around twice slowly and make sure you see everything to make it worth the admission.
author: M. W.

description: peaceful relaxing and cute my mother used to take me as a young girl...brings good memories back
author: Lindsey A.

description: Look, the garden is nice and all, but since it is a tea garden, I need to comment on the tea. Now, maybe I ordered the wrong tea (Oolong), but it was pure garbage--mostly twigs with a few pathetic leaves thrown in for cover. They clearly are serving up the "shake" of the tea world, though no one seems to mind. Not that I could really taste the stuff, as I almost gagged on the heavy bleach aroma that was emanating from my cup. Now, I know that the law says that they have to wash out the cups with bleach--maybe someone should tell them they could clean the cups in a bleach solution that's less than 1 to 1 with water.
author: Steven W.

description: the japanese tea garden makes a great destination for a casual walk through golden gate park, especially if you are showing off san francisco to visitors from out of town.  the dwarf trees, wooden japanese structures, stone buddas and temples, and intricate waterfalls make for some great photo ops, and there are several other things to see nearby as well.  its hard to really reach a state of tranquility here, given the number of other people who are also visiting the gardens, but perhaps if you go early on a weekday you can have a more zen experience.
author: Erin C.

description: it's so pretty and it's nicer to walk around in without all the tourists, so go on a weekday afternoon.
author: kristin e.

description: early morning in this place is dreamy. the tiny tea area is quaint, and if you can make it on an off day, very nice to relax in. beautiful setting - bring a date.
author: Darrell L.

description: ooooh my goodness. this place is like a little japanese corner of heaven. it is such a relaxing environment, and a fantastic place to photograph! i have spent many hours watching the koi, sipping tea, and just walking around in the lush, beautiful gardens of the Japanese Tea Garden. love this place :) :) :)
author: lamanjalo b.

description: I came here again today because I couldn't remember the last time I came here . This garden is pretty small .. my boyfriend and I finished walking the whole thing in around 10 minutes . There's a place where you can drink tea and eat those cheap japanese cracker things that come in packages but we didn't check it out because the tables were all full . There's a gift store but it has things with SF on it .. good for tourists , but useless to locals . The garden itself was kinda pretty but not extraordinarly pretty .. in fact , it was kind of plain . I only saw 2 koi fish in the whole garden . Hmm .. I remember seeing more when I was little . I wouldn't recommend this place to people . It's a total tourist trap . $5 for a 10 minute walk is totally not worth it . Might as well just walk around Golden Gate Park for free lol !! But I guess this is a decent place for couples to go or just to shoot pictures .
author: Eileen L.

description: Love this place. Go midweek. On weekends its too crowded and busy to enjoy at its best.
author: Brad D.

description: the garden is really little but it's fun to check out if you're at the golden gate park.  i wouldn't go out of my way to come her though. it feels like you're in japan but on a much smaller scale.
author: Jenn S.

description: This is a cute place.  I take friends and family to see it.  I as someone who lives here, not so much.  But they always seem to love it!
author: Misti L.

description: um....though it's named Japanese Tea Garden... but they are actually speaking Chinese?!:P but nice view lo~
author: Susan H.

description: A bit small compared to other Japanese friendship gardens in the area.  The design makes it feel a lot bigger than it really is.  The tea house, bathrooms, and gift shop are in traditional Japanese architecture (which seems to span several different periods of Japanese history).   Climbing to the top of the drum bridge makes for a Kodak moment with your friends.  The koi pond could have better fish in it.  Stopping for some tea and cookies to contemplate the area gives it focus and makes it an interesting experience.  The location in Golden Gate Park is a mixed blessing in that it is conveniently located next to the de Young museum but it attracts lots of annoying tourists.  Expect to drop $4 for admission and pay about $3 to be served green or jasmine tea.
author: Brandon S.

description: This is my absolute favorite place in the city. I've taken friends from Hong Kong, New York City, other parts of California and Colorado here, and they've all loved it! It's a delicious oasis of calm. I've come in all seasons and I love how the colors change here. Different flowers, different plants are always flourishing. The leaves on the trees change with the seasons. In fog or sunlight, a light drizzle or a strong wind can bring a completely different feel to the garden and makes each visit unique. I avoid the tea house and shop, and prefer to admire the work of the Hagiwara family who first tended the lovely garden until they were sent to internment camps during WWII in 1942. There is a small placque near the entrance that mentions the Hagiwara familly but doesn't explain why they suddenly stopped being in charge of the garden in 1942. There is a traditional zen rock garden, shinto-type shrine with gated space (to separate the sacred from the mundane), koi ponds, giant redwoods, Japanese maples, a bamboo grove, bronze Buddha, and lovely moon bridge. It is a relatively small space and meant to be viewed leisurely so that the different garden scapes can be appreciated. Seflishly, I admit I'm happy the higher admission price seems to be deterring some visitors. I prefer visiting when it is not crowded. I feel this is truly one of San Francisco's sacred spaces, and we honor the Hagiwara Family with our appreciation.
author: ayi l.

description: Another one of those tourist places XD , but one of the best I've seen here in SF. Even though I life in SF and don't go here very often, I think the garden is absolutely beautiful, providing a wonderful environment for enjoying tea. Really worth taking a look at. Since you're in the area, you might as well head over to visit the new De Young Museum, where students of SF get in free with ID ^_^
author: Cindy W.

description: Spend the afternoon at the DeYoung, and hit this place after 5, when admission is free.  It's a very pleasant walk, and a nice place to grab some (pricey) tea.
author: Corey Y.

description: The Japanese Tea Garden is beautiful.  I set my expectations pretty low since anything "Japanese" has basically been stripped of the fine details that is so important to the Japanese culture.  The garden has been maintained and is as authentic as it can be.  ....however the tea house is ONE BIG JOKE!  My traditional Japanese parents came to visit and they were utterly disgusted that they the word "Japanese" can even be associated to the tea house becuase there was absolutely nothing--NOTHING, authentically Japanese about it.  In fact it is embarassing that someone who might not know better is given such a wrong impression of the Japanese culture.  Enjoy the garden, but keep in mind that a) there is no one (at least when I was there) who is Japanese that works in that tea house b) the outfits they are wearing is in no sense mildly close to being a "kimono" c) the mannerisms are NOT classically Japanese at all and finally d) the tea pots and the dishes are something that the Japanese prize.  The cheap unmatching teapots and tea cups should never be used.  ...and finally e) the Japanese ony drink green tea or a form of green tea and nothing else.  The crap they serve there is like calling grade D beef that they serve at Taco Bell, filet mignon at Ruth Chris.  ...I could go on and on, but it really is so embarassing....   it's like if i went abroad and went to an american style restaurant and they hung the US flag upside down-- and everything they served had ketchup on it.  ...I wish they'd re-vamp that tea house or give a different name to the building and don't even try to be a "Japanese Tea House".  It is so insulting.
author: Kelly C.

description: its a very nice garden but not worth 7$ a person!!! there are many gardens just as nice right next to the tea gardens for free. i would not pay to go back into the tea gardens and neither should you.
author: Chris d.

description: i honestly think i'm being nice by giving this 2 stars.  first of all, why am i paying to go see another part of the park?   so there's a few bamboo plants and japanese pagoda replicas . . .  does that really warrant 4 bucks of 2000 square feet?   very disappointing.   i think this would be a 3 star place on one of the free days, but for 4 bucks ( i may sound cheap here) i feel like the tea should be free (another 4 bucks).   anyway, you can skip this place.
author: shar d.

description: a total rip off. $5 to get in and it takes about 5 minutes to walk the whole thing. there is a little gift shop in here as well a little tea shop that serves tea, pop, and crackers. they don't even clean the tea pots properly. there was a bunch of crusty tea in the spout of our pot.
author: cesar z.
